as someone on true carnivore diet, avoiding carbs lowers my appetite, as well as prevents numerous issues of carb based lifestyle. in the short term, supporters of plant diet will deflect carbon emissions towards meat, but i think in the long term, people will have ulterior issues when it comes to plant based diet. think of meat as nutrition gold (and i mean, we are made of meat. meat is a complete food, deal with it). eating plants will have consequential effects of deflated nutrition, aka empty calories in excess carbs/calories and/or toxic chemicals from heavily eating plants.  right now i can comfortably eat 1lb of meat a day, 2 if i'm active. seriously. in terms of a cow, that's one cow every two years (one year if active). the bad press of meat eaters come from people that are eating meat along WITH carbs. like eating hamburgers/hotdogs with buns, plus fries, plus soda, plus barbecue sauce. eat a pure carnivore diet without all of the "luxury" of carbs and you will find you don't overconsume on protein/fat. people think meat eaters eat it and will die from excess fat. yes, the fat tastes good, but it only tastes good in the beginning, when the body says you are hungry. you will find you will stop eating fat once you've had your fill, same for protein. it's really not easy to overconsume on pure meat. only when you had your flavorings and sauces or eat with bread and ketchup and shit, is where the overeating occurs. carbs stimulate appetite.  seasoning is one of the biggest scams of judging good food, and once you add sugar in the mix, you have a recipe of overeating, no matter what you eat. i sympathize now with people that "don't season their food". they eat the food the way it is and tastes the way it should taste.  we talk about carbon emissions, but what about unnecessary carbon storage in the form of fat? tackle obesity before the meat eating. and we tackle obesity by reducing carbs, promoting keto. so there is a biggest problem in the sense that we are not promoting co2 consumers, but instead we are just inflating the human population. we are trying to reduce emissions by changing the diet, but only to balance the emissions for industry growth. which is ultimately the problem of this propaganda. we're not reducing overall emissions, just making room for ever increasing industry.

WhatтАЩs not mentioned is that the pasture lands we use have over the years become accustomed to cattle raising, theyтАЩre not going to turn back into forests and they canтАЩt grow human crops, the only thing you could do with them is put buildings on them. A further point not discussed, is that the amount of greenhouse gases produced from livestock is significantly less in developed countries than developing countries. ThatтАЩs because we have more environmentally friendly practices and so on, so their impact on the environment is not that significant. Where they produce way more greenhouse gases is in poorer countries, thatтАЩs the real impact, but at the same time theyтАЩre not going to change their diet or adopt cleaner methods. So in reality, beef consumption can be reduced although it wonтАЩt be as impactful as you might think in the West, developing nations where it would be more impactful are less likely to stop, and greenhouse gases from people, travel, and industry are far more abundant in the West.

I usually like Kurzgesagt videos but this one is full of half-truths and misinformation. just a few examples, local transportation costs apply on both local produce and international because your avocado needs a lift from the dock to the supermarket. another one is that we can use less space for growing tofu. animal protein is much denser, and you need less of it to get the same protein level, per 100gr beans or tofu have 8-9gr of protein and beef has around 26-30 gr so you need to eat more plant-based foods, that takes area to grow. The argument about methane seems to be wrong. The amount of methane in the atmosphere is determined by the current amount of animals living. It does not keep adding methane like CO2 emissions from fossel fuels (which is not normally available in the carbon cycle).

The video looks amazing as always, but this video is spreading some misinformation.  The claim that cows would take in human grade food and add methane in the atmosphere is very misleading.   Cows eat very little human grade food from crops.  And cows donтАЩt тАЬaddтАЭ methane to the athmospehere. ItтАЩs a circular system, meaning methane gets broken down in a decade or more.   The amount of livestock has been around the same in the west for a long time now, so this claim is absolutely misleading.

IтАЩm going out to dinner ЁЯН╜ tonight with my mom ЁЯСйЁЯП╗ and dad ЁЯСиЁЯП╗ and my
This doesn't account for the increase in crop production to make up for a calorie deficit from giving up meat. Growing enough plants to feed everyone the same amount of protein in plant alternatives. There would still be a net benefit, but probably not as much as the video estimates. It's arguably better to deal with methane because even though it's a worse greenhouse gas, it's short term compared to the heavy tax of carbon. Also, a surprising amount of people don't know this, but feed crops are not the same as edible crops. Most of the grain grown for cattle feed is not edible by humans, and changing to human edible crops would be extremely labor intensive and very expensive. Good luck convincing farmers to give up the profitability of meat production and switch entirely to less profitable types of crops. Damaging the food industry would be a  dangerous move when we are in the middle of a massive diet transition. Overall, the benefit to the climate of eliminating meat production would be similar to the benefit of changing the rules of meat production, and eating slightly less of it.

So, in summary, if eating meat (which is an ethical consideration in itself) there is also an ethical sub-decision between animal welfare and climate impact where they are at odds. From an ethical perspective eating free-range meat raised on grasslands that couldn't support crops or carbon capture but only doing so occasionally because of sustainable production capacity seem like a potential good option if you're OK with consuming other animals. Not commented here, probably because of volumes, is also eating native game meat shot in a sustainable manner for population control, which may be the most ethical option. Because humans hunted down predators to avoid threats, prey populations are a potential problem if not managed both from an environment and the individual animals perspective (overpopulation can lead to boom-crash population cycles where lots of animals suffer), and the by-product of that population control is probably the most ethical meat you'll get.

The long-distance (ship) transport of plant-based food compared to the short-distance (truck) transport of meat does not appear to be an apples-to-apples comparison..  The container ship with my avocado onboard does not pull up to my supermarket.  Both require truck transport at some point in production/distribution.  Did I miss a statement addressing this?    I've seen a lot of information (some misguided) about bias due to sponsorship, but I still like/trust these videos.  However, when the more detailed comparisons (like this one on transport) appear lopsided, it make listeners question objectivity of the meta-analysis (which is really the bottom-line of this video, and many others).

Did they take into account that the feed for cows are the rejected stuff from the humans? Like when a farmer grows oats, the good quality oats are sold to the supermarkets for human consumption. Then there are "feed oats" the lower quality oats. Still perfectly safe to eat, but not nearly as desirable. That stuff is fed to the animals. What would the cost of food be if we didn't have animals to feed the reject stuff to? Who would the farmer sell it to? As a farmer, if I have a bad year (for ex: drought..most farmers do not irrigate..or too much rain and much of the crop drowns out) then we have lower quality crops. Without the animal market, we would be out of business so fast, it's ridiculous (you'd be surprised how much grain is sold as feed quality).   Without a secondary market to sell to, the cost of food will increase exponentially to make up for the losses. Then we'll have nothing but the big factory farms (more control over our food supply, which is what "they" want...ahem...mr. gates).
We have to remember there is a HUGE money trail in the vegan movement. There is a lot more profit for the big guys in selling soy than in beef. My great grandpa was almost 110 years old when he died, he had a meat heavy diet, all raised on his own farm. Never spent a day in the hospital due to sickness. Beware of biased studies (as most are these days, no matter what the subject is). As a farmer, I'm pretty sure we destroy a lot more birds nests on the ground with spring seeding that the cows destroy from grazing in pasture lands. Here in Canada, we're also not clearing bushland to feed the cows because they love to eat leaves as well as grass. I do see farmers clearing any kind of tree to get that little extra land for their crop. Rows of windbreaker trees are constantly being destroyed for that extra land. It drives me nuts. Pasture lands support local wildlife a lot more than fields of soy or other crops.

(tocotrienols, sulphides, isoflavones, phytosterols, phytos t a n o l s) Each type of fiber lowers cholesterol levels. Fiber absorbs it. Lignin very much. Phytosterols compete with the cholesterol molecule for reabsorption in the small intestine. Phytosterols also lower cholesterol levels. Not only is the lack of cholesterol harmful, the accumulation of precursors that are not further converted is also harmful. This connection is known from the studies on SLO.  Smith-Lemli-Opitz Syndrome.  A cholesterol deficiency syndrome.  SLO shows that nobody can seriously say what damage exactly is caused by which cholesterol level. This is a truth we must accept.  But! people with very high cholesterol levels are well advised to adopt a vegan diet until their levels drop. But this diet also includes cutting back on saturated fats, sugars, less fruit, and less white flour to lower triglycerides, which are cholesterol transporters. When the triglycerides are high, the liver suffers from obesity. High triglycerides cause the bad LDL type B!  'Animal' cholesterol causes good LDL type A!  We know the reason for atherosclerosis nowadays.   And some people with a genetic disease do very well at 'plant based' if they are perfectly consuming all the nutrients necessary for humans. Oxidized cholesterol comes from oxidation. Oxidation kills us. This type of oxidized LDL cholesterol cannot be taken up by cell receptors, it is deposited. Plaques form. We have a non-trivial influence over the opinion of many people after all.  So. How does Kurzgesagt do sponsorships?  Usually potential sponsors get in touch with us after seeing one of our videos they particularly liked or that is related to what they do. We start a discussion about what they are looking for and whether we can work together.  Kurzgesagt is mostly looking for a good fit that does not feel weird on the channel. Does the sponsor look for a video about a certain topic? Do they want a shoutout? Do they want to promote a product that would feel totally random? Have we been planning to do a video about their field anyway at some point in the future?  The better the sponsor aligns with us the higher the chances are they want to work with us and vice versa. Which is also one of the reasons we want to talk first and get to know the person responsible on the other side, as well as give them a chance to get to know us. One of your worst videos for sure.. The entire premise revolves around cows magically creating methane out of thin air, which is simply not true. Plants absorb CO2 from atmosphere and turn it into cellulose, cow eat plant, cow transforms cellulose in methane, cow fart, methane enters atmosphere and is then transformed into CO2, CO2 is absorbed by plant, cycle is complete. There is literally zero CO2 or methane created in this process; only recycled carbon. If we instead do as you suggest, and take 70-80% of the corn- and soy-plant and throw it on landfills (instead of feeding it to cows), the cellulose will still break down, in large part into methane. And no, we humans CANNOT eat cellulose properly, we cannot eat soy-cake, we cannot eat the leaves or stems of a corn plant, not even die-hard vegans with purple hair can eat it. So instead we use this trash, the leftovers, the by-products, and we give them to cows (IE Recycling) and turn it into human food.
8:54 the soy that is being used to feed animals is completely inedible for human consumption and is a byproduct of other crops

insane too see how much we stuffed up the world lol
1. All agriculture is 100% carbon neutral. In fact, all forms of carbon that come from living things is carbon neutral carbon. This is because all carbon involved in the lifecycles of Earth is RECYCLED. There's no way to exceed the carbon budget with agriculture because the carbon put into the air by agriculture is eventually reabsorbed by said agriculture. Atmospheric methane has a half-life if 9.1 years, meaning half the methane from cows from 9 years ago is gone already. It's sitting at steady levels. It is not increasing. Also, the wild bison of North America produced nearly 90% the methane of cows today. They did so for MILLIONS of years.  3. Not only do cows eat the grass that we cannot eat, they eat the grains unfit for human consumption (bugs, etc...), and the bits of food we do not eat. The corn stalks. The stalks of soybeans, etc... Also, crop rotation may produce an excess of certain crops. Soybeans are good for repairing soil, so they are often grown as a trash crop for next year's corn. Sure, SOME land that could be used for human food is used for cattle, but it's not nearly as much as you think it is.  Overall, terrible propaganda video. Meat haters are so biased it is insane. Take your religious fanaticism elsewhere.
Just looking at figures won't give a complete picture. How these figures are calculated and how they impact climate change needs to be taken into consideration. Like ruminant animals mostly eat farming by-products otherwise going to waste. Drinks mostly green water(rain). Creating methane whose carbon is from grass and part of the cycle in nature unlike fossil fuel emissions. So mere numbers won't give the full picture.
Rice doesn't produce methane. When grown in anaerobic conditions,  aka paddies which they are typically seen being grown, the bacteria living in that environment is producing the methane. Which is inevitably taken up by the rice plants and then at that point the rice "emits methane". However, just because rice can be grown in paddies doesn't mean it has to be. Therefore rice not grown in standing water would not produce methane. That is a huge statement of misinformation regarding rice that was said in the beginning.  Rice is grown in paddies because it helps with weed prevention since rice CAN be grown in paddies preventing other plants from being able to grow, especially during seedling stage. So it's the bacteria in the traditional rice growing process producing methane, not the rice itself. Reference is I work with rice and the microbiome associated with it.

I think one issue with going vegan that isn't talked about often is - we don't actually have a perfect break down of what a human body needs.  Science isn't quite there yet.  Plus the human diet is attributed with our intelligence so if our stomachs have to become more complex on an evolutionary scale we may be causing our intelligence to move back down.    I have noticed that the vast majority of vegans don't look healthy.  Their muscles hang from their bones differently, their skin complexion is a little different in tone, and when speaking to them they seem to have a harder time with sustaining longer logical threads (this could just be due to emotions about their favorite topics).     I have no doubt that some day humans will stop eating meat; science will figure out the perfect nutrition for longevity, costs to create food will favor a shift from current production techniques, people will continue to find it distasteful to kill other creatures to survive (there is a trend in this direction and a disconnect between food and it's production), and/or scarcity will make changing our food a necessity.  Personally if I could eat a ration pellet that extended my life and never had to worry about food again I would.  I like eating as much as anyone and make some very delicious foods, but it takes a lot of time that I could put to other enjoyable things in life.  Right now we favor food gatherings but that is mostly because we are highly controlled right now.  We are constantly told the best thing to do is go out to eat, have a bbq, gather family to eat.  As long as this is the way we are nothing will change, but it will change, everything changes eventually.  I'm just not so sure that we will survive with our emotionally charged unwillingness to change.  I hear crows are having their own version of the stone age, maybe they will evolve next and do better.

Your video is researched but I  think is also quite incomple. If we only consider the factor of their emissions you also must count how it would affect the food chain as their niche would be different.  If we stop eating beef, lamb, pork and chicken: -what would happen with those animals? Would they become wild or would we still use them to obtain milk, eggs, etc...? -Would they be freed somewhere or would they remain in farms but free? -How would it affect an animal to be left free after being depending on humans for feeding and protection for such a long time? Would they actually survive on their own? Let's not forget that actually, the fact of living with humans, protects them from predators like wolfs, lynx, bears, lions, panthers, tigers, cheetah... just to name a few... -wouldn't stop eating beef, lamb, pork and chicken increase the population of those animals, increasing their eating of plants, seeds or whatever they feed with?  - Would an increase of the cow population increase their methane emissions as well? -Wouldn't an increase in cows, lambs, pigs and chickens make them a target for other predators? (which would actually be bad for humans, because the population of those predators would increase as well?) Those are just a few questions, I have much more. As you said, it is a complex subject but all humanity becoming vegan would bring a whole set of issues that vegans don't seem to care about.

If your house is flooding because of burst pipes, you don't just start telling everyone in the family it's their own personal responsibility to grab a bucket and start bailing water out the windows more and more...that would be a pointless task, only slightly delaying the inevitable. You HAVE to go to the source of the problem and patch up the leaks quickly while you then start working on replacing them fully.

This video is one of the more balanced videos about the impacts of eating meat(beef). You deserve the 6M views it's got. I would like to point out that a lot of it is isolated facts. For example a lot of the worst offenders that skew the average comes from slash and burn methods in places like South America. This can be overcome by eating home grown beef(except for those living in the areas of the worst offenders of course). Also some of the figures are hiding some not mentioned underlying facts. For example cows are part of the natural cycles. If you don't eat beef it doesn't mean the emissions are 0, because you still need to eat something. Similarly the cows turn grass into fertilizer(cow pat). If we remove all of the cows will we not have sheep, horses or something else that is part of the natural cycles taking it's place to turn that grass into fertilizer? how much of the methane output from normal activities will be reduced if we remove the cows? composting requires energy and that in turn releases greenhouse gases. But it's all in a much larger natural cycle that I believe should be excluded from man made greenhouse gases. What I'm saying is that the figures look bad for cows mostly due to it's position in the natural cycles, but replacement in those positions will have equally bad looking figures.
CO2 equivalent is one of the most misleading things in the world of emissions.
Personally I believe switching to 100% grass fed would be better since the amount of meat we waste is more than we actually consume

Presently one of them picked up the blood-stained weapon, and began to pound the dead pig. Others joined in with any sticks and stones that they could gather, until their target began a messy disintegration. Then they became bored; some wandered off, while others stood hesitantly around the unrecognizable corpse - the future of a world waiting upon their decision. It was a surprisingly long time before one of the nursing females began to lick the gory stone she was holding in her paws. And it was longer still before Moon-Watcher, despite all that he had been shown, really understood that he need never be hungry again

The problem is that there's massive negatives to both sides of the aisle. Vegans, and Carnivores. What gets glossed over by many vegans is monocropping and how horrible it is for the planet. I'll take a farm full of cows over a soy farm any day of the week when it comes to the impact on our future. The reason is soil depletion. Monocropping does this at an extreme rate and is leading to a rapid, potentially catastrophic loss of usable farmland. Compared to cattle, which, while bad, does not compare. While yes, most of the soy is used for cattle, if you nixed cattle all together, you would still run into the problem of those remaining monocrops destroying the soil and when they have to move to the lands that were spared due to not being used by cattle, you still run into the same issue you started with. Only difference is that there will be less methane but instead of greenhouse gas issues you now have a starving population. Let's not get started on the animal rights activists claiming that vegan diets involve less death. Those people have clearly never stepped foot on one of these farms to see the ridiculous death toll of smaller creatures killed during the crop harvesting process. Again, this isn't a pro meat/anti vegan argument. Simply to say that unless we figure out a way to speed up the process of soil turnover, monocropping will almost certainly do far more damage to our ability to live on this planet then factory farming will. The goal should be to figure out how to eliminate as much negative from both while also preserving both. I personally don't trust lab grown meat, there's just way too many variables that go into the life cycle of a creature that eventually winds up on your plate, mainly from a nutritional standpoint, for me to trust that a lab grown burger will have the same nutritional profile as a grass fed burger does.

But this isnтАЩt about the environment. Meat is not an environmental issue as much as it is a pressing ethical issue. Even if eating meat did not at all negatively impact the climate actually, one would still have a moral imperative as far as possible and practicable to desist their consumption of animals for food, fashion, cosmetics and entertainment by mere virtue of animals existing for their own purpose. AnimalsтАЩ bodies are not ours. We have commodified them for profit because they are vulnerable, and erroneously believe that we can do with them as we please due to our speciesist bias (which is completely arbitrary and absurd). A cow is a pig is a chicken is a dog. There is no meaningful distinction among sentient beings that entitle us to regard some with care and support the brutalization of others. As philosopher Peter Singer puts it, тАЬAll arguments to prove manтАЩs superiority cannot shatter this hard fact: in suffering the animals are our equals.тАЭ Which is the only characteristic that is worthy of consideration when it comes to our assignment of moral worth to animals (the ability to feel pain; which all animals raised for food unequivocally possess). With this in mind, it is therefore unjustifiable to promote, in this case the eating of animals, if one has the means not to. The practice of killing animals is unnecessary and therefore is a moral atrocity and injustice. In short: animals are not human resources and do not go willingly to their execution, no matter how they are тАЬraisedтАЭ or treated. All exploiting and killing of animals invokes violence and bloodshed, and is done through a lens of impunity and dominion.

I'd be happy to switch to a vegan diet if it wasn't for the fact that all of them are nutritionally deficient. Vegetal proteins are not PDCAAS complete, and vegan diets are notoriously lacking in Vitamin B12, B9 (folates) and iron. You could supplement with a multivitamin, but the evidence that vitamin/mineral supplements have any effect is still highly debated, so you might not be getting what you need in the end. Not an easy nut to crack.

Interesting video. The title is misleading, though. The badness of meat does not only depend on the degree to which it contributes to climate change. There are some other issues which determine that meat eating is bad. One is the question of how morally right it is to inflict suffering on animals and kill them when we do not need meat for survival (as is generally the case). Another is the question of how moral it is to use plants to feed animals which we then eat, while we could also have used those plants to feed humans and solve the problem of world hunger. Yet another is the role of meat eating and the increased risk of pandemics. There are more examples of issues determining the badness of meat eating. So I would say: meat is bad for many reasons.

I find people tend to look at things with an all or nothing mentality. Making changes in moderation tend to have a longest lasting effects. My family used to eat meat almost daily - mostly poultry & fish, but on occasion, beef or lamb. But when my wife became a vegetarian, our son, who's an even bigger meat lover than me, and I started sampling the vegetarian dishes she initially made for herself. The plant based dishes were so tasty that our son & I just started eating whatever she made. I was surprised to realize I didn't miss meat. However, once-in-a-while my son or I might crave a steak or burger or chicken wings or sashimi, but not often. My son and I probably have meat about once a month now тАР and that's us not setting out to reduce our meat intake. I'm not saying it will be this easy for everyone, but it's really not as difficult as you would think, especially with all the impressive alternatives that are available today.
One thing I canтАЩt help but wonder, is what was the source of food like before we industrialized and farmed them? And what was the state of carbon and methane emissions at the time?  YouтАЩd figure methane would still be an issue with buffalos, woolly mammoths, and wild cows roaming around freely without human interference. Is global warming a new issue, or has it always been a thing and only accelerated fairly recently?

There is a big point missing, when the things we feed to beef decompose, they emmit carbon dioxide too. So technicaly that carbon would anyway end up beeing released as methane. I think something that wasn't mentioned is the methane argument really doesn't make sense. Methane only lasts for about 10-12 years. So long as we don't increase the population of cows on the planet, methane is not a problem. Methane has only been linked to cows because our beef intake has increased drastically in the last 2 centuries. However, as long as it doesn't keep on increasing, our methane footprint won't change
In short?   YES!! Bad for your health and bad for our environment
I guess they forgot to mention that the amount of CO2 removed from the atmosphere by pastures usually compensates for the CO2 released by machinery and the cows feeding on said pasture. Of course, there are many different variables at play (kind of pasture system, number of animals per acre and location - to mention a few), but more often than not, the production of grass-fed beef will remove more CO2 than it releases.
Thank you for addressing some of the most widespread myths about food emissions and the ethical problems associated with animal agricultureтАФmeat-eating drives global warming, biodiversity loss, pandemic risks, and animal exploitation. So let's say the world goes vegetarian:   - 4% of total human greenhouse gas emissions are neutralized.   - Dairy production increases to meet demand for quality fat and protein - Emissions from dairy sector significantly rise.   - Demand for eggs increases for the reasons as dairy - Emissions from poultry don't go as far down as anticipated.   - 250 calories per day per person is no longer meat, but plant products.  Plant based food production for humans goes up 10%, with associated emissions.   - Small leather producers are put out of business as a wave of cheap cow skin hits the market.  The consolidation of leather producers reduces competition and the prices eventually go up.  Global use of pleather and other petroleum based products increases to compensate.  Emissions- blah blah you get it.   - Wool prices drastically increase, as income from lamb and mutton production disappear.  Petroleum-based synthetics take over, as above.   - Asian goat herders, no longer able to food themselves, sell their herds to industrial fabric producers.  Carbon footprint of Cashmere and Mohair industries increases.   - Grasslands all over the world once occupied by domesticated ruminants are now occupied by naturally occurring ruminants, which have increased by an unprecedented tens of millions.  They eat and fart just as much as the domesticated animals that used the land before them.   - Some unexpected demand for farm land for animal feed arises, as all the calories previously supplied by meat industry byproducts have to be provided by plants.  This includes foods for pets and work animals that are not exclusively carnivore.  All dogs are now vegetarian.    - Demand for flattened rainforest and associated local labour drops, causing the governments of those countries to further subsidize the sector.  Another industry takes beef's place, saving money for consumers all around the world, but increasing the carbon footprint for that product.   - Burned and rotting rainforest continues to release the same about of C02 and methane as it did before.   - Ancient cultures around the world see a massive exodus, as traditional farming methods fail to produce enough calories for the tribes at their current populations.  They adapt into some kind of city life, with an associated increased carbon footprint.  Are we still confident we can even get that 4% reduction?!?!?  Ignoring all of the above, within two years, human emissions are back to where they were before we went vegetarian.  Human increases of greenhouse gasses has been going up 3% on average every year since the 1940s.  Removing 4% of that increase rate won't slow it down by any significant amount.  Also: Total annual methane has gone up about 10% in the past ten years, yet total number of beef has remained the same (about 1 billion).    So I guess the question is.... how  is targeting the meat industry an efficient use of time in any conceivable manner?  If we're going to solve global warming, we need a fundamental shift.  Not a plan that *at best* *might* get a 4% reduction, with significant caveats.  It just seems intellectually and emotionally lazy.  There's actual hard and important work to do and think about.  Go go and think about those things.

90% of what we feed to ruminant livestock is human-inedible byproducts of agriculture, like corn stalks and husks and almond shells. 94% of water consumed by cattle in the United States is from rainwater that would have fallen on that location anyway, and that water is later urinated out in the same area. It doesn't just sit in the cow forever. The cattle are turning all of this waste into edible meat products for us.

here's a factor you forgot to include in your research; waste. it doesn't matter if i personally eat less meat or that i buy it locally to save on emissions on transport. the producers of said product will produce it and transport it all the same, and the stuff they don't sell simply gets thrown out. a significant amount of people need to adopt the same logic and stick to it, for this to even remotely have an impact, and while that might reduce the carbon footprint locally, you need to remember that these are businesses, they'll simply find a customer elsewhere to buy what they can't sell to my community, be it at reduced price or not. it doesn't matter, the same amount of product will be produced and sold.

I'm actually flabbergasted by just how stupid this video is, and that people are lapping it up.    Methane (carbon + hydrogen) released by cows came from the plants they ate, which absorbed it from the air.  It's a cycle - no new carbon is created or removed.    Carbon released from burning fuel which was pumped from underground carbon sinks, is releasing carbon into the air that otherwise wouldn't have been there.    See the difference???

5:00 - Everyone focuses upon CO2 emissions and yet they don't think about other environmental costs, and these costs have knock-on effects to CO2.   Avocados are a great example of this and it's why I chose this timestamp. Avocados require a ridiculous amount of water and the wests demand for it has resulted in poor water management in many South-American nations. This has caused droughts and crop failures which increase CO2 output as other crops have to be shipped in or water has to be pumped away from the rivers which supply rainforests.   As always the people who claim to be solving things are often incapable of understanding how the world is far more complex than they believe it is.
The reality is, changing our diets to meat free (specifically beef) is the easiest change and choice we can make to help our planet.

It is true, we can't rely on grass-fed beef to meet human consumption because of its inefficiency. This does not mean we need to grow grains to feed beef cattle. We can divert high energy food waste that would have ended up in landfill because of poor rating for not meeting consumer demands to replace the grains in cattle feed. Consequently, the food waste, which is now cattle feed would reduce landfill emissions and spare land used for grains. This is what we should do!
There are controversies in methane from cattle contributing to man made emissions but the author of this video doesn't want to dive deep into it. This shows that there's a hidden agenda... apart from cow, man made methane emissions come from many sources including, Paddy rice production, organic and food waste decomposition on landfill sites, and ancient stored carbon removed thru fossil fuel production (which when you want to do proper LCA of transportation, you would see how much this sector contributes to greenhouse gas emissions). Anaerobic process by microbes in the ocean, glaciers, and termites are natural sources that also contribute to methane released into the atmosphere. Life Cycle Analysis (LCA) used in estimating the carbon footprint from the beginning to the end of a product, usually use a 100 yr global warming potential to standardize non-CO2 greenhouse gases (e.g. methane and nitrous oxide) emissions to that of CO2 for calculations. However, methane does not stay in the atmosphere for 100 yrs like CO2 but 10yrs and is gone. So this video contains half truth...but I like the animation though ЁЯдФ

Ok, this is driving me crazy, so I have to say something. Excepting the 'burning down the rainforest' bit (which is bad), everything being described here is JUST the carbon cycle. All agriculture is. In short: CO2 is taken from the atmosphere by the plant and made into hydrocarbons (100%ish of carbon in a plant comes from CO2). Plant dies or gets eaten. Hydrocarbons are broken down into CO2 by an animal or methane by bacteria- and yes, cows (and many other animals) make methane because they have bacteria in their guts. If those plants die without an animal eating them they wind up turning to methane and CO2 anyway, and methane breaks down into CO2 and water. Of course, it takes longer and the proportions are different depending on environmental factors ect., but that's really beside the point.  The point is that ALL the carbon involved in the process comes from the atmosphere. Your WORST case scenario here is agriculture (including cows) has no effect on atmospheric carbon at all. That isn't likely, since some carbohydrates (cellulose in particular) take a very long time to break down completely unless burned. A varying proportion of the cellulose will wind up in the dirt or underground and be there for the next 100 years. So most of the time agriculture has a net REDUCTION of atmospheric carbon.  So what I got from this isn't that we shouldn't eat meat, just that we shouldn't be buying it from Brazil.
Carbon footprint aside, I refuse a vegan or vegetarian lifestyle because I'd rather contribute to the destruction of the planet than get polluted with estrogen from soy.

The CO2 equivalence argument is deeply flawed, as the methane produced from ruminants are part of the natural atmospheric cycle. Before the Europeans arrived in North America, there were estimates approaching 50 million bison roaming the plains.   Animals arenтАЩt the problem. TheyтАЩre necessary in ways most donтАЩt realize. Our management of them is the crucial element.

Dead soil?  Water pollution?  Carbon emissions seem only a slice of the problems regenerative farming seeks to address.  Properly done, regenerative farming uses plants and animals, just like nature.  It seems to me that either extreme - approaching plants only or approaching animals only - is not truly sustainable in the long term.  On a related note, what kind of research is there into the effects of the Haber-Bosch process (and its successors which I assume exist) on climate change?  Reducing the addition of carbon while increasing the removal of nitrogen from our atmosphere sounds like it could produce the same greenhouse gas concentrations at some point, while magnifying the effects of other gasses in the atmosphere with unforeseen (largely due to being unstudied) consequences.
I understand the carbon footprint your talking about, but I believe you a missed a few parts. The blame that is put on cow, and other modern meats for the carbon foot print is I feel over stated. For explanation, before we mass produced cattle, the were around 60 million bison, 45 million antelope, 40 million white tail deer, 10 million mule deer, 10 million elk, 2 million big hope sheep, 1 million mouse and around 1 million wolfs, and that only North America, and I couldn't find number for animals such as bears ,mountain lions, and other large animals. Not even counting the vast number of large birds such as ducks and geese, that would also be there. All the billions of creatures, would have been putting out a massive carbon footprint before humans killed off the vast majority of them and started farms and ranches, that are producing the same carbon footprint. Now I'm not saying that we're not having a impact, but the impact is from deforestation, not because the food we eat, plant based foods and growing crops account for just as much if not more Deforestation as cattle. Speaking for North America that is, place like Brazil wiping out mass areas of rain forest for cattle is leaving a massive carbon footprint, that if we changed our way today would still take decades to fix.  So the 26% carbon footprint that is from food, can really be cut down to a much smaller number.  I would like to see you account for all that in a video.

I love red meat. But I eat it sparely (once a month at most) and I choose the best quality. Not because of any moral qualms but because that's how my diet happens to be.    The whole obsession with climate change is (in my estimation) sometimes is a dumb one: the domino already has fallen and the effects are already very hard to counter (and there is no serious study that can assert, scientifically and with acceptable accuracy, that the best efforts will stop whatever the consequences that are in the horizon) .When politics intervene, the whole issue goes beyond reasonable to become the most fashionable (and even "sacred") form of pseudoscience: as an example of many, countries depriving themselves of some forms of energy (see Europe's conundrum now) only to allow other (huge) countries to mess the planet without containment.   Ecological sustainable efforts are laudable though and I encourage those. Our technology is improving so much that (as the video says) even some almost sterile lands can turn adequate for farming.    The world population is about to peak: it's not about sheer numbers but the shape of they population pyramid. And the world is (statistically) aging, even if some countries (and particularly one continent) still is relatively "young" (that is, they still have more children than old people). All in all this mean that there will be less people and less people will bring both problems (as economies are built for growth, etc.) and blessings (depopulation, less environmental stress, etc.).   The best scenario would be that of lesson for the future, whatever it is (and if we survive Nuclear Wars or whatever): stabilizing the world population at a respectable number (they played with the idea that an ideal number was reached in the 1900's at 2 billion) while enjoying a better technology and knowledge of all things ecological and biological. But that's just a utopian dream. Reality don't take sides: only applies consequences.

And trying to push for zero, and fight for progress even after a compromise or collaborative set goal effort - where everyone wins at least something to be happy - that will absolutely kill all progress, and we'll see a major relapse that we may never come back from.... Very disappointing for a video that claimed the issue is complicated. No mention at all about regenerative agriculture or rotational grazing. Also almost half of livestock feed is made of crop residues and by-products that are not edible by humans, so if we got rid of livestock those residues would need to be burned or left to rot. The comparison made on nutrient density is also off, it was a net comparison on how many nutrients are present in food, but it doesn't take into account that although plants may have nutrients, it is very hard for our bodies to extract those nutrients. You will poop out most of the nutrients in plants, whilst your body is able to absorb pretty much everything in meat. Meat is a superior food by far, but this is not recognized because the dominant narrative has become so biased against it. There are also essential nutrients we can only get from meat. And where will we get our "organic fertilizers" if we got rid of livestock too? This felt like the common propaganda that is already common out there, not a real investigation or nuanced view.
Something that was not covered here is the sequestered carbon from regenerative agriculture with grass-fed ruminants. Although it may not be a huge portion it's certainly important to mention with this topic as well as an important calculation to offset some of the beef emissions from factory beef/ruminants.

In Germany there is another way of thinking about vegan. We, a friend of mine and me, found an important point, which causes problems with vegan diets.. Here  the reason why humans need animal products.. it is because of cholesterol.  We need a little amount of cholesterol in our nutrition. It is like this:  Great apes, all eat kinds of animals. Chimps are hunting. Cognition had something to do with nutrients.. Chimps are the best, compared to us, in cognition.  In breastmilk is cholesterol. In each  mammalian milk. Great apes feed their offspring with milk for a long time, orang utan until 8 years, until they are grown up..?   Plants are lowering cholesterol in different ways. Some plant ingredients are like statins. ( Tocotrienoles, sulfides, isoflavones, phytos t a n o l s)  Every kind of fiber lower cholesterol. Fiber absorbs it. Lignin very much.  Phytosterins compete with the cholesterol molecule for reabsorption, so phytosterins lower it to.  Other plants ingredients work like phytosterins and lower cholesterol.. beta glucan, mycosterins.   Statins harm healthy people. Low cholesterol, means lack of cholesterol, this harms in multiple ways: .. low bile acids, poor fat digestion .. low vitamin D, poor immune system, poor calcium storage, other deficiencies due to interactions .. damages in the brain and nerv tracts .. low hormones.. fertility?  .. damages in cell membranes, chance permeability of membranes, damages in organelles membran.. increasing .. low Q10 enzyme, Q10 is an intermediate product in cholesterol synthesis, low energie.   Not only the lack of cholesterol harms, in addition, the enrichment of the precursors, which are not further converted, is harmful. This connection is known from the studies on SLO. Smith-Lemli-Opitz-Syndrome.  SLO shows that nobody can seriously say, which damage exactly will be caused by what cholesterol level. Thats a truth, we have to accept.   And people with very high cholesterol levels are well advised to eat vegan until their levels drop.  But this diet includes also watch out for saturated fats, types of sugar, little fruit, little white flour to lower triglycerides if they are high.  And some people, with a genetical disease, are very good in vegan if the eat perfectly all the necessary nutrients for humans.  According to my source, there is 1 in 500 people with this genetic makeup.  .. What do you think?  Ive forgot  to mention oxidized cholesterol. The real problem for our vessels is the oxidized LDL-cholesterol. It can no longer be absorbed by cell receptors. One can't get it by lowering one's cholesterol either.  Phytosterols also oxidize, same problem...  We are not scientists, just pioneers in thinking and have brought the different sides together.

Something I should point out should anyone care to read this...  Poultry and pigs do not exclusively eat feed crops. They're all foragers who will get whatever they can from the land.  With appropriate stocking density in a leader follower system, Pigs, Poultry, Cattle and Sheep (and perhaps goats, if you include a healthy shrub layer into the treelines, but make sure the sheep are infront of the goats {ideally with poultry between} to protect the sheep from parasites. The goats eat high, so long as they have enough food they should be safe) can all graze the exact same silvopastural system with a huge net increase in overall animal carrying capacity (though the number of animals of each species will go down.)  How do the pigs and geese fatten? That's what the tree layer in the Silvo (meaning forest) layer is for. You load the treelines on each side of each pasture with nut trees that produce through the autumn, culminating in the natural temperate pork harvest period around November-Decemer.  This also tempers the video's obsession with cattle methane by diversifying the meat products.

"No matter how we twist and turn it..." Food is a large part of the human contribution to carbon dioxide emissions, which itself is a small overall part of global, natural carbon dioxide emissions. But is it a driver of climate change? IPCC reports list human activity as responsible for around 3-5% of global greenhouse gas emissions, and even if humans ceased to exist tomorrow, carbon dioxide would be produced by other processes, and at best, we can only modulate that 3-5%. I understand "lies to children" and all, but please tell more of the whole truth. Human activities emit 40 billion tonnes of CO2 annually, and that's on the high side. Natural processes emit 760 billion tonnes annually. Of the total emission, food production is a small sliver. But a portion of mankind will continue to regret its own existence and progress as long as man exists.
The problem is not meat,  the problem is overpopulation.

The premise is false: CO2 is bad. The gas is essential for life on Earth, the more we produce the better the environment grows. Consequently, meat is the best food because it produces the most CO2. Carbon-monoxide CO, on the other hand, is a poison that isn't produced by meat, but is used in packaging to preserve its colour. Cattle ranching doesn't destroy wildlife as much as crop farming does. Water vapour is by far the largest greenhouse gas contributor, but those stats are buried in favour of the climate change agenda.

Well, what about the effects of photosynthesis? I mean, cows don't magically conjure methane out of nothing, it has to come from somewhere. And where does it come from? The atmosphere! With the help of the sun, carbon dioxide and oxygen is converted to carbon hydrates in crops, inluding grass. When cows eat this, they are simply part of a circular ecosystem, which has existed for billions of years. Why would this system suddenly be broken to produce more carbon than was put in?
Talks about methane when linking source that talks about CO2 equivalents. So the point about methain is compleatly irrelavent since it's already have been calculated to effects of CO2. Same source points out how forest burning accounts for 2% of GHG. Which is a mute point, because a study from 2018 shows we actually have more trees then we had in 1982.  Crops for animal feeder emits 6% GHG. Crops for people emit 21%. About 3kg of crops is needed to produce 1kg of meat. So we gain 4% from crop farming just for people assuming we want to have about the same amount of food in mass. 4% of 26% all food emitions is 1% total.  40% of livestock emissions are from farts. I'm not gonna include manouer because we will still need to fertilize the fields with something. Not gonna include land changes, because again, it is false that we have less trees today.  To recap. 26% is all food emitions. 30% of that is from all livestock. And 40% of that is from farts. So 40% of 30% of 26% is 3.1% of total. Add to it 1% that we save no longer needing to feed animals and we have at best 4.1% reduction in GHG in CO2 equivalents if you go vegan.   Since according to the video about 60% of livestock emitions come from beef and half of beef is used for meat consumption, if you just quit eating beef that's 1.4% reduction in total emissions.  When people talk about quiting meat, they really seem to forget that we still need to produce, process, package, transport store and refrigerate all the new food substitutes, as well as fertilize the fields and do something with waste. Waste that will produce methane.  Obviously 4.1% is not nothing. But transport (just cars) depending on source contribute 8-15% and by moving to solar we can reduce emitions by about 25% (by my calculations). And the thing is, at least with energy, it requires absolutely zero compromises from people. And governments are already subsidising solars. Then there's the fact that technological improvements increase efficiency, reducing GHG emitions. US for example houses 6% of world beef population but is producing 28% of world's beef (did not verify this myself).  It's also interesting how they are talking about deforestation of rain forests, but it's not like africa or south america are exporting beef to the US. Even in central and south america malnutrition is an issue. Not as bad as africa, but still. Should they stop cutting down trees and just starve? Not that the deforestation is an issue, as mentioned earlier. But even if it was, what would they offer as a solution to those people that don't have enough to eat? I didn't read much to it, but I found an article talking how land gained from burning down rainforests is used for poeple crops and only after the soil is no longer viable it's transformed for ruminant animals. So it's not like they burn it for animal farming.

@Kurzgesagt - In a Nutshell ---> *This video contains many fundamental inaccuracies* that could be perceived as spreading non-factual information. Therefore, I studied your Sources & further reading. Unfortunately, I have to say that I have encountered severe shortcomings, whether in your interpretation or in the sources noted.  Example No.1: at 00:01:24 _"Worldwide food production is responsible for about 26% of all human-made GHG."_ Your source: Poore & Nemecek 2018  My finding: 1. Nowhere is an exact citation of the source. But I helped myself because this author team published only one document in 2018 entitled _"Reducing food's environmental impacts through producers and consumers"._ 2. This document *contains literally only one sentence:* _"Today's food supply chain creates ~ 13.7 billion metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalents (CO2eq), 26% of anthropogenic GHG emissions._ *3. No research, no given source. Nothing.* 4. To date, there is no scientific work to confirm this figure exactly. Only a lot in the form of an estimate. And, if we agree - estimation is not an exact science.  And this is one of the many examples your video is based on. So from the point of view of responsibility for disseminating unverified facts, you should consider withdrawing it.  If you are really interested in spreading the facts, you can contact me directly. I have been doing this part of science for a long time. I am in favor of reducing emissions, but scientifically and not populist. This is more suitable for politics or people who have other interests in it = and such approach will not save this planet.
I did a calculation:  Beef has 70% more calories than potatoes.  But... there's complications.  That 70% longer time alive wouldn't go higher due to higher protien in beef becuse the body can't use all that. Potatoes have all you need.  Beef's extra protein would be converted into glucose (that conversion used up calories).  So the 70% goes down lets say to 65%.  THEN... you could factor in the health risks of beef.

Most days, I am vegetarian. Just by accident.   Fairly shocked at how biased - but pretending to be factual - this video is. dont like the meat or you dont wanna eat it? put it on my plate, ill take care of it for you!!!!
i dont think "what i've learned"'s main point was that meat wasn't bad for the environment; he states many times that meat has a negative environmental effect. **rather, his video was a response to the growing narrative that meat was absolutely the worst thing for the environment and that we could save the planet and solve our problems simply by cutting meat out of our diet.** he objected to this narrative because it was beginning to distract from the massive harm that fossil fuels had on the environment--his implication is that cutting meat out of our diet will be next to useless unless we do something about fossil fuels, which are exponentially more harmful.   there are two discourses around meat-eating: ethical and environmental. "what i've learned" is not concerned with ethics of meat-eating, but with saving the environment. there are people who are largely concerned with the ethics of meat consumption, and they seem less concerned with the environment than they are with stopping meat-eating. they will overblow the environmental effects of meat-eating in order to artificially bolster their ethical argument. (i doubt they're aware they are doing this, i dont think they would intentionally push arguments that would harm the environment). "what i've learned"s main mission is to undo these misconceptions. people are misinterpreting his video as an (ethical) defense of meat-eating. his video is not a defense of meat-eating, it's a defense of the environment.  what i've said is not a comment on the facts of the matter. i don't pretend to know, and it's a complicated subject: for instance, "what i've learned" states that cows dont add more methane to the system, while fossil fuels do add extra carbon dioxide that otherwise would have been trapped underground--this is true. kurzgesagt says that methane, while existing in smaller quantites than carbon dioxide, is quantitatively more harmful to the environment than carbon dioxide--this is also probably true. neither of these facts refute the other, they're both relevant. i don't know if fossils fuels are really way worse than meat for the environment, or vice versa, or if it's about even, or whatever.  what IS important is to clarify the intentions and biases of both sides of this discussion. humans dont judge arguments purely by their logic, they also judge by assuming intentions of the people presenting the argument. many people are ethically biased against meat-eating, and this is likely to skew their logic. "what i've learned"s channel also seems to be biased towards meat consumption, so he's not exactly bias-free either. as for kurzgesagt i can't tell; they present their arguments in a cold and neutral way, but an ostensibly neutral presentation can still mask deep biases. but kurzgesagt's video APPEARS to refute "what i've learned"s video WITHOUT actually engaging with his actual argument, and this is a dangerous (and probably unintentional) misdirection.  i will say that different people have differing levels of susceptibility to their biases; some people are less likely to warp their logic according to their biases. according to my own judgement, "what i've learned" seems to be relatively (emphasis on relatively) impervious to bias-distortion. but this is a purely subjective judgement on my part.   a quote from Anna Karenina: "Levin had often noticed in discussions between the most intelligent people that after enormous efforts, and an enormous expenditure of logical subtleties and words, the disputants finally arrived at being aware that what they had so long been struggling to prove to one another had long ago, from the beginning of the argument, been known to both, but that they liked different things, and would not define what they liked for fear of its being attacked. He had often had the experience of suddenly in a discussion grasping what it was his opponent liked and at once liking it too, and immediately he found himself agreeing, and then all arguments fell away as useless."  and an interesting tidbit that i learned from vsauce: evolutionarily speaking, people don't use logic to arrive at conclusions. they use conclusions to arrive at logic. logic is a social behavior used to convince others of their conclusions.  so one must ask: if it wasn't logic, how did they arrive at their conclusions?

Beyond protein quality, we don't eat meat just because of protein. Thinking in these terms, eating anything else than vegetable oil for caloric intake is terribly wasteful.
So this ignores the evidence that regenerative farming, grass fed beef included, can actually sequester carbon at a significant rate. According to calculations by Joel Salatin of Ployface Farm, if everyone farmed cattle the way he does, we could sequester all the CO2 produced by humans since the start of the industrial revolution in about 10 years. I realise this wasn't part of the video, but it also ignores the massive animal death count from conventional monoculture farming.  Here in Australia, our largest pea growing farm shoots hundreds of animals (including native animals) per season to prevent crop damage. Not to mention that those animals still living are deprived of access to that land. In regenerative cattle growing for example, there is still food and habitat for native animals, albeit less than native forest, but surely still significantly better than nothing.

This results in 3 Effects at once.  A.  Vegetable Food becomes Cheaper therefore becoming more Attractive to People thus Promoting a higher Ratio of Vegetables in the Diet.  B.  Farmland used for Human Food becomes more Profitable therefore causing more Farmers with Suitable Farmland to Produce Human Food directly which will reduce such Farmland being used for Animal Food.  C.  Food Prices except Meat will drop thus improving Living Standards for People.

I raise a small beef herd and agree with pretty much all of this.  We've left over 40% of our property as forested land and kept all the grass and forage native instead of planting invasives as an attempt to compensate.  As time moves forward I want an electric skidsteer, tractor, utv, and four wheeler.  We're working on powering the whole farmstead on solar panels within the next three years as well. This video is only concerned with carbon gas emissions though. Torture and slaughter would still be bad even if livestock were somehow not a factor in climate change at all. When you consider the sentience harm angle instead; the production of eggs, dairy, chicken and fish products causes much more harm than beef does, because you make much more bodies suffer to produce the same amount of food since each of those bodies is so much smaller than an adult bovine. If you want to go vegan for ethical reasons but still don't want to cut all animal products in one go; consider cutting fish and eggs/chicken first. Then pork, then dairy/beef; in order of most suffering to the least suffering directly caused by torture and slaughter. Similarly, hunting smaller game is worse than hunting bigger game; because you have to kill so much more in order to get as much food; and sentience is very much _not_ proportional to body size.

I don't really care about the environment when it comes to why I'm vegan. It's really all about not letting animals suffer.   It's very convenient for people to forget that cows and pigs are species that have sophisticated emotions and social interactions, that egg farms keep chickens in tight cages as they develop leg- and other growth-related problems (there's tons of pictures and video), and that male baby chicks are killed because they can't lay eggs or be used for meat as they don't produce enough meat for it to be "worth it". Fish suffocate and die painfully from the lack of pressure when taken out of water, obviously.    There is no in-between, you are either vegan or you support _some_ level of animal suffering because you want to indulge yourself with animal products. It's really that simple.
Pretty well done video. However I was disappointed in coverage of the methane issue which is routinely misrepresented just about everywhere. Pound for pound, the methane emissions of all animals is roughly the same. The difference is at what point we emit methane. Ruminants emit the most while digesting. Other animals emit from their feces. Cow manure emits very little methane. Manure of pigs and chickens (and humans) emits a lot.  Pound for pound, anything that eats is going to produce about the same amount of methane while digesting or through excretion. Keep telling vegans that arguments for reduced meat consumption are very strong but arguments for complete abstinence are very weak and counter productive. Of course, once one admits that reduced consumption of beef is the stronger argument, one comes perilously close to acknowledging that reduced consumption of everything is in order and that the degrowthers have got it right.

Summary!  Does meat have a negative impact on our environment? YESЁЯШ╖ Will people (including me) stop eating meat because of that- HELL NOЁЯдд So is it worth giving a second thought? NO ( don't stress over things you are sure you cannot change)ЁЯдЩ great vid btw
1:02 "Zero-carbon tractors, refrigerators, and cookers running on renewable energy, and electric trucks"  This was probably on purpose, but I'd just like to underline the wrong, short-sighted, frame of thinking that all these techno-solutions seem to stem from.  Let's take electric trucks. We *already* have a more carbon-efficient solution for freight transport on land over long distances: Trains. (Even non-electric ones.)  We have to stop thinking in terms of "How could we make X 0-carbon?", and start thinking in terms of "How can we structure society differently to reduce carbon emissions *right now*?".  This is what I mean by "short-sighted". Paradoxically, by trying to invent new and shiny solutions that rely on technological advances, we fail to see the bigger picture, and we close our eyes to the real, concrete solutions that are *already* available and that can *already* have a meaningful impact. All because - I think - they usually mean compromising our comfort in some way or an other.  Like reducing our meat consumption for example... Or our consumption of anything, really. Or, even more radical, trying to gradually reduce the global population. Because if we fail to do so, there will be a point when it *will* reduce. And it won't be gradual.  So thank you, Kurzgesagt, for educating people. The work that you're doing here is essential.

So dino-farts were never a thing... ?
Climate change is very important, but it's not the only basis on which to evaluate meat... or anything else.
CH4 emissions from cattle are from burps (and manure in some manure-management systems), not farts.  Also, GHG emissions from agriculture, including meat production, are part of the short carbon cycle.  That is, agricultural production moves around carbon already in the atmosphere and biosphere.  Conversely, fossil fuels add carbon from the long cycle to the short cycle.  Treating agricultural emissions as equivalent to fossil-fuel emissions is inaccurate and unhelpful.

Id love to hear your thoughts on permaculture food raising. You use the same bit of land to raise tree and shrub produce as well as annual crops beneath those and use animals to graze that down and keep limbs high on trees. That keeps disease down in the plants and the grazing helps fertilize the soil. By rotating the animals (beef or otherwise) you keep over grazing down and using multiple kinds of animals helps to keep grazing even so no one kind of plant gets over eaten. This method stops tilling, which keeps erosion down. All the trees (if mixed and not in monoculture rows) helps boost diversity and encourages insect and wildlife. This means almost no need for fertilizing or pesticides. That means no toxic run off and the soil grows dark and healthy as it catchs lots of carbon.
What about the carbon footprint of seafood? Fish, squid, prawns and the like. Curious about how they compare with other meats.

Am I the only one who takes issue with Kurzgesagt focusing on beef as a stand in for all meat, despite saying beef is an outlier? I believe that chicken and pork are together more popular and more widely consumed meats worldwide, no? Why not focus on their emissions vs plants?  But let's assume beef was the only meat consumed by humans. Considering the methane produced by cows, of course beef will look much worse than plants in terms of emissions. But methane from cows can be reduced by altering cattle diet (e.g. putting a little seaweed in their food) or capturing it at the source (helmets and bags for cow burps and farts). Those changes would likely alter the emissions calculus significantly, and those solutions are being tested right now, but there was no mention of them in despite this video focusing heavily on beef.   Also, even if cattle and other animals eat more than non arable grassland and eat from feed crops, isn't it possible farmers are actually giving those animals the ^waste^ from feed crops? Humans only eat certain fruits, seeds, and roots of any given food crop. That isn't much of the plant mass on the average crop that humans consume. Considering how often farmers have been caught reusing and recycling waste products to increase production in other instances, it's a strong possibility that the wasted plant mass from feed crops is what's really fed to farm animals meant for slaughter. If true, it's a bit misleading to just say farm animals "mostly eat feed crops" as if they eat the same parts of feed crops that humans do.

I have doubts about the statement that 65% of land used for Beef is not useful for growing crops. There are many ways to Terra-form land so it becomes useful for crops. Aztecs grew crops on floating man made islands, and fed thousands. Greenhouses can allow the growth of many crops in colder climates. The Inca grew many crops on man-made stone, and earth steps built on steep hills, and mountain slopes. Algae, and fish can be grown in large metal, or plastic tanks of water. I think your statistics are based on land that factory farms can quickly till, seed, fertilize with chemicals, and harvest (low labor) with mechanical machines. Factory farms can produce large quantities of certain foodstuffs, but at a substantial environmental cost that isn't taken into account by our capitalist system unless maintaining high production on the land is important for future profits. Otherwise these people could care less about the land, water, and air where crops are produced--- that's someone else's problem, like the locals who live there. We just want to make a profit, and don't give a damn whether the locals suffer or not. Disgusting self-centered people, borderline criminals. That's why family farms were better although possibly less efficient of producing massive quantities of certain foods, but more environmentally friendly because they lived on the land, and many grew varieties of fruits, vegetables, and farm animals for themselves, and to sell locally.
I have to disagree with you on something...which is a rarity...the part where you talk about the shipping costs of plants overseas vs eating locally. While its true that the shipping containers are more fuel-efficient, you also have to ship them directly to the stores in the same manner that a local ships their food...in the end, you are producing more CO2 by buying outsourced food, meat, or otherwise, than buying locally grown meat. In all honesty, if you want to compare apples to apples, buying locally as a vegetarian is a lot more planet safe than buying imported plants and plant products...its the same as buying meat locally vs buying meat products and imported meat. You run into fallacies when you try to compare locally produced meat vs imported veggies.  When you don't buy locally, you commit to buying foods that you arent 100% sure where they are coming from and how the food is produced...massive farms that produce veggies do produce less CO2 emissions but can destroy local ecosystems just as bad or even more than cattle by killing the local vegetation and animals in the ground.  Lastely, I feel that this vid was more of a social experiment because you are usually more thorough in your videos when it comes to research and take more of a middle stance on things like this...similar to your older meat and dairy video you did before.  Even though I disagree, I still love your content. Keep up the good work otherwise  :)

This video appears to be full of a lot of misinformation.  Most Soy does not go to Humans because Humans are not capable of digesting it (it is mostly dietary fibre), it is a waste product that is going to release CO2 anyway to burn it but animals like Cows which have much stronger digestive systems than we do are capable of consuming it. The primary driver for Soy still remains human consumption, not animal consumption and just goes to show how wasteful things for humans actually get. Generally speaking, Humans pay more for Soy than farmers pay for animal feed, you'd be a fool to sell even 1 gram of human consumable soy to intentionally instead go towards animal consumption.  But there is just a massive issue that is straight up ignored, this is just comparing carbon but soil degradation is another issue which is very much as relevant, most crop farming has left much of the ground dirt infertile for plant life. We could be looking at most farmland today lasting only between another 50-100 harvests. There are however ways to improve soil quality, such as mixed farming which is where you rotate around what you grow on the land, you also rest the land AND graze animals on the land. While climate change does need to be delayed and slowed as much as possible, destroying most of our arable land is equally if not a potentially worse situation which is just ignored.

9:23 here you compare the carbon cleaning capabilities of 3 billion hectares of land over 100 years compared to the amount of CO2 produced in one year. Not an equal comparison, this is lying with statistics. If we annualized both, the 3 billion hectares would only clean 8 billion tons of CO2 a year, about 16% of the CO2 produced in a year. So if everyone in the world went vegan and if we used the 3 billion hectacres solely for carbon cleaning, we'd still barely make a dent.  We need to focus on taxing carbon emissions instead of pressuring individuals to change their eating habits. The majority of carbon emissions are from big corporations, let's fix that first since it will have the most impact. They're the reason, they are the problem, going after them is the solution.

Some of this is 'bullshit' eg at 6.40 it outright says that crueller farming practices can 'sometimes' be less destructive for the planet, but it just exaggerated that for effect. Factory fed cows produce waaay more carbon emissions than grass fed beef. The less cruel farming practice *is* the better practice for carbon emissions. In other words, eat grass fed beef if you're going to have beef.

"Vegans have never been able to define or measure that their diet causes less deaths/suffering than an omnivorous one. They are ignorantly contributing to an absolute bloodbath of trillions of zooplankton, mites, worms, crickets, grasshoppers, snails, frogs, turtles, rats, squirrels, possum, raccoons, moles, rabbits, boars, deer, 75% of insect biomass, half of all bird species and 20,000 humans per year. Two grass-fed cows are enough to feed someone for a year and, if managed properly, can restore biodiversity.  Vegans likely exploit more animals than the average person. The Vegan Society officially rejects beekeeping, but many commercial crops require to be pollinated by domestic bees that are forced to breed, shipped around and then worked to death. It's principally impossible to have a nutritionally complete vegan diet without forced pollination, but fodder crops do not exploit bees. As a result, human food crops kill five times as many bees as all livestock slaughter combined and directly support honey production (taking excess honey is necessary for colony health).   Since vegans somehow manage to justify systematically poisoning and torturing insects by arbitrarily declaring that they can't suffer ("sentience"), they might aswell consider eating them. The same goes for bivalves, since there's about as much evidence that they feel pain as there is for plants."  (This is obviously about the ethical aspect rather than environmental)

Lots of falsehoods in this video. 1 of the biggest being that clearing a forest for grassland results in massive Carbon loss from the soil and permanently damages its future storage potential. In reality forest soils have very little carbon storage in comparison to other biomes. Carbon storage in soils is related to the amount put in thru plants/bio and amount lost thru microbial use. Forest have poor plant undergrowth. Trees themselves have large lignin heavy slow growing root systems that add very little to soil carbon. In fact they can be a net negative since they suck large amounts of moisture from the soil (transpiration). The wetter the soil the more carbon can build up since you switch to anaerobic microbial process. So in reality clearing a forest for a grazed grassland pasture can increase soil carbon by a massive factor. It will increase the carbon input massively thru life/death cycle of fine rootsystems of pasture grasses. The cows waste also adds to the system thru increased carbon/ fauna/ microbial. The soil will become wetter and more productive to carbon storage because the grasses dont extract the amount of groundwater that trees do and the water table will rise. You really have to do a proper carbon budget and there is a ton of context missing from this video.
There's a fatal flaw with this train of thought: the idea that more efficient food production will lead to people conserving land. That isn't how people behave, and there are many historical examples of this. When people are able to farm more efficiently, they don't use less land; instead, they just continue using all the same land and just produce more crops. And not only is this empirically true, it also makes perfect sense in terms of the incentives people chase after, and the short-sighted, self-centered decision-making processes they employ. And given that more efficient agriculture really leads to more production rather than less land usage, you then have to ask yourself whether you truly believe that higher production is more environmentally friendly - and I'm willing to bet that you don't.

4:20 - That bit about avocados (and other plant-based foods) being transported mostly by "insanely efficient" container ships is BULLSHIT. When transported internationally, _perishable_ plant-based foods like fresh fruit and vegetables are more commonly packed on to jet aircraft. This has a _much_ higher carbon footprint. So kilojoule for kilojoule, your oranges (imported so you could eat them out of season) might be worse for the planet than your steak (especially if the cow was raised on pasture).

I like meat, especially beef (I mean steaks, BBQ and stuff is so yummy). But for 2 years now I have largely reduced my red meat consumption.  I switched from a diet with a lot of beef to mainly chicken (and pork a bit). I went from eating beef almost every day to 2-3 times a month. And... I don't  really miss it in the end. I appreciate the moments I eat beef and don't take it for granted. I now consider it as a delicacy.  At the same time I am trying more and more to have vegetarian or vegan lunches.  I'll be honest though, I don't think I will be able to switch to a full vegetarian or vegan diet any time soon. I am also aware regarding animal cruelty, that the fact I still eat chicken is not great.  If we could eat less meat in general it would just be better on so many aspects. Cutting red meat is way more easy than I thought and I think is a good start for people who want to think a bit about climate change.
Another solution is lab meat, as i imagine that would significantly reduce carbon production from the meat since you're not growing a whole animal, just the part you intend to eat. Would also free up farmland that can't be used for human food production to be used for foresting like you said (Which honestly, given what was said in this video would probably save the earth from impending climate disaster) Sure, some will refuse to change their farming lifestyle. But once lab meat is cheap to produce and plentiful, it'll likely be easy for people to switch to it rather than real meat, and it might end up as a luxury product one day.  In short: Lab meat will reduce the demand for animals bred for meat.
