You IMMEDIATLY juxtaposed this figure ("800 billions Tonnes over 100 years) against 50 billon Tonnes per year.... it's not 800 compared to 50 as you displayed (with a graph no less...this is clearly intentional)...the real comparison is, based on what you a presenting in the proper context...smh, we'd save 8 Tonnes per year by shifting to a global vegan diet. Theres different ways of converting methane to co2 equivalents. The old one was way worse than the one science now recommends. Not sure which one is used for this video.  A constant number of cattle in the world will have a constant methane concentration in the atmosphere. A change in population of cattle will have a rather large impact in the short term.

So 2 things you didn't mention.  The first is that the vast majority of plants have parts not fit for human consumption.  Most farm animals actually can process the whole plant and most farmers process what can't be used for people into feed for the animals.  The second thing is general health when it comes to meat alternatives.  A typical veggie or "impossible" burger not only contributes to plant waste since humans can't process much of the plants used to make that patty, but the ingredient list is much more complex and the calorie count is often over double for beef.  The last thing we need as a species known for overeating is more calories in the same amount of food.
And yet beef is still the best thing going.

It is well known fact that the figures are inflated for meat production. The meat production used entire lifecycle calculations yet the plant production only used a portion of the lifecycle. According to the Environmental Protection Agency, just 4.2 percent of greenhouse gas emissions are from livestock agriculture, with beef contributing 1.4 percent. I feel like there is a lot of low level misleading or lying going on here. Avocados come to your local shop on container ships while beef is hauled there on trucks... but how do the avocados get from the docks to your local shop? Does beef get better if it's from Australia or Argentina and gets transported most of the way in containers on super efficient ships? It felt like a false or oversimplified argument.    And then there is the matter of pigs...   Pigs eat exclusively feed crops??? Anyone who has seen pigs on small farms knows that pigs eat absolutely anything. True omnivores. They eat people, garbage, feed crops, grass, weeds... anything.  Unlike ruminants they are monogastric and so not optimized for grass consumption... but to say they exclusively eat feed crops is to say something not true--in other words, it's a lie. Obviously cutting sugars and carbs is generally a good idea, but IтАЩm also excluding fibers from plants. as much as i love kurzgesagt and learned so much from them, i have to disagree(just to share my perspective) with some points. like the carbon emissions of locally sourced stuffs. you can safely assume there are way more people who are further from the nearest market than those closer to it especially in developing countries, which a larger chunk of human population is in, where there are lesser numbers of facilities for distributing commodities to the masses. which would consume more fuel? each houselhold in a community traveling to the same market just to get basically the same or similar kinds of food? or a handful of nearer local producers and distributors delivering those same stuffs to each of those same households? extreme examples for the sake of comparisson would be the difference between that of everyone growing their own food on their backyard with that of everyone going to the same market to get food, which system would consume more fuel?  and raising cattle, for the most part, is carbon neutral because the carbon they emit are the very same carbon the plants they consumed absorbed in the atmosphere. so they're just farting back carbon from where it came from. applying the logic that a cow's carbon emission is large because it farts also applies to every other animal. an adult human on average exhales about 1kg of carbon dioxide a day, given that we are billions then that's a couple thousand tons of carbon dioxide in a day. and humanity is just a negligible percentage of earth's biomass, just imagine how much carbon the entirety of earth's biomass emit on the daily through respiration (yes, even plants do it).   the main culprit for the increasing carbon content in the atmosphere are fossil fuels being burned, reintroducing carbon from the remains of ancient life, trapped beneath the earth, has absorbed. it creates an imbalance where there's more carbon emitted to the atmosphere than being absorbed from it.  the solution would be to restore balance, how to do it? decrease carbon emissions by shifting to carbon neutral fuels and developing more efficient ways on how we use energy from the fuels we burn and increase the carbon absorption by growing (planting is merely a part of it) trees(fruit bearing oned would be smart). would it be a logistics nightmare? possiby... would it be worth it? worth more than a participation trophy by bitching about world issues, pointing out who or what to blame and attacking anyone who disagrees but failing to offer a viable solution thereof, let alone participate in it.

An important factor this whole discussion ignores is what is natural, or a baseline, as the current emissions from beef and other large consumable animals is equivalent to pre-colonial levels in the US and outside the US around medieval levels. And have been so for as long as it's been measured.  People, especially the green lobby, like to pretend 0 CO2 is the goal but ignore the fact that humans have replaced a lot of animals and that going to the other extreme is just as bad.

And there's nothing to suggest karma doesn't exist; wave-particle duality appears to demand the existence of an observer, meaning your perspective will most certainly be accommodated by another living thing after your death. They both took this one electron universe theory very seriously. Wouldn't it make sense that consciousness defines the particle because it _is_ that particle? Our consciousness is constantly about 80 milliseconds retroactive from the objective present due to the time required for light (i.e. information) to travel the wavelength of our extremely low frequency animal neural oscillations, but the scientific community has never appeared to contemplate that this could mean probability collapse happens back here. Why wouldn't it? Because otherwise there is a temporal disconnect between the retroactive observation and the observed event happening much closer to the objective present. No, rather, it makes much more sense to insert an observer operating at all frequency ranges relaying causal information between observers at different frequency ranges (i.e. temporal locations), and A.I. very nicely facilitates this probabilistic relay. Folks you donтАЩt have to completely transition over to a meatless diet. You can make an impact by simply reducing your meat intake each week. For example, some folks only eat fish on Fridays for religious reasons. Well, you can begin to incorporate a meatless diet once a week and see how it goes. IтАЩve been a vegetarian for over 3 years now and to this day I am still discovering new tasty meatless recipes. If you love to cook, give it a try.   We can help reduce our carbon footprint by minimizing the amount of days we eat meat. Also the more people that are open to meatless options means more innovation in terms of cuisine. So us vegetarians and vegans benefit as well.
I'm always a bit skeptical of fully vegetable based diets; It seems to me for everyone who says that it's entirely reasonable to switch over, there's also data suggesting that the nutrient balance of meats is fairly well tuned to our nutritional requirements, and we don't fully understand the physiological impact of a lot of the micronutrients in a wide variety of plants (particularly as they relate to mental health), to say nothing of the impacts of, for example, a high soy diet in men. It seems to me the obvious solution for most people isn't going 100% meet free, or 100% meet, but some happy medium inbetween, with a regular "beef Friday" or having beef the first Friday of the month, and then picking two other days of the week to have chicken after that week, and doing your best to be meat free the other ~21 days of the month.

So, there are some additional bits of information I think would be helpful for context, as someone that has a degree in and has worked with the animal product production industry: 1. There is such a thing as ethical factory farming, and we need to install those practices in every factory farm. Just like it's more ethical to keep your cat indoors (because they're weapons of mass ecological destruction) we probably should do this with livestock species for the sake of efficiency. We just need to provide them with toys, adequate space to exercise and/or exercise equipment, and proper sanitation.  2. Most farmers, even corporations, care a lot for the welfare of their animals. That's because welfare (stress, disease, injury) drastically affects the quality and/or quantity of the product. This includes making sure they get proper nutrition (production chickens are not malnourished, I promise). There are still things that can be done better, especially for some areas, but we're getting there at faster and faster rates as the data comes back that we can make more money by adjusting our animal management.  3. Product labels are misleading at best. Let's look at chickens: No antibiotics ever means if an animal gets sick they're killed instead of treated. Free range/cage free means they're packed in a warehouse with no hope of developing a proper pecking order (injuries out the wazoo from constant fighting). Pasture raised means they're constantly exposed to disease from passing birds and die at a prodigious rate. The best system we have is colony caging, which is sometimes labeled cage free and sometimes not labeled at all: you put about 30 birds in a very large cage so they can establish pecking order and hurt each other, and they still have room to wander around and socialize/play.  Please don't pay for eggs quadruple the price of regular eggs and that end up hurting birds. Thank you for coming to my Ted talk.

tbh I think it is possible to sustainably eat animal protein if it is truly local, and by that I mean that the animal is native to the area you live in. Like, if we were to genuinely restructure the way that we source our food so that it is completely eco-friendly, it would require us to return to a more hunter-gatherer style of food-sourcing. However this idea presents a lot of problems.  A: It would drastically impact our everyday diets. A lot of the animals used as dietary staples (cows, pigs, & chickens) are native to Eurasia and parts of Africa. This means we'd have to get comfortable with eating animals that aren't considered part of a "normal" diet, and probably a lot more fish/aquatic animals if you live near bodies of water. This would also change what plants we eat (wheat is in the same camp as cows, chickens, and pigs). B. It would be extremely difficult if not impossible to continue producing food at its current rate. I do think it would be better given the sheer amount of food waste that our current system produces, which only adds to the rate of emissions caused by food. Honestly, the current models of plant agriculture is also extremely harmful to the environment (even if it's not as bad as meat agriculture). C: Obviously there are people with dietary restrictions due to medical reasons, could be a food allergy, diabetes, autoimmune diseases, kidney disease, or cancer. If you can't survive off of the local foods, you're going to need to supplement your diet with other foods so you can have a healthy diet.  D: Straight up, a change in our everyday diets as radical as this would just be a hard sell. Like the video says, we don't take very well to someone stepping in and saying that we can't eat the foods we're used to, especially if it's being positioned as a moral ultimatum. Not to mention, even if we hypothetically somehow managed to do this, given our current socio-economic system, many of our current food staples would return to their previous status as luxury goods that only rich people can eat on a regular basis unless you live in an area where the food is native to, which would just be a kick in the teeth for people who didn't want this change.  I have a lot of thoughts and criticisms about our current models of food production, but can really only give you vague ideas about what we can do to change it. I do think we can change it, it's just going to be a very rough transition for a lot of reasons

Sadly, if we were to cut beef totally out of everyone's diets... the cows would still be around.  Sure, they wouldn't be in the vast numbers they are, but they would not just vanish overnight.  We'd have to cull them... and then the meat would go to waste, since we wouldn't be eating it.  Then consider if we didn't kill them all, and some were left.  Would we let them roam wild, which would cause a natural resurgence of their population, or would we put them in zoos?  Either way, they'd still be releasing the emissions that they naturally do, which is a large part of why we would have cut them out of our diet in the first place.  That's just the cows though.  So say we cut beef totally out of our diets and reduced their numbers greatly, and just kept the remainders in zoos so there were no 'wild' cows left.  All of the crops we grow to feed the cows wouldn't be needed- wait wait wait no.  If we take an energy dense food out of the equation, we have to account for what we'd eat in place of that food in order to keep our diets bringing in the same level of energy.  So in reality, we would be eating a lot of the crops that Were being grown for the cows to eat.  Cutting out beef, or meat in general, isn't a perfect solution.  We evolved as omnivores.  We have dietary needs and meat is a part of it.  Its the Excess that we've grown to accept as normal that's the bad thing.  Being Vegetarian or Vegan doesn't mean all that much if you're still eating in excess.  Somewhere along the lines, humans forgot what moderation means.

The thing that is often missed about feeding crops to animals, is that we aren't growing them solely to be fed to animals. If we grow corn, we can only eat the grain part of it. The stalk and the husk, we can't, but cows can. Aside from a bad harvest or the occasional ear of corn that's missed at harvest, the majority of the crops that cows eat are not crops that human's could eat instead, its in fact smart waste management.

Overly optimistic. Yes, we can try and push for a change in behavior and it can be affective. But, often the best thing we can do is just try and make luxurious things more efficient, since people will, 9 times out of 10, give efficiency and environmental impact the shaft if it means a higher standard of living and they can afford it.

Food is a multi sided complex topic. Corporate farming scaled beef and chicken production using hormones and antibiotics in interest of profit. They claim itтАЩs to drive the cost of food down and make food more accessible to all.   Trade offs are more transportation emissions and water waste that is required raise and process meat.   Health wise meat can be an important part of your diet and a good source of iron, omega 3, and of course much needed protein. Meat becomes harmful to our health when we over consume and or the quality of it is compromised.  The ideal scenario would be to consume proper amounts of meat (couple times a week) that are produced in humane ways (grass fed beef, free range chicken) locally. This supports a balanced diet, promotes local business, cuts down on emissions, and provides more humane conditions for food source animals.  Meat isnтАЩt innately bad. But like many things corporations have made it bad for us physically and environmentally.

if this was in the debate that was brought up i would have given up
One thing I always get peeved on this topic is that there always seems to be a missing argument. There HAS to be some theoretical proportion of animal feed that is more sustainable than no animal feed whatsoever.  We know GNU's in the savannah are a keystone species, that is, if they are removed the entire ecosystem dies (and in general grassland needs some amount of ungulates pasturing on it to thrive). Thus there have to be ungulates and thus there is some proportion of ungulates that can be converted to human food. I don;t know if it is 10% of all current consumption or 1% or 0.1%, but there has to be SOME percent that is more sustainable than 0 (once more because you are going to have ungulates pasturing on grassland anyway).  The other argument that is usually left out is that hunting (and I guess gathering) is the only carbon neutral or even negative  source of food we have at the moment. It's obviously not going to feed that many people, but which proportion of people can be fed with hunted game? Is it 10%, 1%, 0.1%?  There's also an obvious bias in the video since it analyzed the worst offender (beef) primarily, what about all the different species of fish?  Farmed salmon vs wild caught salmon? Canned tuna (which is a completely different kind of tuna than the big tunas that until recently were endangered)?    And there's also the implicit assumption that all humans can live on plant only diets, which we know is not as clear. Different populations diggest food differently, in part due to genetics and in part due to gut microbiome. A diet rich in dairy is fine for a norwegian but would kill many Japanese people. A diet very rich in fish oil is amazing for Inuits but not very healthy for other populations. The same is true for plant based foods, not everyone can eat the exact same plant based diet and remain healthy and things like food allergies might make it impossible to survive without meat.  And then we have the issues of pets, dogs and cats are carnivores and need meat.  Rather than "meat is bad", I want to know an estimate of what would be a reasonable frequency of animal product consumption? One fish a day? On chicken a week? One cut of beef every 3 months?  What budget of meat production do we theoretically have for each food source? That's I think more useful.
I think we will need a part 2 for this video focusing on fish and seafood and its impact on Co2 emissions :)

You presented facts about "good" beef producing 1/10 emissions, beef being a much denser source of calories' and the benefits of transportation and packaging efficiency separately.. Facts don't exist separately from each other in the Real world. Here in Northeast Wyoming we herd cows in forests...I am pretty sure that the greenhouse gas emissions would be higher if we cut them down for crops...not that they would grow very well
About the argument for crops humans can eat being fed to cattle...   Humans can only eat a small portion of the grain harvest, the stalks and such cannot be digested by a human (though you can eat it, itтАЩs just fiber). Those can be fed to cattle, and often those are what is fed to cattle. The statistic is misleading, because it says 40-ish percent of cereal produce is fed to cattle, that often includes the stalks which humans donтАЩt eat. It IS much more efficient to do it that way.

The IPCC report admitted methane is not a CO2 equivalent. It was overstated by 3-4 times. That fact was of course not widely publicized. We also have to understand that the carbon put into the air by cows came from plants (grass, corn), so it's not the same as carbon that came from the ground like petroleum.  Also, here in the US, beef production is very efficient. The number that's always thrown around (18%+) is the global average. These are details that are never given any attention.  Always be weary of top line numbers when viewing videos like these.

I've worked at a good few health clinics and while anecdotal, all the times this has been brought up, the issue comes back to children. A completely vegan diet requires rather strict food sources to gain what you need from, but children are growing and people have shown time and time again that they are unable to care for themselves. When what a child requires varies much more heavily than an adult who has finished growing, are regular individuals really able to care properly for their children? Sure, meat and other such sources may not be good for the environment and may be a little to easy to gain a surplus of what you need, but that is still better than the alternative of getting _less_ than you need. Some issues may not be apparent until years later when it becomes apparent that they did not get everything they needed for their development.  Again, if so many people show that they are barely able to care for themselves and only a few who go for a full plant diet do it _correctly_, I am not exactly jumping with joy when considering that children will be subjected to that too. The deal-breaker on veganism for me has never been the question of whether it is more eco-friendly, it has always been the fact that next to other industrial emissions, food is relatively small, and that it is always put forward aggressively and condescendingly as a duty strictly incumbent upon the consumer, when the scale of the industry is such that it is virtually un-boycott-able without fundamental changes at the level of investment and technology. This is the kind of diet activism I can get behind, fostering a measured understanding and maintaining the ideal of reduced emissions without getting overexcited or cruel and petty about the specifics of method. At the end of the day humanity and our animals are going to have a substantial footprint, that doesn't  mean we have to view our habits as evil via a Malthusian logic.

That those farms HAVE to use fertilizer because there is no way to replenish the nutrients fast enough by natural means. Between the causes of the emissions and the note about how more cruel farming practices are greener in terms of emissions, it got me thinking. It's not actually eating the meat that's causing emissions, it's that the animals are allowed to live in the first place. So a vegan diet doesn't directly reduce emissions, rather it allows for livestock to go extinct or at least greatly reduce in numbers depending on how well they do in the wild. If they do too well it might even be necessary to cull what remains to make the benefit significant. I wonder how much feral hogs emit, or how livestock compare to wild animals in general, and whether or not vegans who are vegan for the environment should support hunting. This leads me to think about moral questions I didn't expect to think about, such as at what point it becomes ethical to cause a species to go extinct, and whether or not being selectively bred to be livestock should be a factor or if it's purely a matter of cutting emissions due to long term consequences.

As a contrasting example, the CFC global movement in the 70s was a good, successful story on how humans collectively act for a good cause. It was so effective at stopping humans using the old fridges and aerosols that the ozone layer started to recover recently and will fully rejuvenate in the next few decades.   Why was it so effective? Because it was personal. Scientists pointed out the detriment of exponentially increased skin cancer rates in the southern atmosphere if the ozone layer continued to deplete. What I don't understand is what they actually expect? It's not like stopping the consumption of cows would make their methane production stop, especially not with the lack of natural predators, so what, are we just going to kill all the cows and waste their resources? Cows aren't just beef, they produce milk too, and quite frankly, a human with a vegan based diet produces as much if not more methane than a cow. I would also like to add that animals and plants are also a two-way street, you may need plants to raise animals, but you also need animals for long term healthy farming. Plants don't grow without fertilization, and soil doesn't stay nutritious without animals rotting back into it, and farm land is also a lot less trees to produce us oxygene.
The alternative is to drastically reduce the numbers of cattle & not replace them. (Bovinicide?)  There's also the economics factors of developing nations like Brazil & the fact that we feed 6 billion more people today than, at anytime in the Earth's history before 1900. Perhaps if modern cities had much higher levels of self sustainabilty & "eat local" incorporated into them, the economics would change enough to make a difference. Supply & demand, it's not just for breakfast anymore...

I have concerns about global averages,  because production methods are very different. In so-called developed nations, deforestation is not currently happening for either meat or animal agriculture. It isn't that it didn't happen, but it is not part of the current life cycle analysis, yielding very different impacts from countries which are currently converting rainforest to food production. If you can find lifecycle analyses relevant to food production in your state, I advise looking into those.

From National Geographic:  тАЬScientists have measured big increases in the amount of methane, the powerful global warming gas, entering the atmosphere over the last decade. Cows or wetlands have been fingered as possible sources, but new research points to methane emissions from fossil fuel productionтАФmainly from shale gas operations in the United States and CanadaтАФas the culprit.тАЭ

You can simplify this when you think about it this way, the more "energy steps" between you and the food you eat, the more energy gets wasted from the initial "energy packaging". Plant makes proteins/carbohydrates, then the animal has to eat it, then you eat the animal, and so on. Every step produces waste before the energy gets to the next step. So yeah a plant based diet, as far as you can go with it, is always more energy efficient.  The real issue is overpopulation tho.

so mammuts also change climate by produce too much metan and co2? today animals is nothing compare to megafauna
It isn't meat that is bad for the environment. It's humans. We are too extreme.  We don't need to eat as much meat as we do. Industrial scale farming is damaging because there's too much of it going on. There is a level where it is sustainable, but it will never produce enough meat to satisfy some people's apparent need to eat it several times per day.  On the other end of the spectrum, we have people calling for the elimination of meat products (and therefore a heck of a lot of animals) entirely. Which would have disastrous consequences of its own. It is just as extreme as the excesses of the meat industry.  Like it or not, we have nutritional requirements, some of which obtaining as a vegan involves processes which scaled up would cause entirely new environmental catastrophes. Take omega 3 for example, vegans are told that this is present in walnuts, but what isn't being said is that the walnut has as much Omega 3 in it as a carrot has retinol. However, unlike the carotenoids in the carrot which we can readily make into retinol, we don't convert the compound in the walnuts (or any other vegetable sources of ALA or GLA) very well. Not enough to get the RDA. Algae are currently used to make vegan omega 3 supplements. But scale that up in order to provide omega 3 to all of humanity, and how much of our water will we be giving up?   Because of the misconceptions about proteins (eg, that you can't get enough protein from a vegan diet, which you *can* it is just a bit more complicated) a lot of vegans went hell for leather on quinoa, which has had negative effects on the food security of some South American nations.  The intentions are good, but the applications were not considered.  Sure, we could cut carbon emissions by doing away with all livestock, but we would also cut the nutritional benefits of our food and then that would be the thing threatening our survival.  We need to veer away from extremes, because all they will do is kill us all.
Theres no difference if methane gets in atmosphere from cows or dissolving grass.

While the emphasis is cherrypicked for climate change a lot of information on raising cattle was missed.  For example by having ruminants graze naturally, a grassland that is poor will eventually be restored over a short span of time, say 20 years. This means absolutely no grain finishing as this removes the cattle from the pasture. This naturral process sequesters carbon and allows the bacteria in the soil to flourish as one isn't spraying insecticides on the crops.  As for cattle consumption, people are going to have to get past not eating what is known as offal, that is, kidneys, livers, stomach, heart, intestines, brains tongue, etc. over half of the animal is essentially waste from a human consumption perspective. Eating cattle that is grass finished, means the whole damn thing has to go to market.  Consumption of offal would all by itself reduce the numbers of cattle needing to be raised and slaughtered by about half. It used to be that was what happened but first world humans like the skeletal meat far more than organ meat, but it should be sold and consumed. It just has to be cooked right to taste more palatable.

Fun fact: When covid 19 started, lots of vegans went quiet. It has been found that Covid 19 drains your vitamin b12 in your brain. Vegans happen too have an extremely low vitame b12 diet since most of it comes from animal product. Why is that? Because only a few animals can produce vitamin B12 from being exposed to sun light. Cows are great at making vitamin b12. Humans can produce some but not enough for survival espicially since we spend most our time inside buildings away from the sun. Plants do not produce vitamin b12. You can get vitamin b12 from meat but its not the only way because milk and cheese also has lots of it.  Some people argue that they are vegans and are getting their vitamin b12 from energy drinks, if you are one of those then i have bad news for you: You are not a vegan because the vitamin b12 from those drinks comes from animal proeucts.  So what happened to those true vegans that went quiet? Well they died. Because when you dont have enough vitamin b12 in your brain, your brain stops working. Plants do not have brain organ so they do not need vitamin b12.

Until I start seing a more "official" world movement on this. (Meaning, that countries starts to implement laws for it...) I will lean on the side scepticism. And assume we won't get anywhere with it in practise. The moderate efforts individuals put in to change their diet/life style, is unlikely to make much of a difference I think. I already have very low energy, so I would rather not spend the rest of that on my diet! As soon as the world makes it more approachable, I'll be there and ready to sign up.
To piggy back on the "buying local isnt always better" thing, some crops are grown far more effently in some areas over others, so once you account for transportation its still just better to grow it in the "easier" place. An example would be growing citrus in CA year round outdoors and shipping it across the country, vs growing it indoors in a colder, maybe less sunny or hospitable part of the US, although potentilly closer to more customers.
Another thing I always like to point out is that if there are people wanting to become vegetarian/vegan but have a hard time giving up meat, you don't have to do it all at once. A reduced meat/dairy diet is a really good way to start that!
Don't get rid of meat, just go with chicken or fish, continue to eat vegetables, soy, and beans. We can lower our carbon footprint.   Chicken also takes less resources to raise.
Caution should be taken when interpreting these statistics.  The paper it is based upon is global sources, and aggregates data from countries where agricultural practices are extremely inefficient.  In the US, these efficiencies are continually improving and produce a FRACTION (~20Kg CO2/Kg) of the CO2 emissions cited here (~70Kg CO2/Kg!).   The comparative nutrition argument breaks down very quickly when this factor is taken into account.  There is also much room to improve in the emissions arena, via regenerative farming practices and technological improvements.  We should aspire to the ideal when making conclusions and not be resigned to the current predicament in which we find ourselves.  Cheers

Would be great if you did a video on regenerative farming and how the use of livestock (like cattle) actually can help climate change because it mimics the natural grazing pattern of animals. Regenerative agriculture results in an increase in soil carbon deposits, water retention, plant and insect biodiversity, and improved pasture conditions. Not to mention it cuts down on greenhouse gas emissions, water pollution and creates nutrient-dense crops.

It's really interesting to see what hot topic veganism is and what advice they are giving after different videos. When it's a video about Covid, at the end of the video, there often is the advice that we have to get vaccinated, we have to wear masks, we have to social distance, ... if we want this pandemic to end. When it's a video about climate change in general, at the end of the video, there often is the advice that we have to drastically cut our greenhouse gas emissions if we want to stop global warming. It's different though when they talk about meat when they scientifically explain how it's really bad for the climate, how there are much better options, and how claims like "we're using the Earth's surface in an efficient way" are just marketing tricks. In that case, at the end of the video, they tell you it's up to you to decide what to do with this information. They just gave you all the information which only lead to a few very similar solutions, but they won't dare to talk about them.  I'm not really blaming science communicators for this. In the end, if they would only be "half rational" (saying the right thing without thinking about what it will actually cause), a lot of people would stop listening to them. Very likely those who they are trying to reach. What it says about the people who are making these videos, is that they are not just science journalists but science communicators who know how to communicate. But it especially says a lot about this society, where a lot of people stop listening to you if you say something which they don't like, even though it's still true. Living in your own reality is just too comfortable. But I really think they are being a bit too careful. Yes, perhaps the message at the end of the video shouldn't be "You're a really bad person if you're still eating meat", but it could at least be something like "Going vegan or at least vegetarian might really be a good idea. And if you only eat meat like once a month, you could still do better, but you already did a lot."

8:44 What you're saying is not wrong. Only 19% of global soy production is consumed by humans. But you're leaving out an interesting detail. Only around 2% will become stuff like tofu and alternatives for animal products. The stuff which is always accused of being the cause of deforestation of the Amazon. The rest becomes oil. Oil, you can use to fry tofu or meat. Also, and I can only talk for Europe here, virtually all tofu, soymilk, and other soy stuff for vegans and vegetarians is made with soy that comes from Europe.
I became vegetarian in late 2020. My reasons are in part environmental, but primarily because of the pandemic- the factory farming of animals increase the risk of new pandemics, and I donтАЩt want another one in my lifetime. Videos like this are so, so important to cut through the overzealous ideologies on both sides of the debate. ItтАЩs important for vegetarians and vegans to recognise that if everyone stopped eating meat, we would still fail to meet co2e targets. Meat-eating environmentalists have to accept that they are  doing the single most impactful thing that is in their control. For everyone else, I hope that we can continue to engage sensibly on this, and only come to the table to discuss it if you are sincerely open to listening to (high quality) information on the subject and be ready to consider how that information challenges our current views

"You can decide for yourself what you want to do with this information." This is why I respect this channel. In the end the biggest difference can be made through education. People need to buy in to a choice to turn things around. And no matter how much you may disagree with dissenting voices or how much the research contradicts them, they are a necessity. Some ideas that were radical and shunned in the past have proved to be important. For as much ignorance, conspiracy theories and blatant political propaganda there is out there, having a world in which that can exist is more important than one where we weed it all out under the pretense of knowing the absolute truth. This channel informs and then invites you to research and form your own opinion, it doesn't tell you what you ought to believe. To truly believe something, you have to arrive at it yourself to some extent. Good work.

There is a way, but it involves dismantling the capital giant that the agricultural industry has become. We would have to redesign our urban environment, our yards, and communities to accommodate self grown crops, and the raising of animals.  If you grow and eat most of your own food you are being extremely sustainable, more so than driving an electric vehicle(there is an article published on this somewhere). The biggest milestone we have is how this will effect the economy, since food production we have become reliant on grocery stores, petroleum to get to them, and taxation for the production of it all.  Go do some research on how the price increases from wholesale (farmer) to shipping, storage, shipping and market. It is market up (obviously) to make it all profitable.   We need to be independent for our nutritional needs. Reintroduce permaculture and promote self sufficiency at the expense of comfort. Comfort is killing us.

I think the only thing not discussed here was that nutrition isn't calories or just protein, its the nutriends, vitamins and minerals. So for grass fed beef you get a much healthier food as well. A lot of these plant based meat alternatives use ingredients that are known to cause inflammation or hormonal issues. Also, those better treated animals also produce less methane than the factory formed animals.   If you treat animals better you get less methane and more nutritious food which is the opposite narrative than this video which focuses on the use of land. In the end this should have been more neutral between the systems. There is also research in adding things like seaweed to factory farming to reduce methane as well. And of course there is cultured meat.   What I'm most concerned with here is that a lot of the meat alternatives aren't all that healthy and its harder to get the nutrients needed for a healthy life from just plants. We need protein and fat to live, we don't need carbs and plants are heavy to one side of the equation.

This is one of the most complicated problems facing humanity today. On the one hand, change is absolutely necessary. On the other hand, the obvious change, is to ask most humans to change the culture they have been part of for hundreds of years.  Eliminating meat from the human diet is an impossible task. Most likely the better solution would be encourage less meat, which will already help. Other than that, improving farming techniques and lab-grown meat are promising options.

While I totally agree with the information brought forth in this video (and strongly believe in it- as demonstrated by my long-standing commitment to vegetarianism) I feel it also prevalent to bring up the following: there is no such thing as "land that cannot be converted to farm land" and fertilizer emissions are not "non-removable." I'm a scientist, and I've done field research in both sustainable farming and theoretical research in extraplanetary colonization- there are plenty of ways to remove fertilizers, replacing them with symbiotic soil fungi and intelligently crafted ecosystems that efficiently cycle "inaccessible" nutrients back into useable forms, even in completely barren environments and slightly rocky hills on earth are even easier to convert to farm land- when using the appropriate crops and potentially engineering that is. All three arguments are wrong. 1 meat is actually better for you than plants of any kind. There is nothing in a plant that is of any superior nutritional value to meat and usually of much inferior value and often toxic to the point of being deadly. 2 meat requires a fraction of the land manipulation and resources of crops and produces a tiny fraction of the greenhouse gas emissions plant farming does. 3 animal farming is often done on land not suitable for plant farming. Plant farming is often complimented by animal farming and would suffer without it.  Note. Plants actually pollute more over their life cycle than meat and the emissions estimates for meat are extremely exaggerated. Only intensive factory farming raises the emissions of meat and thatтАЩs due to all the grain and soy theyтАЩre force feed. When doing the plant estimates theyтАЩre probably not including all the fertiliser pesticides land manipulation and transport.
Meat requires the intentional killing of sentient beings. Plants don't.

Just eat the bugs maaaaaaaaaaaannnnn
I really understand the idea "vegans are better for the climate change thing". Okay, overall it actually is... but that's not necessarily real if you think about biodiversity conservation, especially for grassland ecosystems... **First of all, I emphasize on this, it is abhorrent the conversion of rainforests to make way for livestock production (especially thinking that we have our own natural grassland)... And yes, it is necessary to reduce meat consumption. But aside from that, it's especially frustrating to see some grassland ecosystems in southern Brazil (which I grew up close to) now being close to extinction due to the modern economic shift from livestock management to monoculture, be it soy, corn, Pinus or Eucalyptus. Until our recent history it was possible to see these ecosystems in different degrees of conservation, varying in terms of the type of management used. In areas well managed with livestock, they have a high species richness, little compaction and even high soil carbon content, sometimes being an important factor for the perpetuation of these communities. Today, many areas simply no longer exist thanks to poor agriculture (which leads to the conversion of habitats and the loss of carbon stocks fixed in the soil to the atmosphere is taking place here as well).  These ecosystems were usually neglected and maybe in this video it was too. I know it's due to reasons such as the lack of time to exhaust the debate, so that's why I wanted to bring this discussion up.

Alright, IтАЩm not sure how well informed the people who made this channel are. Yes, there will always be a small amount of emissions even if we were to switch all energy to renewables and electricity based transportation. However, it isnтАЩt about a quarter of emissions that come from agriculture, itтАЩs the majority, about 51% or so. Even if you combined the emissions from all forms of travel, it still wouldnтАЩt be close with the emissions coming from agriculture. And most of that is from cattle raising. 1. Cutting down trees and wild plant species to make room for cattle and other things means less carbon sequestration in the area. 2. That empty space is typically used for cattle rearing and not much else. WeтАЩre talking thousands or even millions of cows in a cramped area, not allowing anything to grow. 2. Cows fart. A lot. The methane coming from growing rice comes nowhere near the amount coming from cows. And methane is a much more potent greenhouse gas than carbon dioxide. 3. Most of the agriculture used in the US is to grow food for cattle, not humans. And there are billions of more cows being raised around the world than there are humans currently. 4. All those cows in a single area not allowing anything to grow kills the soil. All the microbes and bacteria that help keep the soil healthy die from being exposed to UV rays. TheyтАЩre also killed by pesticides on farms that grow plants. Less microbes means poor soil, and poor soil means less carbon sequestration from plants because there arenтАЩt as many, and since there arenтАЩt as many plants as before, humans need to come in with tons of fertilizer to get enough yield from the farm. On top of that, farmers typically use way too much fertilizer and a lot of it isnтАЩt even used on the farm. It flows into rivers when it rains and then into oceans. That fertilizer causes a major increase in algae. DoesnтАЩt sound too bad. I mean, plants (especially algae) take in carbon dioxide and leave oxygen. Well plants also breathe oxygen and release carbon dioxide. Just on a much smaller scale. Photosynthesis can only happen during the day, so at night all that algae sucks up the oxygen in the water until it runs out. Everything in that area dies, including the algae, and youтАЩre left with a dead zone. No fish, no plants, nothing. Which releases what? A ton of carbon dioxide when all that stuff rots.  Ploughing, pesticides, fertilizer, all the components of modern agriculture simply do much more harm than good. Making land and parts of the sea completely unusable, as we saw with the infamous Dust Bowl incident. But there is a way to fix it, and create better yields in the process. Copying nature.  Increase biodiversity by planting dozens of different species in the same area. Shade trees, fruit trees, perennials, etc. instead of monocultures. Allow grazing over a large area, so that the herds of animals continue to move and more importantly, give the vegetation time to regrow before being grazed again.  We already have the answers. But hardly anyone is talking about them. And even fewer are putting it into action. But those who have, are already having much more success than those who sit around with there thumbs up there asses.

I donтАЩt agree with the Shipping VS Sourcing Locally section of the video. Sure transporting goods on a container ship is very efficient but the ship arrives at a dock in Europe and then all the containers are loaded onto trucks that then drive on roads to warehouses and then supermarkets. Not to mention the transport to get the goods to the ship in the sauce country.  Where as locally sourced food is just from suppliers to warehouses to supermarkets.
The takeaway I get from this is this: CO2 is an inevitable cost of feeding humans. Regardless of how much or little meat we consume, it will always be there. The more people we have, the more people we need to feed. Even if the world becomes exclusively vegan, we will always reach a point of no return, where the cost of feeding those people causes too much environmental damage to be long term sustainable.  The issue isn't the food, is the people. There are too many people demanding to be fed, and a planet only capable of sustaining so many. In any other ecosystem, when a species grows past its capacity to feed itself, it begins to die off until it reaches a reasonable level again, which sometimes may include extinction.
I can't help but wonder, what happens with CO2 and other emissions that come from production of supplements we would need to use if we just stopped eating meat? That should not be taken out of the discussion.

one thing that I think people should know [that this video didn't mention],  pasteurized meat production (cattle that eat grass from grassland) actually give a NEGATIVE yield of co2 emission (search on google on this study paper), because "every grass that is eaten by the cattle induce stress in the cell of the grass plant and makes them grows faster by absorbing more CO2 in the air and soil that the animal release".  somehow this is become a forgotten symbiosis-mutualism biology we all learn from school and has never been considered in the table to calculate these emission problems.   if you ask me how much CO2 does a natural honey farm yields? without doubt or any research, I will say negative too. this is just how nature has balance stuff for millions of years now. it is just the way of us, as humans, always wanting to find a way to create products/foods as cheaper and as faster as we can that cause CO2 heavy emission because we cheat with nature for our short benefits.    and also I don't think plant based meat products must be supported, all plant base alternative meat right now is used heavily on the soy-based plant, or worst, using palm oil, which both have very unstable unsaturated fat that goes rancid so fast that they need to use a preservative or some GMO to make it last longer and protected while in storage.  I've done this research for like 8 years when I was so interested to be a doctor and scientist in human nutrition. and I believe this trend [of swapping anything from "real nutrient-dense food" to "alternative modified plant food"] is just another "big guy business" strategies happen so many time just like decades ago. let's remember how Butter (milk fat) was damned so bad for humans that Margarine (plant soy-palm oil-modified fat) sell gone rocket. or maybe we can say the same with the weed vs tobacco battle in the 80-90s. and so on.

Cattle can eat parts of the crops that are not edible to humans.  Also, it's worth noting, that even though according to your data more than 50% of human-edible crops are fed to animals, huge amount of >human< food is discarded and not consumed. And that happens predominantly with plant-based foods, not animal-based.  Despite all the claims of how animal fat/protein are dangerous and carcinogenic, there is little evidence to support it. Animal products can be very healthy to consume when not combined with highly insulinogenic carbs. Vegan food can be highly processed and it's completely industrialized, at this point it's a fad, and a lot of people who follow vegan diet have little regard to actual healthy nutrition.   It's possible human health would massively decline if vegan became a more predominant diet. We have a gut close to that of carnivores, more capable of digesting nutrient dense food such as meat.  It's also worth mentioning that there is evidence to show the contrary as well, that lands are turning into wastelands from massive GMO usage and overusing them without regards to their restoration. There's no real proof that picking a veggie burger over a meat-based one is ultimately best for the environment.  I would like to state that the idea that "vegan/vegetarian spreading more widely as a diet would help with the environment (or our health)", has about as strong evidence as the claim that "fat shaming helps fat people lose weight because it motivates them to eat less".

It's too simplistic to demonize beef like this. Grasslands that get no input at all have cattle graze on them, it's a biogenic cycle. The methane is only produced by the cellulose in the grass which has grown from absorbing co2 from the atmosphere. It's a 10 year cycle - there are no inputs, its sustainable beef reared on redundant land. Grass is a perennial, it absorbs co2 all year. I'm a farmer is as loose as I own a boat. Is it a rowing boat? a speedboat, mega yacht etc, boat isn't enough. neither is lumping together farmers. Cattle in brazil, cattle on huge cattle lots in US, barley beef systems are not the same as grass fed beef on a  10 year cycle. 30% of methane is from cattle, 20% is from rice but paddy fields don't make good clickbait headlines so we simply ignore this.  Co2 from burning fossil fuels is not comparable to beef production that doesn't burn fuel, grass reared cattle. The only contributors is transporting the cattle, buy local from the farm supplier  and it's as neutral as you can get on co2. Cow its grass, breaks down cellulose & starch IN the grass, burps out methane, methane goes up into atmosphere, breaks down as co2 and water, grass absorbs the co2 and water and releases oxygen back into the atmosphere via photosynthesis. A natural cycle that is ignored when looking at the ways farmers are farming and instead demonized by some of the terrible global practices and  short term views creating scary headlines

Truth to be told, the climate problems is ultimately driven by one human desire, 'pursue of satisfaction'. No one have a right to deny any human being to improve their life in all aspects of life. Like this video examples, meat is the highest satisfaction regarding of food taste. The poor people who wanted to improve their life would like to increase meat consumption. It is the same in ease of transportation, better housing, better tools, better education etc. All we need is better planning and more option to get the satisfaction we need. For examples, the Dutch and Japanese have more viable option to transport anywhere in ease such as in bicycle and fast train rather than only gas-driven automobiles. And most of them rather choose the alternative one than car if both option have equivalent result. It's the same for food, there is a need for better option of food to rivaled the meat than we currently have. To told people to switch to less 'satisfactory' option are not accepted of course, only if the option food is equally rivaled the meat taste, or better. But all in all, we must PLAN BETTER. If we fail to plan, we plan to fail. The infrastructures need to be planned ahead, so any problems can be cope ahead. The economy must be planned more diversely, so no 'all egg in one basket' situation became a high-risk problem. We need to do more NEW things to have MORE option, so R&D needed more funding. Essentially, more unique option provided more flexibility for us humans to survive the future ahead.

Overall love the video as always, but there is a glaring issue in comparing the emissions of shipping 1kg of avocados internationally vs 1kg of beef locally.  Those avocados don't magically warp to the grocery store from the dock. Even though mass freight shipping may have a lower impact for distance traveled they still have to go through additional distribution hubs and arrive to the local store by truck just like the beef. From the prospective of someone living in a landlocked state in the middle of the US this will also add the additional emissions from the shipping from the coastal port. So the avocados would come in at 2.5kg of CO2 for international shipping + 18kg of CO2 for the "last few miles" + the shipping from the coast to a local distribution hub. So any international food shipments should be more like 20.5kg of CO2 + the additional CO2 getting them from the port to your town.  I didn't miss that one of the main points there was packaging and transport is only about 11% if the overall emissions. But that did feel kind of intentionally misleading about transport emissions created for local vs. imported food.

Humans thrive on eating meat - beef, especially organ meats, are some of the most nutrient-dense foods on the planet. So in terms of nutrient density, the CO2 argument is a little disingenuous. It's not only about calories, nutrients matter too. Regenerative grazing can actually absorb and capture CO2. Cows aren't the problem, mass industrial farming is. I'll stick to beef burger patties over highly processed low-quality pea protein patties.  Western countries don't have a calorie problem, they have a nutrient density problem.

9:08  Provided that we completely remove meat from our diet, how do we satisfy the immediate deficiency caused by the lack of an energy and nutrient dense food category? @Kurzgesagt тАУ In a Nutshell    I'm just going to go through the some of the statements you've made and clarify them or just disagree with them.   First, methane emissions in rice.  As I understand it any soil that is water logged long enough will eventually turn anaerobic and start to emit methane instead of co2.  So, this can become an issue with any system that has insufficient water use intensity.  Those tend to not to be grasslands or savannas because they are very good at handling varying amounts of soil saturation.  This topic is worth a semester in school all by itself and is far more involved than what you are showing. You also briefly mentioned nitrous oxide.  In most of the US, the nitrous oxide and the pollution of waters with nitrates and phosphates is due corn, soy, poultry, and swine sectors.  And no, the corn and soy industry is not the same as the beef and lamb industry.  Also, waters that are heavily polluted will also emit nitrous oxide and methane. As far as the emissions in agriculture, those numbers are flawed as hell.  The flaw can be seen in this example.  Let's look at an acre grassland with 6% SOM and grew 5 tons of forage and has 1 cow.  Let's assume the cow eats all that forage in one year and emits it as co2 and methane and stores some of it as mass.  If the next year the SOM is still 6% and it still grows 5 tons of forage, then net increase in heating affect due to that system is 0 because the amount of carbon in it on average has not changed.  All the LCA's I have seen make the assumption that these emissions exist without first being sequestered.  In fact, a scientist that sits on the IPCC recently called analysis that takes the sequestration side of the equation into account as "paradigm shifting."  To be clear it is not "paradigm shifting," it's a complete analysis.  The methane side of that can be addressed later.  So, any real gains in atmospheric carbon are going to be almost entirely due to the expenditure of fossil fuels in the system or ecological deterioration.  You also made the assumption that it is the meat industry that is causing the deforestation.  If you were to actually look into this, you would see an acceleration in the rate of deforestation and rangeland loss around 2008.  This is a notable time as it coincides with a rise in the price of corn and soybeans largely due to consumption from biofuels.  That is still occurring today.  If you look at satellite photos of the amazon you will see pasture pushing into the rainforest, but if you look closer you will see farmers right behind them pushing forward.  They are being driven out by government backed economics, same as in the US. The argument for efficiency in factory farming is somewhat limited as you completely glossed over the inefficiency of their externalities which are never truly taken into account in any LCA.  Also, it still does not address any fossil fuel use, or the role ecology plays in agricultural systems.   Your breakdown of crop uses is not wrong, but it is pathetically naive and idealistic.  And the same goes for your argument about setting land aside for nature.  Here are a set of questions for you to think about that might help you understand why your view is naive at best. 1)  Will a piece of farmland feed more people with or without cows? Hint: The answer is with. 2)  How does a natural grassland differ in emissions from a grassland with cows? 3)  How do methane emissions from wild animals in these systems differ from methane emissions from cows?

Kurzgesagt: "Your diet does not give you an ethical high ground." Also Kurzgesagt: "Your burger is killing Brazil and also the environment."
Ok... stop counting methane emissions as a greenhouse gas more potent than carbon dioxide. Methane is thermodynamically unstable in the presence of oxygen. And unlike glucose which can sit with oxygen just fine as long as you don't burn it, methane will _oxidize_ under sunlight. Astronomers look for methane and oxygen in the same planet as a possible sign of life because there needs to be a methane source (which doesn't have to be biological, but on Earth it often is) to sustain it in the presence of oxygen. Meteorites produce a tiny amount, but these are very tiny amounts that would be make methane at levels near impossible to detect even a few light years away, unless a giant meteor hit and created lots of methane, which would be mostly degraded within a millennium if it was a particularly large one.
Artificial plant meat that tastes like beef  If they do that this would be solved it just needs to be a little more known
An important factor that often doesn't get mentioned in this conversation: Economic bracket. Part of the reason why a lot of people don't switch to a vegetarian or vegan diet is, quite frankly, because it's simply too expensive. Because of lower nutrient density (and the need for frequently expensive supplements to replace nutrients ususally derived from meat), it's often more economically efficient to buy one burger patty that keeps you nourished all day, than a large pile of high-qualify vegetables that don't. Not to mention, besides the inefficiency inherent to buying a lot of expensive, low-nutrient plant-based foods, they tend to spoil extremely quickly, and not much money has been invested in developing (affordable) tech for preserving greens or other plant-based foods for longer periods of time. At the end of the day, whether we like it or not, humans are omnivorous, and we do require certain nutrients to survive. It is entirely tenable to eat a vegetarian or vegan diet with enough expensive dietary supplements and vitamins, and enough budget to buy the sheer quantity of fodder on a regular basis, but most people simply don't have that economic privilege. People don't just buy beef because they like it, they buy beef because they often don't know where their next meal is coming from, and they want to make their dollars stretch as far as possible while they have them. Speaking as someone who grew up at the bottom of the economic barrel, to whom hunger (and even sometimes a lack of consistent access to drinking water) was a daily part of childhood, the days we could afford to eat meat were the days when I could think clearly, and the days when I didn't go to bed so hungry I couldn't sleep. Telling poor people they need to save the planet by buying a whole lot of nutrient-light food they can't feasibly afford or store is always going to fall on deaf ears. If you want to fix the food emissions crisis, you have to fix the economic crisis first.

The majority of CO2 assesments for live stock don't take in consideration the many byproducts an animal has, which are currently essential components for a number of industries.  For instance blood (food, fertiliser, dyes, inks, laboratory equipment), the hide (leather, gelatin, adhesives), hoofs and bones (adhesives, fertiliser, pet food, plywood, glass, charcoal), hair (brushes, felt, textiles), manure (fertiliser, fuel), internal organs (medical gauze and materials, enzymes, hormones, instrument strings, vitamin tablets), and fat (cosmetic lotions, candles, detergents, fabric softeners, insulation, medicines, antifreeze, crayons, paint, deodorant).  I don't want this to sound like the above is a defence, like the video stated "it's complicated" and makes it very hard to ascertain the true carbon impact of a "steak" as it's linked/shared with so many other products.   We should all afterall strive to eat less carbon rich food, and reduce our environmental impact as much as practicable.

The planet Terra is part of the Via Lactea. Terra orbits around the Sun, and the Solar activity is the main  driver of climate on Terra. All other planets in the solar system also seem to have some influence on climate on Terra. Why do humans think they can control solar activity? All we can do is find ways of producing food that are less polluting and harmful for other species, and capable to subsist climate changes. Are humans, the dominant species on this planet, willing to change to the primitive ways of life?  Hunter-gatherers' comunities were more sustainable, more "in tune" with the planet's resources, but their life was not so "comfortable". We are omnivorous, we get all nutrients our body needs from several sources. Our digestive systems are not adapted for strict herbivorous diets, in fact there is a lot of nutrients in plants we are unable to process. There are several studies showing children with strict vegetarian diets have nutrients' deficiencies, and in consequence, vision and immunological problems. What kind of life quality do we want for next generations?

a question about pollution cased by overseas transportation vs land transportation: according to the video, land transportation causes way more pollution compared to overseas. the thing is, that as far as I understand, the usage of overseas transportation of food only adds more steps and overall use of pollutant land transportation to complete the process of transporting the food (getting the food to the ships, loading it, unloading it, spreading it to the destinations...).  so, correct me if I'm wrong, as I understand, the reason that buying food that was transported overseas is more efficient is that it makes food that the process of producing it was the most ecologically efficient, accessible to more regions, and the ecological efficiency of the production transcends the inefficiency of land transportation?

A lot of things were not adressed here. First and foremost, animal meats are much much healthier for humans and most vegans cannot live healthy lives, even with supplements. Secondly, animal meats are about 5 times as nutrient dense as common carbohydrate foods such as rice and corn, and while it takes some 230L of water to produce a kilo of beef, it takes 90L of water to produce a kilo of rice. HOWEVER, since the nutricional value of rice is 5 times lower, you have to multiply by five to reach the same nutrient value as beef. Meaning that it actually takes 450L of water to produce rice which provides the same equivalent nutrition as a kg of beef. And while talking about water, beef and other sources of animal meats gets about 90+% of their water from greenwater (rain) while crops use 99% freshwater sources that humans need, making crops by far the biggest offender of water wastage. And, speaking of wastage, around 80% of all food waste in the world is fruits and vegetables, which produces far greater emissions of methane in landfills around the world. Also, when it comes to feed, most additional feed which is given to livestock comes from the inedible parts of plants we produce for humans. Of course, we are not giving the actuall corn to livestock, rather we give the cornhusks and such- meaning that these product come to use instead of, you guessed it, rotting in a landfill. And what about cow farts, are they really producing methane? No. They are upcyling it, it goes from the atmosphere, into grass, cow eats grass and release the methane, so its a circle but they arent producing any more methane. And this issue with releasing methane is combated by producing beef more and more efficiently, as we are already on the way to do. Its also calculated that the emissions from previously untouched wildlife herbivores were greater than todays level from livestock, meaning that even if we did replace the livestock with normal nature, we would have the same issue again.. and its really not an accurate image presented here regarding airable land, most land is not fit for crops, and so its a question of either having ruminace there or nothing at all, meaning we almost never choose between producing livestock or crops on a given location. Also, livestock provides 50% of all fertelizers in the world, and is the only organic source, so if we remove lifestock, we also remove organically grown crops, and have to increase our production of artificial fertalizers dramatically (which means more emissions). I want to end by bringing it back to my main point, human health. The nutrients found in animal product are almost impossible to replace, because most vitamins and minerals are only accessed by the body in certain forms, and many of which cannot be absorbed if coming through supplements or vegtables. Studies have also shown vegans to be 40% more suceptible to bone breakages also. There really isnt a lot going on for the vegan debate in my opinion, its detrimental to our health and the emissions discussion is not favouring it (livestock production keeps getting better and better as well) so yeah, eat more meat, be healty. I'll end on the note that the obesity issues in the whole world can be blamed on corn, fruits and vegetables, as the carbohydrats have infested every single product, making us fat and have killed us in the 10s or 100s of millions

IтАЩm curious about what the Kurzgesagt team might think of animal based biosequestration using techniques outlined in Alan SavoryтАЩs book тАЬHolistic ManagementтАЭ. We are currently in our first year starting a regenerative farm in Nova Scotia. We raise KuneKune, a special kind of pig that eats grass, along with goats, chickens, guineas and tomatoes. We agree more people should eat less or no meat, especially in westernized countries. Anyway, we hope to capture a sizable amount of carbon by increasing diversity and total biomass on our land. Mechanical sequestration has seen limited success (to be fair itтАЩs new technology) but we think farms like ours might be the ticket, or at least part of the puzzle. We would love to see a video on this subject. Keep up the great work!

I would love to see you do a video on different farming practices. A lot of food emissions issues can pretty directly be linked to modern farming vs small production, no-dig farming such as no-dig market gardens, front yard gardens, and permaculture. In these models, clearing of land isn't a part of the process because they encourage basically turning lawns into food sources. And they encourage farming to be self-sustaining process (re permaculture specifically) which cuts out emissions of typical modern farming upkeep like cultivation, fertilization and herbicide use, etc.  Re cow methane: adding kelp to their diets greatly reduces that emission source. Of course, other sustainable farming practices must be utilized on top of that, and over production must be greatly curbed - which is where changing our diets to very plant based comes in.

TLDR: Locally raised, rotationally grazed beef solves all of the issues presented in this video.   There are a couple flaws in the analysis: (1) The video discussed that the comparison of beef to plant foods needs to be based on more than weight, but they stoped at protein. What about amino acid profile, mineral content, essential fatty acid profile, etc? Their level of analysis here is too gross, not fine enough with regard to the subtleties of human nutrition. We, as humans, need more than just protein. (2) Grass-fed cattle needs to be differentiated into two categories: cattle stocked on land in the traditional fashion and rotationally grazed cattle. The latter allows for greater stocking densities on the same amount of land without external inputs. Though this method is not in wide use, it could be, and it offers additional nutritional and environmental benefits over the traditional method. Cattle raised in this manner mimic natural ruminant herds which facilitate the capture of carbon, the building of top soils, the reduction of run-off, and the building of biodiversity in the pasture. At the very least, an analysis should be performed between the most ideal cattle management systems and plant production systems with consideration towards a full nutritional profile, not just protein and environmental benefit, not just harm.   :

This is what I feel about Veganism, this debate, humanity as a whole, and these are my solutions.  I believe Veganism is a cult. Blindly worshiping animals & nature, prioritizing those over all else. It's not about diet, it's about saving animals & nature, even at the cost of humanity. Not just avoiding meat, and animal products like leather & gelatin.  To my knowledge, Veganism is realistically detrimental to the body, because of missing nutrients you can get from animals. And the raw-Vegan diet is even worse, because they don't even process or prepare those plants to make them more digestible, leading to them wasting away and dying faster.  And before any Vegan says, "There are supplements you can take,  there's algae that makes Vitamin B12" or whatever. Yeah, when poop hits the fan, harder than covid, Vegans will be in the same boat as Diabetics with insulin, needing to obtain some special, life or death thing, among the chaos.  Even if I can grow that algae, and whatever plant that provides nutrients easily obtained by eating animals. How do I obtain farmable versions or seeds of those plants, and how long will they take to grow?  I don't have my own home, let alone an offgrid home with a greenhouse and whatever the F is needed to grow algae.  Meanwhile, I can hunt, fish, and maybe grow some certain plants indoors.  I believe anyone who became a Vegan or Vegetarian for animal & nature reasons, are fools, because I realized, for humans to survive, let alone thrive and be happy, nature has to suffer, has to pay for it in some way.  Whether farming meat or plants, you're still taking that land from nature. Whether you live like the Amish, have an underground base, a houseboat, or underwater home, you are still taking that space from nature.  Whether it's engines or Electric Vehicles, we mess up the environment just finding, collecting, and refining the metals to make them. We're messing up the environment obtaining & burning fuels, messing up the environment obtaining, refining, and recycling battery, solar-panels, and wind-farm materials.  Do you all understand?  People just being alive, let alone comfortable, with modern conveniences & pleasures, all harms the environment.  We can try to reduce that harm, but it is a fools-errand to try to dramatically or completely reduce our effect on nature.  Maybe we can build cities & farms in more barren places, like deserts, the frozen poles, and floating cities, each in giant boxes, with air locks for doors, contained water, air, and waste treatment, these sealed off cities & farms, protecting the inhabitants from the conditions outside, and those same walls protecting nature from people.  But how many Fs will be given, to fund such cities & farms?  Also, Vegans & Vegetarians shouldn't feel so high & mighty not killing animals, because you are still killing plants. How do you know plants aren't sentient? How do you know they have no mouth but must scream?  Plants can't run, fight back, cry, or be "diplomatic". They defend themselves with chemical warfare.  We cook the crap out of them, to disable those toxins, and things like caffeine, meant to kill us like bugs, in low doses, we treat like stimulants, medicine, and seasoning. Poison go brrrrrr.  Think about it.  Other than salt, everything we eat, died for us to live. Blame nature or some deity, but be plant or animal, we must take lives, to sustain our own.  That is just the way it is.  The sooner you all accept this and everything else I said here, the better your lives will be. We can try to reduce our impact on nature, but, at the same time, not wreck ourselves to do so, or treat outer people so poorly for not being the lowest impact possible.  If they're not carelessly littering, or polluting a lake or river, leave them alone.  How "sinless" are you to judge anyone else? How much is your own life an impact on the environment?  Yes, I eat meat, I love motorcycles and motorsports, and battery tech. But I also do my best to mind my own business, treat others how I want to be treated, not litter, I recycle when convenient, especially if it's aluminum & glass, and I don't steal from, torment, violate, harm, kill, or war with innocent people, like the government does.

As a cattle producer and having been educated in proper grassland management I can confirm there is a load of misinformation in this video. With proper rotation of forage and grass you can gain almost a 90% grazing period per year. New Zealand has already done major studies to greatly reduce their emissions since sheep and cattle outnumber humans by an astronomical amount and have caused major issues with high urine concentrations.

Also the North Americas had many millions of ruminant animals on the land before they were over hunted. The 2.5kg only account for the ship, we are missing the 1970 truck from argentina that drives the animal to the butcher, another one that drives the meat to the ship and then a 3rd one that drives it to a storehouse where the 4th is coming in to distribute to the shops and finally we are driving our car to that shop to get it. local meat at least here in denmark means within 30km, thats not even close to 18kg. There is a very important point that I always bring up, and it's an ecological one. When energy goes up on the food chain, you loose 90% of it. So, when we use, let's say, 10 kg of cereal to feed a cow, we will only take the energy of 1 kg of it. That means feeding people with that cereal instead of using it to feed lifestock is way more efficient and is a better use of our resources when we think of lowering the land use, carbon emissions and shortening inequality, ideally.
You could show proof that people are putting fire in Amazonia for meat production. As far as I know, the climate and transport are terrible, with too many pests for cattle and terrible roads. My father's trucks already went there; the drivers wanted to know the place. The freight prices are terrible, the damage in trucks is too extensive, and many cattle would die in transport. Indigenous people act like pirates charging crazy fees even if the loading is good for them; I couldn't even imagine the price they would force you to pay if you had a cattle truck leaving there. This idea sounds like an exaggerated fantasy to me. It's way easier to believe that ONGs are putting fire to ease gold extraction as they did sometimes...
