The way I understand it is that the major driving factor of emissions is more on the growing global population. So if population decline emissions from meat and vegan diets would decline drastically?
No matter how deep their arguments about meats contributing to the carbon emission, the total carbon emission byproducts of conventional modern transportation from your private cars, motorcycles etc contribute nearly quadruple the amount (you can search the internet or do your own research). So, an average meat eater that walks more or uses public transportation still contributes less to the global carbon emission, than vegans that drives a lot. These examples aren't actually relevant, but food is a basic human need, and you really need those proteins, vitamin Ds, calciums, etc. You may argue some sources like soy, however these requires more amount to give the same amount of protein that livestocks (or animals in general) give. However, changing your lifestyles a bit can help to reduce carbon emissions rather than merely stop eating meat. Walking or using public transportations to reduce the carbon emission (if possible for reasonable distance), reducing the usage of air conditioners and other CFC products etc, using renewable energy sources instead of fossil fuels, and so much more. Veganism is a choice, if you don't want to eat meat, then I respect your preference. However if you force other people to be vegetarians too, we'll going to fight against you. However with all that said, please spread love

Morally, we should adopt a plant-based food system and move away from the continual exploitation of animals on land or in the sea.  There are also many ways to grow crops, away from the typical mono-culture styles of farming found in the west. Agri-forestry and similar styles of Hegel-Culture are available to grow co-growth plants which foster a great relationship of edible and non-edible food systems to humans, whilst providing a habitat for other creatures to be sustained within, and which promotes diversity in ecosystems. While the information used in the video is based in empirical and objective data, the presentation shows some personal biases on the author/producer's side. The most direct example would be the frame comparing one data on a 100 year scale (800 billion) to a single year scale (50 billion), that is a very common tactic used to misrepresent data while technically not being wrong. If memory serves me right, Kurzgesagt themselves (or another educational youtuber, I forget) made a video about how this kind of propaganda-esque techniques are used to mislead the audience. But I guess since the intentions here are noble, we should be okay with a little propaganda and misleading comparisons? /s

Don't forget that even just reducing meat intake can help a ton, you don't have to cut out meat completely.  Just make 1 meal (or 1 day) a week meat-free. It's a tiny change that will encourage you to try new recipes (and find new favorite meals!). You'll also get a better idea of how difficult it  would be for you to reduce meat intake even more or to go full v*gan. Some people will find it extremely hard - they'll miss the taste too much, or not find good recipes. But I just didnt buy' meat at the grocery store, then did it again. All the sudden it had been 3 weeks without meat and I barely cared. Ribs and bacon were the only things I missed. 2 years later and then bacon didn't even taste good anymore.   My #1 advice for people is to search for recipes that sound fun/good. There's so many new foods and meals to make that it can keep your meat-cravings busy for months.

The video makes it seem like they're comparing least-efficient transportation of meat vs. only the most efficient part of the transportation of plants? Meat is also put on container ships, and vegetables also have to go through "last-mile" delivery...  Also, no mention of the methane cycle (that methane goes up and down and stays constant, and has since before modern factory farming and matches the methane in circulation from natural herd sizes, and herd sizes are not increasing and have been pretty stable), and the video pretends that cattle and other agricultural animals are eating human-suitable food--they're actually primarily eating waste that is human-inedible (e.g., corn husks, plant talks, and food not considered attractive enough to bring to market).  Ignoring the fact that we have a huge food waste problem, that our systems of agriculture necessarily produce plant products that are inedible to us but edible to agricultural animals, and that these animals turn that byproduct into super nutrient-dense food is frankly disingenuous and disappointing.  Animal products are absolutely a key part of the path towards efficiently feeding the world. Our food-waste is a much more serious issue, and improving our food waste habits would go a huge way towards decreasing the inefficiency of cattle.

It's kind of deceptive to compare CO2/KG of protein between meat and potato's. If you eat 100g of meat in a day, this provides roughly 25g of protein. If you would want to get the same amount of protein eating potato's you would need to eat more than 1KG of potato's, which doesn't make any sense. Hence this is a stupid comparison. And this is essentially the whole point of meat; cows, from this perspective, are just a way to concentrate protein. The cow can easily eat multiple KGs of food a day, extract the nutrients, and store (part of) them. This helps us because it means that we do not have to eat 5KGs of vegetables a day to get enough protein.

I cycle or bus to work. I even cycle or bus to do most of my errands. I use reusable bags, my bike's saddle bags and/or my backpack for groceries. I use a reusable coffee mug and reusable water bottle. I keep chopsticks, a spoon and a fork in my backpack so I don't have use to use single use plastic utensils. I use reusable containers for lunches. I purchase most of my produce in season and as local as possible. I only purchase beer/wine/whiskey that is made within 100km of wherever I happen to be. I hunt a deer and a few turkeys/ducks per year to supplement my meat intake. I use warm water and vinegar as my main cleaning agent. Soooo... in other words, you can replace beef and cow milk with something like chicken and goat milk and still help the environment? Well, I wouldn't mind that then.
There's an issue with how those 26% emissions from food compare to much of the other 74% emissions. When you burn fossil fuels, you keep releasing new carbon content into the atmosphere from stores that were trapped deep underground. That slowly gets absorbed by the soil or sea, but that has its own issues, since it's adding CO2 to the overall surface system. When cows or rice release methane it's an entirely different process: CO2 is absorbed from the atmosphere by photosynthesis and its carbon is converted to CH4 by the cows' digestive system or the microorganisms in rice paddies or what have you. That CH4 remains in the atmosphere for some time and eventually becomes CO2 again. So food production is not adding any more greenhouse gasses _per year_, provided it remains constant. It does contribute to global warming by replacing a fraction of the CO2 with CH4, which is a more potent greenhouse gas, but that's at a steady state - that is, any new CH4 added per year replenishes the CH4 that naturally reverts to CO2 over the same period of time. Unless you burn down forests to increase your farmlands and pasture lands, the effect of that 26% is far milder than that of the fraction of the remaining 74% that relies on fossil fuels.
Why are there so many misleading graphics in this video?  For example, the graphic comparing international transport of plant products vs local transport of meat implies that it is much more environmentally friendly to transport plants overseas vs meat locally.   However, these plants STILL need to be transported locally once they reach the port.   Yes, the shipping overseas part is more efficient, but the graphic and narrative imply that the overall impact of shipping plants internationally is less than that of  beef shipped locally (which is obviously not true).   Similarly, the graphic about CO2 reduction by reusing land space indicates 800b tonnes of CO2 could be removed from the atmosphere (over 100 years).   This is then compared to our ANNUAL production of CO2 (50b tonnes), making it look like reclaiming this land alone would solve our CO2 problems, where it would actually take out 8b tonnes per year out of 50b.    i.e. when comparing numbers, always use the same units.  I believe I saw a couple of other misleading items, but I'll have to re-watch to double check.  The data seems right, but the way it's presented is quite misleading.   This is unfortunate to see in a Kurzgesagt video, as it is mistakes like this that meat proponents will grab onto and use to claim the whole argument is wrong.

As someone who has done some of the studies for lifecycle carbon footprints I can tell you that the values aren't accurate. We leave out certain factors that are hard to calculate such as wastage. Reliable and accurate data is hard to come by but there is an undeniable lead in plant waste. This raises plant carbon values compared to meat. Another is human digestive efficiency. 100g of animal protein in the mouth isn't the same as 100g of plant protein in the mouth. It also has an effect on human gaseous emissions. There is also the use of leather, wool and feathers plus manure and slurry as opposed to synthetic  alternatives which all have high fossil fuel dependence. We simply don't factor this in to the meat Value. We put it in a separate category and give it the same value even though even it's all from the same animals. We also don't consider the values of dairy even though, as this video points out around half of all beef is dairy cattle. We are in essence calculating the cost of a cake and only giving the benefit of one slice and then comparing it to the cost and benefit of a full cake.

Gave you a dislike because this is a propaganda video. It's propaganda because it constructs a narrative by asserting some facts that favor that narrative and withholding others that destroy that narrative. You close your propaganda with a really disgusting passive aggressive line "Even if you find the most environmentally friendly beef in the world, your burger still comes with a significantly higher carbon footprint than a veggie patty. You can decide for yourself what you want to do with this information." Aka, you can decide for yourself are you gonna still be eating meat and destroying the planet because it tastes good, or you're gonna become a responsible adult and throw that meat in the trash and start eating veggie patties. Well, I'm gonna be a responsible adult and throw that veggie patty in the trash and eat meat. Why? Well, because a 70 gram veggie patty holds 124 calories from 4.4  grams of fat, 10 grams of carbs and 11 grams of noncomplete plant protein. And that's shit food. Meat, patty of the same weight has 197 calories from 12 grams of fat, 0 carbs and 21 grams of complete protein. so, just to get the same amount of protein you need to eat 2 veggie patties, which holds 20% more calories, you're gonna have to chew through double the size of food and in the end, it's still not complete protein so you're gonna have nutrient deficiencies and lose muscle mass. So, It's not just the nutrient density that matters, it's the nutrient quality. Otherwise we could be living off of licking lard, since fat is the nutrient that holds more than twice the energy of the other two.

There's no question that we need to reduce meat consumption. But there are a few things, not necessarily about meat but climate change overall, that I want to point out: 1) Green house gas might be an easy parameter, but if we really want to mitigate/prevent climate crisis, the main focus should be on ecological destruction as a whole. Cos soil erosion (say due to plowing), water pollution, desertification, biodiversity destruction etc are rather more important. 2) What about food waste and the fact that plant based food are wasted many times more? 3) Why not work towards making vegetable based food more available? Why just talk about an existing food habit? For example - in our and many similar South-East Asian family, we consume roughly 250g meat/week (1 kg for 4 people, once a week). But that's mainly possible cos fish and a large amount of vegetables is part of our cuisine for centuries. 4) CH4 emitted by cows don't add any new carbon to the atmosphere, rather it's the same carbon that used to be CO2 a few years back, got converted to grass, leaf, etc and eaten by cows. CH4 farted by cows do cause net damage, cos it's more potent. Still, it's kinda misleading without considering this. Since this comment questions this video, and also quite long, it's very likely that YouTube will push it at the bottom, as a result. Still, if anyone is reading, plz give a thought.

I think the problem is still a little bit overblown... Yes absolutely, we shouldn't burn the rain forest to put cows in it, or for any reason really. And sure... beef as a single product emits more than others, but is kind of an unfair way of putting it, meat-based food is a lot less varied than plant based, not to mention is consumed in lower quantities overall. If you look at the bigger picture, livestock as a whole actually produces similars amounts of emissions to agriculture (5.8% and 5.4% respectively counting rice), and if we account for grassland and crop land, agriculture ends up emitting more than livestock.  Also kind of unfair to look at the methane produced by all the cows, instead of just counting the excess of cows, remember that there used to be 60 million bisons in the US, alongside a lot more raindeer and oher ruminants. Since methane production exists on a cycle, how do we compare to the natural existing numbers from millions of years. And the excess is the real number we have to worry about.  Yes I agree that reducing livestock would probably be more efficient, even if that increases emissions on agriculture overall, surely we can reduce some percentage, but since food is absolutely mandatory is hard to say hoy much, already there is less than a percent of difference between the two industries, meanwhile there is the gigantic 73% of emissions by the energy and transportation sector...  Of course less emissions in food in worth persuing, but it should be something like our fifth priority. And don't let anyone tell you that eating less or no meat is the best thing you can do for the environment, it is not.

This entire video is premised on conventional industrial agriculture practices, which are basically the entire problem. If you start from the premise that this is the only way agriculture can happen, then you could reach these conclusions - but you'd be an idiot.   The idea that ruminants grazing on grass is some hugely destructive human invention very conveniently ignores the fact that before cattle were introduced to North America, most of the continent was teeming with bison. There's many old stories of bison herds so vast they could continue for days, literally impossible to even estimate. Possibly even in the millions. When it was bison grazing the plains for countless millennia, that was all G. But if domestic cattle, with the same ruminant digestive system, should be grazed on those grasslands that used to be flooded with bison... well, that would be a catastrophic existential threat! Because "The ScienceтДв", I guess?  Regenerative farming has proven to be a net carbon sink, and significantly so. Turns out that growing crops & livestock the way plants & animals grow in nature is way better ecologically than relying on synthetic petrochemical fertilisers & other chemicals, and feeding animals a diet they're not designed to live on which causes all kinds of flow-on effects (like increased methane burps, for eg).   Isn't it crazy to think that when you replicate natural ecosystems, you don't end up throwing everything else out of whack? *Imagine that.*
IDK if anyone else has mentioned this, but the only thing that I can think of that is worth mentioning that this video didn't point out is the fact that 80% of the oxygen production on Earth comes from the ocean, and most of that is done by plankton.

Yo why the thumbnail change?
Numbers donтАЩt really make sense, and the studies you use have been heavily critiqued. Looking at each individual country you can see meat production produces a much smaller percentage of carbon emissions then advertised in this video. EG Japan says meat production accounts for 1% of their carbon emissions, the USA says only 4% this is the same trend with other major countries. You also use a lifetime metric for the meat, but not for the transportation which skews the viewpoint toward meat being a bigger producer of CO2 then the vehicles used throughout the entire cultivation process, which again is an inaccurate representation of the subject. Usually your videos are pretty good but this one seems to not be researched quite as well as others.

I'm calling BS on the claim that vegetable alternatives are better than straight beef. Why? Because they require orders of magnitude more industry than a cattle farm to produce the same amount of food. It's even admitted in your own data that land repurposed for beef farming is included into the "carbon emissions" of beef; somehow I doubt that same calculation is done for all the crap needed to keep your hormonally horrifying impossible burger production going. There's too many ways to twist the data, and too many lies being peddled by the various industries involved. The vegan diets also ignore all the vitamins and supplements that're necessary to live, which require their own industry to be factored in because you can't get those all from vegan sources in the required amounts. We also can't feed kids vegan diets, it causes them to be physically deformed and malnourished. In fact, this malnourishment causes them to be measurably shorter than meat-eating counterparts, by 6"-1.5ft. Humans are not designed to eat only sugars, starches and fibers. I guarantee you that if, *IF* anthrogenic climate change is real, we will do everything in our power to solve the issue before changing out dietary habits. And that's assuming we don't just double-down on them when we've got an extra 20% space for pastures and agriculture if the tundra recedes.
The answer is actually really simple, it's just that 75% of humanity would not be happy. Humans need meat to survive, we are omnivores. And being an omnivore doesn't mean you could just live off one or the other, it means you need both to survive and be healthy. Growing meat and farming responsibility, just eating less beef, pork or chicken should be what we're doing right now already. I love a good steak like any other, but the fact of the matter is the reality is cruel, and that you have to rob a life of a future to live another day. I don't support giant meat industries, companies like those trick common folk into thinking that we need to eat meat more than we need to, and gaslight you into feeling like meat animals are objects, and that it's alright to treat them as such. If people respected their food more, our climate literally wouldn't be as bad is it is now.    Also stop having so many kids. Too many humans. Simple as that too.  ' But 0rthrus! You can't tell people they can't have children! It's the right to life! '  Adopt, or have one kid.  If you think about it, humans are no different from bacteria. They devour everything they can and flourish, and when things run dry, they die off.  Unless a freak Asteroid obliterates the earth or some other disaster,  we will make ourselves extinct. At the very least genetically bottleneck us until we all look like club-footed goblins.  Thank you for coming to my TED talk, like and subscribe, and have a great day!

Another note about grass fed livestock that a lot of people forget: they compete with native wildlife. Cattle ranching is the primary barrier to reintroducing wolves, mountain lions, and other predators in the American West and other spots worldwide. The cattle also compete with grazing animals like deer, elk, and bison

I've reduced the amount of meat I eat, and what meat I do eat is wild. And the cost savings are pretty nice as well.

I simply love how ironic it is, every video or discussion about climate changes always come to Brazil at some point. The truth is nobody wants to understand jack about Brazil and most people even believe we speak Spanish here. Sure, we have most of the Amazon florest (60%), but it extends to 9 countries that gets the other 40%, with some having little to no political movement to protect it. As brazilian I'll give my most honest opinion: the strongest economic stimulus Brazil receives from the world is to farm your food. Want to really help Brazil to protect Amazon? Stop buying food from brazilian farms. It'll reduce the need for more space for farming and we'll start focusing in industry. Do you know Brazil sell a lot of minerals and buy the products simply because we have not enough industry to benefit those minerals into the subproducts? But no, we are not all forest here as some might believe out there. S├гo Paulo is the biggest economy center in South America, with solid industrial production and representing most of the country revenues. People should really try to know Brazil and stop treating us just as Amazon, that could start the needed revolution to change what most believe as needed to change.
You touched on a lot about animal agriculture, but have you seen how detrimental some crop production is? You should make a comparison video. A quick example is the avocado industry. In Peru they destroyed the natural habitat, take the natural water (which is extremely scarce in the regions) and reroute it to the avocado tree farms. Avocado trees use up more water than almost any crop, and now that they are so popular the local population has decided to destroy most of the native land by causing draught, killing all the natural surrounding predatory animals and then releasing non native grazers that destroy the last remaining native vegetation trying to withstand the avocado farm draughts. It seems disingenuous to take a stance that meat alone is the worst when there are countless crop examples that are just as bad to the health of the planet. I'm all for fixing the problems, Ima say it now, with the amount of hydroponic technology and research the future seems pretty good on more efficient hydroponic operation designs (like vertical farms). The only issue is we can only grow select cultivars with hydroponics as of now, mostly leafy greens, herbs and only a few fruits/veggies.  Also, veganism would never work I'm sorry to be the one to say it. Even "herbivores" eat animals from time to time to makes sure their nutrient requirements are met, and to have a sustainable amount of nutrients from crops alone would means most land we would theoretically free up from getting rid of animal farms would just have to be giant monocultures of crops for us to eat instead.

Honestly, you don't have to become a vegetarian (overnight). You can also just... eat less meat. Or give up beef. I am generally very much against blaming individuals for climate change rather than companies, but when it comes to food I do think that consumers can make a difference.

This was a good topic. But, there was a lot of information left on the cutting room floor, I think. First and foremost, the local delivery emissions has nothing to do with your diet. You will have to go to the store for the food, and the food has to be shipped to your store anyway. I assume buying local meant farmer's market. Which is nice if you don't live in a food desert. As far as beef emissions, ranchers and ag scientists are working on that. Feeding kelp to cows has shown a lot of promise in reducing methane. Other methods are being investigated as we speak. Also, lab grown meat, which is very near on the horizon as a consumer product, was not mentioned. But, the biggest killer of all people going vegan is the simple fact that a good portion of the population in the US CAN'T go vegan. Or even vegetarian. Because those protein sources are much more expensive than cheap meats. To replace the protein in 100 grams of beef, you would need to eat 590 grams of quinoa. Simply put, poor people can't afford to go vegan. Especially in the food deserts so prevalent in the US. Whole Foods doesn't set up shops in the poor areas, but McDonald's sure does.   And, to round this whole conversation off, let's not forget that most of the world's emissions comes from only the top 100 corporations. I'll give up the beef once people convince those corporations to emit less than raising food.

A problem with their point that they don't bring up. That grain used to feed animals is typically hardier varieties that can grow in more places than crops that feed people. Meaning that farmland still couldn't be converted to food production. The shear logistical problem of changing global diets is a massive problem as some of the highest emissions In meat and dairy production come from counties that are already food unstable. The vast amount of jobs lost and the inability to compensate the food production are important factors. People should eat less meat but ultimately this argument is a distraction from the real problem; fossil fuels. It's even pushed by the fossil fuel industry to take the target off their back. And it's used by conservatives to make people look like crazies. Focusing on fossil fuels is by far more important if we want real reductions. Nuclear energy and green energy grids are the things that will actually drastically reduce emissions. There are only marginal gains to be made in food production and we plain need food.

Most people speak of animals, and how they are reared as products. ThatтАЩs the fundamental difference as l perceive them, and treat them.  I see them as living, feeling, creatures like me, and l hate,  we decide,  how long the live, where they live, under what conditions they live, and how we manipulate their food, to use their meat as soon as possible, and shorten their life span at our will. Many babies of all kinds of different animals in different cultures are eaten before they are one year old, as their тАЬmeatтАЭтАЭ is especially tender.   It is horrible in my view point, how we treat animals even as pets like for example dogs short lines on their neck, mostly totally controlled by us, when they can move, when they have company, when they are allowed to run. To me this is cruelty. Many dog owners leave their dogs more than 9 h alone at home. In some countries like South Korea, China dogs are versatile used, also raised for eating among other purposes like any other animals. In wet markets all fish, тАЬsea foodтАЭ are tortured alive in buckets, tanks, etc. where the are squeezed in on top of each other half alive,  and lobsters are alive tide up, and thrown alive in boiling water, dying slowly in the heat, as most people believe animals have no feelings, only because they cannot speak. Pigs scream in terror, when they sense they will be killed, and they try to escape, cows mourn, and cry loudly, when they are separated from their calfs, and If you would once dare to go into an abattoir you would probably not eat meat ever again. I have seen so much suffering of animals, while travelling the world, that l became a vegetarian. I am not a fanatic, and l do not lecture anyone, what to eat. I decided only for myself, and l am happy with my decision, and my lifestyle based on veggies, fruits, grains, nuts and so on, but l do not interfere with anyone elseтАЩs diet. I love Kurzgesagt and IтАЩm veggie but this is the kind of shady statistics reporting IтАЩd expect from a tabloid newspaper. 800GtCO2e over *100 years* vs. 50GtCO2e over *1 year*, these figures should not be compared on the same graph, they have two different units and this is misleading. Obviously planting more forests is good for climate change and creating ecosystems but in the first 10 - 20 years trees donтАЩt capture that much CO2 as theyтАЩre not big enough or gaining mass quickly enough to remove large amounts of CO2 and even if we did plant these forests itтАЩs an average 8GtCO2e/yr removed (with a time delay) vs 50GtCO2e/yr emitted. We need to change the way we see trees in relation to climate change: Donald Trump, Nigel Farage and other former climate change deniers and sceptics back planting trees to prevent climate change so they can then justify not cutting their emissions; trees canтАЩt save us from climate change, they can help but we donтАЩt have enough land area to grow enough forests to offset our current CO2 emissions. Stopping slash and burn forest destruction is an absolute must but new forests are only a part of the solution, they arenтАЩt the solution themselves and wonтАЩt do all that much by 2050. The only thing that will prevent climate change is a maaaasive reduction in the amount of CO2e that we emit, letтАЩs hope we have the collective willpower to make the political and lifestyle changes required

This video is awesome. One caveat: beef CAN have a negative carbon footprint IF it sequesters carbon in regenerative agricultural systems. Regenerative ag systems require some animals to help cycle nutrients, and cows can do this. However, this only works in areas where cows are native species, and they would be extremely small in number compared to today. Even more, people would probably be consuming 90-95% less beef in such a system, because you'd harvest cows much less frequently than plants and insects. Tldr: probably still shouldn't eat meat

Ok Kurzgesagt team.  Praise and a Question: I love your work.  This vid I learned that my understandings of this subject are mostly correct but I was challenged in how I thought about global shipping. Thanks!  But as I understand from "drawdown" 2017 by Paul Hawkin, Refrigerants are a large part of the global warming impact of transporting food. This is hard to quantify i Know as it's often a latent issue. And obviously refrigerants are everywhere, in air conditioning and refrigeration from the new ones being created to the old ones slowly leaking in landfills around the world.  Can you Please Please Please consider a video or 2 on understanding the refrigerant situation, both in terms of food's impact on global warming bt also the wider unseen global warming contribution?

I wonder if growing meat in a petri dish is less detrimental to the environment. Because if we take as fact that by 2100 food production alone will ensure our future is doomed (CO2 emission being high enough to cause irreversible effect on climate) then by definition we either have to improve food production or we just accept a future where we are extinct.  But that doesn't mean we have to avoid all meat sources or only produce meat for the uber rich. If we can grow meat in a lab, then we bypass any moral and ethical concerns re: killing sentient animals and we avoid the problem with emissions and so forth.  Since I don't personally believe meat is going anywhere, I think the future will be some sort of hybrid world where lab grown meat is the norm and the upper class gets to eat actual animals. Also I think we'll be extinct one day but that's a given.

Unfortunately such videos aren't helping. I've seen some on the topic and they all contradict each other. I guess this is the curse of YT - anyone can make a video claiming they reasearched the topic well, but we'd have to be experts to know who's right. What I didn't like about yours was: 1. You didn't mention the fact, that livestock eat a lot of unusable parts of crops. Tell me, what would happen with that waste if we didn't feed it to the cows? I can't think of any other way, that wouldn't result in a release of greenhouse gases into atmosphere. Namely, we could burn it as fuel or just leave it and let it rot or ferment. 2. Although we have a lot of livestock, we also killed most big wild animals in the last 2 thousand years. Our livestock fills that gap. So it's not like all of this methane is caused by our civilization. Some, perhaps most of it was being produced centuries ago by wild animals. 3. A misconception about forests and other biomes is they produce a lot of surplus oxygen. Plants themselves do, but when you take into account all the organisms in a biome you find out it actually doesn't produce much extra oxygen. In case of forests main factor are bacteria feeding on old roots, that actually consume oxygen and produce greenhouse gases. That's why cutting down forests that are older than 10 years of age is beneficial. Trees produce a surplus of oxygen up to around that age. But after that ther roots start to rot and it cancels out that effect. We owe all the oxygen in our atmosphere to algae in the oceans, that produced a small surplus of oxygen over millions of years. So, when you say that instead of feeding grass to our livestock we could let it grow in order for it to produce more oxygen, you may be badly wrong. That may actually be counterproductive.

Great video!
This video does some things wrong, typically with the framing. For example, it doesn't point out that only like 4% of greenhouse emissions come from animal husbandry (according to the EPA). They had the opportunity mention this at the start of the video, but instead they said worldwide food production alone accounts for 26% of emissions and could use up our "carbon budget" by 2035. Okay, but it should be noted that food production is not just meat. So we get rid of the 4% of emissions that come from meat and we're still fucked. Cutting meat out completely might spare us... 6 months?   It further obscures the relative insignificance of meat with weird framing at the end. It that says 800 Billion Tonnes of co2 would be removed over the course of 100 years if we replaced animal farmland with co2 scrubbing plants. And it points out that we collectively release 50 billion tonnes per year across all sectors. It then shows the 800 billion Tonne figure side by side with the 50 billion tonne figure, as if to suggest 800 billion is a lot. Well, it is a lot. But 50 billion tonnes by 100 years (the appropriate comparison) is 5000 Tonnes. So if we erased all animal farming and replaced it with plants that were 100% as efficient at scrubbing the atmosphere as soon as we planted them as we would like, we'd have made up only ~1/5th to ~1/2 the amount of co2 we'd otherwise have released over the course of 100 years? Which, again, may take us from 4% greenhouse emissions from animals to -8% best case scenario. I am not sure how we're meant to interpret this.  It is a complicated subject. I am still not sure what to think either in terms of overall cost benefit. What I am fairly certain of is that meat is not even close to the most important vector to attack with respect to emissions. That should have come across more clearly in this video. Again, meat represents ~4% of our greenhouse gas emissions. Another thing I think they didn't do due enough diligence on is the nutrient bioavailability of meat per greenhouse emission. They only looked at protein. This ignores the overall comparative nutrient/antinutrient profile of plants. I'm not sure we could survive on plants as they're currently cultivated and sold to us. One thing I learned from the video is that the best forms of meat production drastically cut greenhouse gas emissions. This was followed by an argument that the economics of generalizing best practices is impossible. I'm not sure about that. At the moment, we haven't organized ourselves to be maximally efficient at delivering high quality meat on a green economic budget. If we pursue that end, we might just achieve it. As implausible as it may be, lab grown meat may take us much of the way there.

The main issue i find about the whole diet dilemma is the extremes of opinions. Eating massive ammounts of meat is bad. Eating no meat at all isn't a good solution either. The thing is, something i have only seen a handful of people recognize at all, is that there is a whole area of middleground. There are no simple solutions to the complex problems we face.  Our best shot at improvement is eating _less_ meat and balancing it out while _also_ buying meat that is as responsibly produced as _reasonably possible._ We simply have to take responsibility for our own living standards, something seemingly most people are not willing to do.  It's small steps in the right direction but at least small steps are possible compared to the alternatives. You don't move a pile of rocks all at once. You have to move each rock one at a time.

Unlike most of their other videos, I feel like this one doesn't really flesh out the issue enough.  Food is pivotal, and I feel it deserves more effort and attention to detail.  Diversity in our agriculture and in our diets is important.  I feel like the big elephant in the room was the statistic about dropping production of beef by 70% to reduce the waste of resources that could be put directly towards food.  Could we consider the possibility that reduction of beef consumption, rather than elimination, is the answer?  How much would we need to reduce?  Also it is difficult for me to believe that these statistics about transportation emissions are accurate.  I have heard about a shipment of watermelons that traveled three times across the US before being sold to a store.  This is because of our commodification of food and lack of regulation in the market to reduce emissions.    Another consequence of trading food like stock, which is important to discuss in this context, is food waste.  How much carbon could we save if our stores were smaller and we wasted less food?  Also certain animals can be used to turn waste into valuable food.  Factory farming is a nightmare and lacks the frugality of the truly local farmer, and our distribution methods fill dumpsters with food waste that is illegal to collect while thousands of people die of starvation in the US.    Also what about those of us whose diet needs to not be soy-based?  Or people with digestive issues that need the nutrition density?   We should always discuss food wholistically instead of in one context.

This suggests that if everyone became vegan that we would save a load of land but what about the land needed to grow the vegetables to feed a huge influx of vegans??
One thing that the anti-meat argument tends to avoid addressing is the ecological impact of releasing all of these farm animals back into the wild. Not even taking into account how sudden shifts in the population ratio of prey vs predator animals affect population growth, the increased competition for resources among animals, or the strain on plant life from a massive increase in roaming herbivores, there's the microbe issue that could lead to the unintentional decimation of existing wildlife. Much like how indigenous populations were ravaged by diseases introduced during the era of exploration and colonization, there are pathogens that domesticated animals have adapted to which wildlife have not encountered before. Getting humans off of meat is still going to require a massive culling of livestock before they can be reintroduced into the wild.

It's fine in moderation
my opinion, personally, is that there's no easily conceivable way to completely phase out beef quickly, but I think we should work towards steering our culture away from beef and towards less carbon footprint heavy meats, get yourself a McChicken instead of a big mac, things like that. Feed our children less beef to steer their early developing palate away from it, get your children accustomed early on to foods that are better for the environment, so that they will prefer it later, and feed their own children the food they've learned to like. It's much harder to change our own habits and diets the way we are now, but for children, they haven't really developed their habits and preferences yet. Obviously we will have to work on changing our own habits and diets too, and it may seem unfair to feed your children food different to what you're eating, or to make a separate meal for them than for yourself, but steps must be taken to change humanity's culture on the way we consume products, and culture is not something easily broken or changed in a single generation, it takes a concentrated effort and lifetimes of minor steps to make lasting changes.   Obviously, we don't quite have that time, but if we can cut out as much emissions as we can, we can give ourselves more time to work on changing our culture to avoid simply falling back into the same issues after we think "the problem is gone now, we can go back to the way we were"

The shipping part of the video was intellectually dishonest because the last mile of transportation happens for all food, but in the visual, they only show veggies being shipped on containers and only meat being moved on trucks. It's not a statement so they can get away with it, but it's obviously a visual manipulation tactic. Let's not ignore the fact that meat has a higher nutrient density. Meaning the emission cost of transportation of meat may likely be less per nutrient.

ItтАЩs misleading to compare transporting meat locally to transporting veggies globally.  The point is local transport is more harmful (yet unavoidable) than global, efficient transport.  Eating meat isnтАЩt a sin, but exclusively consuming it in fast food form is certainly a waste.  Favoring grass fed beef and shopping locally, if possible, are enough to keep your conscience quiet.  Also donтАЩt waste anything, use the bones for broth and consume the liver and other organs.  Thinking big picture and climate change about your eating habits seems like a couple jumps past what is useful to us.  Personally IтАЩm way more concerned with the additives and extra processing that is used for everything at your typical supermarket.  I want real food, even if it farts!
So simply put, we should be eating a plant-based diet sourced from farmer's markets and micro-farming where possible.

Kurzgesagt. We need to STOP criticizing each other for our food eating choices. I think this is one of the most reductive videos I've seen on any topic on this channel.  A serious unanswered question:  When you calculate the gas emissions per kilogram of beef, are you calculating for the entire lifespan of the animal? Or just the emissions of processing the beef at the end of it's life?  I have a feeling that calculation is deriving gas emissions from any possible area it can. Every fart of the animal from birth to death. Every inch of land and water consumed. So forth.  I'd be curious to know what the result would be if you include the calories and protein derived from the dairy and other products of the animal throughout it's lifespan. Instead of just a kilogram of beef.  A kilogram of beef is not all that humans gain from a single cow. Why are so many other products being excluded? Milk, cheese, butter, yogurt, ICE CREAM, leather, medical products.  But more importantly:  Why does every one of these arguments against meat (because that's what this video is) seem to pretend that the capitalistic tendencies of meat producers is inevitable and cannot be addressed through legislation? But that doesn't mean factory mentality producers have to continue to be allowed to overproduce, pollute our environments and process animal byproducts in ways that cause harm. Cattle farming has also significant historic and social implications. For example, in Latin America it reaches back to the reconquista of Spain, where expelling the moors freed-up vast ranges of land that were the given to a select few individuals.   Since these people wanted to live comfortably as nobles, the easiest thing to do was use the vast lands for cattle, as it took the least amount of investment and upkeep.  This process replicated and expanded during the conquest of Latin America, with the continent being carved-up between the descendants of conquistadors and high government officials of the empire.  The result, is that land access for campesinos wanting to grow crops is limited, with cattle over representing the agricultural output of many of these nations.

The more I hear about climate change, the more I realize that we really need an engineering solution to it. I don't know if we have the capacity as a species to dig deep and give up 90% of the luxuries we've obtained through the industrial revolution for no immediate gain. I'm sure once all the forests catch fire, the crop famines start, the hurricanes and tsunamis destroy our cities, and the great dying commences, we'll be ready for hard times to save our lives. But before that? I seriously doubt it. To really be effective, these solutions need to be government mandated. The government that actually enacts all these bans is going to immediately revert to being a developing nation that's deciding not to develop. And that's how civil wars start. It just isn't going to work in a timely enough manner to *prevent* a climate disaster. By some metrics, disaster is where we are already, and we're still sluggish to peel back our progress.  The Deep Adaptation paper probably puts forth what is, unfortunately, the most realistic solution: learn to live on the pressure cooker version of earth.

I think the point of the anger towards videos making this kind of case is that theyтАЩre narrowing the context until it seems like removing meat makes tons of sense, and also taking a perspective which assumes very very little of human ingenuity. The video isnтАЩt referencing biology, economics, third world manufacturing technology, all of which is relevant to the meat eater, but not to the narrow framing тАЬIs meat bad for the environment (in this context under these measurement)тАЭ?  If we truly need to eat meat, we will figure out a way to make it sustainable. If we truly canтАЩt, weтАЩll figure out a way to make cereal not cancer inducing. Right now, meat is your healthiest option. That might be a shame given whatтАЩs in the video, but in actuality thereтАЩs a lot more to it and youтАЩre perfectly justified in eating meat. In our current world, I can't understand why CO2 emission information is not required on packaging of food. Nutritional information is required, why isn't CO2 emission? Instead of focusing on the type of food, whether it be meat, vegetables, fruit, or others, we could instead focus on the actual CO2 emission caused by that specific product. I'm not an expert on the area, but I've been wondering about CO2 emission information on product packaging for a long time, and it would be helpful for us consumers to pick a certain product over another one, to more actively seek the green alternative.

Isn't the actual problem releasing carbon from fossil fuels? Instead of being trapped underground, it can act as greenhouse gas in the atmosphere. Keeping livestock of course will increase amount of methane, but as I understand it, it is rather constant - cows are basically circulating carbon, which was already in the equation.   In other words, if we stopped burning fossil fuels and keep livestock as it is, amount of greenhouse gases would stay the same, therefore it's hard to compare methane "released" by cows with carbon dioxide from coal plants.

Cows eat a lot of the crop we can't eat. When we grow wheat we give them the stalks, when we grow almond we give them the shells. There's a lot of crops we grow that we only use a teeny tiny percentage of the final product, so the rest we give to cattle as to not waste it.
The best beef, as the video points out, produces 9Kg of CO2 per 100g of protein, while Tofu (the worst plant alternative) only 3.5. So the best beef produces a bit over double the Co2 than tofu. Is this beef a little over double more nutrient dense than Tofu? I imagine its much more than that, making this beef one of the best foods right? So the problem might not be beef, but the way weproduce it.

тАжmost of the grains and crop that animals eat are not good enough quality for human consumption. Rotational grazing, soil conservation etc. use animals to restore the co2 in the land and later grow food in it in cycles. The industry has significantly lowered its emissions rates in the past 20 years and is coming up with more environmentally friendly ways constantly. Like the recent research on adding seaweed to cows diet to lower the methane they produce. I don't understand why people take objective facts presented here and keep trying to make subjective claims of value about this. "Eating meat is bad." That's an opinion. "The process of rearing animals that will be processed for consumption, and the distribution of that animal product produce a lot of CO2 emissions compared to plant-based products" is an objective statement.   "You shouldn't eat meat," is not the way to convince someone to make a change because it's just your opinion. If you instead say "you should try to limit how much meat you consume or consider a protein that contributes less to the climate change, because climate change is making our current way of life unsustainable," I imagine you'd have a more productive conversation.  Just ending with a personal question that was left unanswered by this video, how does lab grown beef stack up against other meat or vegetable options? Is it a viable strategy to replace cattle ranches without forcing large scale changes to the typical American diet and still have an effect on reducing climate emissions?

Beautiful video as always, but I have to disagree with the way it was presented. Based on your information, It's the WAY companies handle the beef industry as a whole and how it's arbitrarily categorized and scored in the life cycle assessment. Saying that "Beef emits 71kg of CO2" places the blame on individual consumers who have limited impact, rather than companies who directly affect the life cycle assessment the argument is based on. Saying "Beef PRODUCTION emits 71kg of CO2" more accurately portrays the information used. Otherwise, love the videos, keep up the good work.

e
I think the video fails at two important points:  1, Nutrient density, where it only mentions proteins and calories. No talk about other key nutrients that are found in meat in abundance, but at the same time lack from vegetables, or are very difficult to get  - iron being one of them. Iron can be found in many plants but it's very rare that it is found in a digestable form - for example because the same iron-rich plants contain materials that prohibit the integration of iron into the body. 2, Transportation - avocados also need to be delivered by truck both before and after they get on the ship. The comparison of local meat transportation producing less emissions then shipping avocado from South America stands on a very shaky ground.

That comparison between the Co2 emissions of Poultry and Beef makes me feel that much better that i've almost for an entire year now been eating 95% chicken meats, the type of "real" meat that causes them the least. But what about fish? How much emissions does a trout cause?

Methane produced from ruminant animals has not changed  for hundreds of years, there are less ruminants in North America today then there were in the 100 years ago (think ten of millions of bison). Regardless the methane they produce is already accounted for in the carbon cycle, it is not "new carbon" like fossil fuels... This is not "new" emissions , you should rather look at new sources, troubleshoot, what has actually changed... perhaps energy and transportation in the last 100 years?

Very important and informative video, especially for us Brazilians. Even though many of the Bolsonaro lovers would call you communist liars, as their lack of intelligence and capacity of thinking.
The video is interesting but there's plenty more stuff that is not even mentioned: food waste is the first and probably most important, IMO. Some estimates indicate that food waste is around 60%, addressing production without addressing this first doesn't seem the smartest approach to me. Also, there's some interesting statistics on the percentage of food waste by kind, and unsurprisingly the less expensive ones (vegetables) are the most wasted. Wasted food ferments, which itself produces methane and CO2.  There's also the aspect of crop rotation or lack thereof, soil impoverishment, yield, loss of biodiversity, etc etc. This video while good literally just scratched the surface and would deserve a much more in depth follow up

I could agree on that "the more animals suffer, the better they are in terms of climate change because they are way more  efficient". But is this really good for our health? Animals do not eat their original food (e.g. grass) anymore. Crops replaces their original food. Funny parallel, humans do the same. We originally ate unprocessed foods like nuts, vegetables, fruit, meats. Our original foods are replaced with processed foods which contain sugar, flour, oil (with low macro-nutrients and fiber). See what happens... diabetes, lung diseases, neurological disorders have skyrocketed in the last 50 years.  Animals also suffer from this radical diet change. So we give them antibiotics to survive then we eat them. I think this approach does not support our health in any meaningful way!
You should make a video on the human health perspective. Check out Drs John McDougall (The Starch Solution), Michael Gregor (How Not To Die), Neal Barnard, Caldwell Esselstyn, T. Colin Campbell (The China Study), and also the documentaries The Game Changers and Forks Over Knives. ЁЯСМЁЯП╝

Doesn't the majority of animal feed consist of things we can't eat?? Like husks and stems? This means that animal production isn't only not wasteful, but it's also making the most out of our resources
Is it also worth considering the restoration of dried arid areas into grasslands with mob grazing methods?
Another factor that's also interesting to look at is the use of water. As that is also a limiting resource in some places on earth.
Hi, friendly neighbourhood ecologist here! I've got a few things to add.  I bulk buy my meat from local farms. Free-range, grass-fed, high welfare within the local area. How is that worse than importing plants like soy from halfway around the world. Planted on deforested lands and grown with fertilisers and pesticides? You should also consider that ruminants can convert the inedible components of food crops such as stalks and husks. I am not just speaking about carbon emissions, but the total environmental impact, including the release of pesticides, fertilisers and how many species can use that habitat.   But ultimately this doesn't really matter. Are humans really capable of veganism? Genetics has shown some people are very poorly adapted at converting plant fats to essential fatty acids. Some people have few copies of AMY1A, meaning a high starch diet will make them sick. As such genes are related to ancestry, they are often combined, including genes that increase people's demand for animal nutrients.  An extreme example is me, low amylase production, bad reaction to plant oils, and a condition called hereditary fructose intolerance (which means I die if I consume too much fructose). There is no such thing as a sustainable vegan diet for me and many others. Because we would be unable to sustain ourselves on one.  Over 80% of vegans quit, and no large-scale vegan societies have survived the millennia. Despite the theoretical benefits it would bring. I would suggest veganism is not a viable solution to feeding the planet.  Instead, perhaps a combination of intensive sewage powered greenhouses, hydroponics, seaweed, and garden allotments to grow plants. While we get our animal nutrients from holistically grazed grasslands, animals fed on agricultural waste products, closed system aquaculture, sustainable shellfish, and insect farming is a better combination to allow humans to flourish without causing as much damage to the environment.

Not to take sides, but i am pretty sure there should've been couple of other points in a topic, which i heard over the years: 1. Animals eat parts of a crop that are not suitable for human consumption as well as "discarded" crops not suitable for market. 2. A lot of commercial farms discard vast amounts of crops, due to lack of demand, so to avoid getting caught behind crop cycle, it's just destroyed (not composted). Also cetrain crops either not suitable for animal feed or not commercialy feasable to transport to animal farms. 3. It's not just emissions. Water is an important resource as well. 4. Issue of a dietary and cultural consumption of beef. A lot of cultures in the world consume organ meat and other byproducts of meat undustry, while others have a much larger red meat market, which greatly reduce amount of "usable product" per animal.

I really enjoyed the video, but I feel like you mis-representated the CO2 equivalent emitted per year. You're using different units. One is CO2/year and the other is CO2/100 years. At a glance, it looks like the CO2 removed would far outweigh the CO2 emitted, when in fact the CO2 emitted is 6.25 times greater if you account for all of those 100 years (if you assume the CO2 emitted stays the same).   I would have liked you to say which beef was 10 times better "CO2"-wise than the worst beef, that could have informed people about which beef to choose over another. In addition to the environmental impact, animal agriculture is the main source of new diseases, probably caused this pandemic, and if nothing changes will cause another.  It's also a waste of resources as we already produce enough plant food to feed all of humanity but we give it to livestock instead while people starve.  The health benefits also seem to favour a plant based diet, given you supplement at least B12 (which we otherwise nowadays get via animals that has eaten supplements).  Most antibiotics are given to animals which drives the evolution of antibiotics resistant bacteria, which could have dire consequences on modern medicine. The majority of CO2 released by cows is taken from the atmosphere in the first place. Cows don't eat coal, they eat plants that pulled their CO2 from the atmosphere. It makes them borderline solar powered. The only time they actually release CO2 is through tractors, water pumps and transport. All 3 of those can be switched to nuclear power and in doing so, cows would become carbon neutral. (One caveat, they produce methane which is worse for the atmosphere but degrades into CO2 so they don't produce CO2 but amplify the effect of a finite amount of it. Also if you use their manure to power vehicles, you can skip the methane part and get energy to boot.)
Thing is we donтАЩt need tractors at all for growing veg, we can grow enough on no till living organic. Bio intensive

The emissions from animal agriculture have been seriously underestimated in the IPCC report.   They took the numbers from the FAO, who are partnered with several meat and dairy promoting organisations .  Read Sailesh Rao's paper for a demonstration . The true number is somewhere between 51-87% , including the opportunity cost of the land used.

Let me explain if I burn a ton of coal that co2 is there to stay, the carboniferous period is ended and without any new organism that changes the capacity of the earth to absorb more co2, most of what I have emitted burning that coal will remain in the atmosphere (ok the actual molecules will change but for a really long time the surplus will remain) Now let's look at the meat emission aka animal burp and fart, there is methane and co2, both of them come from the carbon that a plant has taken from atmosphere and the next year they will grow again (they will take different molecules from the atmosphere) but in a world where beef is the only emission of humanity technically we should emit every year only what the new crop and grass to feed cattles absorb the next, so is a zero sum, right ? Technically all the methane produced from cattle isn't added to the environment. It is because methane has a different life cycle than carbon dioxide. If you add more cows they wouldn't add more methane into the environment. It has a lot to do with how methane circulates in the environment. An example of this is when a cow eats grass the cow farts and poops methane gas. This methane gas reaches the atmosphere and stays there until a downpour of water happens. This has been going on for thousand's of years without any human intervention. Then the grass will absorb said methane and the cycle will repeat. It doesn't add. America has one of the most efficient cows in the world. Cows in the middle east produce much less in meat and milk compared to their western counterparts. An actual way to make them less harmful to the environment is to make their cows more efficient. But it's not obvious to the normal person. It's not. Does Jordan Peterson talk about the best way to solve climate change is to make poorer countries richer? Mind you he has read over 200 books on climate change. It's because poorer countries make more waste per person because of their less efficient sources of goods and services. It's not obvious to the normal person they only listen to what rattles their emotions. It's much more encouraging to hear Bring down the system rather than make cows in the middle east be more efficient or try make everyone richer.

What this video seems to be missing is that cattle, which is grass-fed, emits much less GHG in total than factory bred cattle, because of the way cow metabolism works. Protein rich foods like corn and soy are accountable for much higher GHG emissions, as their production needs a lot of fertilizers, such as N20 or NH3, which appear in enormous quantities and heat up the atmosphere even faster.

God. I hate vegans and their pseudo-logic. They talk about livestock farming being so awful for the environment, yet just about all of their foods contain things like palm oil, which is causing a massive environmental disaster. I canтАЩt take them seriously with hypocrisy like that.
7:57 "Pastureland alone can't support the ruminants living on it." The caveat here would be "with traditional grazing methods". Which are letting them eat whatever they want and go wherever they like. But with rotational grazing by design a paddock must be large enough and healthy enough to support all animals on it. It's less yield but sustainable (for the environment and the needs of the animals), with less cost in, and sometimes slightly more profitable per animal.   Unfortunately it's not very popular as it requires more work per person and less profit overall. Fewer animals taking up the same overall space means less total money even if each animal earns the same or a little bit more. As much as 90% of the land goes unused 90% of the time (Being left to rest to recover the natural ecology before the cows come in to keep it from getting too wild). There is also a lot of fencing (electrified mesh) that needs to be moved manually in wedges every few days. As well as water troughs that need to be moved and refilled to each new paddock area.  As a consequence really only smaller farmers that one can get to care more about the sustainability of their business and the environment are likely to adopt it. Whereas big commercial farms are perfectly happy to keep doing things the way they have been. As if not more profitable per animal but less profitable overall is no real incentive for commercial farms to change their methods. And if everyone switch to rotational grazing it would also take up a lot more land overall to sustain the same amount of cattle as we do now (though this would be greatly mitigated by needing less land to grow feed on).
But if you're counting the emissions for clearing land to produce beef, none of that measure applies to the sustainability OR ongoing emissions cost of current beef production.  If someone's science is conflating two different things (the ecological costs of beef production, and the ecological costs of *expanding* beef production) on an issue this controversial, I have to entertain strong suspicions that they may have an axe to grind.

I'm sorry but transporting 1kg of mass no matter if it's avocadoes or beef requires exactly the SAME energy. That's physics.
Interestingly enough, the average first world citizen eats 2 to 3 times more meat than is nutritionally valuable or recommended. Even by eating the proper nutritional values of meat we would reduce our footprint by 2 to 3 times without giving up the valuable collagen, amino acids etc from meat. Meat offers essentially elements to our diet that lead to our brain developing further than that of our ancestors.. typically it isn't the meat itself that is cancerous per say, but the things stored in the fat of the animals that was fed to them (think growth hormones and a sedentary lifestyle.) Most studies of the health effects of meat don't properly differentiate between the quality of the meats or the preparation of them even though those uncontrolled variables can have a massive nutritional impact. There is so much gray area involved in reducing carbon footprint in nearly every way. Even outside of food.

Cow eat grass. Cow burps and shit. Grass eats shit and burps (methane ->co2). Cow eat grass. No new co2 is added to the atmosphere. The studies they used have things such as "manure management" and farting cows as measurement of emissions, but once again no new co2 has been added. They also used the study that didn't include waste in the video (but had it in the sources) and ask yourself this: what food products do you throw in the garbage bin the most? By a large margin vegetables and grain products are thrown and while they rot away methane is released. Cows can eat all the byproducts of vegetables. If you grow soybeans for example you are also left with the stalk, leaves and what not. That is used as feed and can't be eaten by humans, the soybean (the actual bean) feed for animals is all a byproduct left from extracting the oil from it. Lastly chemical fertilizers actually use fossil fuels (natural gas) to produce it. Meaning new co2 added to the atmosphere.
if you cut meat out of your diet, you didn't do much, actually - it's just another slab of meat that won't get sold and will just instead be thrown away and wasted on nothing. people seem to not realize that not eating meat does NOT mean less animal death or meat production - they will always produce the same amount of meat or only go up in meat production. people need to stop putting so much pressure on other individuals and instead try to hold the industry itself accountable. same with emissions overall - politics have been trying to make individuals bad for trying to live their lives as normally as possible instead of reducing factory emissions or closing down environmentally destructive factories.  another big factor people don't seem to take into account much is the dietary value of meat. without meat i assure you literally all of us will be suffering from various deficiencies. unless you want all people on the planet to have to chug supplements daily, that is - which aren't too healthy especially in the long term, aren't a replacement for getting the nutrients yourself, and are expensive. not to mention the strain it'd put on the pharmaceutics industry, which is also SUPER not good for the environment, and also directly poisons us because pharmaceutical companies most often dump drugs and waste products in water. yeah. the industry is responsible for a huge amount of water pollution.  i love kurzgesagt, and i usually love all of their videos, but this isn't it. it's not that i feel "attacked" as a meat eater - sorry, but i'll keep eating meat regardless. what i dislike is how it showed barely any arguments *for* meat consumption, making this a video with unbalanced arguments, although i understand that this as a video was meant to mostly cover the negative impacts of beef.

The thing about cows is that they are not just used for beef. In the video it was mentioned that dairy cows are used also for milk but there are many other parts of the cow that are used, such as its skin for leather or fat (tallow) that is used in antifreeze and hydraulic break fluid. Pretty much the whole cow is used. I find that a lot of climate change videos forget this and make the claim that a cow has a huge footprint for this one use case. I went into a coffee shop the other day that was trying to promote the use of non-dairy kinds of milk (oat and almond) and they used similar data showing a cow's large environmental impact and why you should try oat milk but they failed to also mention a cow's other uses such as for beef. I understand it can get complicated but I rarely see an argument where the individual breaks down all of the uses for a cow and then weighs all of those benefits to its environmental footprint.

The biggest problem is overpopulation. Most global problems can be linked to it.
Agriculture videos like this present information in a way that is both informative and also somewhat misleading.  Total emissions is only half the story.   Net emissions is what's important.    Cows cannot emit more carbon than they consume from plants.  Cattle are 100% made of carbon from the atmosphere.  Therefore, the net contribution of all living things, cows included, is zero over time.  Carbon is a cycle.  A lot of carbon exists in long-term storage underground, which we humans drill or till up and put back in the atmosphere.  This causes a net increase in atmospheric carbon levels, which is considered a contributing factor to global warming.    If carbon reduction is our goal, then we should focus first on controlling the processes which introduce carbon from long-term storage into the atmospheric cycle, not the systems which simply recycle that carbon.    Ruminants have been an important part of the lifecycle of grasslands for eons, and their presence is quite beneficial for the land.  When combined with no-till practice and intensive grazing, ruminants stimulate plant growth which creates a net carbon sink into long-term storage in the soil.   Recommendations to achieve our carbon reduction goal: 1. Consume less energy and resources overall 2. Transition to renewable or nuclear energy sources 3. Adopt sustainable agricultural practices, including no-till and intensive ruminant grazing
Also if all of that food was not fed to the livestock, it could provide enough of food to humans multiple times over. And this did not even touch upon ethics and health questions, which are other 2/3rds of the whole picture.

Giving up meat feels difficult because most of us have been eating it since before we can remember, and it's so culturally engrained, we often have a personal attachment to it. Before I gave it up I think my key self-justification was "I disapprove of animal cruelty; I only condone ethical meat," and cognitive dissonance allowed me to believe that although factory-farmed meat was out there, it couldn't be the stuff I was buying. But it was, obviously - because almost all of it is.

Something I've not seen addressed -- "All cows burp and emit methane." But suppose there were no cows? Would the wild population of deer and buffalo merely fill in the gap and produce a similar amount of methane? Will we be encouraged to limit the wildlife population to limit the emissions from them?  If cows are bad, but deer and buffalo are okay, why not hunt and harvest those deer and buffalo for human consumption? After all, they are an excellent method of converting forest and grassland into something we can use. And if that makes sense, why not replace them with a species of animal that we can breed for greater efficiency; namely, the cow?

9:21 -- Let me get this straight: if _everyone_ on Earth went vegan, we'd have an additional 3 Bn ha of land that could (maybe) be used to draw down 800 Bn tonnes of CO2 equivalent (CO2e) over a hundred years. That's 8 Bn tonnes CO2e per year, vs the 50 Bn tonnes of CO2e we emit per year in total. Not as important as stopping the transfer of **geological** carbon from belowground to the atmosphere, for example.

I find it a bit odd how little time they spent on the beef that was low in greenhouse gas emissions. Sure it may still be higher than non meats, but if we focused on that you gain a huge benefit without not asking people to give up something they love.  To be honest though the real problem I have with anything vegetarian or vegan is that they try to copy foods that people are familiar with. If I have a vegan burger it will automatically be compared to a real burger. If companies focused on making vegan products that are novel there would be no real thing to compare it to. Easier to give up a burger when I don't have to eat a fake burger that just constantly reminds me how much I miss burgers.  Now I am sure that I could find a way to do cook vegan for myself without just taking every dish people make and making it vegan. However I not only wouldn't know where to begin, but it also would require a society level of retraining for people. It would be nice to have some vegan options at stores that are not just knock offs of the real the real thing.
Apples to oranges comparison like expected.  Let's talk about beef because its an outlier. Best beef is twice the carbon footprint of the worst veg but half that land is not tillable and half that beef is also used for dairy but we don't want to get into that. Also the protein is more legitimate than a calorie comparison but not as relevant as a fat comparison would be. Protein is easy enough to come by in a vegan diet if you ignore the phyto estrogen hormonal imbalance problems. Fat, in abundance in Western diets now, is important to child development and would become very scarce outside of tropical and arid sub tropical diets with no way to expand those climate zones. And methane gas emissions occur when plant matter decays. This cycle is sped up through digestion of livestock animals but their waste is also used to make fertilizer for commercial farming. Plant decay and the need for fertilizer would be bigger problems, not less, if there were not livestock animals 'processing' vegetation now. A new paper by New Zealand and English scientists concludes that going meatless will only have a small impact on a personтАЩs overall lifetime carbon footprint.  The paper, published in the Swiss-based Sustainability Journal, was written by researchers at Auckland, Massey, Victoria and Oxford universities, the New Zealand Agricultural Greenhouse Gas Research Centre, and the Ministry for Primary Industries (MPI).  It found that giving up meat would only reduce the average personтАЩs lifetime contribution to global warming by 2 per cent to 4 per cent.  That was because long-term, the benefits in not eating meat were largely offset by the carbon dioxide created to produce alternative foods and the relatively short life of methane, farmingтАЩs key greenhouse gas.

One thing that doesn't make sense is the part talking about transit emissions, showing cargo ships using less which is wrong; each one using over 20,000 gallons of petroleum per hour, and then saying the meat locally sourced and sold contributes more? That doesn't add up, unfairly favorable towards plant based foods.  Using the metric, carbon per kg isn't a fair nor accurate measurement for, gas waste per weight of product of solid state matter per transportation method, i.e. trucks only weighing few tons with higher carbon ratio (fuel consumption + vehicle weight) vs ship weighing thousands of tons with it's lower ratio still far out pollutes hundreds of trucks over due to the amount of fuel it requires,  it's how you get such discrepancies and look more favorable to the ship when in reality it's not the case and why things that looks good on paper should be looked at closer.  For arguments sake of the ship, also there will be other food products, even meats will be on there with the veggies as well, so how come meats don't get any emissions reduction for being on the same ship with the plant based foods that get to them if the ship is so emission efficient?

I honestly think it's the *WAY* things are looked at that should be changed. For Example, even if we cut down on eating animals, then *US, The Humans* will be the ones producing an inappropriate amount of methane. Methane, one of the main culprits of climate change, is an inevitable by-product of the digestion of Plant matter like cellulose and such. Also, yes it is true that, pound for pound, certain kinds of nuts or legumes do have more proteins than pork or beef does... but the thing is, the meat products have MORE of the easily digestible variety of proteins. So, you gain more protein from meat, even though there's more in peanuts. 8:19 "The only way to sustain our high demand for meat is by growing crops and feeding it to our cattle..." I love Kurzgesagt, but the idea the there's ONLY one way to sustain meat demand is naive and completely had my interest in this video drop sharply because of it.  Spoilers: the demand is high not because of the steak impact on climate in and of itself, but also because of how many of us want steaks. It's a 2 variable problem (1 - what is the action, 2 - how many perform the action). Stop treating it like a 1 variable problem. Making less meat eaters (yes, have less kids - I know, it's like a radioactive subject no one wants to touch) also helps this problem, hence, there's absolutely more than one way to sustain stuff, and in most cases, all ways matter at this point.  Just be honest about them and don't come across as if human procreation shouldn't/can't be a part of the climate change conversation, like it's free and has no impact, because too much human procreation is the largest part of the problem at this point (too little also a problem, yes). On the transport issue and differences between local and imported by sea... how is that possible? Doesn't the transport of meat add to an already existent distribution chain? Yes the transport by sea itself doesn't produce much but in all locations the way to prepare beef should be the same, they'll still go to a butcher, simply not a local one, and they do get transported by truck/train to wherever they're sold  Think of it like this: Local distribution: Butcher -> transport by truck/train to warehouse ->shop ->sold Imported by Sea: Butcher ->transport by truck/train to warehouse -> loaded on ship+ ship transport -> Unloaded from ship + transport to shop/warehouse it needs to go. Imported by sea does add a larger distance and carbon footprint and the numbers given at 4:42 seem incomplete or cherry picked to account for only some situations as not all cities are near the sea/ocean.   You guys said that most of the CO2 gases from transportation are  emitted at the last leg of the road as it is being distributed to shops, problem is that distribution will happen regardless of if it's shipped by sea or by land so the way it is transported is less important than the fact that it is as 1 kg of beef will produce the same co2 footprint as 1 kg of rice.
