from meat love to meat hate
I think the solution for the average American/Westerner, is to be mindful of what you eat. The undeniable facts are that meat is worse for the environment than plants, HOWEVER it is possible to have an ethical and sustainable diet that includes meat. The goal should be a whole foods, plant based diet (this is not the same thing as a vegan diet). If we center our diets around eating more of a "good thing" instead of eating less of a "bad thing", it becomes a lot easier to make changes on a societal level.   Try to cook more. Its cheaper and better for your health if you can spare the time. Cooking can be fun by learning new recipes. Try to center vegetarian/vegan/plant based recipes, and you'll naturally incorporate more varied veggies and will begin to eat less meat. If you can cut out fast food, or only choose veggie options when eating out, you will be surprised by how quickly your diet changes.   Think of meat as a treat instead of the center of the meal. Knowing what you know about the animal ethics and environmental ethics, try to weigh out whether your personal enjoyment is worth partaking in meat consumption. Learn to tell yourself "no I don't NEED that, I just want it, and its okay to go without wants".   Be kind and understanding to other people. Much of our diet is affected by our financial situation, the society we live in, and our mental health. Some people live in food deserts where fresh food is near impossible to obtain, or they work so much they dont have time to cook. There are strong cultural aspects to meat dishes that can leave people feeling alienated by cutting out meat altogether. Some people have a lot of diet restrictions because of sensitivities or eating disorders that make finding nutritious alternatives to meat extremely difficult, expensive, or time consuming. Cooking can be more difficult for disabled people or those with executive dysfunctions (the mental processes associated with "getting things done").  Sustainable lifestyle changes take a VERY long time to make. Be compassionate and helpful, to yourselves and to eachother. Shaming people does not work to change their behavior. If youre a vegetarian or vegan, try cooking meals for your friends to show them that we have food thats just as tasty as meat dishes! Or try to help them come up with meat substitutes for their favorite meals. Educate people about the environment in a nonjudgemental, non preachy, empathetic way. We were all in their shoes once.   Background: mostly vegetarian/transitioning, only eat meat on special occasions (typically once a month or every couple of months). I've been cutting out meat only for 8 months

Kinda surprised by this slip up, maybe I'm missing something, but showing the CO2 emitted as per year while showing the CO2 removed at 100 years is really disingenuous, and not necessary for establishing that removing 800 billion tonnes of CO2 in 100 years is a good thing. It also looks like the scale of the bars are set so that they'd both look "full" at 800 billion tonnes, which doesn't make  sense given that their time scales are different, so the bottom bar would be "full" in after roughly 16 years, compared to the other at 100. Obviously the bottom one is labeled as per year, but the point you're trying to make here (visually: 800b is a lot more than 50b, but conceptually: 800b is a lot but maybe not so much when we're emitted 50b per year) is unclear.

This is annoying; it is wrong to consider food as part of the carbon problem. The carbon in plants and animals was taken out of the atmosphere within the last few years. When it returns, that is a zero-sum. The new carbon that has been locked away in compounds for millions of years being broken down and released is the only real cause of greenhouse gas increase.

00:00 Africa would like a word with you
Brazilian speaking.  Soy Moratorium has become one of the main ways to prevent deforestation for soy planting, private companies made a social pact not to buy more soy from places deforested after 2006. Since then deforestation for this purpose has dropped precipitously, Greenpeace makes a lot of hype about this initiative. So it became fixed in our environmental laws.  Deforestation for pasture has fallen over the years, being restricted to "grileiros" groups, that is, the reason is the theft and resale of land, illegal wood or mining and not necessarily cattle raising.  Unfortunately around here there are almost no incentives for reforestation, almost predominant are legal obligations or for carbon/environmental credit (Mandatory for public/private works that have an environmental impact).  Private reforestation initiatives end up getting lost in the giant state bureaucracy, so we will hardly see projects like the competitions to create the largest reforested forests in the world here, as India, China and other countries have done.

I would add clean meat to the video, even though it's still very expensive, the technology has everything to revolutionize food.  The source would be the same, soy and the like, but without the animal to emit methane, and consuming only what is necessary to grow in the laboratory. This will free up regions for reforestation and overall tends to lower human food costs.  Aside from the moral issue of killing animals, it would be an easier transition for non-vegans.
Didn't expect such fail from Kurzgesagt. The net carbon emission is the release of carbon that previously wasn't in the air, like burning coal and oil. If we convert all our technology to renewable energy sources so does an agriculture. Carbon emission doesn't count breath of cows for example because it is the release of carbon that was previously captured from the air while raising crop.
At this point I don't even care anymore. The effect everything has on a changing climate is largely fear-mongering science. We think we're smarter than we are. While it's a given to reduce emissions wherever possible, it's a simple fact that we exist. And unless we "unexist" there's only so much we can do ... or even should do. I'd recommend some anti-fear climate research, but of course then I'd just be a climate denier or whatever the current term is.  Fact of the matter is: Could I stop eating meat? Yeah, probably. Would that be a life worth living, when good food is largely responsible for getting some enjoyment out of life? Not really. We CAN all survive on tasteless gruel, as long as the nutrients are in it, but what's the point in living then? That's just survival at best ... not living. Maybe lab-grown meat will really go through the roof. Say bye bye to farm animals though. Or finding alternative means to reduce these emissions, if they're really such a bit contributing factor. When you factor in research that claims that the man-made impact is pretty small overall, 25% of "pretty small" is even less.

*Contrary to common belief, grass fed beef doesn't negate beef CO2 impact at all because most pasture have already achieved the state of equilibrium where the CO2 absorbed is equal to the CO2 emitted (from soil organic mass buildup/decomposition) !*
What I see in this video is a straw man argument, тАЬbeef bad because Amazon rain forestтАЭ.  Where I live on the Great Plains an argument can be made that beef production is good for the environment. Prior to the arrival of Europeans, itтАЩs estimated that plains bison numbered 30 million and wood bison 170,000. Beef cattle are good replacement for bison. Both are a large ruminant whose  cloven hoofs break up the hard pan giving seed a place to germinate and spread seeds nutrients in their manure. Maintaining the health and natural diversity of the native grasslands is important in maintaining a carbon sink. Use the search term тАЬGrasslands More Reliable Carbon Sink Than TreesтАЭ in your favorite search engine. As someone who deals with life cycle assessment everyday I must say that the LCA study forgoes on one important aspect; the right functional unit. If you start comparing food based on the nutritional value of protein types instead of total protein content, some plant based alternatives actually start performing worse than, let's say, chicken. Of course environmental impacts are just one thing to worry about, if you include the potential spread of diseases any sort of animal bunking is a bad idea. Just to say: it's always more complicated than you think!

Im disappointed in this display of information. The destruction of the rain forest is an attack on biodiversity not CO2 sinks. The rain forest doesnt really "breath" in and out to the rest of the world. However the conifer forests in Russia do. The land isnt good for human use (cold all the time) and only really supports animals that can eat pine neddles and animals that eat other animals. These forests span most of Russia and "breath" in and out with the seasons to the rest of the world. There is a cool NASA video that shows this. I feel it is disingenuous to infer that the destruction of the rain forest will increase climate change. I also feel it is suspicious that data about fish is left out of this video. I'm not a super expert or anything so when I can spot one fairly obvious omission and a bending of the truth, I have to take more time to think if these are a result of ignorance or malicious intent. I'm quite nonplussed.

Why no one brings wars and the weapon industry to the global warming discussion?! Why a cow fart bothers the world?! instead the main problem is "humanity" especially greedy ones.
Another factor is that people often use eating food they find tasty as a comping mechanism for their emotional and psychological difficulties, many of which are unaddressed, and for many, meat dishes are their favourite coping mechanism.   Those who quit eating meat often do so out of guilt or shame, and basically force themselves to go without the coping mechanism until they find a new one to replace it, while beating themselves up in an unhealthy way in the process, and then might feel inclined to project their guilt and shame onto others, for self-righteous preaching is another form of coping.   There is another way that someone might quit eating meat though, and that is getting to the point of psychological development, through therapy (lets be honest most people need it), methods like journaling, and other beneficial practices, get to the point where they face their emotions more, rather than escape from them with reliance pleasurable distraction/numbing methods, like tasty food, and no longer have so much repressed issues to cope with, say, tasty food.   I highly recommend the latter, rather than the former, since it benefits one's life as a whole, but aside from that, while some people might be receptive to being guilt tripped by others and/or themselves into forcing themselves to quit eating meat despite relying on it as a way of coping in life, many people, perhaps even a majority of people, will not take that route ever, once tasty food is a coping mechanism for them, and in fact a significant portion of the population would probably react with anger and actively resisting vegetarian advocacy, cause they'd feel defensive since, their way of coping would feel under threat.   Personally I would say to really help the climate and contribute to better treatment of animals via less consumption of meat, a better route would be indirectly to approach it, by encouraging meditation, journaling, easier access to therapy, and such methods, so that people won't feel like they have to cope with their suffering in life with pleasure, whether it be from meat, cigarettes, or something else that serves the same purpose in their lives.
About destruction of forest for farmlands: it's not just for creating beef farms, but also to grow the spy and cereals needed to feed all the cattle. So eating meat will also increase beef feed production. So all those people saying "soy is also farmed over destroyed forests" are right, but the majority of that soy goes to cows and meat animals

This is complicated inded. I mean the attempts to reduce emissions. Being alive is causing emissions anyway, so the most effective solution would be a suicide. Of course, this is a ridiculous extremum and we need to find a compromise.  Choising a type of food we eat is one of them but I wonder how much emissions we would reduce if for example we would stop watching (and making) movies. And in general all entertainment and lesure industry - It's not necessary for the survival so theoretically we could resign from it.  And what about traveling? How much would we reduce emissions if we would only do the travels that are essential for our existence? for example: we could spend our holidays only within walking/biking distance from home.   Let's go further - no art, no sport, no communication over a longer distance. No food processing over the basic one that makes it eatable. Use one set of clothing until it falls apart. Otherwise this is all unnecessary emissions from the perspective of humanity phisical survival.  ... Unfortunately this is also our civilization, our culture, our lifestyle and identity. So we have to make decisions, resign from less important things, keep those that means more to us. For those that we keep, look for the solutions to reduce the impact on environment. And the food is just one of the things we have to deal with. We don't need to resign entirely from high emission products, instead reduce their amount that we eat. And what important, concentrate on avoiding food waste, because the highest rate of emissions per calorie is from the food that we don't eat and just through away.

Isn't the comparison at 9:35 a bit deceptive and dishonest? You're comparing a co2 removed over 100 years to co2 gained per year. At a quick glance, the graph implies that removing 800 billion tonnes of co2 is a great improvement compared to today's emissions, but that's not necessarily true. Make the co2 emissions every 100 years and it's 50,000 billion tonnes emitted, which looks worse.

To think that the ecological problem is limited to CO2 emissions is to ignore a large part of the problem. We shouldn't just focus on that. For example: the land used for intensive breeding becomes completely sterile, impossible to grow anything on it for years. This is also pollution. The waste rejected by these factories (cow excrement which is harmful to the environment if present in large quantities and stuffed with chemicals, etc.) is released directly into nature and destroys rivers and groundwater. This is also pollution. And these are just a few examples. (Oh, and wanting to raise cows in areas that humans cannot monetize to do something is neither a solution nor an argument. The planet does not belong to us and it is not because a corner of the earth does not serve us that it serves no one, even less that we can monopolize it).  To think that, CO2 emissions = pollution, is true. But pollution = CO2 emissions is wrong and that misses a big part of the problem.  But it would take a much longer video if not several to deal with the subject in its entirety. Gut video anyway ЁЯСН.

I looked at your sources because I was wondering about your statement on long journeys which would be more environmentally friendly than short circuits. The calculations seem biased to me. let me explain :   To calculate the environmental impact by taking into account only the carbon footprint and only by comparing local transport with transport by plane or container are two mistakes. Why ? Because international transport does not stop at planes and ships but also before and then all transport by truck, from the producer to the port (perhaps with an intermediary) then from the port to another then from the port of arrival to seller (with perhaps an intermediary). In addition, longer journeys spatially can also be temporally longer, which implies specific techniques and technologies to preserve food over such a long time. The packaging may be reinforced and may also require additions to the products themselves.

The methane from a cow is enclosed within a loop. When the feed is eaten, the methane is released into the atmosphere and then reqbsorbed by the growing feed. Therefore all the methane produced from cows goes back into the environment (rather) neatly.

Great video as always, but you are missingt one critical point:  PLANTS DO NOT CONSUME CO2  They can temporarily bind some carbon in their bodies, but when the plant dies, the carbon gets released right back. The whole animal vs plant food conversation requires willfully ignoring the actual elephant in the room.  Overpopulation, and how it only gets worse with every passing year.  There's this na├пve idea that by removing animal based food, we will magically "save" CO2 emissions, when we are projected to increase our overall population by 25% by 2050.  This is before even accounting for the reality that a lot of our current population isn't even using 1st world levels of CO2 emissions, but WILL eventually seek to do so via industrialization.  At best, most of the schemes for reducing emissions cause a reduction in standard of living, while just kicking the can down the road a decade or two, until population growth erases any "gains" you made.  We either innovate our way out of the problem (probably some form of nuclear powered carbon capture scheme), or we somehow convince the world at large to drastically scale back it's population.   Assuming we actually want everyone to experience the comfortable life of say, middle class america, we are already well beyond the earth's carrying capacity of 2 billion or so for that level of lifestyle.  Even if we somehow resolve pollution/emissions, we are going to have a rough time past 2050, due to widespread depletion of easily obtainable phosphorous.  Which is critical for the industrialized farming that sustains our current population.

I think that the majority of the calculations for carbon footprint on food are biased. its simple mass balance calculation. for every kg of cereals that you fed to the animal you actually fix a huge amount of CO2 producing that cereals in the first place. The crops are also carbon fixers, the cattle do not grow on  antiobiotics only you know? the plants fix CO2 as part of their photosintetic process and that CO2 fixed by the plant are fixed in the animal fat and so on. the calculation is biased because they only take into account the total ammount of CO2e of the cattle but this cattle is eating grass and cereals that already fixed CO2 from the atmosphere in the first place. Its more complicated than just point out some paper that makes only part of the cycle calculation, you need to see the entire cycle as a whole and determine if the actual balance of that specific cycle is accumulationg more CO2e on some part or are just in balance. for fast natural cycles I think the balance is near to zero, in some cases a little positive sometimes a little negative. the actual problem is to put CO2 that comes from a slow cycle in a fast cycle, the use of fossil fuels is an example of that, they came from a slow cycle and are used very intensively, so intesive that the natural cycle cannot fix the CO2 equally fast and then there is the accumulation on some part of the cycle. the CO2e balance in earth is almost zero, (not taking into account space dust) so in reality the road to zero emmisions is imposible. the actual objective is first reach the fixing CO2 state process (to balance the actual accumulation of CO2 in the atmosphere) and then gradually reach the balance. This is the core of sustainability, do things that involves enter in an existing balanced cycle and be able to be in the cycle without disturbing the entire process. We all need to read more about sustainability in order to have better arguments for CO2 and global warming related topics. This is my personal point of view. I'm a chemical engineer specialized in process design BTW, we encounter a lot of misunderstanding in the interpretation of chemical process all the time, mainly in understanding the maximum principle of chemical reactions and cycles: In a chemical reaction, matter is neither created nor destroyed - Antoine Lavoiser-.

I really enjoy you channel, but as an agronomist, I canтАЩt avoid to say that some informations are quite biased. To say that in Brazil theyтАЩre burning forests to produce pastire is quite a exaggeration. The local enviromental laws assure that in rainforest areas, only to 20% of your total area can be used to farmland. The burning areas come from SOME illegal burnings and most of the time, from natural causes due to dry seasons with prolongued times. Other is to say that vegan diets will reduce the carbon emission, which is a lie. As the vegetable production will require more volume per square hectare, to saciate the hunger of one human, youтАЩll need more produced mass. In global scale of meat projibition, youтАЩll eventually require thousands if not millions of extra farming land to saciate the same hunger, and even then youтАЩll need to supply humans with some nutrients you can only obtain throuh animal consumption.

welp, time to question my diet for the 5th time this year.
The main issue I have with the emissions attributed to livestock is that they have to extract carbon from their environment in order to grow. They can never emit more carbon than what goes into them, so there can't be a net increase of carbon into the cycle. The only way to add carbon to the cycle is to release that which has been sequestered for a long period of time, which is usually done by the burning of fossil fuels or deforestation. While those emissions come into play during the raising of livestock, they aren't direct emissions from the animal itself and could theoretically be reduced to zero with technological advancements.  Is the argument then, that each livestock animal is essentially transferring carbon biomass from plants into carbon dioxide and methane faster than new plants can grow, thereby reducing the total amount of plant biomass on the planet to increase the gaseous carbon in the atmosphere? If that's the case, isn't every animal doing the same thing simply by existing and contributing to the consumption of plant life? If that's the case, eliminating livestock won't solve the issue, they only make up ~4% of the animal biomass on the planet, which leaves a lot of animals that still need to eat. If the same land is used to raise the same amount of livestock (including in this the land that is used to grow additional food for the livestock), and it can do so indefinitely with proper management, there should be no net carbon emissions from the animal itself.  Therefore the only increase of carbon in the system has to come from activities surrounding the raising of livestock, which can be reduced to 0 if no more land is cleared and we can create zero net emission transportation and other things that provide for the raising of livestock.   I'm sure there are plenty of holes in my ramble and I know that tackling climate change will require us to find novel solutions to a great many challenges. I just don't think 'cows be fartin' is an viable explanation that warrants the total elimination of meat from our diets.

This video is misleading due to false equivalences. Comparing CO2e emissions from food to fossil fuels is wrong. CO2e emission sources should be categorised and compared as such. For example sorting them into reversible, irreversible and cyclic.   A reversible example from your sources would be: "Converting that land released a lot of carbon into the atmosphere. All those historical emissions sum up to about 1400 billion tonnes of CO2. Therefore, we could technically regrow forests and put a big chunk of that 1400 billion tonnes of CO2 back into vegetation, with diet changes or improvements in farming practices."   Irreversible is burning fossil fuels. (Ignoring carbon capture technology)  Cyclic is simply sources that fall into the carbon cycle. (Nitrous oxide has atmospheric half life of 114 years and methane of 12 years)  All these categories have an impact on the climate but should be treated differently (*Note: I am unsure of how to phrase the justification apart from how they are defined and how we should look at solutions to problems caused by them). Statements such as: "Actually, transport and packaging combined are only about 11% of all food emissions." have compared all three categories. Statements such as "We can emit only another 1405 billion tonnes until 2100 in order to keep the temperature rise below 2┬░C with a 67% chance. If we were to keep the annual food emissions for another 80 years, we would emit 1356 Gt in total until 2100." are also unclear of the type of emissions which are being talked about, as just above that you have stated the 1400 billion tonnes is reversible.   I also have a problem with 'net' carbon emission due to possible blurring of the source of carbon. I love your videos, but this one seemed kinda...manipulative. I generally agree that people should try to eat less meat, I eat meat myself and try to eat less of it. The amount of resources dedicated to farming meat could be spent on just growing cereals, which keep longer, and since they don't have to go through an animal, we would retain more energy. Solving world hunger and reducing consumption of meat IMO go hand in hand. I agree and accept most of the statistics being presented in the video. But, there were some things that I noticed which I find disingenuous. The most prominent example I noticed is at @9:20.   "If we spared 3 billion hectares of land, we could remove 800 billion tonnes of CO2, over 100 years. By comparison, we emit about 50 billion tonnes per year"  800 tonnes of CO2 over 100 years is 8 tonnes of CO2 per year that we would be able to reduce. So what that means is, if we swap to an entirely vegan diet (that was the condition for 3 billion instead of 2 billion of free space), we would reduce out CO2 footprint by 8 tonnes per year, out of 50. Don't get me wrong, 8/50 is close to 20% and a 20% reduction in our carbon footprint is incredibly significant and a lot of people would find it worthwhile to pursue.  But the graphics they chose to show were 100% misleading and  made it seem like swapping to a vegan diet would remove 800/50 times the amount of CO2. Why show the two graphs side by side when 1 has a timeframe of a 100 years while the other has a timeframe of 1? Thats manipulative and taken right out of the book "How to Lie with Statistics". You don't need to manipulate the graphics to push a narrative, the truth of a 20% reduction in emissions is already extremely good, who wouldn't think that was a good outcome? There's no need to put the number 800 besides 50 to make us feel like swapping to a vegan diet has a much bigger impact that it actually would.

For instance i bought a meat package from a farmer who buys/adopts young bulls from the dairy industry that otherwise would be killed and discarted because they are a breed that is not fast growing so not wanted by the beef industry, they raise them for 2 or 3 years on grass only and then butcher them for the meat. It is more expensive but locally grown and only fed grass from their own pasture.     And what was not mentioned in the video is that raising cattle in the field with manure and urine going directly on the field saves a lot of methane in the atmosphere because of the actions with Hydroxyl radical that are formed by photolysis of water on the fields they walk on, that particle reacts with Methane and breaks it down into  H2o and CH3  and reacts with things like Nitrus Oxide or Oxigen from there on to more harmless gasses and CO2.

My main question for these statistics is where does the carbon come from? It's coming out of the herbaceous plants and soil, which receive their carbon from the air. So are these numbers out of cycle carbon emissions like fossil fuels or in cycle? Because I think in cycle carbon emissions can be safely ignored, which is why I'm skeptical of many claims made about food production emissions, even plant based foods. I'm certain beef has more out of cycle emissions than feeding a human corn and soy, but are both far lower than estimated?

One suggestion I've heard for greening-up Beef production is shifting from feeding cows grasses like corn to feeding them seaweed, which has been demonstrated to result in much less methane (because it's easier for them to digest).  I don't know if it's remotely feasible to farm seaweed at the kind of scale we'd need to replace the crops we currently feed them, but that definitely seems like a possibility worth studying - if it would work, we'd have the added benefit of reducing the amount of land needed for crops.

While picking up stuff for Thanksgiving dinner last week, I was struck by how crazy it is that I have such a wide, varied selection of high-quality food just five minutes from where I live, available year-round and 24 hours a day, for honestly a very small price relative to my personal means.  As someone who's both hunted and grown my own produce, it's no trivial thing.  Human society simply wouldn't exist without organized and highly-developed systems for producing and distributing food; it's at the very core of who we are as a species.  My only gripe with this video is that the comparison at 9:21 is a tiny bit misleading and could have used 10 seconds or so more playtime to put things in context, but it's not that hard to pause the video for a couple seconds to digest it.  Personally, I've been cutting back on meats - especially beef and processed meats - quite a bit over the last few years since learning these and other facts.  Partly for the environment, partly for health (my iron levels tend to run high and heavy consumption of processed meats has been linked to health problems in the long term).  No plans at all to go full vegetarian or vegan; I still enjoy me a good burger or steak on occasion.  But moving red meat & sausage from a dietary staple to an occasional treat really wasn't that tough to do.

Especially if it's just being given to all livestock rather than targeted at individual animals. Wondering about lab grown meat. We know it's not even close to sustainable now but could it be? What kind of challenges would there be to implementing this on a global scale assuming we have the technology?
FDA website states that the number of livestock has only increased by 5% since the 40s. What's different is farming methods and cattle feed that has increased beef yield with minimal increase in methane emissions. Methane breaks down into CO2 after decades, and plants take the CO2 to build cellulose cells and carbs which cattle and humans consume. It's a closed loop  where no new carbon is introduced, if you don't count the idiot governments allowing the burning of forests for more farmland in developing nations.  Think about it logically. Cows fart methane, where does the carbon in methane come from? Plants! And where do plants get carbon? From CO2, during the day, and plants release O2 in return. Humans exhale CO2, where does the carbon come from? Our food! It's a closed loop.  What we should focus on is fossil fuel which releases millenia old carbon back into the atmosphere. I sincerely believe this is all actually big oil drumming up a scapegoat to divert attention away from this fact. Millions of tonnes of crude oil that has remained safely sequestered underground now gets pumped up and burnt for energy. This is not a closed loop.
What exactly is the best beef though? Should we go for 100% grass fed, or the cheapest factory farmed beef? The video seems indecisive on this point as they both have their upsides. But there's got to be something you used as the benchmark for that ultra low beef carbon number, what is it?

Most of the food used to feed cattle is corn. However, the carbon flux for cropland (including corn) is a net emission of 9.4 metric tons of CO2 per 100 acres, compared with the carbon flux of grassland with a net sink of 1.4 tons of CO2 per 100 acres. That's the reason why holistically planned grazing has been proposed as a viable alternative.

I object: You are bordering on the "false cause fallacy" when you attribute the destruction of forests/land use solely to farming. Other forms of human expansion contribute to that, and some contribute quite a bit. I would like numbers to see how much farming land use has expanded compared to other things. This objection is not meant to imply the argument is wrong (that would be the fallacy fallacy if I did that), just that is weaker than it could be otherwise.  so what's the solution? Let's be honest: a plant-based diet is dramatically superior in the modern world. It's healthier, it's cheaper to produce both in terms of natural resources and money, and it has less environmental impact. You can hedge around these facts with your "whataboutisms" all you would like, but every single statistic supports these facts. Eating animal products is about the taste and nothing else. Those who consume animal products are trading off all of the advantages of a plant-based diet for a taste experience. Even the argument about animals turning crops we can't eat (grasslands) into food we can falls flat when you consider that if animal agriculture was wiped from the planet tomorrow and all of the land used for grazing was left fallow, we would still be able to produce THREE TIMES enough plant-based food to feed the ENTIRE world (i.e. every single person) with just the arable land and technology that we have RIGHT NOW, largely because we would be able to use the land for "feed crops" to produce human-consumable crops. I know that Kurzgesagt works hard to produce a balanced, science-based approach to big questions, but the answer to this one is actually very simple based on data that we have collected for decades: meat really is that bad, and we should stop consuming it immediately. Does this mean that we should send jack-booted thugs around to take away all the hamburgers? Of course not. However, that doesn't change the answer to the question.

8:20 I suspect this to be somewhat false. Yes, we feed cattle with crops that we harvest, but I'm pretty sure that's mainly the part of the crop that we don't eat. We eat the seeds/corn on the crops, but the rest of the crops is pretty much just grass that we would throw away. That type of unedible grass from the crops is what we mostly feed animals with (I'm pretty sure at least).
Great information here, as always! I would love to see something about hunting in the future. I live rurally, where hunting, fishing, gardening, and even foraging for things like berries and mushrooms is part of our lives, and I'm curious how much of a difference is made by harvesting directly from nature. I imagine it must be significant! I'd also like to mention that rabbit is one of the most sustainable meats as far as farm raised animals go. They eat almost exclusively dried grass, their poop is fantastic natural fertilizer, they grow and reproduce quickly, and they take up very little space (even when kept totally ethically). It's a shame they're so cute - that's the only reason we don't see them in grocery stores!

I think an important part of the discussion around beef that was left out is desertification. we know that grasslands can be regenerated and deserts turned to grasslands by properly managing and herding cattle. this is largely caused by seasonal migrations of the animals, in a similar pattern to what exists with wildebeests or used to exist in the great plains with the huge herds of bison. they redistribute the nutrients from the grass and the seeds as well, in addition to feeding the vvarious other animals in the area, like predators, bugs, and all that. so where we have food deserts emerging next to factory farmed animals in a tighly controlled space, we see the evidence that in general that there is a mismanagement of the animals and land. properly managing cattle to reverse desertification could massively offset the carbon cost of cattle in the first place and regenerate ecosystems which act as carbon sinks

You forgot to consider that buying locally also effects the demand for factory products, including meat.  So it doesn't just effect transportation and packaging, but also production.   The effect would vary depending on how many switch to local, but I don't think the difference would be huge.  Nevertheless, that should also be considered when analyzing if buying local could actually lower emissions.  Also, it wasn't clear whether open pasture cows actually emit more methane than factory cows (which is more pertinent to global warming than whether open pasture is a good use against the factory).  Also, perhaps the concentration of methane within a small location must effect the environment very differently than an area such as an open pasture.  The latter could potentially be trapped or cycled through the environment more efficiently.. I dont see why buying local wouldn't have a positive, meaningful effect on lower emissions.

But crops and animals are part of the carbon cycle in the atmosphere. So that part of the carbon and methane were always there, even before humans existed. Methane production largely depends on the cow (and other species producing emissions) populations on the planet. If we stopped eating meat we'd lower carbon emissions, by a fixed and constant amount, when we eventually reach the next carbon cycle equilibrium. This won't clear the carbon emissions produces by burning fossil fuels.    The real problem are carbon emissions due to fossil fuels. They were not in the atmosphere before we started burning them. Burning fossil fuels even at a constant or decreasing rate accumulates carbon emissions because they are not part of the natural carbon cycle on the planet and there is no equilibrium point. Carbon emission will just grow indefinitely or at least until we mine all deposits.  Reforestation is not a complete solution either. Those new trees become part of the carbon cycle and they'll lower the carbon emissions by a fixed constant amount when the new equilibrium point is reached.   While I do agree that going vegan or at least drastically reducing meat consumption and reforestation will help in the short term (20-100 years) those are not real solutions. The real solution is to stop burning fossil fuels. But we can't do that because right now there is no alternative. We are very far from producing all our electricity in a Eco-friendly manner. Again I think a short term solution here is probably nuclear power and long term solution would be wind, tidal and solar power.

9:33 It seems like a really misleading comparison to show how much carbon is saved over 100 years versus how much is produced in one year. I realize this doesn't automatically invalidate the point being made, but it's a very, very bad chart, and way below Kurzgesagt's usual high quality presentation.
Why don't you consider fish and fish farming in this? Or insect farming? I'm just curious. It isn't just meat-eating or veganism. An increasing amount of people are eating a Mediterranean/pescetarian diet that makes use of fish as the main protein source. There are studies that show that crickets are one of the most eco-friendly sources of protein. Farmed salmon is less calorie dense than beef, but it can be better for you in the long run because it has lower levels of unsaturated fats and higher levels of omega-3 fatty acids. Tilapia grow very quickly and contain high levels of protein. Fish farming doesn't come without its own environmental risks (land usage, crop usage, runoff, etc), but it's far less than meat. Insect farming is incredibly efficient and cricket farming could easily scale to the point that cricket flour becomes an incredibly efficient way to provide calories and nutrients. You very briefly touched on the fact that potatoes take a lot less carbon to make, but you didn't mention at all that potatoes contain most of the nutrients a person needs to live, and that a person can satisfy most of their nutritional requirements by eating potatoes, black beans, and fortified grains, all of which are very low in carbon emissions. They don't have to eat fancy soy-based meat substitutes. Plenty of vegans and vegetarians eat beans, potatoes, and fortified rice and cereals and have healthy balanced diets. Many people in cultures all around the world eat mostly beans and rice as staples of their diets and have for centuries. You leave so much out in these videos that it's starting to feel deceptive to me. I wonder if it's even possible to have this entire discussion in 10 minutes at all and if you're not acutely aware of that. You leave out so much in the name of making a succinct balanced argument that fits into 10 minutes that it's almost disinformation for how narrow it makes the topic seem. Why do you even bother making these videos to "inform people" if you don't actually inform them of anything substantial? Most of what's in this video is stuff people who are interested in this topic will either already know or can easily find out with a few google searches.

Big gaping gap in your logic. I was a vegetarian for 30 years, a vegan for the last year and a half of that. In spite of putting a lot of work into making it as well-balanced as I could, I still ended up severely malnourished. It turns out I have a number of genetic issues that interfere with my metabolism of some nutrients, especially plant-based nutrients. I become deficient in taurine, vitamin A, Omega 3 fats, among others. And I'm not alone. At least one in five people have some of the same genetics. Different cultures have had different diets which has influenced what foods they're able to eat and which they can't do without. Being a vegetarian is not an option for me any more. There's also a seemingly large amount of talk about how preserving forests will be the main key to reducing CO2 and preventing more carbon emission. There is no acutaly change in the level of carbon emission until something is done with the deforested land, and contrary to popular belief, forests are horrible carbon sinks. The amount of detritus, decomposition, decay, and animal life CO2 emission offsets the carbon sink properties almost entirely. Notably, this is mitigated if we are talking about "new forest" as opposed to old forest. But for this to be a viable means of carbon capture, deforestation wouldn't be the answer. Clearing forests and replanting would be.

"Cattle raised on a factory farm that never get to roam pastures" You guys are honestly dangerously misrepresenting the organization and structure of factory farms. There is literally no way to raise cattle without pastures. They're often raised on Cow/calf lots which are in fact pastures where the cattle roam for up to 2 years before being sent to a finishing lot, which is the "factory farm" of your derogation. They rarely spend less than 2 months there and are only kept longer if it is harder to get them fat enough for eating. If cattle weren't allowed to roam pasture, they would never build up the muscle that composes the meat source. PLEASE do your research and stop denigrating factory farms based off of malinformed and subpar knowledge about the industry. You are ACTIVELY misinforming people.

Something like 30% of soy is digestible by humans, rest is waste which we cannot do anything with. Also things like distilled grain, its a byproduct of alcohol production, once again, its not fit for human consumption but cattle love it.

Point 3 I like how you included the fact that non-arable land is used by cows to convert inedible grass into edible beef...  However, the point about cereals and food crops going towards feed for cows was disingenuous - cows are not eating the 'human edible' parts of the plants (such as the wheat ear); rather they are consuming the in-edible parts (such as straw and husks) that humans wouldn't be able to eat regardless.  Has anyone who did the research for these figures ever worked in the dairy or meat industry?

WAIT, THERE'S MORE!  1. When you calculate recovered land from giving up meat or going full vegan, you are not considering that people don't just stop eating those foods, they need to REPLACE the nutrients they used to get from it with something else. How much land is needed to produce the crops that will be replacing the meat that isn't produced? Since these vegetables are not as efficiently digested (we're not ruminants), humans need more too (edit: supplements and vitamins go here too).  2. Several people are having success recovering barren land via grazing rotation. No heavy smog-emitting machinery, just heavy animals who produce fertilizer as a byproduct, animals who do not turn into forever-junk when their time is up like a tractor (we already have uses for every last hair). This looks to be as important as crop rotation, but is not widespread yet.

Great content! It would be interesting to have a similar video about food from the ocean with algae, fish and mussels and their ecological impact.  Thanks for all the awesome videos!
Your explanation of the transport of food via oceanic shipping misses the complete supply chain. The complete supply chain must include the transportation to local shops, within the destination countries. That increases the emissions by combining both shipping methods, ships to transport the food across the ocean and trucks to deliver the food to local destinations. Thus, buying locally in fact has less carbon impact than having food shipped from other countries.

it pisses me off how you talk about "how much crops are used to feed animals" but yet don't talk about the rule of 10%. WHY no one does that?  anyway, if you're reading this let me explain that rule. basically an ecosystem is seen as "storage" of "biomass" (in other words, different kind of foods for different kind of steps in the food chain) for example, growing 1kg of grass or for example potatoes or carrots doesnt' take much else than just a heck ton of carbon, a bunch of water, free sun light and a spoonful of mixed minerals (talking about a life in an equilibrated ecosistem that doesn't require fertilizers) but for example, to grow one kilo of hervivore meat (such as the cows) you need to feed them 10 kgs of plant matter and if we want to feed a human exclusibly on meat so he/she can grow and live his life... well, 1 kg of human meat would require10 kg of animal meat which in return is 100kg of plant matter...   and the same goes for fish, a white tuna feeds on other fish and moluscs, it's carnivore and can reach weights  of 200kg, 200kg of carnivorous fish require 2 TONS of other fish, which in return is 20 TONS of placton/algae. 20 tons of algae will only produce 20 kgs of human meat, if you go to the carnivore route, however the hervivore route only takes 200kg of algae/plancton (if we could feed on it without risking our health lol). i know it may sound a bit morbid but well, just think about a kid growing.   you get the idea... that's basically the only reason we need so sooo much crops and most importantly crop space to feed the animals,.

There's something I think is an important factor in this discussion: I, and many others I know, would be quite happy to go meatless if a couple conditions were met: if the meat-substitutes available to me were equal to meat in taste/texture and were the same or a lower price? I'd happily quit buying meat and instead buy meat-like-substances. Price is a powerful incentive, if you can offer really tasty plant-based meat substitutes for a way lower price than the real deal, people will make the choice on their own. . The important factors on a replacement are user experience (needs to be so good an imitation that a casual enjoyer can't tell the difference), and price (needs to be substantially cheaper than meat to compete strongly).

But wouldnтАЩt freeing the land not used for more trees and grasslands increase the oxygen in the atmosphere and lead to larger insect growth since their size is tied to the oxygen content? IтАЩm sure people donтАЩt want another Carboniferous period of giant insects again in the modern day.
There is one other factor that was not taken into account in this video. Our population (approaching 8 billion) is making it ever increasingly difficult to produce enough food to sustain it. We will likely need to continue raising animals to help feed the World's population. However, there are ways to go about this more efficiently and additionally, 1st world populations should really focus on consuming less calories in their diets. It may be that a smaller meat component to diets will be the proper way to go along with careful focus of using marginal lands to raise smaller herds of animals. Before anyone chirps in and says that we should thin the human population out, please tell me, who gets to decide who lives or dies and just how do you think you would be able to contain the "culling" to a specific portion of the population without causing massive social unrest and perhaps even more death and destruction? No, we have nearly 8 billion people on this planet and we have to learn how to help ALL of them.

Dear Kurzgesagt,  Great video and well researched!  I would like to add a little info on the beef that may be interesting.  In Denmark there's a concept where environmental organisations or individual enclaves buy some cows to keep down the grass on natural land with low nutrients.  The good thing here is that the cows serve the purpose of keeping these areas with a high biological diversity. It is a tad along the same idea as "rewilding" although in case, the animals gets slaughtered by the end of the season.  For sure the carbon footprint here is also high, but the cows serve a vital function for the bogs and meadows.  In many cases these animals does not receive addional feed. They usually thus produce less meat at the end.   I'm not arguing whether to eat or not,  but I thought it was a curious detail.
I understand that  meat generates immense co┬▓ but I have to eat it as culture and religion I can't do that?

When the question of whether we should give up animal husbandry for the sake of the planet or not, we need to ask ourselves two simple questions. 1. Is it possible to make tasty pancakes using milk other than cow's milk? 2. Is it possible to make Ruthenian dumplings without using cottage cheese? As long as the answers to these questions are "no", the earth can fuck itself.
How does driving a truck across town produce TWENTY KG of co2??? Even if 100% of fuel was converted into co2, thats still more mass than fuel used, and is impossible.
In NZ dairy cows take all the fertile flat lands near rivers. We call them "dairy flats" they go onto hill country, or partial "barn raised " feed pads in winter more and more now. So they are using huge amounts of arable land in NZ and also fertilizing so heavily that we have fertilisers that have leached into the rivers that water our major cities especially Auckland. That nitrate level will rise for decades even though farmers riparian plant and reduce their nitrate use now because it is coming from old nitrate reaching the aquafer.   By contrast beef cattle are on the hills, although that land could also do other things but less intensively.
One important part you didn't mention: altering your diet doesn't change how much meat gets produced unless you also change several millions of other diets, which reasonably is very hard to do. But it's also reasonable why you might not have mentioned it, since what little impact this video makes would become zero if you mentioned it.

Interesting how we say food is the problem. Aren't too many people the problem? It would seem to me if people were to have fewer children, we could all eat whatever we wanted. If a couple has only one child, they effectively reduce the world's population by one. Having no children reduces it by two. Having two children maintains the population. Having three, and the population grows by one. It used to be we worried about having enough food for the growing population, but now it would seem due to the amount we need, our food may kill us. The ideal scenario is that we anticipate our environmental problems instead of reacting to them. A simple change in the amount of children we each have would gradually return this planet to homeostasis. That should be obvious to everyone.

I'm honestly very skeptical about the "farting cows" part. In pre-colonial times, North America was inhabited by some 30-60mil wild bisons, which were pretty much cows. Today the population of domestic cows in the US is around 93mil. So if the fart rate of a bison is approximately the same as that of a domestic cow, we will get x2 rate of cow farts on average comparing 1500s to 2000s, which doesn't feel that significant. It's important to note that hunter gatherers were more hunter than gatherer. It's very easy to support a population of a few hundred thousand than a few billion., so we are now running into a problem that there are so many animals being reared for meat that it is causing huge climate damage from grazing, and global warming from methane production. Question- Aren't cows and other livestock carbon neutral?  My initial answer to this question is YES. From my understanding, livestock cant produce more carbon then they consume. This is more or less supported by every conservation law in physics and engineering [conservation of mass and energy, ect]. If a material balance was done on the process, the carbon released must be equal to the carbon consumed. In fact, more carbon is consumed then released due to accumulation of carbon inside living organisms ( AKA they grow and sustain themselves). When this process becomes carbon positive is when we consider human interactions. This begs the question, Why is the consumption of meat and other natural resources the focuses of climate change when their inefficiencies are entirely contributed to the inefficiencies of Human society. I feel like saying "Cow farts are a big contributor to climate change" is missing the point. Cows themselves cant be more than carbon natural and only when human interaction is consider does it change to carbon positive. Kind of feels like this argument is focusing on the symptom rather then the Cause. That being the introduction of more carbon into the atmosphere that was not apart of the carbon cycle.  This is something I have been contemplating for some time and this video gives me the perfect opportunity to ask. I feel that looking at climate change through this lens helps separate the bullshit from the actual solutions. If I'm misunderstanding anything or missing any key information please let me know and Thanks for another great video that resulted in me questioning my thoughts and assumptions.

There are a few things I believe are worth mentioning. 1. Switching to pure-grass fed doesn't mean less beef. If you allow the feed crops to die and don't replant them, they can be replaced with native grasses, which cattle can graze on. You could also plant a small amount trees here with minimal cost to the amount of grass. If they produce food, then it becomes a small bonus to production. In other words, restore the natural savanas. The selfish argument for this is that then you can get grass fed beef. The selfless is so that emissions from cattle and harvesting are reduced, and there are also plants to remove carbon from the atmosphere. 2. A tofu burger actually kills *more* animals than a grass fed beef burger. As counter-intuitive as that is, even without pesticides, when harvest time comes, there are a lot of animals in the farmland. They could be birds, frogs, or many little bugs. When the combine rolls through, they have two options: run or die. If they run, they live in a disrupted environment, and disrupt wherever they wind up. If they die, well, they die. A grass fed burger only kills one cow. If the cow accidentally eats an aphid, oh well. That's the circle of life. 3. Today, the harvesting combine produces emissions when harvesting, which even if this isn't any more than that produced by cattle on the same amount of acres, it's still worth factoring in.

There are some wildly incorrect statistics here, for example the best beef in the world тАЬarguable of courseтАЭ come from a farm in Georgia, White Oak Pastures and the LCA (life cycle assessment) shows their beef is negative to a factor of 3.5 or purchasing 3.5 lbs of the beef means the equivalent of 3.5lb of carbon sequestered. Also without large ruminant animals on the landscape specifically prairies the land will degrade, retain less water, and become more prone to fire. For anyone interested please take a look at Holistic Planned Grazing or Adaptive Multipaddock grazing. Regenerative Ag and Permaculture practices demonstrate solutions to this perceived issue. What needs to be done is change all farming practices to be inclusive of and a benefit to the surrounding environment. All chemical and synthetic ag needs to be phased out and a large focus on soil health needs to be our global focus.

odd question but has Kurzgesagt тАУ In a Nutshell considered these 3 points when weighing the healthiness of cows for the planet?  It is not terrible if you haven't, just wanted to know. ps: it would be nice to see a future video on the impact of "no-till" practices on carbon emissions since you have made this video on farming. thanks.  -In the consideration of the carbon footprint of meat, farming practices used too feed cattle account for up to 83% of the total emissions.  -Electric tractors would only be able to help if "no till" techniques are implemented, soil that has been "torn open" by  plows releases most of the carbon that the grassland or crops have drawn out of the atmosphere back into it.  -No plow techniques also leave farmland that would lie bear part of the year suitably covered with vegetation for "near wild" grazing. While also reducing the need for nitrogen fertilizers and other high-carbon ways of increasing crop yield.
I hate this explanation because, feeding lots use grains, which produces more gas in cows (more methane). Grass fed cows produce less gas (methane) because cows can digest them better. Also localization is better because shipping containers produce more pollution and oil. Trucks produce less than big boats, and they travel in a less distance than shipping containers. In general those are very big misunderstandings that you made.    Edit I found out methane takes up about 11 percent of global pollution. The methane in the air gets turned into carbon and might get absorbed by plants, and grass.
I dont think its realistic to think people will give up beef any time soon, but I do think that its possible to deal with the extra emissions as a whole. nature has answers im sure, its been doing it for hundreds of millions of years.
One thing that you didn't mention, to my surprise, is the population of livestock. When you point out the counterproductivity of grassfed animals, you didnt mention that it's due to keeping the population (from factory farming to grassfed) the same. I.e. (100 grassfed cows produce more methane and require more land than 100 factory farmed cows). The high number of animals transitioning to a different farming method only sustains demand, but if the goal is to reduce greenhouse emissions, wouldn't the idea be to switch to grass fed AND reduce the population of livestock (ultimately people would have to eat less beef)?

A quick note on the whole "cows turn useful the useless lands". I think that it should be questioned what counts as useful, what we can exploit directly for money? The Amazon is extremely hostile, it's horrible for planting we can barely hold a road together there and lots of it is unhabited. BUT the forest regulates the climate. Not just like in a global warming we'll day someday in the future way, it literally regulates rain in a relatively short-term. The southeast of Brazil, where I live, is already starting to feel the effects of deforestation with intense draughts, which are already bad enough even excluding the fact that we use hydroelectricity and now are plunging into a energy crisis that is forcing the reopening of thermoelectricity   Edit: Jesus Christ... Here, I hope this can clear things up: I'm not being combative towards the video or the channel, I just was expanding on a topic they brought up to initiate a discussion about it. I'm not saying they referred to the Amazon on that part either, I'm using the Amazon as an example to demonstrate that land can be useful for us as a species without it having resources we can directly extract for it (like food in the example they brought)

Great overview of meat's impact on CO2eq emissions, but greenhouse emissions aren't even the worst part of meat's environmental impact. Animal agriculture is the leading driver of species extinction, land use, water use, coastal dead zones, habitat destruction, oceanic plastic pollution, and potentially of antibiotic resistance among dangerous bacteria.
No matter what anyone tells, history does not lie. When industrial era started, the emissions went up. So, anything that uses a machine, will contribute to CO2. Now THIS is the kind of content that will push science towards better solutions for the entire world. Kudos, Kurzgesagt. You guys are ACTUALLY doing gods work.
People never seem to bring up that there are a whole lot of things that can only be found in meat (for the most part), and tons of stuff that is in high quantity in meat. Protein is in everything that lives, you could go around drinking sewage and you'd still be fine for protein; same for every macro-nutrient, they're in everything. The issue are micro-nutrients, plenty of which only exist in meat or don't exist in large enough numbers in plants. Vitamin B12, for example, is found in abundance in animal products but can only be gotten from Shiitake mushrooms, seaweed, and tempeh if you avoid meat; meaning you have to consider the environmental impacts of growing these foods, not just grains.  We tried eating nothing but grains before, everybody got rickets and then we discovered nutritional science and stopped doing it. We should be trying to considerably reduce meat consumption, as even 100g daily is more than enough to get basically everything you need, but going full vegan will cause major issues; as well either start developing society wide health problems, or run into the myriad issues of trying to grow so many exotic plants in such quantity.
This is what vegan try hard to tell everyone. Thanks a lot Kurzgesagt.

"Isn't farming animals just a smart to make the best use of unused resources?" Of course it is, if you think like a psychopath, it surely is!
You are forgetting an important thing here: - organic farming without temporary prairies is extremely difficult. Say, alfalfa, or clover prairies that are planted to last a few years (3 to 5) to clean up your land of weeds, by reaping and harvesting the prairie very often, kill annual weeds before they have the time to produce their seeds, thus allowing you to remove heavy competition for your crops, as well as lowering the pressure of viruses and insects on your field (since said temporary prairies are not subjected to the same pests and diseases as other crops). This means that you end up with lots of alfalfa or clover hay, which can be used to feed animals, and in turn gives you lots of manure to fertilise your fields. Organic systems do and will rely a lot on animal farming, that is unavoidable, and saves farmers having to use pesticides, which in turn improve the environment as a whole.

Unfortunately, this video didn't touch on the following points:  1- Nutrient density, the fact that meat is denser in macro & micro nutrients & amino acids overall compered to vegetables & fruits which usually high in one group of nutrients while lacking in others.  2- Vegan diet, requires farming more invasive plants species to meet the domain for for high fat - high protein plants, which over compete with other crops for resources & geography( such as avocado & broccoli).   3- water consumption, nutrient dense crops such as walnut & almond consumes large amounts of water to grow the trees to fruiting age.  4- 14% ~ 18% livestock GHG emissions, this figure is misleading as its a global percentage of the countries percentages. This ignores the facts that there are outlier percentages in the developing countries which have higher percentage not due to larger production of livestock but due to lack of technical advancement (factories, transportation, etc...). (North America (USA, Canada, Greenland and Bermuda, emits just over 0.6 gigatons of CO2-equiv per year, which is roughly ~1.2% percent of all global emissions).  5- Humanity going full vegan will only reduce emissions by just 4.3%, a recent тАЬmeta-analysisтАЭ of all the peer-reviewed papers on this topic found that giving up meat altogether would cut individuals' total emissions by just 4.3%.  6- Complementary duality of agriculture & livestock, farms produce crops for human consumption, crop residues sold for livestock farms as fodder, manure sold back to crop farms as organic fertilizers.  9- Chemical fertilizers, to produce a crops enough to satisfy the need fro humanity to go vegan, we will have to mass produce chemical fertilizers which will produce more GHG emissions than livestock could ever do, not to mention the pollution.  8- Number of livestock in north America, it should be noted that a recent study showed that the number of livestock in north America is nearly the same as it was before 1600 (around 75~85 mil), where hunting during the colonizing of the area drove buffaloes to near extinction, & now the total number of livestock & the wild life is nearly that number again (85~95 Mil). Which concluded that the GHG emissions from livestock shouldn't have that much of an impact on global warming.  9- Wasted food, one of the most critical failures of the food industry as a whole & plant based especially (due to short shelf lifespan ) is waste. As food waste is estimated at between 30-40 percent of the food supply in USA.  10- Smokescreen, it's has been noted by some researchers that oil groups are funding researchers, politicians & activists groups to market the livestock industry as the primarily suspect of GHG emissions to use it as smokescreen to alter attention away from them.

4:24 - International shipping wouldn't be more efficient because you still have all of the local and regional shipping to to, just as with locally-produced food sources. It's just that the sea freight wouldn't add significantly to the total. It goes from the farm to the processing plant, to distribution centers, to the shipyard, across the ocean to your shipyard, to your local distribution center, to your store.   Locally produced food goes from farm, to processing center, to distribution, to your store. There are potentially less than half the steps and emissions of international food.  I know this specific example compared plants to meat, but they reiterated that international shipping doesn't make a big difference over local food, which isn't true

I know this is probably hard to quantify but how would a shift from beef to lamb/mutton or goat meat impact emissions? Both sheep and goats are often able to survive on land that cattle can't survive on (due to being more arid, lower quality grazing, etc), much of which would not naturally support prairie-style grasslands or forests, and which is unsuitable for growing crops on either (often somewhat rocky, mountainous and with thin topsoil). Moving to the means of livestock that can be reared on these kinds of environments would seem like a good idea but I don't know the actual figures on it

A few people here are claiming that livestock feed is inedible and thus, justifies the meat industry, however, there are some significant problems with that claim.  There's a report called *'Tackling Climate Change through Livestock: A global assessment of emissions and mitigation opportunities'* that details this -- skip to about page 17.  It's not that livestock feed is made of inedible parts, it's that the crops grown aren't high enough quality for human consumption. The land is still used to grow crops, it's just that the crops aren't being treated as they would be, had it been grown for humans (e.g. with pesticides). The reality is that crop residue (e.g. stems, leaves, and roots) only makes up about a quarter of overall livestock feed, the majority is just poorly grown crops, on land that could be used for high-quality plants fit for human consumption.

Oh jesus you're on this again.  The carbon cycle is a thing.  It doesn't matter that a cow farts, that carbon was _already in the carbon cycle._  If we hadn't raised that cow, the carbon it farted out would have gotten into the atmosphere just fine when it decomposed by some other means.  The (arguably) problematic carbon emissions are from _extracted_ carbon only, like fossil fuels.  Getting very tired of you "not wanting to dive in too deep because there's controversy" when there's already controversy over how bad carbon emissions actually are, and whether it's within humanity's power to change things, and you have no problem going into that.  It's more dishonest of the Kurzgesagt brand than I've come to expect.

The topic of meat eating has to bring up the topic of human impulse control, behaviour, compassion, more than it does the topic what is good for us physically, because it's already been shown by so many people that you can live just fine off of many diets.  The art of knowing when too much is too much is more important to talk about. Like, how we control our own emotions and make intelligent decisions as a whole. We're really, really not good at that. Factory farming, deforestation, these things are Our fault, ultimately, because we can't get a reign on our impulses and corporations go out of control when the first paycheck comes in. And it's not just in how the world changes it's how we treat eachother.  When certain localised bubbles of society discovered that it was not a necessity to kill to survive, and that they had options, but still wanted meat - so still spun the gears of the meat grinder, for want - not for need - that's when we crossed the line into 'too much' territory. Look at carnivores in the wild. They don't have a choice, or an option, if they do not harness the dread fear of starvation into a killing instinct, they will die. We're given a remarkable opportunity to distance ourselves from that.  I do not see how the world would be a worse place if we distanced ourselves from that. I see it as kind of weaning from the breast of mother earth herself. All these little loops of forced emotional reality that these animals must cling to to survive, and we're smart enough to figure out ways to not take part. It's not like we will just lose the survival instinct, either. Humans are more than capable of educating themselves on such matters, of training, of practicing. Hell, most people between the age of 14-18 know how to use guns and some survival techniques just by playing videogames!  It would definitely aid our survival should we ever leave this planet, if we could cut out our obsession and addiction with meat mostly because of the benefits it will have on us mastering our impulse control. If we just swap over meat to plants right now, we'll be in the same situation environmentally, except there might be a bit more damage to the Ozone from all the Human farts as we now eat masses of beans. The benefit to the environment will come from better impulse control. And us quitting meat - even though we want it because it's so tasty - when we know we don't need it, would be the ultimate test for our impulse control. I mean, it's kinda important, this. If anything is going to spiral us into some kind of dark future, or no future at all - it's gonna be this. We need to get our act in gear and mature when it comes to this.  Lab meat isn't there yet, in my opinion it never will be, as the stem cells are harvested from fetuses, which aren't grown in a Sci-Fi channel green tube, they're born from a mother animal. In my eyes lab meat is less us weaning from the breast and more us desperately hanging onto an out stretched nipple by any means necessary. But plant based nutrition is getting there.  There are already tons of alternatives for meats and some of them are really tasty like the new FUTURE mince, naturli mince,  meatless farms, beyond burgers. The vegetarian butcher do plant based strips made to mimic chicken and it's the stuff KFC or Burger King use in their plant based chicken burger. Since I've adopted these alternatives, I've noticed a marked decrease in my consumption of these kinds of foods in general. They come as more of a treat, than something I eat every day of every week. This is the key to us being able to map out our survival into the future. If the whole human race has good impulse control then we can actually make a plan for us all for the future. If our production is at a relaxed level and our consumption doesn't start demanding it to go into an insanely high gear while some CEO barters with the devil to keep the money coming in- at our future's expense!!!! Then we actually have a shot at surviving into the future. Indefinitely if we get off this planet.  Take it from someone who had 4 collapsed lung incidents over 6 years ending in a double major lung surgery and diagnosed with emphysema before he finally quit smoking. Impulse control is important, lack of it is destructive, and the damage is irreversible.

Bowhunting FTW.  Harvesting overpopulated wildlife from forested land  = negative C02 emissions.  Bowhunting is nearly renewable (no ammunition expended that needs to be produced).  Hunting licenses and permit fees fund land conservation and those lands trap co2.  Deer, for example, produce less methane the cows but harvesting overpopulated animals from naturally occurring herds cuts those emissions.  I bow hunt on my own property so I literally can walk my food to my freezer.  If I grow carrots in my backyard, IтАЩd still be using fertilizer which adds to co2 emissions.  With a negative foot print, bow hunters are thus infinitely superior to vegans.

8:33 Do you have any source for that?   Also, you're not differentiating between edible and non-edible parts. In 2018, FAO report claimed that 14% of edible crops is being used to feed animals. Rest is like stems and other parts that we cannot eat. Same with industry - using as an example of sunflower, the flower seeds are used for direct consumption or processed into oil, but the rest is either used as biomass for electricity or as a food for animals. If we didn't' do that, it would've gone to waste. Looking at the size proportions of the sunflower plant itself, statistically 80%-90% would've been used by animals/industry then...

As I know how much you love insects, a great idea for a video would be on how insects can turn non-biodegradable plastics into biodegradable subtances. This could also tie in with this video as you could use those insects to feed livestock. The UN has done quite a lot of research on it. Rather than deforesting land to grow crops for livestock, you can have skyscrapers as "verticle" farms which take in large quantities of plastic, feed them to insects, then feed the insects to the livestock.   It wouldn't stop the issues of methane produced from cows, but turning plastic waste into an edible food source for animals is a great way to reduce our carbon footprint, especially in animals like chickens which already produce less carbon than cattle.

The statements made about how much of the world's grain is used for livestock feed is misleading. The numbers may very well be correct, but those percentages that are used for livestock feed are of too poor of quality or have deficiencies that prevent them from being human consumption quality. It was necessary to mention an aspect that I consider important. The equivalent CO2 emission by cows comes from emissions absorbed by plants before being ingested by animals. It is unfair to compare emissions from other sectors that emit CO2 that was stored underground for millions of years, with the emissions of CO2 captured by plants the year before.
"Let's say this represents one cow, which will keep me in food for, let's say, a month. Now that cow needs this much land and food. Well, you can imagine, that cow needs x by x amount of land, and you can grow trees in it. Around that cow, you can have goannas, kangaroos, wallabies. You can have every other single Australian animal in and around that cow. If I was a vegetarian, to feed me for that month, I need this much land, and nothing else can grow there. Herein lies our problem. If we level that much land to grow rice and whatever, then no other animal could live there except for some insect pest species. Which is very unfortunate."  Steve Irwin to The Scientific American

I feel like some of the points in this video are being misrepresented or contradictory.  1. Talking about how cattle are used on land that is unsuitable for growing food crops, then going on to state that converting it all into forests would sequester a huge amount of carbon from the atmosphere, seemingly forgetting that the vast majority of that land would also be unsuitable for forests.  2. Talking about how cattle are able to turn inedible crop byproducts into a nutritionally dense and easily digestible food, then going to claim that huge amounts of food crops are fed to livestock that "could be fed to humans", but forget that the majority of that is the same inedible material that cattle are so good at converting into edible food. Yes granted pigs and poultry do eat a lot of human edible food, but this video is focused on cattle. 3. Carbon emissions, they present the carbon emitted by cattle to be equivalent to the carbon emitted by burning fossil fuels, which is redicilous. The methane emitted by cattle is just part of the carbon cycle, the net carbon in the ecosphere isn't changing. Yes methane is a more potent greenhouse gas than co2, but because of its comparitvely short half life and much lower prevalence in the atmosphere the actual impact on climate change is greatly overstated. The emissions from the fossil fuel industry is greatly more damaging as it is introducing new carbon into the system that wasn't there before, not just recycling it. Not to mention that the cattle are also sequestering carbon themselves in terms of the carbon that their bodies are made from. Yes the destruction of rainforests for the sake of cattle farming is terrible, but saying that livestock living in rocky terrain where no large trees are able to grow are just as bad is incredibly misleading.
