Next t├нme can you include how much land we would need if we produce less food waste since it is around 40% in some countries also how curing obesity would help because many obese people ingest 2- 4 times more calories than they need.
After responding to a few comments here, I just want to say, climate science, agricultural science, and ecological science are all made up of individuals wanting to do their best with the data they have available, but interconnecting them all is not often a concern.  I've worked in all three areas, and while everyone I've worked with is doing their utmost to make their studies purely scientific and their data accurate, they generally are just working to get more funding, and those that submit their data (very good data, I should say) to, are generally just looking for funding more than change.  Science is unfortunately very intertwined with politics, and a perfectly well researched study on issues that impact us everyday may not see any action if it seems inconvenient or harmful to  leaders more concerned with short-term goals. We've seen it with past leaders, we see it with current leaders.  If you have strong feelings about any politically-charged topics, I encourage you to go straight to well-reviewed (meaning scientifically peer-reviewed) sources and see the data yourselves.  Though Kurzgesagt, as far as my area of knowledge, has never gone far astray or misleading in presenting good science in a fashion anyone can understand.  But I REPEAT: go to the peer-reviewed journals and articles yourself, don't accept shitty youtube personality's or news station's summaries. Review the data, and summary, and the methods, and make sure the journal you read is both peer-reviewed and a trusted journal by a variety of established scientists.

The main point of buying local is to reduce food waste. Most of bulk produced fresh products travel to multiple locations if not sold, and eventually can end up back where they started or wasted. You canтАЩt say buying local is worse for the environment without considering this.
Double counting the fossil fuel emissions from transport there. Please remember the basics of the carbon cycle. If you release carbon that was removed from the air decades ago there is little affect, if you release carbon that was removed hundreds of millions of years ago, that causes a major change. And you didn't address the presence of wild ruminants and methane. To take North America as an example, there are only about 10% more ruminants now as compared to 500 years ago. I'm sorry but this video absolutely strawmanned the position that meat is not inherently bad for the environment. Even suggesting that factory farming has a lower footprint than an arrangement more similar to hunting wild ruminants should be ringing alarm bells of logical fallacy.

How can you say with a straight face, to millions of people, at 4:25:   "[on freight ships] Shipping one kg of avocados from South America to Europe...will generate around 2.5 kg of carbon emissions, while one kg of beef from your local butcher will come in at 18 kg of CO2"  You said it yourself, freight ships are efficient as in, they can transport 100k-500k tonnes of goods. But those are a lot of goddamn avocados. And did you also calculate the transport from the avocado farm (via trucks i assume) to the South-American harbor, and then from the European Harbor to the other countries?(which is also via truck) And for the people who choose to buy locally: 99% it isn't because people want to save the world. It's because they (probably) know what the local farmers are feeding the animals they eat later. I bet they prefer the idea of supporting local businesses than a international conglomerate. To have more space for coffee beans, and soy.  Do you know why there's massive deforestation in Romania? Because there's demand for wood in other, more modern countries. The same countries who are so concerned with global warming, yet they're the ones who try to change our diet. If only they could remove greed from their diet.  2:55 - "A kilogram of beef will keep you alive much longer than a kilogram of potatoes. If we compare emissions per calorie per protein? Not much." It's been well documented that meat protein is absorbed much better than soy/whey/tofu, and especially potatoes... Not only that, but meat contains good amounts of fat as well, it being necessary for our body to function properly. Please examine the Savoury Institute and their revolutionary method for cattle/sheep grazing on marginal drylands. Basics are.. Degraded land is regenerated, production is increased dramatically and (recent studies show) more carbon equivalent is sequestered than is produced. I always hate when noone mentions that while a great or even the majority of the farmed crops go to farm feeds this doesn┬┤t mean much. It┬┤s not like out of 100 farmlands 60 are dedicated to feeding animals. Especially when it comes to grains such as soy and corn, the byproducts are a lot. The majority of the crop consists of the stem the leaves and other parts of the plant that are given to create pellets and animal feed. Not to mention that a lot of the grains that were destined for human consumption are still given away to make animal feed as byproducts that would be thrown away anyway due to quality control, product chain issues or even low demand in a certain area. We just have less grain garbage in contrast to the amount of fruits that are thrown away into big piles each year; I am sure everyone has heard about the exorbitant amounts of fruit wasted each year. There is just less of that when it comes to grains, because what's garbage for us is a good meal for cattle, pigs and chickens.

One of the obvious untruths which Veggies indulge in, is when they do their "Why meat is bad" calculation as if all meat is grown the way Americans do it. The vast majority of beef and mutton in the world is grown on natural pasture, not profit-greedy American "feed-lots". And the vast majority of natural beef pastureland is unproductive scrub and arid land that is TOTALLY unsuitable for commercial human vegetable crop use.

Holistic farming methods are not only carbon neutral, but also carbon negative. In Australia and New Zealand, the beef industries have set carbon neutral targets by 2050, and many farms are already there. I live in Australia and there are already carbon-neutral beef options on the shelves.  This feels like a massive oversight for In a Nutshell. Ruminant animals, if farmed correctly, can actually REMOVE carbon from the atmosphere. There are an opportunity to STOP CLIMATE CHANGE, not worsen it.
I think this video highlights something that has been sadly lost nowadays. Veganism has been pushed so heavily that it is seen as the 'only' reasonable choice. Tell a group of people that you're going vegetarian and you're likely to have at least one ask 'why not vegan? Dairy is still terrible!'. Everything we hear seems to be pushing veganism and anything short of that is seen as a failure. Sure, it definitely is the best choice if you're okay with it. But we know that actually, just switching from beef to chicken or cutting down your meat consumption to a few days a week gives most of that benefit with relatively little sacrifice. I really don't understand why the 'low hanging fruit' approach isn't being pushed more.

I grew up on a farm. My family raises cattle and we sell them when they're about 9 months old. Until then they are never seperated from their mom. They eat grass and hay as 95% of their diet (rest being corn). In summer they live in the alps where crop farming is literally not an option worth considering. In short, they live the most animal friendly way possible. However, that is an outlier of beef production on a global scale. That's also ofc reflected in the price. I hope in the future we will eat meat less often, pay attention to animal well-being more as well as environment friendlier production, and therefore have more expensive, but higher quality meat - and hopefully lab grown meat as a cheap alternative, as well as ofc the already existing protein-rich plant food. I have a controversial idea for drastically lowering pollution.  The problem at its core lies with us Humans. What if we collectively started opting for reducing the number of kids we have? Instead of making children of our own. WE should opt for adopting children who need it.  because the biggest source of pollution is simply the fact that there are more and more humans on our planet. if we can stem the population, in a humanitarian way, i.e nothing forced, but rather a change of mindset. That is, instead of having our own children. We should have a mindset that encourages adopting children from developing countries, who really do need and deserve a better life and a future.  We know Developing countries will usually always have a bigger population boom than Industrial countries. Industrial countries have most of their needs covered, and quite many families and people live fine a low number of offspring. However, in developing countries, they tend to have much more children, both for their own future security for their parents, but also due to limited access to contraceptives, knowledge, and most importantly, a functional law and order system. (rape can be a big problem and is often unreported in developing countries) hence why every day, children are born into poor conditions and families unable to support them. They grow up in the slums, and they couldn't care less about the environment as they are more busy finding means for their own survival than the survival of the human species in the future.  So that's where the idea comes from. instead of having kids of your own if you are one of those growing up in an industrial modern stable country. How about adopting kids from developing countries? That way they grow up in a much safer, more stable environment, and they can get proper education and their carbon footprint will be much smaller. You also reduce the pressure of ever-growing poverty in Developing countries, allowing them to shift into an industrial country much easier when it is not down ridden by corruption and crime that stems from a large population of poverty.  It's a Win-Win situation really. The people living in wealthy countries still can have their families. But at the same time, it alleviates and reduced the poverty growth from poorer countries, giving them space to grow and turn into industrial countries faster which in turn gives them more wealth that can be used to shift over to more sustainable environmentally friendly industry.

The video was decently argued, as expected from this channel. Still, I think there are some caveats that you missed.  1 - The completeness of protein from meat makes it a much easier source of protein, while plant protein is hard to combine to get an effective growth 2 - intensive cultivation destroys soil, while grazing can restore it, so a part of the farmlands should be periodically left to cattle 3 - animal products contain other nutrients at a density much higher than plants, with few exceptions. Veggy alternatives are a poor failure nutritionally and while ok once in a while they are not an alternative. Insects could fare much better in that sense. 4 - an animal should be used in every part, from organs to bones to lean cuts. This greatly increases the efficiency.  So, yes, we should eat a little less meat, mostly grass fed, and change the way the whole animal is used. By law.

9:04 What does beef-free diet mean? Not eating cow meat, but still enjoying milk, cheese, chicken, etc. are ok. Or not eating anything a cow can make?
One thing you didn't mention, is that cattle are often fed the stalks, blades, and hulls, of the grain crops.  That is, the parts of the plants we can't eat.  This stuff, if discarded, or composted, could produce lots of greenhouse gasses, from decomposition and from transport.  Cattle and other livestock also produce manure that we often depend on to fertilize the crops, especially organic crops, and many places have regulations which disallow the use of human sewage for fertilizer, and even if it could be allowed, it would still have to be transported from urban areas to the agricultural areas.  Yeah, the complexity of this whole situation just keeps on building.  The fact is, whatever we do, we're probably boned, because there are too many people on this planet, and the numbers keep increasing, which means more farmland, less forests, and more greenhouse emissions.

This is a really complex subject and it would be impossible to cover every facet of it it a video but I think the video is kind of one sided (for the record I'm a big fan of Kurzgesagt and honestly not a even big fan of beef). I don't think comparing greenhouse emissions from biological sources to emissions from fossil fuel and mineral sources is an apples to apples comparison even if they were chemically identical. Emissions from fossil fuel and mineral sources is carbon that is being added to the carbon cycle that had previously been sequestered from it for hundreds of millions of years, whereas emissions from biological sources are just moving carbon that is already part of the carbon cycle (today's cow burp was last year's CO2 which became the crop that the cow ate).     Also, if methane emissions from livestock is the problem that the video makes it out to be, there are additives (such as certain kinds of seaweed) that all but eliminate methane emissions (at least from cows), or we can add microbes to the livestock's feed that eats the methane while it is still in the animal's gut and converts it into an essential nutrient for the animal or in the worst case convert it to CO2 (which would reduce the emission's effect 20fold or so).     As far as land use goes for supporting these animals, there are ways of farming that are much more efficient than typical factory farming that actually simulate an entire ecosystem by having certain kind of livestock and plants share the same land, performing different roles. Some of these farming techniques are actually carbon negative and actually make the land more ferial over time. They aren't used more often because they use to be more labor intensive (now with things like GPS, aerial multispectral surveillance, and global wireless internet this no longer needs to be the case) and are actually restricted or outright illegal for use in  commercial farming due to (usually) well intentioned but outdated laws and aren't widely known about because as a busy commercial farmer, why learn what you aren't allowed to use?   There is lots more to say but I don't feel like writing a novel in the Youtube section and I don't think you really feel like reading one lol.
Is it really true about buying local change nothing? In your movie it looks like you eat that avocado or whatever from cargo container on a ship. Did you add up all other transport necessary for bringing goods on ship, and then from it to shop shelf?

Cutting down trees doesn't really release any carbon in the grand scheme of things- if that wood is harvested properly and used. Think about it- every plank of wood used to build a house or a shed, is carbon that's been sequestered- and then, the spot where the tree that plank came from used to be, can now grow a new tree. I know that's not the main discussion of the video- but I just had to make this point when I heard the point about cutting down trees to make new fields, that (selectively) cutting down trees (and then replanting them) isn't bad. It's just rotating out for the next generation of trees.   Since we started fighting forest fires, WE now have to steward the forests that flames cleaned and refreshed. If we don't, they're going to become cramped, rotting, unproductive messes, or massive fire hazards- and I know this, because I've SEEN this.

Caloric density was stated, but not nutritional value. Someone who requires more can get it by eating meats and fewer meals where they can't get all the nutrients without a very diverse vegan diet served in very large portions.  And, in this world where we're seeing increased food sensitivities, alternatives aren't always an option.   3D printed meats are starting to show up, the processing increasing the caloric and nutrient density. However, these foods (like the impossible burger), require increased food processing, which has negative environmental impact.  The real bottom line is there are too many people on this planet for it to naturally sustain. We have to come up with methods for recycling the waste byproducts of our food production process, especially the ones which cause climate change.

I think this video is searching too specifically into a single direction that we can take. It's also fair to acknowledge other possible paths. One of those is synthetic or lab grown meat, something that has been proven possible but is too expensive at the time. I have allergies to the most common animal based foods, such as milk, eggs, any sea meat, and even beef. I have tried vegan replacements for some stuff, but I either really hated it, or felt it wasn't anything special (with the exception of vegan cupcakes, they rock). I've lived with these allergies my whole life and I never once felt left out or like I had limited options. I've only ever mentioned my allergies when it was relevant, or when I wanted an ice breaker that shocked people with how much stuff they eat that I can't. I'm not 100% vegan, I have chicken since it seems to be the one thing I can eat that basically every takeout place offers. Although I have allergies I'm also picky with food, and I have still managed to completely change my diet in order to avoid unhealthy foods like potato chips or sugary candy. So when I see videos like these, I struggle to imagine why people resist to simply the idea of eating similar things to what I have daily for my entire life. My food life is by no means a bad one, nor is it difficult. I highly recommend just looking for foods that don't have any of the animal products I'm allergic to in them, they are a lot more common than you may originally think.  Let me know if you would like me to list or explain what I eat and where I eat or anything related to what I eat.   Have a good day!
Deforestation in the Amazon rainforest is primarily for its timber and other resources, and is often illegal.  Livestock producers and farmers are legally obliged to protect a large area of тАЛтАЛtheir land or, if that is not possible, they have to finance a protected area.  Unfortunately, the current government is being very ineffective in monitoring and combating illegal deforestation.

A few oversights: 1. Human settlement has driven away large herbivores, which has somewhat recently been discovered to be to blame for desertification in some areas. Proper use of cattle herds can fill the ecological niche while producing food. 2. Using cover crops in farming can reduce tillage (improving carbon sequestration in the soil. Grasses are actually better for this than trees.), and can reduce need for mineral fertilizers. To break down the plant matter for seeding the following year, we can use the digestive tracts of large herbivores. 3. Livestock feed uses up the vast majority of our waste agricultural products. A few examples: crushing canola to produce vegetable oil leaves a mealy byproduct, which is fed to livestock. Wheat not suitable for human consumption is referred to as 'feed wheat'; three guesses why, and the first two don't count. A large amount of potatoes and other vegetables aren't suitable for a supermarket or making fries, and they're commonly fed to livestock.  My source: I grew up on a farm, studied agronomy in college, and continue to talk to people in the field of agroecology.

So, the thing that I am taking away from this is that itтАЩs not meat in general that is causing this, but how we produce it. As explained, to support our diet, we get rid of helpful, carbon storing trees. Our problem is not entirely that we are farming, but what we are farming too. We have been conditioned to think that we should live off a narrow diet of certain foods; beef, pork, poultry, corn and wheat, to name a few. But humans can eat pretty much anything, including some of the more taboo and exotic foods, such as crickets, seeds (who knew you could eat an acorn), leaves, and certainly even rodents. Heck, you can eat deer, rabbit and even duck. You could probably even eat lions, jackals, coyotes, foxes, eagles, bears, lizards, and maybe even some snakes. Basically, humans evolved to not be fussy eaters. So it is kind of an anomaly that we have limited our diet so much in the past decades.

The problem isn't with cattel it's with the system itself. Most rangelands have adapted with grazers with similar preferences to cattel like buffalo for millions of years, both animals prefering grass instead of brushes and Forbes which is most commonly preferred by smaller rumminants. Most grasslands in North America and throughout the world are actually highly productive in carbon sequestration and most of the time it is very unproductive to turn it into cropland. Methane produced by rumminant animals is typically produced in feed lots not on native rangelands. Please don't have a problem with the meat itself and rangelands instead take issue with the large feed lots. Just because a empty grassland or wetland isn't growing your vegetables don't take issue with it. I do understand that the world population is growing and no solution is written in stone and we must use adaptive management. If you want to combat climate change through your diet buy locally from nearby ranches before cattel are sent to a feed lot or, teach yourself to hunt and fish.

What is up with the graph at 9:24 - 9:36!? Kurzgesagt is showing the amount of CO2 that could be removed per _100 years_ by following a vegan diet and reforesting the returned land (800 billion tons per century, aka *8 billion per year)* while showing the amount of CO2 we pump out _per year_ (50 billion tons per year). This gives the false impression that these 3 billion hectares would be enough to cancel out *all of our CO2-equivalent emissions,* which is far from true according to your own data. Why would you show the values in this way if you were going for an unbiased and trustworthy video and not trying to manipulate the viewers into believing falsehoods? This severely undermines your credibility, Kurzgesagt, and honestly, I'm pretty disappointed with this video. I can't really trust all your other conclusions here with this manipulation of statistics.

Oh and if you're so worried about a run away greenhouse emissions, perhaps you should stop letting so much god damn water into the air. CO2 isn't nearly half as bad as water. Actually water is 45 times worse than CO2, and a matter of fact, if you increased the CO2 emissions a thousandfold, you'd soon see, that CO2 would effectively stop further Greenhouse emissions, and actually cool down the planet, due to how plants waste water by draining the soil of it, each tree, produces 150kg of steam per day on average, that's equivalent of 6750 kg of CO2 per tree, or 6.75 Tonnes of CO2 in equivalence. So even if 3 hectares of trees would reduce CO2 by 800 Billion Tonnes, it will release a lot more water into the atmosphere. About 10000 times more.

I'm surprised they didn't mention any other the developing solutions to livestock methane emissions like seaweed feed supplements or methane capture for biogas use. The asparagopsis taxiformis and armatus seaweed will cut cow methane by 80% at 1% of their diet and 98.9% at 2% with similar effects on sheep and goats. Personally, I've severely limited beef in my diet until I can get meat raised in either of these ways and I recommend others make substitutions until then as well. I'm also disappointed neither they nor anyone else ever does the climate diet footprint of non beef eaters along with standard western, veg, and vegan diets.

That happens regardless of what food you eat.  The big Walmart Semi-Trucks, mostly Food.  Not just meat.  The rest is fairly accurate though.

the animation improved?
I live on a beef ranch. I believe it's a lot more environmentally friendly than people think. Grass fed cattle replace other species, such as bison, eating the grass that the bison ate when they roamed the country. This means the cows are no more of an environmental problem than the wild herds of bison in the parks, or the buffalo in Africa. (No one ever suggest wiping out wild bovines to end global warming.) The cattle are on grassland, which helps pull carbon from the air, so they'd actually be helping prevent global warming in a way, just like the bison before them. They also aren't impacting the wild animals here like farming. When people farm, they rip up the land and plant one crop, destroying the habitat for many wild animals. Cattle simply roam across the land, grazing the grass, leaving the other animals alone and able to go about their lives, lives that would be disrupted or even ended if the animals were living in a corn field during the harvest. It is true we do harvest hay for them to eat in the winter, but one must keep in mind that cattle can eat a lot more of any crop than humans. For example, if you grow a corn stalk for humans, humans can eat the kernels. The cow can eat all eight feet of the stalk. We can harvest three crops of hay off a field in one year, or we could harvest one crop of wheat for humans, and the humans would just eat the seeds. (The rest of the wheat plant would be used as straw for cattle.) This means that you can get WAY more food for a cow off a field than you can if you're trying to feed humans.  So in the end, I think that the calculations saying how bad beef is for the environment are way off, calculated by people who don't know enough about beef and how cattle are raised.
In summary: Yes, it is!!

Just wanted to throw this out there, in the U.S beef industry as a whole is split up into a few different portions. Almost all (+-90%) of calves come from cow calf operations run by families be it private or contracted. Then when a calf gets weaned they are sold off to a either a feedlot or another cattle ranch to get them to roughly 600lbs. Then after that they go to a feedlot for about 3 to 5 months. To get to the point I feel the term factory farming is misleading as it's not a style of raising cattle from birth till death but more of a part of their lives that's nescisarry. Long story short every part of the beef industry takes pride in putting high quality food on the table for their families as well as yours.

Regardic caloric efficiency. It greatly depends on the meat. Fish farms and factory-farmer chicken are very very energy efficient at converting animal food into human food. Both well over 50%. On the other end of the scale, cows are 10% and many other animals are below that.  Fish farms also have some nice niche partitioning going on that synergizes well with humans. They have very low land use and we either have difficulty farming or straight up can't eat many of the primary producers in a fish's environment. Fish can also be sent out from rivers to graze or hunt in the ocean and unlike cattle, they will reliably return home, meaning you can effectively have a fish ranch 75% the size of the planet.

Yo I don't care if my meat is made of plants if it tastes good and keeps me fed I'll eat it
Wow: 23 days and you didn't address any of the inaccuracies in this video from the German version to the English one.   Let's start with soy: this has got to be the most irritating of all the claims made by people who advocate against eating meat because it's technically true! But even so, this is still an obfuscation of the facts.  Yes, 77% of the soy that's grown is used to feed animals. However the majority of all the soy grown is defatted soy. This means the beans have had the fats extracted from this to make things like vegetable oils which the majority are used for cooking and making soy oil foodstuffs, while the remainder is used by industry to make almost everything you can think of from paint additives to medicines to plastics.   Prior to the 1940s almost no Soy was grown for animal feed as corn was the staple crop fed to livestock. The reason for this switch has to do with the discoveries of the Industrial Chemist, Dr. Percy Julian, who created HUNDREDS of discoveries with the soy bean and it's oil in the back room of a paint company over a period of 20 years.   Now, take a wild guess what percentage of the soy bean is oil. 80%? 65%? 40%? Nope.   It's 21% - 23% ~ Exactly the amount that's extracted and used for human food and industry. I will say it again and again and again because it's true; The Soy that is Fed to Cattle is WASTE ~ Unusable by anyone for anything except as landfill, which when it then decays produces the same green house gases of Methane and Carbon dioxide people are screaming about.   This brings me to point 2) Climate change - Yes, Food contributes to our climate changing. However the source of that Carbon is what makes the difference. I can prove this easily:  We raised Billions of Cows, Pigs, Chickens, Goats, Sheep and every other kind of meat you can think of since the beginning of human civilization. Probably earlier since the cow, in it's most rudimentary form has been domesticated for 12 500 years.   I want you to consider that: Billions of cows over thousands of years never affected the climate. We know this because of ice core samples taken from Antarctica: They capture bubbles of air which we can use to recreate the ancient atmosphere, and for the entirety of human civilization, we see a flat line: 1% increases up and down in atmospheric carbon composition but no major change until the 18th century.   In fact, I can tell you the day that climate change started: May 4th, 1776: James Watts and Iron Mad Wilkinson kick off the industrial revolution. Suddenly, there's a massive industrial demand for fuel, and this dense, energy rich rock called Coal suddenly goes from something used to help heat homes for part of the year, to a massive industrial resource necessary for the large scale manufacture of commercial goods for an ever growing market.   The Ice Core samples see the CO2 rate skyrocket, and the graph has been going vertical ever since.   So which is to blame? The system of food creation which has, for the past 12 and a half millennia created no discernable effect on the climate or the large scale industrial production that, like an unceasing forge continues to consume the world day and night?  The idea that any carbon creation as bad is a poor excuse to stop eating meat: that carbon came from the atmosphere, it wasn't taken out of the ground and thrown into the atmosphere where it will stay for the next million years. At best it's a canard to keep doing other things that pollute because you're offsetting it by not eating meat.   -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------   Point 3) Environmental degradation: This one annoys me to no end because it stands on the assumption that if we all just stopped eating meat, the attacks on the environment would suddenly stop because this is the only thing driving them. But its' not. It's more obfuscation.   Let's take the Brazilian rain forest as an example: It's been the government policy of Brazil to exploit the rainforest since 1956. Doesn't matter who's in power.   Moreover, the amount of beef that people eat has fallen sharply: the average US diet consumes a total of calories has shrank by half. In terms of grams per person it's decreased by a third from the 1970s from 150 grams to 101 grams. This is due partially to rising costs and falling wages, partially due to the rise of chicken and partially due to health and environmental concerns.   But lets say we all stopped eating meat tomorrow. I'm in a generous mood: The rainforest is still doomed. The reason for this is simple: it provides the Brazilian government with no capital or revenue and as such would still be slashed and burned or logged for timbre.   Brazil btw is in the correct tropical zone to grow things that are in high demand, such as Vanilla, and the amazon basin sits on heavy metal deposits as well. To put it simply ~ the rainforest would continue to be destroyed because the government that enables it's destruction sees no value from it. As such, unless preserving that forest is worth money to the Brazilian government no action can stop it from coming down short of a military invasion on behalf of the environment.   This is true in the other forest biomes that are just as important to our carbon capture and sink: The Siberian Boreal forest, which has contained  just as much carbon as the Rainforest, is currently being logged to meat softwood timbre demands with NO agricultural pressure on it: You cannot grow food in the arctic.   Borneo saw a 65% reduction in it's rain forest for the input of oil palms - that forest is just as dead, and it's carbon is just as much leaking into the atmosphere.   Madagascar cut their rainforest back by 95% to make room for vanilla cultivars.   In Costa Rica, 1/3rd of the rain forest was cut down for oil exploration and continues to be destroyed.   If you want to conserve the rainforest you have to make the rainforest worth more alive than dead. I can prove this easily by citing the case of the Mountain Gorillas:  Prior to their conservation, their habitat was being encroached upon by farmers looking to grow rice in order to increase their income. When the forests were conserved as gorilla habitat and the locals given a cut of the tourist and scientific dollars that flowed into the region, they stopped killing the Gorillas because now they were making more money keeping the environment for the gorillas than they would if they just converted it into farms.   Chopping down the forests for Quinoa isn't somehow a more noble pursuit because it's being done for trendy non-animal based foods. A dead rainforest is a dead rainforest it doesn't matter what you turned it into.   The pursuit of profits, not meat is what's destroying the environment and could be easily fixed.   As for the claim that if we removed all the land we used for animals and turned it into wild lands. Yes, it sounds nice - Except that 800 Billion Tons over 100 years is 8 Billion tons a year.    We Emit 50 Billion Tons per year at the moment: you are comparing two VERY different numbers.   Even if we removed ALL the foodstuffs and their greenhouse gases from the list, Humanity would still emit 37 Billion tons of CO2 per year, meaning your total mitigation would be slightly less than 20%.   It's an even less meaningful number compared to the total atmospheric carbon: 220,000,000,000,000 Tons or 220 Trillion Tons of Carbon Dioxide currently makes up the atmosphere at 0.04%. To get the atmosphere down to 0.03% we'd need to eliminate 15 Trillion Tons. All the Deserts and Farmlands turned into forests and pasturage would only eliminate less than 1 Trillion Tons in 100 years.   Conclusion; Meat isn't the problem - in fact it's a rather minor part of the problem at 15% of global emissions. The problem is extractive capitalism  externalizing the costs on our globe and everyone busy arguing about what' the best individual solution rather than just regulating the businesses and industries that got us to this problem in the first place.   If you really want to save the planet, you need to petition your government for mandatory emissions standards on industry to make them become more efficient - 4% increase in efficiency per year would have done the trick it in 1976.  You need retrofitting of homes, You need stronger environmental regulations that can't be challenged in courts, and most importantly of all you need to make conservation pay so the government at the local and national levels sit up and pay attention.   This has been a TED talk. Thank you.

So, shouldn't we be focusing on making sure oceans don't get too acidic, etc and try to make way to create more phytoplankton that produced O2 growth? Forest do contribute O2 production but it consumes quite a good chunk of it back to release CO2 again anyways for other various functions.

Warming isn't going to be fixed by reduction in beef or anything else really.   The political will to do so simply doesn't exist anywhere in the world and even if it did in some parts without everyone getting in on it, it becomes virtually useless. The amount of grassland we need to grow food and use animals could be severely reduced by using greenhouses.   The main downside being the amount of power they consume.   We can basically put reflective objects between the sun and the earth to cool the planet. Tanake Kurzgesagt, Just wanted to offer some perspective since this video seems to be operating under some logical inconsistencies. Firstly, the framing of animal husbandry as antithetical to agriculture and/or 'ecological preservation' is of course silly and false. Large grazers are crucial parts of many habitats and many communities are exploring how to utilize meat animals in large-scale ecological restoration. One of the most devastating events in terms of ecological contributions to Atmospheric Carbon is the destruction of Great Plains habitat. This destruction didn't happen solely because of a desire of settlers to create cattle grazing land, but also because of the US policy of destruction of Native grazers (e.g. Bison). I've noticed that your videos that talk about humanity generally seem to adhere to the mythological and not-at-all objective believe in cultural evolution: "Humans hunted/gathered, Humans did agriculture, then Humans did industry and that's how we know progress has happened." Of course this idea gained traction and 'evidence' within the context of your and other Western country's fascination with finding an objective reason for the wholesale destruction of 'less-evolved' civilizations. I'd recommend, free of charge, that you take a moment before your next video and consider how Germany's own colonial history might lend itself to your presumption of cultural evolution. I think it'd be really edifying for your team. Anytime you're willing to listen, indigenous people are ready to educate.

While eating less meat is a noble goal, animals play a crucial role in the small farm permaculture cycle. They graze so I don't have to mow around fruit trees and clean up crop debris. They poop so I don't have to buy petrochemical fertilizers. Chickens are amazing as bug eaters, so I don't have to rely on pesticides.  There's a lot we need to do to turn agriculture around from current destructive practices, but getting rid of meat products entirely is not it.

People often look at it as an all or nothing situation, but it really doesn't have to be. Just try to lower the amount of meat you consume - even just one or two meals without it per week can make a pretty big difference! I started making a tofu stir fry once per week and I started changing my diet to include more fish and chicken instead of beef. You don't have to give up meat completely to make a difference. And over time, you might come to realize that you don't even need as much meat as you thought to feel happy and satisfied. I almost never have beef anymore and I'm totally happy even though I used to consider beef my favorite meat.

Just by the fact that meat production is not a very efficient way to produce food (besides all of thoes greenhouse effects). There's why: First, the global population is getting rich and growing. This is a fact. Never in the history of human kind, there's so few percentage of global population below misery line. In all over the world, the average salary are growing. When people get rich, they consumption will growl. The demmand of meat will increase together with all the other foods, while the landscape offer will decrease to support it. The price of the meat will rise much more than other foods and the average population will change it food consumption behavior. while more and more people get rich and can afford better and better meals, thoes less efficient food will exponentialy rise its price, simply because more and more food will be needed to support the richer population's hungry. The final result is: Meat and others not efficient methods of producing food will be luxury, a small portion of the marketshare, while others types of food will overpower just by demmand and supply. It will be way more demmand of thoes other foods that people can afford that the expensive meat. That fenomenon is happening right now. Everyone who eats meat are noticing this effect, but don't understand why. There's the answer: It just not worth it.

The Texas State Senate passed Concurrent Resolution 3 (SCR3) on April 15, 2021, condemning the Chinese Communist Party (CCP)тАЩs involuntary organ harvesting from prisoners of conscience.  Angela Paxton, one of the state senators who introduced the resolution, said after the Senate vote, тАЬEverything about it [the organ harvesting crime] goes against treating individuals with the dignity they deserve simply for being a human being.тАЭ  She believes the resolution will serve to educate Texans about the atrocity. She said some people may have heard about it, but they donтАЩt speak up about it and simply treat it as a rumor. But тАЬwe want to go on record and say that тАШthis is happeningтАЩ and we condemn it,тАЭ she said.  Donna Campbell, another state senator who sponsored the resolution, said, тАЬThatтАЩs an atrocity. ThatтАЩs a human rights violation that no nation should turn a blind eye to.тАЭ  Campbell added, тАЬHopefully, this resolution will say to the medical community: tell your patients this is wrong. Because I think patients unknowingly become a partner with the murdering of innocent people. There needs to be a global outcry that тАШthis is wrong.тАЩ Nations need to sanction China for this kind of behavior.тАЭ  Below is the full text of the resolution.  CONCURRENT RESOLUTION  WHEREAS, For the better part of two decades, China's communist regime has been engaged in the vile practice of forcibly removing human organs for transplant; and  WHEREAS, In June 2019, the independent China Tribunal announced its finding that China's regime had for decades practiced systematic forced organ removal from prisoners of conscience; it is believed that organs have been harvested from hundreds of thousands of incarcerated people, mainly Falun Gong practitioners, but possibly also Tibetan Buddhists, House Church Christians, and members of the Uyghur Muslim ethnic minority; and  WHEREAS, China has welcomed an influx of тАЬtransplant tourism,тАЭ whereby individuals critically in need of transplants pay thousands of dollars for one of 60,000 to 90,000 transplant surgeries conducted each year; the number of transplants far exceeds the number of voluntary organ donations in the country; moreover, Chinese hospitals are able to schedule transplants of major organs within two weeks, suggesting nefarious foreknowledge regarding the тАЬdonationтАЭ of these organs; by contrast, America's highly developed organ donation system requires that recipients be placed on a carefully curated list to await the transplant of an organ; the timing of these transplants is not predictable, as an organ may not be available for hundreds of days, or in time for a specific patient; and  WHEREAS, Falun Gong, a spiritual practice centered on the values of truthfulness, compassion, and tolerance, became immensely popular in the 1990s; in July 1999, the Chinese Communist Party launched an intensive, nationwide persecution designed to eradicate the spiritual practice; Freedom House reported in 2015 that Falun Gong practitioners are the primary victims of forced organ removal and face an elevated risk of dying or being killed in custody; and  WHEREAS, On July 20, 2020, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo denounced 21 years of persecution of Falun Gong by China's communist regime, declaring in a press statement: тАЬWe call on the PRC government to immediately end its depraved abuse and mistreatment of Falun Gong practitioners, release those imprisoned due to their beliefs, [. . .] and address the whereabouts of missing practitioners. Twenty-one years of persecution of Falun Gong practitioners is far too long, and it must endтАЭ; and  WHEREAS, United Nations Special Rapporteurs have called on the Chinese government to account for the sources of organs used in transplant practices, and the World Medical Association, the American Society of Transplantation, and the Transplantation Society have all called for sanctions on Chinese medical authorities; resolutions condemning organ harvesting from prisoners of conscience have been adopted by the parliaments of Canada and the European Union, as well as by the Foreign Affairs Committee of the United States House of Representatives, and it is important to join the international outcry against this major violation of human rights; now, therefore, be it  RESOLVED, That the 87th Legislature of the State of Texas hereby strongly condemn China's practice of involuntary organ harvesting; and, be it further  RESOLVED, That the 87th Legislature of the State of Texas encourage the medical community to educate Texans about the risks of travel to China for organ transplants to help prevent Texas residents from unwittingly becoming involved in murder in the form of forced organ harvesting from prisoners of conscience; and, be it further  RESOLVED, That the 87th Legislature of the State of Texas respectfully urge the United States Congress and the president of the United States to pass laws and adopt measures prohibiting collaboration between U.S. medical and pharmaceutical companies and any Chinese counterparts linked with forced organ harvesting, banning entry into the United States of those who have participated in unethical removal of human tissues and organs, and providing for the prosecution of such individuals.

as someone who has been vegan since i was 15, I really think that the best way to make progress is to work together. But working together does not mean forcing people to eat differently, or shaming them. We just need to be informative and at the same time understand that individuals are not entirely to blame. We have to be facing our frustrations towards the companies that make it very difficult for us to eat well. And we have to realize that while our individual actions do matter, we are so much more powerful together. And realizing that companies are emitting so much more than we could comprehend, while simultaneously making it harder for us individuals to do our individual part in helping the climate and the lives of animals. We also have to think about how animals AND workers are mistreated and tortured in these systems. There is a lot of environmental racism in target demographics of food, and in who works and who is underpaid. There are so many issues and i feel that a lot of people are alienated from talking about these issues just because they aren't vegan or aren't vegetarian, etc. Everyone deserves to feel welcome and not ashamed of the way they live, especially when they're trying to learn about these issues, and when those people are probably the most affected by the systems we are trying to change.

It annoys me that I can't see the dislike ratio.  As usual a lot of very well researched points were made, but some of the data showcased in charts is downright manipulative. You brushed off the fact that agricultural products also need to be transported inland. No mention of the amount of creatures that are killed per harvest (rats birds etc that get caught in the harvest process which is done by machinery) What grade of the food produced is fed to cattle? How much emissions and carbon trapped in the soil does tilling produce? You made a very valid point about soy, but you don't mention that soy has had a rapid growth in demand due to popularity of vegan and vegetarian diets requiring it. Sure an argument can be made that replacing pasture lands entirely to produce soy there (not true but let's assume so) would create less emissions. But them you come back to the issue of an increase in demand anyways due to the population increasing as time goes on. Alternatives such as design and production of equipment that can convert greenhouse gases into o2 are also being produced. I firmly believe everyone should be free to eat what they like. everything said in this video relies on the belief that the planet is warming unnaturally and that it is a serious problem, which is a very large stretch knowing what we know. the climate is random, at least to our perspective, we cant predict anything that will happen because of just how many variables there are and how many unknowns there are. its like trying to identify a famous painting from just one millimeter of it. everything climate change advocates say is based on speculation and assumption, which historically has never been correct (there have been claims about the climate for 60 years, none of them have been correct). now, with that said, we do indeed know that the average temperature has raised a small bit since we have been able to record it, but what we don't know is if this is natural or unnatural, and seeing how little we know about the climate, that will be unknown for a long time. lastly, we don't know if it will be a serious threat, in fact we know it likely wont be one. sure the average water level will raise a few feet as the water heats upslightly and expands, but the only areas affected by that will be waterborne and beachside regions, meaning that the worst we will see is a few towns and cities seeing water damage challenges. this heat wont kill the ocean or the coral reefs either, the ocean will evaporate a bit more and the clouds will balance out the heating effect, and the coral reefs are used to changes in temperature because the temperature isn't constant and often will spike drastically, if they cant survive a few degrees increase, then they wouldn't be here.

The mere existence of cows contribute to climate change according to data. This is one of the things that triggered a change of mind about the climate change movement. The age of large mammals (in pre-history, before humans drove them to extinction) already has a lot of methane production that should be of concern to experts today.   With many many factors intertwined, it seems like the only real solution to 'climate change' is the big reduction in human population and a halt in human progress. It's anti-human.   My stance now, is to accept climate change - climate is never constant anyway. But I maintain environmental concern. So I support (1) efficient energy use, (2) a life of low-moderate consumption, and (3) minimization of pollution.

Search for: "Eating less Meat won't save the Planet. Here's Why" Youtube is confusing
Huge miss in the CO2 transport costs comparison.  CO2 cost for those big transport ships is measured per tonne per kilometer, which means that the transport cost is only low because of how much they can carry per trip, it does not mean that the ship isn't costing a figurative ton of CO2 to operate. Most transported food needs to be climate controlled, so we can use the .023 figure, but if we're talking about eating locally and assuming that these transport ships are loaded with nothing but food (which is something we can reasonably assume since there is so much food transport) we can subtract 1,300 kg CO2 eq per kilometer per ship taken out of the equation from our CO2 budget. If everyone is eating locally then these ships simply aren't traveling anymore and those tonnes of CO2 don't get added to the atmosphere.   Furthermore, the numbers provided assumes that there is no need to transport the food to and from the port. This would reasonably be further than transporting food from a local farm and/or butcher to your home since there tend to be fewer local ports for a given state/country than farms and butchers and would use the very same methods to transport the foods locally. No matter how you slice it eating foreign foods adds CO2 into the equation and eliminating the CO2 cost of transport could take us from 26% to nearly 21%, which is a savings of almost 20%  Finally, the numbers given don't reference that several popular transport foods like green beans and berries are commonly shipped by air, the most CO2 expensive method, by far.  Also, by the numbers they provide in the description, chicken and eggs both beat out rice in the CO2 per 100 grams protein scale.
I mean they crap on the local food production, however they do not mention that here food is locally produced is also usually produced in a way that regenerates that environment and in this way the benefits cancel the negatives of local food production, whereas globalized food production is more efficient per say, however there are no regenerative benefits to it, in fact is usually the opposite, so global food production only brings in negative, the fact that it is efficient does not change the fact that is the major destroyer of environments. Often times I feel the regenerative aspect of locally sourced food is either missed or emitted on purpose. I hate to say it, but I have seen similar arguments in the Can YOU Fix Climate Change? video where again they make the point that the best solution is to adopt technology with our money, but I find that this is only half the story. The problem isn't a matter of meat being eaten, regardless of your preferences, it's the fact that meat historically was a luxury food which has moved into the staple category resulting in emissions because the demand then grows proportionally to the population. You have to feed x number of cows, pigs, chickens, etcetera for every human that eats meat.
The point is this if we are the all powerful  humans to the cows ЁЯРД, and we do this to them, if there is a more powerful and advance creature in the universe that wants to do the same to us, what excuses can we possibly give to not be treated the same way?
At 1:46 there's a bit of a discrepancy AND a clear biased opinion.   Well it is true by saying that "global transport" by big freighters is more efficient, that in the end has NOTHING to do with the cargo. This argument can be made with ANY cargo, sourced locally or not.   Furthermore, it is RARE that any product is made right besides a harbor.  Meaning, to get from the producer to the harbor and then from the other harber to the Shop is done mostly by car.  So, it is actually WORSE to go for global sourced Products if you factor in the WHOLE transport chain.  Allso, Plant based foodstuffs suffer under the same Issue if they are sourced Locally. And it works in reverse for animal based foodstuffs too if they are sourced globally.  All in all the transport argument is kinda useless and the biased is deeply flawed.

Animal farming is responsible for 87% of GHG emissions. Yes, 87%. food does indeed get old. Ever try eating the same thing for over a year?   Btw if you wanna help fight climate change, its more impactful to stop eating mono crops like corn, banannas, almonds, palm tree (oil), and other plants like that than it is to stop eating meat entirely. SOME meat can even be additive to the nutrition of the soil and reductive of total waste, though factor farms are obviously not an example of this.   And the amount of CO2 beef emits? A lot of that is from the aforementioned mono crops. Cows for instance, fed with certain varieties of sea weed have their emissions of methane cut by over 90%. Also the very process of giving them the corn meal we commonly use puts off most of the methane in the cycle on top of increasing the amount of methane the cows themselves produce. Thank you for this, very well put. I wish there had been such a tight and accurate summary 5 or 10 years ago in this format. The science has been quite clear on this topic since FAO's 'Livestock's Long Shadow' was published in 2006, 15 years ago - or even before that. And the whole thing is quite obvious, too, if you know basic biology / energy flow in ecology.   When you eat beans / soy / any protein-rich plant or cereals (instead of first feeding it to an animal with bad conversion rate, and then eating some parts of that animal) you get to keep most of that energy & protein that's in those plants, instead of losing most of it to the animal's metabolism and moving around. In food chains you lose roughly 90% of your initial energy content per trophic level.   Farmers / producers have been of course trying to reduce this waste of energy and protein, simply because it reduces required agricultural inputs and thus saves money. The more efficiently your farm animals can absorb the energy and nutrients from your fodder crops or pastures, and the more you restrain them from wasting it on moving around, the more produce / money you make. This has obviously led to refinement / mutilation of animal species (chicken that gives painful birth i.e. lays eggs every day instead of twice a year like their original species, etc.) and later factory farms and all that sick sh1t, which even most of the regular meat-eating people can't bear to watch on a video, let alone visit such a place.   Now the big question is: After freeing all that huge amount of land from this wasteful and unsustainable food production, how to convince countries & people to rewild as much of it as possible, instead of just trying to make maximum profit from it, like they used to, to feed the ever-hungry economic growth. After all, the living planet which sustains us demands it, the struggle against climate change and mass extinction demands it, but our economic system (which has become global) demands the opposite. It demands endless growth, which means utilizing more and more resources & natural areas, producing endless amounts of disposable trash, all while our planet - our only home - is already in a catastrophic state. But for those who don't care about the future or anything, only fast profits matter.
Im still eat my meats, its not my fault companies are making more money to be evil, regulate it better and have money go to research/development into making it better.

Developing countries can have 3x 4x or even 10x (in extraordinarily rare cases)  the amount of carbon emissions compared to developed countries. I loved the fact that you made another video on this topic but I wish you talked more about the cycle of methane (which still doesn't help but puts it more into prospective) and the varying impact depending on where you live.

Great video explaining the situation. I admit, I am very fond of eating meat, and it would be extremely difficult for me to set my bias on this issue aside. I wonтАЩt be becoming a vegetarian any time soon. Here are a few points not mentioned for the pro-meat eating side.  I canтАЩt argue with the facts presented, but the assertion that we should all change our diets for the sake of slowing climate change is naive. 40% of Americans still refuse to get vaccinated against COVID. How can you seriously expect even a majority of Americans to make a lifestyle change that is considerably more difficult?  While there are alternatives to meat that provide protein, meat has the unique property of having no complex carbohydrates, making them ideal diet foods and essential for low sugar diets. Other than leafy greens, there are few low carbohydrate alternatives among other food groups. We canтАЩt fight AmericaтАЩs obesity epidemic while simultaneously telling people they canтАЩt eat diet foods. Eliminating meat consumption would doom someone with severe diabetes to a life of endless lettuce. IтАЩve tried eating salads on a regular basis before, and you get tired of it very quickly.  Humans are naturally omnivorous. While humans have the unique ability to deny their nature, it is not without hardship. Telling Americans to change their diets would have a success rate resembling other attempts to get large populations to deny their natural drives, like telling teenagers not to have sex. ItтАЩs just not going to work that well.  Over half a million jobs depend on meat production in the US.

There really is no good reason to not be vegan.
To anyone curious, check out the regenerative agriculture farms here in the states, white oak pastures is a good one. They're more efficient at producing meat and they're actually carbon negative because of the topsoil rejuvenation.   The video also doesn't take into account the health ramifications of long term veganism and the emissions used by the health care industry. And before anyone starts with the red meat kills you argument, there is absolutely ZERO evidence in the literature that shows a causative link between red meat and heart disease or cancer. It's all epidemiological food frequency survey nonsense with a hefty dose of confounding factors that would never stand in any other field of science. No one knows what diet will lead to longevity, because that would require sets of identical twins locked into metabolic wards for life with every factor tightly controlled, which will never happen. We can see the short to medium health ramifications of meat versus plant based diets though, and with healthy user bias removed there is a clear winner, the diet we've adhered to throughout the vast majority of our evolutionary history, one comprised mainly of animals, as the stable nitrogen  isotope testing has found in every ancient hominid population.

Yeah...meat isn't the optimal option.  But plants have the opposite problem.  Meat is a really inefficient way of producing and concentrating the nutrients we need.  The process is slow, it's an extra collection of steps to the whole process, and it does have some environmental issues resulting from all that. . But plants can't do the job alone as they are. . There is no such thing as a "superfood".  Nature doesn't do that...ever.  Also, even the "ancient grains" or other stupidity that people go on about, are all genetically-modified crops.  They weren't modified in a lab, but there's literally nothing, in the entire world, that anyone eats (even tribal peoples), that has not been thoroughly altered by direct human interference.  Not one thing anyone eats today, is a product of nature.  Period. . But, all that cross-breeding and controlled breeding, isn't enough.  we do have to tamper directly with genes to get the results we'll inevitably need.  And not just with the food, but ourselves.  It must happen, or the do-gooders must accept sentencing hundreds of millions of people to death.

So the average American consumes 25 kg of beef a year. In the US beef only produces 22 kg of CO2 equivalent per kg - no deforestation for beef production in US. So the average American produces 550 kg of CO2 equivalent per year from beef consumption.  This is only one 6-hour plane ride per year, or driving 3.5 miles per day in a gas vehicle. Less than 12 miles per day in an electric vehicle. I think context is important.

It is really hypocritical that North America and Europe, after having devastated their native forest in the past, blame Brazil (like this video) for not preserving its native forests. As a comparison, Brazil has about 66% of its territory preserved as native forest, while USA has 20% (data from 2017). Europe had 7% of all native forest in the planet, nowadays it's got only 0,1%. Brazil's 66% of preserved native forest is equivalent to the total territory of all  European Union countries combined. So, of course Brazil should do an even better job at preserving its native forest, however it is really hypocritical to see North America and Europe playing the "good guys" after what they have done to their own forests in the past.

Something important to point out is the "best" beef in regards to climate change is from factory farming. Hell on earth. There are inseparable ethical issues with animal products. After all, meat was someone's body. Milk is breastmilk from a new mother meant for her child - cows don't just leak milk constantly for no reason. And the genetic modifications we make (whether through natural selection or direct modification) have detrimental side effects to their health. Cows suffer from how large their utters have been forced to grow now. Chickens bred for meat break their bones as a regular occurrence under their own body weight.

Bullshit. This whole thought process of thinking of emissions as "carbon footprint" makes no sense because it's less than the sum of its parts. 10 kilograms of beef produced and shipped to an end consumer emits less than producing 1 kilogram and shipping it 10 times. That's, of course, assuming that you don't think beef itself emits kilograms of CO2 like this video kindly puts it.  Also, the narrative seems to spin it around like *you're* guilty for climate change. You're not.  What does it matter if you eat vegan food when burning fossil fuel is the leading cause of emissions? When there are hundreds of millions of vehicles burning fuel all at the same time? When coal power plants emit volumes of a swimming pool per second?  This individual approach to climate change assumes everyone will go vegan and cut beef out of their diet. They're not going to. I'm not going to. Call me whatever the fuck you want, if i didn't buy that steak someone else would have.

One huge problem with this video is that Kurzgesagt isn't neutral.  They believe that being vegan is the best way, buy the truth is that it's such a complex matter, you can't summarise it in a 12 minute video. For example they said that 19% soy is for human use. But you can't use 100% off the plant for humans. You extract the oil (20% of the weight from the plant) the rest, the soy waste,  is used to feed animals.  So very little of the total soy plant production is only used for cattle.
Nothing will solve this issue effectively until we can sequester the carbon remove it from the air with new tech.
Lots of people don't know this but 20% of all palm oil and 89% palmseed oil is used for production animals. It binds their food into pellets. Even more rainforest can be saved.

These seem more reasonable than the hard line imposition of veganism.

I like meat, it tastes great. I definitely understand people's apprehension towards moving away from it, but the one thing I love most in this world is humanity. I want our species to remain eternal and become a permanent prescence in this universe. I think the emotion based arguments of ethics and morality are asinine and irrelevant to this discussion; our preservation is the only criterion that matters. In all likelihood humanity will be the last organisms to go extinct from climate change, and it won't be for a very long time even if we do not get our act together, but the longer the Earth lasts the more time we have to make certain that we put ourselves into the position in which we can live forever. I think the personal freedom to eat the food which you desire is great, but you must assess the consequences. Luckily there are options to be considered that allow us to remove the agriculture of animals and still have access to meat. Lab grown meat is the only long term solution for those that don't want to cease eating meat, but the technology is still a ways away.

More CO2 means a greener planet. NASA has revealed that human-emitted CO2 has vastly helped plant life to flourish. I predict that in the future, CO2 emissions will be considered a benefit. After all, current CO2 atmospheric content is low compared to earlier eras, and the low current levels have coincided with an increase in desertification. All of the CO2 we emit was originally taken from the atmosphere by photosynthesis and then stored in the earth by geological processes. The photosynthesis occurred by solar energy - making fossil fuels naturally stored solar energy, and we are simply putting back into the atmosphere CO2 that was once naturally there. The very mild warming CO2 emissions cause is not harmful, and the "feedbacks" and "forcings" part of the alarmist theories are pure fantasy and already proven wrong by empirical evidence. We should not be afraid of a slightly warmer, much greener world. So eat your steaks. Drive your SUVs, fly often, and consume as much electricity as you like. Planet Earth will thank you.

Very well presented--one thing missing is that "buying local" beef and other meat often involves going to a trusted butcher who has a relationship with local farmers, who are more likely to raise the cattle, et al., with better practices (giving the "high quality" meat that would show the 1/10x factor in emissions). Local farmers also don't have the capacity to over-produce like factory farms, so if all/most beef were local, there would generally be an increase in quality and a decrease in quantity; this should compound in benefits of reduced emissions and improved food enjoyment.  At least, this is my current understanding of localized agriculture as a butcher-going consumer, not an agricultural scientist.

My father happends to have dairy farm. It is true that we would have to use large amount of grassland to even allow cows to walk freely on it. Not only becouse cows would eat it out, but as the walk they also destroy grass same as u see humans do when they make shourtcut on grass in parks, lawns etc. So we would have to have at least 3/4 separate pastures to get our cows to walk freely but also would have to restore grasslands (regrow and maintnace jobs) but also would have to have yet another ones to store some grass for cows to have smt to eat in winter. Another thing is that if we put our cows on mainly grass diet we would get much worse milk ratio from them. Dairy cows maight be 1t in weight but theirs stomachs are very delicate and they need special diet (we have 3 dietician and vet preparing healthy and efficient food for them) if not feed correctly they would surley cut on milk and probably ll lack some vitamins, proteins etc so they would surley become sick since they are not wild animals anymore etc.  It is also true that meat cows get worse food since if they fall sick we don't care if they cut on milk since they are not milked as long as they can just stay well most of the time and grow all is good.
con tro vissy
It's especially interesting how getting rid of all meat for everybody (except for the 1% of the 1% ruling class) still doesn't make a dent in greenhouse emissions, because there are poor countries that rely on fossil fuels and inefficient burning methods. Plus, it's also interesting how it doesn't mention that in the 20th century, forests everywhere around the globe actually started to grow back, not diminish. Why? Because people switched to coal and oil and stopped cutting down trees for fuel, and more CO2 makes trees regrow faster as it's their food.  So I'd rather conclude that while we definitely should address deforestation (only with nuance: did you know that most brazilian forest area cut down is converted to tree farms? Did you know that tree farms are more efficient in carbon capture than wilderness?), we have no solid reason for changing our dietary habits.

Hey! I'm working on a project right now where we take yeast, edit them to convert methane into methanol. The goal is to get an A.C./filtration system that has panels of inoculated media to break down the methane. Methanol is toxic in our bodies as our liver breaks it down into Formaldehyde, but it's a clean-burning source of fuel, and we can use it to power the filters machinery. My hope is to get these panels to industrial cattle/dairy farms in order to cut down on methane released into the atmosphere. :)  My goal is to engineer the microbiomes of cattle so that they reduce if not eliminate methane production, but as it stands the only proteins to break down methane that have been discovered so far are ones that produce methanol...

It's extremely unwise, I mean freaking stupid, to ignore human physiology and say that a calorie is a calorie. If a potato and a piece of meat have same amount of calorie, they have a total different effects on our body, namely, obesity and diabetes, and thus the whole downstream effects and burdens put upon the healthcare system and pharmaceutical industries which are also chemistry labs.  It is also unwise, I mean freaking stupid, to think going all out to raise animals in the natural way, won't change anything. Grass fed and pasture raised animals don't contain same nutrients as the factory farmed meats, which is quite obvious in my opinion.  All in all, I think the total ignorance of human physiology or even animal physiology related to food is the fundamental flaw of this video.
Generally good video but left out a few fairly important details.  Not all the grain grown is for humans yes, however not all grains grown for humans is of usable quality. When the quality is low it is used for animal feed, else it would be wasted and that carbon would be in the veg column.   Secondly, when food production has waste, either quality, or otherwise, the food goes to either landfill or to feed livestock in industrial farming. This waste is not accounted for in the breakdowns, only when first produced.   And finally, although mentioned, the calorific density of vegetables means that to get the same number of available calories for world consumption we would need to clear vast amounts of land, and we would need to ship, store, and distribute a vastly wider diet to make sure all nutritional needs are met. Which is fine in western countries, but presents a problem in underdeveloped places.   The answer is not as simple as giving up meat, switching from beef to chicken or pork is one way, but you can't sell that as a concept. Lowering beef consumption is more viable, but there are many issues with that as well.   And this is not even looking at the environmental impact that farming crops in areas where they are not supposed to be, rice in australia for instance. And the other impacts that monocrops present, and the increased usage of pesticides, herbicides, and fertiliser.
The single biggest problem with agriculture's carbon emissions is food waste. We cannot shut a global industry of this scale down in a century, let alone overnight, but systemic changes to our logistics and purchasing habits (as consumers yes, but definitely as suppliers) is the best and simplest changes we can make to reduce our carbon footprint. Buy less, and use our food more efficiently.

This is a important part of the data, because the inedible parts are given to the animals. If you put it in a landfill or compost it you still get methane for it. If you give to the animals you make a nutrional dense food + methane.

In my mind the only mostly ethical choice for beef and meat from other grazing mammals. Is to take that 77% cut to how much we consume. And only have grass fed meat from land that can't be used as efficiently otherwise. This video doesn't account at all for all the wasted product in meat industry. Most of beef that is consumed makes up only a portion of what's usable. Muscle is far less nutrient, mineral, and vitamin dense than most organ meats. In particular liver or brain. But those are frequently discarded (or at least not consumed by humans; I'm no expert in how the meat industry handles less desirable parts but I'm under the impression there's a lot of waste). All parts of an animal are usseable and useful. But also just in grocery stores, restaurants, and other wise there's a lot of needless trashing of food.  People can relatively easily change their diet once they decide to. Give them a better alternative with more incentives and the will come. For example there should be a hell of a lot more talk about eating insects and how you might do that, especially in videos like these.  On a related note I'm pescetarian and would love to see a similar video talking about the impact of eating fish and other sea life, and where/how it's sourced. Including the impact it can have on local ecosystems. Which is something I also wish was expanded on in this video (or covered in it's own video).

There is a big problem here: Assuming that we can just "take out meat" without consequences. Living totally v** (censorship??) is not healthy for you in the long run, and not many people can actually sustain such a diet. It's complicated and requires that you keep close attention to supplements. Even if you do, you're still likely to suffer from brain fog, frail hair, nails and teeth, anemia and a wide range of mental problems such as depression and anxiety. These symptoms can take years to develop, so just because you've been vegan for a few years and still have all your teeth, it doesn't mean this is not true. Also, kids coming up on a vegan diet are not thriving at all. See Shawn Baker on IG for some perspective. Edit: Why the hell is this comment being removed?? Is YouTube so afraid of people not following the "approved narrative"?
