While this is very interesting and helpful, I feel like there is something missing.  What about homesteads, and livestock that have their diets supplemented with left over veggies from the garden? How does that effect the carbon foot print? And what about rabbit as livestock?
There is definitely a moral/ethical argument against factory farming of animals for meat (or other products, for that matter).  However, in every other aspect, it's less obvious.  Nutritionally, vegans miss out on several key vitamins and MUST supplement artificially to maintain health.  In recent research, animal fats appear to be much safer for human consumption than vegetable-based oils.  Starchy vegetarian diets (and especially industrially-processed food products) appear to promote diabetes and obesity much more than "whole food" omnivore and carnivore diets.  The bottom line is that we still don't really understand what foods are healthy or not, and ultra-processed plant-based meat substitutes are unlikely to actually be good for your health.  The video also missed several key arguments used by meat-eaters (and the meat industry I'm sure) to deflect some blame from the industry (although I'm sure it still deserves blame). 1.  Most animal feed is made from non-edible crops (mentioned) and byproducts of edible crops (not mentioned) that would otherwise be mulched and generate methane.  Animals upcycle otherwise-useless plant matter into food that we can eat.   2. It's not just that very little of the land area currently used for animals (and crops to support them) could be repurposed for other food crops (mentioned) - it can't, and won't.  That amount of land is exceedingly UNLIKELY to be "returned to nature" to reabsorb carbon - there would be too much pressure to use it for other purposes, e.g. solar farms for renewable energy production.  Pastureland is usually much too arid to be used for forests - it's mostly grassland.  Grasslands turn out to be most productive (and absorb the largest amount of carbon) if they have large herds of herbivores (usually ruminants like buffalo or cattle) roaming around them, to flatten the grass, convert grass to manure, and so on.  So... maybe we just need to figure out better ways of managing cattle herds? 3. Destruction of the Amazon forest (which is a significant ecological/environmental issue) is actually much less about cattle ranching than an issue of people not knowing how else to make a living.  Figure out a better way to keep people in Brazil employed, paid, and housed, and there would be much less pressure on the forests.  This is NOT an easy challenge though. 4. An environmental position that farm animals should not be eaten for meat is indistinguishable from saying that we should not have any domestic animals - including pets.  That is, if you ban commercial production of beef and sheep for meat consumption, where is the logical endpoint?  After all, dogs and cats also eat meat products, and other food that could be diverted from food used for people.   If you ban cattle farming, would there be ANY large herbivores left in the Americas?  There used to be an estimated 100 million buffalo on the North American plains, which presumably also produced methane.  Why are cattle having more GHG impacts now than the ruminants of the past (or are they?), and if so, is this something that can be adjusted through better feedstock techniques?  As the video starts out by saying - "it's complicated".

I will make one comment: Despite being "greener", shipping vegetables by boat is only part of the emissions. Most of those vegetables had to travel either by train or by truck to distribution center, shipped from there to the port, from the destination port to another distribution center, and from there to the various stores and groceries. This is why vegetables have a high CO2 emission rating.

I love this Chanel
Here is a video idea on a similar topic: Phosphorous - the extinction you don't know about Basically, we are all afraid of global warming, meteor strike, global thermonuclear war, the collapse of the monetary system, or zombie apocalypse. Barely anyone knows about that we are running out of phosphorous. The current global demand for food requires the usage of fertilizers for the plants, both for human consumption and the consumption of our livestock. The basic fertilizer, NPK, is made of nitrogen (which you are breathing right now), potassium (which is in abundance), and phosphorous. The latter one is a mineral and as such, non-renewable. Add to this that huge amounts of it is unavoidably wasted (for example washed away due to simple everyday things like rain), and suddenly we have a problem on our hand. A big one. Some estimates say we run out of it in 80-100 years, more pessimistic ones expect as little as 20 years considering that the demand is increasing exponentially. Imagine that suddenly bread vanishes from existence, so does meat, and fruit and vegetables become unaffordable luxury. Or, you know, we may experience a zombie apocalypse...

Whilst I agree with nearly everything, there are a few points of contention. For one the local beef vs internationally shipped avocados. These avocados travel across vast distances by, often very outdated and poluting, trucks or cars to get to the harbour. On this side it still moves from the harbour, to auction, distribution centres, supermarkets and eventually your home. With the vast amount of variables it might be hard to calculate but if you count these things for local beef you might as well for avocados. One might even make the mistake of thinking shipping beef from South America isn't that different in carbon footprint to buying local beef. I agree with the sentiment of "buying it locally doesn't make meat better than exotic plants" but it does help eliviate the enviromental strain of meat in general somewhat.  As for stopping the meat industry would free up space for nature, in a theoretical sense maybe. Realistically the owners of these lands would probably want to keep earning money off of it and would switch to other means. Not to mention the carbon currently sequestered in some pastures would likely outweight the possible sequestration of carbon in forests/grasslands in areas otherwise too dry to support high density plantlife naturally. Switching to full grass fed beef could be a lot less poluting. Theoretically even an almost closed carbon cycle with some innovation.
IтАЩm still going to eat meat place the combinations make prints go
My best recommendation to people is to stay open and go slow. Stay open to the possibility that you can make and find delicious vegan recipes, expand slowly your options while cutting meats little by little. I do believe as a whole we can reach a sweet spot where meat is a luxury item, but as a culture we are well educated so its not something that is inaccesible or hoarded. But overall look at your day to day diet, and simply consider how much you are missing on by having a heavy meat only diet.  Food is an experience, it's a ride, it takes learning and de-learning to stay open. I used to be a really pesky eater, all i could stand was meat and heavy carbohydrates, but with the time, education and the right people giving the example, i'm slowly expanding my food options, where sometimes i can go days happy having only fruits and veggies. Be patient with yourself, and please above all else, dont romanticize an ideal, don't fall in love with the way things are. Stay open to the possibility that it might be better for your health and that your life could take a drastic shift by slowly making the changes we need.

What kind of positive impact could we have on reducing carbon emissions, if all *processed foods* were outlawed?...  There would be less factories required to be supplied power or need to be serviced, far less packaging required - that would result in less trash produced...  therefore less trash needed to be collected by a convoy of trucks,  which means there would be less transport of trash to a processing plant,  and less processing plants.  Reduction in manufacturing /transporting of chemical preservatives  and less labs creating artificial flavorings.  Perhaps more importantly, people would be far more healthier and energeticтАж  most likely be happier for it too! A healthier and happier society would have less demand on health services, so that would mean less medicines needed to be manufactured, less health facilities required to be built, powered or maintained.  Lastly, healthier people would be more inclined to walk, jog or cycle to their destinations rather than using automotive transportтАж  Just a thought.

Most people live nowhere near the amazon. My local farmer also does not buy soybeans (or other crops) grown on brazillian fields as feedstock, using locally grown hay instead. If you don't buy locally you have no control over, or even much opportunity to even find out, what other co2 emitting practices are used during the production of your beef.   'Animal suffering is good for the environment':  looking at the studies provided I do not see how this conclustion is reached. The Studies point out that feeding cows high quality hay (which, again, usually is produced locally, on otherwise unarable land) is better for the animals, as well as better for the environment, while I have the impression cows in factory farming are the ones getting fed feedstock grown on those fields that still were brazilian rainforest not so long ago and then, on top of that, emit more methane?
Fun video, but nothing said in it is actually useful anywhere. Global numbers for this topic lump the US in with countries like India. 2 Countries with VERY different efficiency when it comes to beef production. A skewed perception for most will be the result. Even without mentioning the stuff you got wrong in the video.

wonderful as always
I worked in the beef industry for several years and heavily researched the carbon impact of beef. I largely agree with the conclusion of this video. The biggest problem with beef production is a matter of scale. Scaling up production is "efficient" in terms of dollars and profit, but comes at the cost of slash and burn land clearing, intensive monocrop animal feed agriculture, extreme water use and water pollution, and greenhouse gas emissions. Beef absolutely can be raised in an environmentally friendly and low emissions way, but the maximum amount that can be produced without serious negative externalities is less than 20% of current beef consumption. Worldwide, there is not much land that has the correct soil and climate to be good at raising beef, but in a way that does not negatively affect the biodiversity of the environment. Basically only semi-arid grasslands that have historically supported large populations of bison or other migratory grass eating animals.
Comparison on 4:35 is bullshit. Regardless of the cargo, moving either meat or veggies via ships will take less and from the port to your market more.  But I guess that pointing that out wouldn┬┤t fit the narrative.
Humans can't live healthily without meat in some capacity, so what would be alternatives to beef, pork, lamb and chicken?  Or fish?  It's disingenuous to suggest that veganism is an option.  Vegetarianism, yes, but not veganism.

Good video, but there are certain aspects which I am still not sure why you didn't cover.  1. How much of the CO2 emitted by the cows is "new" CO2? Methane breaks down into CO2 and H2O in the atmosphere, which along with other CO2 return to the earth in form of grass, which the cow eats again, forming a cycle where no actual new CO2 gets released into the atmosphere. How much of the CO2 being relaesed is this cyclical CO2 compared to the "new" CO2 released by, say, a fossil fuel engine of the transportation truck?  2. How much of the "crops grown to feed cattle" is actually fit for human consumption? For example, corn husks and almond hulls can't be eaten by humans, but can be eaten by animals, but these parts are still considered as "crops grown to feed cattle"? This seems a bit misleading.  Might add more if I see something else.  Edit 1:  3. Regarding soy. Around 77% of soy is grown for animal feed, but in the video that mostly discusses cows, this is very misleading. According OurWorldInData, only 1.9% of soy is fed for beef and dairy products combined. Half of animal feed soy (37% total) is used for poultry production and 20% of total is used for pork. In a video that discusses beef and cows for nearly all of its runtime, the statistic of 77% of soy is used for livestock feed is misleading. I do not think the Kurzgesagt team wanted to intentionally mislead people, but it is concerning. Another study prepared for United Soybean Board stated that of all soybean meal used in US as livestock feed, just over 10% is used for beef and dairy, which is still food used for cattle instead of people, but not to the degree the video implies. Overall, the fact that so many soybeans are used for cattle feed is concerning, but the main fault for that lies with poultry and pork, not with cows.
Land rotation. Conveniently ignored top soil erosion and arable production concerns surrounding flood plains. Animals can swim  Cattle also naturally recycle top soil by merely enhabitting the land, so free range cattle would help boost the viability of top soil. The issue is that we have fenced animals away from arable fields for centuries and not rotated the lands use. This has led to deterioration of the top soil globally. To remove free roaming grass fed cattle and livestock would spell the end of global food surplus and bring us into an age of famine. Not to mention cooked red meat is one of the greatest reasons we evolved as a species, removing it from our diets will only serve to degrade general human intellect, not hindering but accelerating us towards idiocracy

Hmmm....so you only calculate the shipping efficiency of an avocado across the ocean, and then ignore the total cost of distributing the av.o. The total cost is based on growing it, then shipping it globally, and then distributing it locally. Thus the CO2 costs of an avo include production, then transoceanic shipping (which may be more efficient than the next necessary stage), and then local distribution - the SAME local distribution channel as that used by locally produced beef or whatever.  So clearly the avo, per kg, is far unfriendlier than locally produced beef. Ignoring or overlooking facts is a pretty poor way to conduct an analysis.  Thats why u get no subscription from me. I'm kind of confused as to why transport emissions are included in this video. It kind of gripes me how the video mentions that oversea shipping is the most efficient mode of transport but I do not know whether it being shipped further inland on trucks is accounted for in that number or not. If that isn't the case, wouldn't the shipping emissions just add to the solution of cargo trucks? And even if it is, the raw amount of emissions would always be more due to distance so purchasing locally would be less polluting in both cases. Besides, if theoretically zero emission transport existed the meat issue would still not be solved in the slightest. Mainly because it is a separate issue despite having some connection to the subject discussed in this video. Another issue I have is how the focus of the video was a lot on beef all though I understand why, mainly because of how polluting it is compared to other meat. Yet, I would've liked it if there was a focus on the other meat types as well. I'm especially interested in poultry because of its low emission standard in the first place and the fact that the video mentioned that beef could potentially be made very carbon efficient as well. If the average pound of beef would cost 71kg of carbon and the best beef 9kg, how much can the efficiency of poultry be increased? If that amount of reduction would apply to poultry as well, which I would highly doubt but its just hypotheticals now,  it would be less than a kilogram of carbon per pound of poultry. Would meat as a secondary product from dairy cows being more efficient apply to chickens used for egg farming as well? Since poultry is efficient how much more efficient can we make it with these points and can it be close to being as viable as vegetables?  And for the last thing, I don't see any metions at all regarding the meat discussion is about how much carbon is that is set free is already in the carbon cycle. As the video mentioned a large amount of the beef process is letting cows consume feed that is inedible for humans which could mean that inedible biomass can be turned into edible biomass without adding any carbon to the cycle. It would be good to know how much of the carbon is produced that way since that wouldn't be a net gain on the total carbon in it. I could probably find this kind of info online but I wouldn't know where to start looking. Liked the rest of the video as always. Usually your content always takes a pretty unbiased view on subjects which is something we could use a lot nowadays so thank you for that.

Another great video, but I'm a bit confused about the part at 9:35 The top bar shows the proposed 800 billion tons of CO2 that could be removed by 3 billion hectares of reclaimed/spared land over the course of ONE HUNDRED years. The bottom bar, however, shows the amount of CO2 equivalent emissions emitted by humanity over the course of ONE year.  I don't understand the choice to show these bars side-by-side without adjusting one of them to match the timeframe of the other. 800 billion tons of CO2 sequestered over 100 years averages out to 8 billion tons sequestered annually in that time period. While scaling either of the bars makes the positive impact of reclaimed land seem much less impressive, it's still a sizable positive impact.

Beef is necessarily carbon neutral, because they only consume grass, that grows by absorbing carbon from the air, or crops, that, you guessed it, grow by absorbing carbon from the air. All the methane a cow produced comes from the air.  If so, how could cows be responsible for carbon emmitions? They aren't. We add carbon to our carbon cycle by extracting it from where it was previously sequestered. We burn trees and oil we dug up from the ground and we'll have a problem until we put that carbon back where it belongs.  There's a hundred decisions that are made before I decide that I want to eat beef, that, had they not been made, or had they been made differently, would make my decision carbon neutral. If my decision of what to eat isn't carbon neutral I bear zero responsibility for it.   I was not the one that decided to burn the forest, I was not the one that decided to dig up and use the oil, I was not the one that decided to accept a bribe to ignore environmental issues and I won't see a dime of the cheater's profits, so don't tell me it's my responsibility to save the environment. Personal carbon footprint was devised by BP to ofuscate from their responsibility and has worked wonders for their bottom line.  If you want to solve climate change tax the activities that introduce sequestered carbon to the carbon cycle by enough to sequester it anew, and stop telling me what I need to do to pay for the decisions of unfathomably rich business moguls and corrupt politicians.
Go vegan. We don't have a planet B.
A good point in this for people to realize, as well, is that CO2 isn't the only factor to consider, especially as a more "friendly" environment in that regard can be a more ethically horrible environment for the animals, depending on how reduction is obtained.  Personally, my ideal situation is for the development of cultured meats paired with plant mixtures to take the place of the bulk of meat production (think ground beef and such where the form doesn't matter, fast food, grocery store shelves, in general the places where people aren't expecting 5 star anyway), with a smaller contingent of ethically treated animals left for those who are too resistant, or view it as a delicacy.    (Edit: A note for this, as I see misconceptions in other comments, cultured meat is just that, meat grown in a culture. It isn't GMO or otherwise twisted away from being actual "meat" (not that I inherently view that as wrong, but understand the difficulties both in tech and perception), but requires essentially tricking the cells to think they are still in a growing body. There are good and bad ways to do this, as with everything)  With cultured meats, I can imagine entire new markets of specially grown marinade baths that incorporate flavor directly into the tissues at the most base levels, and even finer control of hygiene for ultra rare dishes, along with control of exact levels of nutrients for health.

Ah yes, my gigantic coal power plant is not the issue, it's bob and his cow that is ruining the planet.  Demonizing cows for climate change is the finest example of butwhataboutism you could ever make. They will teach this in schools in five years hopefully, if reason gets its way in the end.  There are a lot of studies about food impact on climate change and in particular beef, and a lot of them are bogus. This channel claims to be fact based and unbiased, but it stacked as many of the "facts" that paint beef in a bad light as possible and then said "we're not telling you what to think, you make the decision". That's bullshit. Selectively omitting truths that go against your narrative is far from being neutral.  Long story short, despite what this video wants you to believe, even if the majority of the people on this planet would suddenly stop eating meat, it would have an absolutely miniscule impact on climate change. You could literally make a bigger change by turning the lights off in your house more consistently. Fossil fuels are the real killer here, not a pound of beef.

We don't have to argue that humans in many important ways are totally different and valued more than a pig or a cow, but in anyway these non human animals do resemble us; in their care for their children, their ability to feel pain, their social skills... These are ALL characteristics we used to describe moral value to a human being too.. We should talk about how we should see them in our ethical framework, they deserve our ethical consideration and that we recognize the differences we share with these non human animals but only taking them into account when there actually morally relevant. In race for example we recognize it's not a difference in trait that gives these people of different races the same ethical consideration. But if you find the trait that you think it is that differentiate a human being from a non human animal that justify's the differences in treatment. The logic would work as such: you would find the trait, the characteristic, that those non human animals don't have, that if a human being would to also not have we treat the human being like we treat the non human animal.

Hello guys!  There are some informations spreaded out wrongly, mainly by non-specialized media, about my country (Brazil) and the situation of forests in the national territory (tropical forests are just one of the brazilian biomes). First of all, the problems with wild fires happened on a global scale due to a sum of many factors that are really hard to summarise in a few words. We've heard of wildfires across the United States, Australia, and almost every country in Central Africa, so please, don't contribute to a narrative that is enriched with hidden interests that are difficult to be fully traced.   Brazil is not devastating or burnning down the amazon area for the cultivation of soybeans. The vast majority of  national production is highly mechanized and efficient per hectare, coming from states in the southern and midwestern regions, therefore, far from dense areas of forest. I'm not saying that there isn't a challenge in Brazil to reduce problems with fires and illegal appropriation of forest spaces, or responsibilities with rapid climate change and agricultural production, but Brazil is a country that still preserves approximately 66% of it's total territory, with at least 84% of the tropical forest in a mature and/or virgin state.  Please, keep up with the great job bringing reliable and cientific content to your channel, because those discussions cannot remain shallow and inconsequential, especially in your videos.

b'ah. As thorough as you guys usually are, it still feels like you missed some key things here that are skewing the statistics too much. I know this is really detailed, but there's a ratio of methane that was pulled from the air by grass. That isn't "new" emissions like burning coal/oil. That's emissions that were there and mostly got put back. Then as others have stated, the transportation examples seem to have left off the last mile. Feels like you compared shipping efficiencies with last mile cost. But you still have the last mile when shipping. You just now have the ocean liners emissions PLUS last mile emissions. So that's overal worse?  Then there's different types of cows. Especially in dairy. US dairy cows are waaaaay more efficient than, say, india's cows. There's a lot to cut down there alone.   So these potential misses in comparing data make it hard to know if your calculations are correct when comparing meat to vegetables. Did you look into how much is by-products of vegetables vs intentionally grown for cattle? Was the difference taken into account that when you remove 100 cows, then you also have to clear land for farming? Like you said, a decent chunk of land that is used isn't arable. That land will have to be replaced.   And then the biggest point of all. Food is 26% overall. Removing beef would clear up some 15%. That's great and all, but I think it's a moot point until we solve that other 74%. B/c that's asking a lot of peopel to give up something they really enjoy for a marginal gain. Especially when this is extremely hard to accurately compare.

One issue with the "feeding cattles with plants humand could eat" is that it completely neglects that we humans don't want tk eat all the parts of plants. There's stems and other byproducts making up most of the weight of a plant that humans can't digest or are too picky to eat, but cows can thanks to their stomach. There's also lots of byproducts from food factories that gets fed to animals. Just think of all the peels from potatoes, apples etc. when buying stuff that has apples in it. Same goes for most things we eat. Even fish gets grinded into powder and fed to animals.  I'd have loved a dive into this topic as I'm curious as to how much food humans would *actually* eat gets fed to cows.

The reality of climate change and тАЬcarbon allocationsтАЭ is that populations are unsustainable. WeтАЩre working with the idea of every country and city becoming first world and as such, pluck fictional тАЬcarbon budgetsтАЭ out of thin air.   The reality is, places like India, China and Africa have really missed the on ramp of history in regards to development.   With billions of populations in these countries now being artificially supported by fragile supply systems. The sheer numbers of import/export just to sustain, let alone grow are immense and stretch this mythical тАЬcarbon targetsтАЭ or тАЬallocationsтАЭ.  Just like Africa, with population increases after billions of $$$ aid, during what normally would have been population culling famine.   Human climate change is being driven by unchecked over populations in 3rd world and тАЬdevelopingтАЭ countries. Most 1st world countries have stabilised populations naturally (if you ignore rampant immigration, which in itself distorts any climate change argument, even food production)  Population reduction in 3rd world and developing countries is our only hope.

In the case of the Amazon you forgot that deflorastation for pasture is even more inefficient. The Amazon rain forest has a self sustained cicle of life. That is a layer of fertile land that it is sustained by the decomposition of organic matter coming from the rain forest. When deflorestation happen, that cycle is broken and after a few years the layer is used up and what is left is a land that sometimes cannot grow even pasture.

An Idea to raise livestock that combines the space saving benefits of factory cattle and the better quality meat of dairy cattle:  We could build large artificial pastures that collect the methane released by the cattle, which produce meat and dairy products. These artificial pastures could be built to stacked on top of each other to save space and still keep up with the demands of he world. This design could be used for other livestock as well. The methane could be used to generate power that could bring us a little bit more off coal and some oil in terms of energy. I'm not sure if methane can be used for vehicle fuel. These structures could also produce at least some of the feed for the animals to take some of the pressure off the land the world has.  I don't know how feasible this is, but I thought it was a good idea.

What food, if not beef is equivalent in protein? It's not entirely about the carbon footprint, it's about what you do with the protein. If all you do is sit around and do nothing, then _yes_ the meat and emissions that come with it is put to waste. If on the other hand you use meat as part of a balanced diet to _do physical activity_ with and said activity benefits your society, suddenly that argument changes.  Humanity could _survive_ on soy and plant-based protein. But for objective which require strength, where protein is directly responsible for muscle development it put into question what foods could replace beef? There's a reason why it tastes _good_ to most people, and that's because not only of its buttery texture and rich taste if cooked correctly, but also because the body benefits most from it.  And what about emissions from wild animals? We never account for that. Humanity can't be zero-emission because we mammals breathe, fart and burp too. The ideal argument then, if we want for humanity to not be as impactful on the environment is a mass culling of the human race. But _that's_ not friendly to anyone reading this at all.  War тАФ endless, ceaseless war тАФ ironically then can be a boon for humanity not only technologically, but also environmentally. Disregarding emissions from heavy machinery, a mass death of humanity can lead to less emissions and less need to cultivate land for farm use because there are less humans to feed overall, and less nature being destroyed so long we have a gentleman's agreement to not go nuclear.
I don't eat local to reduce CO2 emissions, I eat local (and in-season) to support local businesses, and to not mess up the lives of local farmers elsewhere (for example, farmers in Chile who had all their water supplies robbed by big avocado mafias). For the CO2 emissions, I only walk or use public transportation, I limit overseas traveling, I don't go crazy on the heating and I live a semi-minimalist lifestyle (i.e. less pollution from producing and throwing stuff). And no kids. Besides, when you eat imported (and not-in-season) crops, there may be all this extra step in refrigeration + crops picked when they are not yet ripe and thus less tasty.  I do eat plant-based (though I always have, as a vegetables-loving half-Chinese), and avoid fast foods (and thus their cheap mass-produced meat). The price tag of a good local, non-factory-farmed chicken makes me wince, but oh well, I buy that only occasionally and that chicken gets divided into 10 portions (most go immediately into the freezer) instead of being eaten in just a couple of meals.

I was dreading it but I still felt sad when I saw Kurzgesagt quoting PooreтАжthat study was insanely cherry picked. Their тАШlowestтАЩ emissions from beef was higher than IтАЩve seen LCA for various European beef production. This also leads to an incorrect conclusion that the best of beef is worse than the worst of plant based. For instance textured tofu has a higher co2e LCA than Irish produced beef. Why? Because Ireland has both high productivity and grass fed.    But it got worseтАжтАЩcattle in factory farmsтАЩ not able to graze. These animals donтАЩt exist. Even in very intensive systems in the US most calves are reared on extensive grazing before entering their final stage, the beef finishing process. ThatтАЩs where you see feedlots (the term тАШfactory farmтАЩ is a dead give away for the bias of the researcher in this case). Interesting that Kurzgesagt didnтАЩt use FAO study into this topic that showed 86% of feed for livestock is human inedible, with ruminants contributing a net increase in protein even including feed (source: FAO, Livestock: On our plates or eating at our table 2017). A far more reputable source. In addition the use of 25% rather than the more accurate 14.5% of global emissions related (source: FAO, Tackling Climate Change through Livestock 2013, IPCC 2021) Final conclusion as someone who studied agriculture with a focus on climate change mitigation, this looks like an objective video from Kurzgesagt but isnтАЩt anywhere near their normal standard. Shows signs of cherry picking and bias, but more significantly a lack of agricultural SCIENCE education in the researchers

So the problem is not the meat itself it's the way you raise and feed cattle on top of the insane amount of waste in the western world... I've lived many years in a rural setting, I've seen cows, pigs, lambs, chickens being fed, if not scaled into industrial production they do very little impact in the environment, if anything they do the opposite. Sheep and cows take care of the land, prevent wild fires and fertilize, the same land that can be used a few years later for agricultural. Pigs eat pretty much anything, veggies, fruits, nuts and other plants that aren't edible by humans. I've seen pigs be essentially fed on leftovers. All of these animals are very valuable to the ecosystem and when done properly they come at very little cost. The real problem is industrialization of the meat production business

8:00 yup, 70% less beef, grass fed only, fight me.
I have an issue with the methane thing. Plants absorb CO2. Cows eat plants and burp methane - CH4. Then the methane goes in the atmosphere and in time gets converted to CO2 + H2O. The CO2 then gets absorbed in to plants and the cycle closes. This suggests that cows don't really add to the greenhouse gas volume. They simply recycle a part of it. It's wrong to count the methane burps as emissions and there are papers that confirm it.  The real picture is of course not that simple. For instance methane does react with other chemicals and can have ozone depleting properties but in the interest of science I can't accept completely omitting the methane production and degradation cycle.
Dont forget where we humans come from, meat got us here. Instead of reducing our meat intake per person. Maybe we should consider reducing the amount of people we need to feed

This doesn't seem to really engage with sources of wild-caught and hunted food. Obviously those still need proper management and harvesting quotas but humans have sustainably harvested food from those ecosystems for millennia sustainably.   If you restored all those natural spaces and the species that are native to them, you'd be having stronger local populations of animals that themselves would represent a source of food.   Between that and traditional diets that focus on smaller amounts of meat, fed with waste products that aren't edible for humans, that seems to offer a more efficient path forward than veganism.

I'd like to point out an unacknowledged assumption which is that we must continue to produce food via methods of modern agriculture, which is not true.  Humans produced food for themselves mainly via permaculture for all of "prehistory" and that process did not drive anthropologic climate change.  Using a different essential logic is fundamental to making a meaningful systemic change.  Individual diets mean nothing if there is a systemic pressure to continue business as usual.  People need to not just ask if meat is an issue, but also what systems drove us to this present state of affairs.
Meat is the most nutrient dense food on the planet
Currently writing my dissertation on this topic! (I think I even used the same paper as this video as a key source lol) The more I read into the subject the more I was shocked to see just how impactful our diet is on the environment and I wondered why more isn't being done to change peoples diets. It seems like such a simple change to make for such a bit climate-positive payout. Of course, animal-free diets are not accessible to everyone and meat is a big industry tied up with politics in lots of ways but I hope more people can switch to beef-free, vegetarian, or vegan diets because it really is going to be essential if we want to make a difference in the fight against climate change. I know meat is delicious and hard to give up but if you're here watching this video and learning about this problem I urge you to try! Just one meal a week that's meat-free is an excellent start. And encourage friends and family too, it might not seem like its making a difference but a lot of research suggests that through consumer demand we can get big industries to change their practices to be more environmentally friendly : ) There are lots of animal rights issues that are concerning in animal agriculture too so it really is a win-win to stop eating meat.

I'm a huge fan of kurzgesagt! But I feel they missed some key points that biased this video. 1. Methane cycle: indeed methane is bad for climate change but it's in a different category than Co2. Methane falls from the sky, absorbed by the ground, used by plants then is released again by animal burps or just by dying and rotting. Back it goes in the sky. Unlike burning of fossil fuels, cows aren't not "adding" methane. Less cows may not mean less methane because of the cycle.  2. Regenerative farming: a type of farming that has shown it can be carbon negative and rejuvenate dead land where nothing was growing. I strongly checking out the work of Diana Roger's and Dr. Rob wolf and the sacred cow website.  These don't answer the consumption need but the video showed meat is by far the most nutrient dense food you can eat gram for gran. Reducing meat and dairy in developing countries for example has shown to be a disaster on development of children because they don't have access to the abundance of other food and supplements needed to replace what meat and dairy have. Being a vegetarian, and especially vegan, is a privalage the majority of the world doesn't have.  Just some thoughts from a girl trying to be objective

I would have really appreciated it if you mentioned the health and nutrient benefits of meats compared to other products. From what I've learned, Beef has most of the essential Vitamins our body needs along with other micro benefits. While other foods like Tofu are actually counter productive because of the Soy in it, lowering our natural testosterone due to the estragon found in soy products. Many health experts and enthusiasts would likely then recommend Chicken, which I could get behind if the nutritional benefit, (not just the protein to calorie ration), of Beef wasn't significant enough to warrant its mass production. Especially given that according to your research, Cows that are less nutrient dense and healthy for you, (caged, grain fed), are better for the environment than the best, (pasture-raised, grass-raised), then having Cows that are worth eating, might not be worth the cost to the planet.  Though, y'all briefly mentioned the concept of eating less beef, and thus beef production taking a hit. But, as far as I understand it, that's already a good thing. While Beef is greatly beneficial for your health, ideally you should only be eating it about 3 times a week. Thus, if people slowed their habit of eating Beef every day to something like only on the weekends, or every other day, than that would inherently be lowering the demand for Beef, thus halting the need to produce more land for said cows and ideally sticking with the land we already have. A lot of product goes to waste every day, especially Beef, so, if we are able to recognize the value of Beef, while limiting our consumption, then we could in theory give Beef farmers a better idea of how much product we actually need, which in turn would decrease cow production to the point of Beef being a specialty item that you only are available to get every once in a while, like truffles but not as extreme.  These are serious questions that I would love to have a conversation on, ideally with sources of research I can look at to disprove or amplify any of the points I have made. Thank you for your time, and let's make this planet a better place, together.
While this is a great look at meat production and it's effect on the environment, I always find these kinds of videos in very bad faith when not out into context with other areas of carbon emissions. While moving away from beef all together can absolutely have a huge impact on the environment, there are two problems with it. First, this would be a massive undertaking both economically and culturally. There would be massive pushback from lobbyists and normal folk alike. Second, and most importantly, it perpetuates the notion that climate change is an induvial, moral crisis instead of the systemic capitalist problem it really is. Saying "you need to eat less beef to save the planet" is simple a great marketing tactic that shifts the conversation onto consumers, when we really need to be talking about both our consumer practices and (much more importantly) the contributions corporations or organizations make towards pollution. A few piece of legislation that heavily regulate industrial pollution would have as much, if not more, of an effect on climate change than getting everyone to stop eating beef. Of course this has it's own massive problems, but we already have a massive movement of people who are concerned about climate change, we just need to shift our focus from consumer choices to government and corporate entities to make a real impact. At the end of the day, it's very profitable for large corporate polluters if we are arguing with each other over our own consumption choices, instead of focusing on them, the much larger problem.
If you want to become a vegan after watching this kinds of videos, please consult first a nutriologist. At 7:38 when you say 65% of beef grazing grassland cannot be converted to cropland - what is this based off? Do you have to limit the meaning of the word 'crop' to only mean foods that can be harvested with machines?  (I did try searching for 'Moffat et al' and a few relevant keywords but couldn't find the study you've used)  The reason I ask, is because I live on land that is supposed to be unusable as cropland so generally gets used for sheep, but I've found that I can quite easily grow nuts, berries and other fruit on the land, just not annual crops that require a plough or a combine. The terrain means I have to collect the harvest by hand, but the money I spend on labourers is the money I save from not buying and running a tractor/combine.  I find a lot of agricultural research makes assumptions about farming methods, when these vary wildly from farmer to farmer. In much the same way that agricultural college often teach you to take on 30 years of debt as your very first move in farming, when other routes can be far more desirable... but I digress.

I really would like to share a dubbed version of the videos of this channel. It gives so much information for the world. Brazil needs it.
One consideration not included in the video is the role cattle play in preserving grassland ecosystems. Globally, native temperate grasslands are one of the most endangered ecosystems in the entire world and they need a large grazing herbivore to provide essential services. Cattle now mimic the historic role of bison on the rapidly disappearing Great Northern Plains. Removing that grazing pressure leads to dormant plants, loss of habitat for all sorts of species (like grassland birds that need varying heights of vegetation to nest in) and decreasing soil quality. Watch the short documentary, Guardians of the Grasslands, on our channel to learn more.

For context, 71kg of CO2 is equivalent of driving a car 500-600 km, at 120-132 CO2g/km. That means a typical burger with a 100g patty will set you back 7.1 CO2 kg, equaling to 50-60 km drive. An average commute distance in US is 16 miles, equalling to 25 km.  Add it all up and we now get that having a single burger is as destructive to the environment to as a car commute. Or, if you commute by transit, a single burger will negate all positive effects from transit commuting. ЁЯдЧ

This video was.. uncharacteristically dishonest for Kurzgesagt. You guys missed a lot of important details, and that graph at the end was actively misleading. For the whole shipping vs locally sourcing argument, sure, sending things by boat is much better then by truck. But it's not like it magically teleports onto and off of the boats, it gets brought to and taken away from the docks by truck. So at the end of the day it's just as bad, if not worse then locally sourced food. And for the grain feed argument, yeah, some farms do grow grain explicitly for livestock. But most livestock feed comes from grain that simply wasn't good enough for human consumption. Farmers generally don't grow crops explicitly for livestock, because it's more profitable to grow food suitable for humans.  While I do agree that we would be better off eating less meat, I don't agree with misrepresenting the facts. It's so unlike your videos to be this way, I'm almost tempted to chalk it up to poorly done research, but you constantly talk to experts. There's no way you missed that, and absolutely no excuse for that graph at the end.
Make a part 2! Fish & seafood wasn't mentioned and they didn't mention how many cultures in our world eat insects as a good meat-type food resource.

Not being vegan is kinda sus. What do you want an animal's meat in your mouth?
A distinction needs to be made between feed lot meat (probably not good for the environment in any way, but neither are acres of monocultured crops) and more traditionally raised animals, especially those raised in an intentional, regenerative way that can actually be EXTREMELY GOOD for the environment (breaking up and refertilizing soils that have been depleted and compacted by years of mechanical agriculture and are now being eroded massively due to no life holding them together...for example). Emissions are not the only part of the story either. What is growing in a region has a direct effect on the climate there. Planting trees in an arid region for example can begin to trap moisture, increase local humidity, slow down rain bearing weather, and improve the fertility of the soil - and the diversity of the local ecosystem. Cows, ranched or pastured appropriately, create a number of positive effects on soil biodiversity, which caused positive changes up the chain, too.

Meat is bad for the environment. However, one must consider that if the entire US decided to go vegan, it would only reduce the US' total emissions by 2.6 percent. Look up the research article "Nutritional and greenhouse gas impacts of removing animals from US agriculture" by Robin R. White and Mary Beth Hall for reference. Becoming vegetarian/vegan is a good thing, but there are much better ways to reduce one's emission footprint than to become vegan/vegetarian.

I'm sure the vegans are going crazy in the comments, but saying "we should just stop eating meat" is about as much a solution to climate change as "we should just reduce the population by a few billion people".  1) What we should actually do should be policy-based. Emissions need to be taxed, which would make the price of meat, especially expensive beef, go up, ending in reduce consumption... or more efficient production methods. The entire population eating 30% less meat would have the same effect as 30% of the population going vegan, but it's a much more realistic goal. 2) Bleeding-hearts and hippies need to stop going on about local suppliers, organic foods, hating GMOs or wanting to only eat meat from grass-fed cows who get a hug at least twice a day. Half the time it's just a marketing gimmick, but it actually makes production way less efficient.
Where do the local emissions come from? How much better is it if you walk to and from the butcher?
Helping us make informed decisions - thank you!

While individuals have agency to reduce their footprint, as per Kurzgesagt's other video on climate, the only way this works is large scale enforcement. Beef, lamb, and dairy can not be outlawed, but it can be made significantly less attractive to businesses and consumers. Carbon taxes are one example, companies have to pay for each ton of emission. This would increase operating costs, and either make said industries/restaurants less money. And/or push costs on to consumers, causing other food options to be more attractive. Now of course, this requires policy makers to enact them, but this _can_ be influenced by an otherwise political minority. Vote for people supporting green policy, and vote for them again IF they follow through. Be outspoken in your community, and petition your representatives to adopt climate policy.
There are questions I have that I don't think were completely answered in this video (and maybe I'll have to dig into Kurzgesagt's sources later).  1. What is the complete impact of the diet of ruminant's (cows) to the overall food production climate impact? It's well known that cows can 'up-cycle' certain foods that are inedible to humans such as corn husks. Does the data presented in this video consider this?  2. In the estimates for greenhouse gas emissions from cattle, does it consider where the 'origin' of the carbon /methane come from? Burning coal emits from a previously isolated source of carbon, where as the carbon that a cow would emit is likely from their diet and not 'new' to the carbon cycle in general. It would (in my best estimation) come from carbon that has already been absorbed into plants etc and then just be re-emitted by the cattle post-consumption. Although the total numbers of C02 and Methane are not changed, I think its dis-ingenuous to treat the emissions as the same as say coal and natural gas emissions.   In general, should we try and optimize the efficiency of ranching and beef production? Yes. Should we generally eat a little less meat? Probably. But I would be opposed to the idea that the answer is a completely meat-free diet. In developing countries, they might not have the agriculture infrastructure required to usurp meat in their diets or have the resources required to import the ingredients necessary to eliminate meat from the diets of the citizens.

I haven't researched it fully, but this diet design seems to be common in lower income countries I believe. Not only because of the cost, but also because it's healthier! Yes. It is.  Scientifically that is, Humans dont have enough acid to break down meat effectively unlike actual Carnivores. Our teeth is generally rounded and sometimes flat which is also not effective in chewing meat properly. Carnivores have very sharp teeth that allows them to rip apart meat from the skin. Lastly, as humans our instestines are bunch together along with the other vital stomach organs, also contributing to the very slow process of meat digestion. Carnivores however, have long stretched apart intestines that allow meat to flow and digest very effectively. It's why meats cause so many health issues In us Humans as years go by.. In conclusion, scientifically speaking to live the most healthiest and strongest, humans cannot eat meat. We just have the conscious power of *choice* .  Also for all those who say we need meat for protein, you can get protein from at least 15 other plant-based foods. Avocados being one of them at the stop of my head.  But.. if meats your thing because it tastes good by all means go ahead ЁЯШГ

I feel like this video is deeply flawed- Prior to the year 1800 there were an estimated 60 million bison in North America. Bison emit methane at similar levels as cattle. Currently in the US there are fewer than 35 million cows and less than a million bison.  That means that net emissions from bovines in north America has dropped significantly from pre-industrial levels. The fact that this was left out of the video feels dishonest to me. In the past it seemed like Kurzgesagt did a good job of trying to be fair and present a balanced view of the material covered, but this one definitely feels tilted towards a specific conclusion.
As always, as clear as possible, while not trying to oversimplify a complex question.

"Fun" fact: In Poland, pastures were shelter for hundreds of plant species like orchids, carnations, mulleins, louseworts, buttercups etc. When cows were closed to farms, pastures were turned into forests or farmland. Now thanks to this, 30% of polish flora are endangered species. So in Poland, the closure of cows on a farm resulted a mass extinction of meadow plants.

How about talking about the exploitation and inherent abuse of animal agriculture for once? I'd like to hear some philosophical and rational arguments, if you can think of any
From a cold-clinical point of view given the information presented the optimal solution seems to lock all the animals away in sealed environments, this serves two important factors, it A reduces energy use, thus increasing meat/calorie efficiency, in turn reducing overall emission/calorie expenditure, and B allows us to capture all of the methane excreted by these animals before it can escape into the atmosphere and damage it.  As an added bonus all this extra methane can be reused later for another product, the only real downside here besides the irrelevant ethical one is that concentrating animals together in such close quarters leads to an increase transmission of bacteria and viruses, which means antibiotics become less effective due to increasing mutation of said viruses/bacteria.

a farmer in Canada recently discovered that feeding his cows a special type of red seaweed which is widely available and can be farmed reduced his cows carbon emissions by 80%
Something that  wasn't covered is the high amount of carbon that pastures remove from the atmosphere by just existing/growing, which offsets the carbon created by the ruminant animals.  I've seen interesting stuff on "carbon negative" pastures in ted talks.
I guess this channel is going downhill and becoming sloppier. Some of the things that are with this video:  The transport calculation is plainly wrong - avocado coming from a container would still go through several dispatching centers before reaching the store, thus still traveling a significant amount of road.   In the best case scenario, that cost would be higher.  Second, effects on carbon soil capture due to grazing animals (grass root systems) are not being taken into account, and that alone would make pasture-raised beef barcon neutral (if not slightly negative).  Third, the comparison by protein content, while well-meaning (I hope) is misleading.  Some nutrients cannot be get from vegetables (heme-iron, zinc) so if you really want a beef-to-vegs comparison you should adjust for bioavailability of both micro and macronutrients.    Please improvise a bit less next time.

9:20 - 9:35 Ok so 50 billion tonnes per year, that's 5 trillion tonnes over those same 100 years that 800billion tonnes could be removed (should be a much bigger graph, not a smaller one lol!) So doesn't this mean that by sparing those 3 billion hectares of land, as a vegan diet would permit, we would only cut our CO2 emissions down by less than a 6th - still emitting 42 billion tonnes per year? Which is 4.2 trillion tonnes over 100 years? (800 billion /100 years = 8 billion/year. 50 billion - 8 billion is 42 billion) Anything is better than nothing, but I'm just trying to maintain the proper perspective.

The comparison between local and long-distance transport was not fair. The efficiency of maritime transport can only be invoked if the destination is exactly the location of the port. In all other cases, the emissions of local transport add to the emissions of long-distance transport. So L + l >> l.

The video gave us the following facts,  1) If everyone went vegan and there was no eating meat, that would free up 3 billion hectares of land.  2) If we then converted all of that land to CO2 'eating' plants, that saves 800 billion tons of CO2 in 100 years (or 8 billion tons per year).  3) We emit 50 billion tons of CO2 per year right now.  4) Early in the video, they said 26% of greenhouse gases come from food production, with beef being the highest producer.  5) I could not find if they said exactly how much CO2 all animals produce, but estimating based on the food graph, it looks like all meat makes up around 70% of the gases produced by food.   If I math that, 26% of 50 billion tons a year is roughly 12.5 billion tons. And if 70% of that is from meat, that's roughly 9 billion tons. If the whole planet went vegan, we would have a 9 billion ton reduction in CO2 emissions. But then all those calories would have to be made up by plants. It seemed like there was roughly a 10x difference in gases released by calorie, so that would add about 1 to 2 billion tons of gases back. The new food would need land, but since there is currently farmland growing plants to feed livestock which wouldn't be needed, we'll call it even and say that same land is now making people food. Alright, then if all that land now available from no livestock was turned to forest of grasslands, that would further suck up another 8 billion tons a year. So our overall CO2 emissions drops from 50 billion tons to 35 billion tons, which is a little less than 1/3 of all current emissions.   Is that enough to make a difference? They talked about our "carbon budget" at 1:45, it seems like saving 15 billion tons of CO2 a year gets us about another 25 years. Did I do that (mostly) right?

One factor that wasn't touched upon is that arable land and land useful for crops isn't distributed equally around the globe. If a country (or region) depend on trade for a large part of their food, they are at risk if anything disrupts that trade. Not all countries could even afford to import much food, and unless they let their population starve, they need to use the resources that are available to produce food.
Here's the thing: a lot of environmentalists are also sympathetic to certain animal rights causes, and there was already an anti-meat agenda based on shoddy science claiming red meat would raise your cholesterol and cause heart attacks.  More recent research has called that into question, so now the anti-meat forces have to turn to another argument.  Now, instead of meat killing you, they say it kills the planet.  We've gone from "meat is murder for animals" to "meat is murder for you" to "meat is murder for the planet."  Well sure, cramming livestock onto feedlots, feeding them an unnatural diet and pumping them full of hormones isn't good for anyone, much less the environment.  But meat doesn't have to be made that way, and wasn't until about the end of WWII.  That's one reason why our ancestors lived perfectly long and healthy lives eating lots of red meat and didn't destroy the Earth by doing so.  If we just go back to humane, natural ways of raising livestock, then all of the supposed health and environmental risks of eating meat will go away.
I'm going to be eating more beef the amount of calories per weight and the quality is too good for me to pass on. I do obviously believe in climate change but I'm looking out for number one first and that won't ever change.
This whole video is based on the idiotic premise that each individual should consider the carbon footprint of everything they buy. If that's your strategy for combating climate change, there's a really, really high probability that you will fail. A much simpler and practically automatic solution the problem is to simply put a carbon tax on every product, and economics will take care of the rest. If the prices of different types of food at the grocer reflected their emissions in proportion to other products, beef would become much more expensive and that would automatically make people buy less of it, and buy more of other animal proteins or plant based proteins with a lower carbon foot print. No one would have to educate themselves on what is ethical, good or environmentally friendly, nor would anyone have to make personal sacrifices to satisfy their conscience, because everyone intuitively understands the value of money.

I heard that methane from cows should be weighed differently than co2 from coal/oil. Because that methane is part of a cycle anyways (air - rain - grass - cow - air) and would end up in the air eventually anyways. Lab-grown meat and vertical farms using solar concentrators to capture waste sunlight from city rooftops to light and power themselves and their surrounding neighborhoods are the only long-term way forward as far as I can tell. Take cold, CO2-rich air from the top of the building, pull it down while heating it and having the plants take up the CO2, eject it at ground level as a bubble of balmy, fresh air that surrounds the building. Probably also have a counterdraft taking air from underground and sending it up to expel the remaining waste heat at the top of the building, or in cold areas maybe a citywide central heating network fed by waste heat from the farms and other industry. Put a park and high-class restaurants around it, sell excess generated power (there'll be a lot since most of the building's light is provided directly by the sun). Bam, food production, town square, lots of power generation, citywide thermal management, and significant air quality management all in one spot.  Massively reduce the amount of energy the city needs to expend to cool its buildings by reducing the sunlight that falls on places where people don't go while also using that sunlight to grow food in places where a typical farm is actually just impossible, producing enough food to feed a significant portion of the city in which it's built, if not producing a surplus of food, almost totally removing the need for transportation as well as the reliance many geographical areas have on other places that can produce food. Urban areas wouldn't instantly collapse if they weren't being supported by vast farmlands.  Actually, that would be an interesting video, look at the future of hydroponic farming and what it's going to change about how we approach food.

What I'm getting from this is 'we need to develop better ways of doing a wide variety of things'. This has always been my core belief on the matter - the question of cliimate change is ultimately moot because the basic principle would still hold true if the world isn't burning, it benefits us all to find ways of doing things better and the big challenge is identifying areas where we need to do better. Safeguarding nature is one of those things currently.  The biggest change and biggest problem both is to cut down the amount of beef we eat. Make beef a once a week thing, supplement it with other kinds of meat - pork once a week, lamb once a week, chicken the rest of the time. The problem is this is a social change, which makes actually doing it hard - a large group of people will be unwilling to make this change, another large group will be unable follow through. Thus, this kind of thing would need to be a mandate, which will be hard to swallow. Maybe if it was combine with an effort to improve the culinary quality of food with a system like Blue Apron and the like. What would most be needed is to inform people of quick and easy alternatives to shoving their face full of meat and dairy.

I understand why you may be accidentally using "doomsayer" data. Our science is being politicized and manipulated to fit an agenda. Yes growing rice emmits green house gases like methane, but that is not all that bad. Some bacteria NEED methane like plants need sunlight to make energy. In other words it gets reabsorbed back into the environment, breaks down, and makes the soil they live in more fertile for all kinds of methane producing plants. The methane that escapes this cycle ends up has CO2 in less than a decade but methane is 28x more worse so I say there is no harm JUST AS LONG as we are not producing TONS of methane each 8 year period. But if it is given the time to break down I dont see why we should be concerned about it. Furthermore rice use to be a wild plant mostly to feed insects and crustaceans that evolved with the plant. By removing those organisms as if they were weeds ofc things will be more out of balance. Animals like crayfish can grow in tandem with rice as they each complement each other and create an environment for beneficial plankton to thrive in and their 'denning' behavior along with plankton in the waters producing O2 can control the numbers of methane producing bacteria so it doesnt get out of hand but not so far as it would kill the rice. 70% of the oxygen we breath come from plants like seaweed to rice and not the inland plants like trees (which TBH are more of a carbon sink than an oxygen producing machine).  If we farmed caring about the enviornment more and not just to make harvesting easier for farmers I dont see why we cannot greatly reduce the CO2 footprint of our food. Why keep up the same ineffective farming practice even if we reduce its scale? Nobody wants a reduction or prices to go up because we are forced to produce less. We have an opportunity to produce more while also lowering the impacts of climate change just as much as cutting back, if only we change our methods of farming and harvesting... That should be the worlds solution Kurzgesagt. Not these dystopia future where we poison our planet by the inefficient way we farm and we just say "well, we have to make even MORE cuts to what we grow. Hope youre all fine with eating nothing but potatoes". I am sure people would rather start wars to cull the population than just shut up and obey the master that tells them they can only eat so few varieties of food.

In previous videos on the topic of food I was disappointed that the fact that most land used is unsuitable for crop production, and the use of cattle on native rangelands is a significant benefit for habitat maintenance and conservation, but these benefits were not discussed in previous videos. So, I am glad that they did touch on this in this video. However, they do add the stipulation that grain products are supplementally fed to cattle. Unfortunately, this is a half truth in practice.   Grain production has many different classifications for the use of different grains. Grains are graded on their quality, and poor quality grains that are not up to par for human consumption are fed to cattle. An example of this would be different types of wheat flour. The highest quality and protein grains are made into things like pasta, followed by bread, and finally pastry and baking flour which is the lowest quality wheat that is still suitable for human consumption. Grains that fall below these standards are then fed to cattle. Yes, there is land that is used to grow grain products that could have alternative use for human consumption. However, '41% of grain that is used to feed livestock' is misleading, as a significant portion of this is not high enough quality for human consumption. Grain for human consumption always goes for a higher price, so farmers will always prioritize growing human food when possible, because they make more money. However, some grain inevitably will not meet standards due to a number of factors, this is then sold for a lesser price as livestock feed.   I think there is an important differentiation to be made between different countries, and the impacts they have. Here in North America, the impact of livestock is intensively managed and studied. New and exciting technologies and strategies are implemented every year that increase efficiency, decrease environmental impact, and create a more sustainable food system. Developing countries with poor food security, education, and infrastructure make up a significant amount of the total pollution and environmental impact from ecosystem degradation, due to poor management practices. As mentioned in the video, Brazil burns areas of forest. First, to grow soy products for several years until the soil is degraded and can no longer support soy production, which it is then converted to grazing for cattle. India imports tonnes of grains to support growing populations and artificially feed cattle. The impacts of cattle grazing the North American plains is not the same as developing countries that feed poor diets that result in increased emissions (yes, I understand it is to maintain their livelihoods and feed hungry mouths, but the impact it has remains the same).  As an agronomist, I know that smart people are studying and implementing new strategies to mitigate impact and maintain ecosystems. Experts in the field are coming up with new and novel products that are safe and sustainable. Meat production is an integral part of the food system.
we're too wasteful. too much food in the wrong places.
No matter what we eat, or how much energy we consume, the human population would produce a lot less carbon if there were fewer of us. The number of humans in 1920 was about 1,912,000,000. A hundred years later it was 7,794,798,739. Some countries still have expanding populations. Rather than ask all of us to give up meat, shouldn't the countries, where the population is growing, be asked to stop having so many children? And, for feedlot beef, the amount of methane produced is greatly reduced by adding a little seaweed to the feed.

Something overlooked by this video is that not all foods are equivalent for all people. For some people, a plant based diet makes them sicker and dramatically reduces their quality of life. It's not a black and white issue that can be prescribed a single solution. For many people the choice is a conscientious option, but for some it's an ultimatum to sacrifice themselves.  Imagine if instead of beef it was insulin: The vast majority of people don't need exogenous insulin. Even T2 diabetics can choose to manage the disease before insulin is absolutely needed. Would we just shrug and tell T1 diabetics that their deaths are necessary? Obviously this is an extreme example with radically different economics, but there's an uncomfortable truth to be seen. Any all or nothing measures will kill some people if we don't make good-faith efforts to produce alternatives. Plant-based diets are not the panacea some make them out to be and it's a slippery slope towards eugenics to argue like they are. "Beef is a luxury for me" translates into "Go ahead and die if it's a necessity for you".

The vetgetables  and fruits we eat today are heavily modified to grow very large and seedless and therefore lack alot of the good stuff because they simply do not have the time to accumulate and develop those minerals and vitamins before getting harvested already.  50 years ago, an orange was 100 times as healthy as it is today. Some time ago I decided to reduce my meat consumption. What I was doing before was buying the cheapest, lowest quality meat from animals living in the worst conditions, just so that I could have meat as the centerpiece of the meal at least twice a day.  Nowadays, I eat meat in two or three meals per week. But if I do, I go for high quality, local products, from animals that are hopefully treated better.  And regarding the environmental impacts? Well, we rich people don't suffer much from climate change. It's the poorest people who take the brunt of the negative impacts. And I believe that, at least for now, focusing on lifting these people out of poverty, even if it causes more environmental damage in the short term, is the more productive approach.  China burns huge amounts of coal today. It also pledged to replace all personal vehicles with electric cars in a decade or so. The pollution is an ugly byproduct of this rapid technological advancement. But once you overcome this initial stage, and there is a large middle class with enough resources not to worry about their survival, they can then invest their time and effort into fixing the mess previously committed. And while some damage is irreparable, much of it can be mitigated quite quickly.  Anyway, that's just my opinion, take it with a grain of salt.

I can't seem to find it, but I had found a study that compared not just the GHG emissions per gram of protein, but of the viable digestibility of the protein for human consumption. Plant proteins are overall less effective per gram than animal sourced proteins. I recall that pigs ended up with a little better score than some plant sources, due in part to their eating of waste streams, but cows and sheep were still the worst emitters.

All of this is important to talk about especially because we have a carbon negative way of making better fertilizer than anything on the market (charged biochar - we really should subsidize it for farmers to use!), but methane negative in a commercially productive way isn't possible yet. So someday we'll equal out the carbon we take from the atmosphere and put in, but methane is a whole other problem.
cereal crops are not exclusively grow for livestock  they are grown for human consumption they only end up as feed stocks if they don't meet the quality requirements for food processing. cereal farmers want there crops to go towards  human consumptions as this is the most profitable outcome as it is worth more per tone but if there grain dose not  meet the requirements of the factory's that is when it ends up as animal feed. For example to make bread the wheat grains needs to have 13% protein in the grain farmers cannot guarantee that every single harvest they will get at least 13% of protein in the grain so it is good to have another uses for this gran interims of animal feed instead of it being wasted. another item many people miss from these arguments is that animals provide more than just there meat.

A graphical fallacy in a Kurzgesagt video?   09:32, states that 800 billion tonnes can be removed over 100 years, so 8 billion tonnes a year  But we emit 50 billion tonnes a year, so removing 8 billion subtracted from 50 billion is 42 billion tonnes emitted net.   The graphic makes it seem like 800 billion tonnes is a lot, but also compares one year's emissions to 100 year's removal. I mean the thing about Beef emissions, like yeah they make up a fourth of human emissions, but you also have to realize that humans don't need to have 0 total emissions to restore the balance. For centuries, humans have lived and emitted greenhouse gases through raising cattle among other things, but that didn't cause global warming. What did is when industrialization kicked in and completely swung the natural balance, making it so that there was more emissions than being absorbed by plants. If we simply strive for low-emission beef, while decreasing emissions from all other human factors, as well as employing Carbon Negative solutions like CCUS, we can go back to the natural balance, where we still emit some greenhouse gases, but they're not more than the planet can handle so they disintegrate instead of pile up.

Agronomist and farmer here.  In previous videos on the topic of food I was disappointed that the fact that most land used is unsuitable for crop production, and the use of cattle on native rangelands is a significant benefit for habitat maintenance and conservation, but these benefits were not discussed in previous videos. So, I am glad that they did touch on this in this video. However, they do add the stipulation that grain products are supplementally fed to cattle. Unfortunately, this is a half truth in practice.   Grain production has many different classifications for the use of different grains. Grains are graded on their quality, and poor quality grains that are not up to par for human consumption are fed to cattle. An example of this would be different types of wheat flour. The highest quality and protein grains are made into things like pasta, followed by bread, and finally pastry and baking flour which is the lowest quality wheat that is still suitable for human consumption. Grains that fall below these standards are then fed to cattle. Yes, there is land that is used to grow grain products that could have alternative use for human consumption. However, '41% of grain that is used to feed livestock' is misleading, as a significant portion of this is not high enough quality for human consumption. Grain for human consumption always goes for a higher price, so farmers will always prioritize growing human food when possible, because they make more money. However, some grain inevitably will not meet standards due to a number of factors, this is then sold for a lesser price as livestock feed.   I think there is an important differentiation to be made between different countries, and the impacts they have. Here in North America, the impact of livestock is intensively managed and studied. New and exciting technologies and strategies are implemented every year that increase efficiency, decrease environmental impact, and create a more sustainable food system. Developing countries with poor food security, education, and infrastructure make up a significant amount of the total pollution and environmental impact from ecosystem degradation, due to poor management practices. As mentioned in the video, Brazil burns areas of forest. First, to grow soy products for several years until the soil is degraded and can no longer support soy production, which it is then converted to grazing for cattle. India imports tonnes of grains to support growing populations and artificially feed cattle. The impacts of cattle grazing the North American plains is not the same as developing countries that feed poor diets that result in increased emissions (yes, I understand it is to maintain their livelihoods and feed hungry mouths, but the impact it has remains the same).  As an agronomist, I know that smart people are studying and implementing new strategies to mitigate impact and maintain ecosystems. Experts in the field are coming up with new and novel products that are safe and sustainable. Meat production is an integral part of the food system.

This isnt a troll post as I am Vegan. You didn't cover what would happen if we actually switched to all vegan diets. What would be the result of that?
I see a lot of people arguing about the "thought provoking" comparison of CO2 Emission captured by Lands that would be saved if we cut out beef by 100 years vs. our yearly CO2 Emissions. The idea is not for you to crunch numbers but see that there can be an impact to the change even if its 8 Tril to our 50 tril per year. Currently we don't even have that 8 Tril rather we are going into the negatives every year. If you don't understand the point of the graph and is more worried about its inaccurate representations, then you are overlooking the message. We are not doing anything to stop or slow the emission so arguing about a "what if" scenario is a waste of your effort so shut up.
