Honestly, a lot of the problem with a LOT of the things that produce climate change (not just meat) is that we do not force the corporations involved to take ownership of their publicized costs, as it were. If the transport, energy production, and meat industries had to factor in environmental impact into their balance sheet then we'd see that shit get properly worked on in a very big hurry. After that, we might not even need to worry about individual action, the real engines of destruction will have done it already before we get a chance to impact things.
I don't care if it is.
For the meat eaters who think they just can't enjoy food to the fullest without meat, I used to eat approx 150-200g of protein per day - much more than the average person -- mostly from beef, and chicken. It's a big cultural thing, plus I was a powerlifter who liked protein-heavy diets.  I've been vegan for a few years now, and though it was hard at first, I now have virtually no cravings for meat(still miss some cheese occasionally though). In the last year or so it's actually getting to the point where I'm a little grossed out by meat, something I was convinced would *never* happen. I always just assumed I'd suffer the rest of my life for the animals and the environment, and part of going vegan was accepting that. But instead I honestly enjoy food now more than I ever did in my meat eating heyday (in part because I was forced to become a better cook, I suppose).  Not saying everyone will have the same journey; there are definitely vegans who miss meat more than I do. It can be hard having limited options at restaurants (though it gets better every year). But just letting you know it is possible even for some of the biggest meat eaters to make the switch without feeling like they're sacrificing the joy of eating for the rest of their lives. And even if you don't make the switch completely (for a while, I didn't mind having occasional meat as long as I was mostly vegan), just cutting your meat consumption significantly can make a big difference.
Conclusion: meat as a substance isn't bad, but agriculture and the way meat is produced and raised in mass quantities to meet demand is?  Solution: Eat every cow and set up sustainable hydroponics for raising fish and crops in place of land for cattle?

The comparison at 9:33 is extremely misleading, since the top shows the amount of CO2 that would be pulled out over 100 years vs how much we put into the atmosphere in only 1 year. 800 billion divided by a 100 year span means it would only suck out 8 billion tonnes per year compared to the 50 billion put in per year.

Les go
This is just absolutely not true... A cow, properly managed on pasture, will sequester in the soil 4 times the co2-equivalent emitted from producing the meat from that cow. Giving cows less grass and more grains increases their methane production. Methane does not come out as farts. The methane it produced in their first stomach through anaerobic fermentation and is almost completely burped out. The biological responses to a well-managed pasture pattern provides far healthier ecosystems than for example monocultured grains. Food waste is a far bigger problem than choice of cultuvar/production. Almost 100% of fertilizers used in organic productions are manure, will someone claim that only using mineral fertilizers is a sustainable route? Before European colonization; the american steppes were filled with bison. Some say over a billion animals roamed the plains. The result? Incredible fertile and carbon rich soils, not an increase in temperature from the greenhouse effect. What happened when the bison were hunted down to extinction? The grasslands were replaced with monoculture crops and today these same fertile lands have had their stored carbon released as co2 and now farmers are relying heavily on mineral fertilizers while ploughing intensively, further diminishing the stored carbon... check out regenerative farming or silvopasture if you want insight into climate-friendly animal production. Stop reducing complex subjects down to simple slogans. Be more informed, throw less food

The problem with this, and every vegan argument about cutting down on meat or going vegan, is that the consequences of doing so are CATASTROPHIC on the environment. Not a single damn vegan has yet to explain to me what we do with all of these farm animals if we suddenly stop eating meat. We can't let them out in the wild because that completely destroys forests, and wildlife balance. We can't let give them all the free space to roam around without destroying more land to give them adequate space. We can't let them breed as they like because they would have zero predator's and population control. And because they still rely on us so much, we have to continue to feed them as they populate uncontrolled under our protection. Which means more land needed to grow food specifically for these animals. The consequences of switching to vegan diet without a proper solution that isn't "murder all the animals", is more damaging to the environment than any other alternative.

Why no mention of buffalo? In the 1800s (when things were natural) there were ~60,000,000 bison in America. There are currently 93 million cows in America. That's only 1/3rd more animals producing methane than there were before the industrial revolution. Cow farts are not that much different now than they were before modern meat production. Plus, as noted in the video, the production farmed cows produce less methane than free-ranged ones anyway, so that narrows that gap between pre-industrial levels and modern agriculture even further.

Sadly the thing is that not everyone can rely on the vegetarian equivalent of beef, for the simple reason that they can't afford it. I live in France and in general, 100g of veggie "meat" would cost 4 to 6 times as much as 100g of beef does. With the constant inflation and the stagnation of the salaries, it is very difficult for families and low-income people such as me, a student, to pay 4 euros for that little food. It is mainly a commercial issue in my opinion, since we saw that meat is theorically more costly in general in terms of production, in fact vegan or vegetarian product are subject of a huge marketing, making it "trendy" and it incites shops and super-markets to sell it at  higher prices. I don't think it is an issue only in France and I'm sure much more people would use this alternative if it was cheaper, but it implies some economical sacrifices which I'm not sure big industries are willing to take.

The way you guys set up the local versus global food argument was a little disingenuous/misleading. When you compare the emissions per kilogram of a huge shipment of goods like a cargo ship versus a smaller shipment of goods like a truck the smaller shipment of goods is always going to have a higher carbon footprint per kilogram. However this is assuming that we absolutely have to have global distribution to feed everybody, the truly best situation for the environment would be for all food to be locally produced therefore eliminating all global shipping emissions. Obviously thatтАЩs not realistic we canтАЩt just shut down the global economy but this is the problem weтАЩre up against global shipping is a huge impact on the environment just because you can break it down to a emissions per kilogram argument doesnтАЩt stop the fact that shipping is a huge percentage of the overall problem.

The emissions chart is flawed in the same way the data is always skewed by activists.  Cows don't release any *net* emission of gas. Cows first remove emissions from the atmosphere, then return those same emissions, for a net change of ZERO. The actual emissions released are only from the machinery, and are *less* in total than agriculture. The chart also conveniently ignores the emission heavy plants like Avocados. I stopped watching at that point, because it is clearly a very biased video pretending to be objective.

What about the fact that a lot of animal feed is part of the crop waste?  Corn husks for example, are something that humans don't eat but we can and do feed to animals. There's large amounts of materiel that would otherwise just go to waste which your stats don't cover.
For people not sure if they should stop eating meat because their reduction in personal contribution to global emissions would not make a dent anyway. Consider this:  The more people eat meat, the more it is the norm, the easier it is for people to justify eating meat. On the other hand, the less people eat meat, the harder it is. Not eating meat makes it more likely people around you choose to not eat meat.  The more people eat meat, the more revenue the meat industry will generate, the more it can grow/maintain. The less people eat meat, the more it will shrink.   This is just the rough idea, one could come up with more of these the more/the less paragraphs, but notice that stopping eating meat not just reduces your personal emisions, a very linear result, but it also contributes to an amplifying feedback loop that pushes the entire system towards sustainability.
This is actually what we do in our state: Non-veg is considered as a specialty or something that you can only eat on special occasions (This was followed before due to how poor the economy was and people can't even afford 1Kg of rice, meat was such a delicacy ). We still follow this to an extent where we eat meat only twice or thrice a month . It's not that we cant afford it now but we simply decide to consume less of it.

I personally think that it's extremely unrealistic to expect us to completely get rid of meat in the near future. Even if everyone on the planet turned vegan, we still have billions of livestock animals that we have to get rid of somehow.  That being said, I think it's also important to note how much demand for meat has gone up in the past 30 years. It used to be considered luxury food but now many families practically eat meat every single day and don't really consider a dish complete without it. Iirc studies have shown that Americans households eat 5 servings of red and processed meat per week, while Europeans eat between 2-4 servings per week, depending on the individual countries.   But while we can't give up meat (and god knows how much I love me some poultry), it's good to try and incentivise eating less of it. It would go a long way if everyone in the world (or at least as many people as possible) participated in Meatless Monday, and some coherent nutrition guidelines actually came out.
Matter isn't created or destroyed without a nuclear reaction. Cows aren't creating carbon. They eat carbon and then release it. This video completely disregards that fact.   What we need to focus on is: why is more carbon being added to the cycle? The answer is we're pulling up carbon from deep in the earth and then releasing it into the air via natural gas, coal, and oil.  Not only are videos like this very wrong, they also hurt our ability to work together on this problem. You're just making enemies of meat eaters, not winning allies in the fight against climate change. Renewables and nuclear are the answer, not taking a narrow view of emissions that doesn't factor in consumption of carbon.

5:08 Something I really dislike about the argument used that methane 'only' lasts ~10 years, even of it does have a stronger warming effect than CO2, is that atmospheric methane mainly decays/reacts to form carbon dioxide.  So even after the methane is gone, the initial emissions are still having a warming effect.

Lets see a breakdown on pollution and environmental impact of meat vs plant based argri as well as solutions, active or passive to these problems. Carbon impact is often the argument against meat but what about other factors ?
You can find solutions in beef production if you think creatively. Ideally beef production should be reduced in favor of poultry and pork, but not eliminated entirely. There are other facets to eating beyond pure calorie intake. Humans need the vitamins and nutrients of a balanced omnivorous diet. The ketogenic and paleo diets emulate a more hunter and gatherer lifestyle they are in my view flawed. I hold the same view in regards to the extreme veganism. Humans are surprisingly complex and any solution regarding our diet must be thoroughly reviewed and tested for validity, sustainability, and diversity. Validity means that the diet must meet the minimum nutrition requirements of a human body within two or three meals a day without external support from artificial supplements. Sustainability speaks for itself, the diet must be able to meet the demand of the global population while having a minimum impact on the world. Diversity while seemingly odd in regards to a diet is one of the most critical aspects to a diet. Diversity can establish redundancies in the case of crop failure, allergies or individual distaste while also providing stimulation to the five senses. This is a very tall order and quite possibly impossible to achieve, but anything is possible and who knows what the future may bring.
This was such a well presented and well-balanced fact-based research video. Really appreciate all the efforts!

Cows throw CO2 in the atmosphere, but the CO2 is catched by the pastures (through photosynthesis) and then eaten by the cows. Was it considered in the values shown in the video? The methane in the atmophere almost totally comes from oil extraction. It's not ok to blame the poor cows for it.
dont let that vegan teacher see this
Plant-based foods, specifically organic foods, often rely on livestock production. Byproduct of livestock production is manure. This is used throughout the agriculture industry to enrich soils.  Currently many farms use mined phosphorus  to fertilize their fields. But this is a finite resource and it is being depleted quickly.  Resting fields and planting with cover crops do help rehabilitate the soil but so does resting the field as pasture for livestock. Food systems are exceedingly complicated and it's likely that no one solution will be the magic bullet to solve our climate problems.

The fact I hate the most is that meat is a good source of some nutrients and vitamins, yes...but we throw away SO much. We slaughter cows and use tons of parts from them, but when the time comes to talk about the meat its a jumbled mess.  Some countries actually have cultural problems around the meat cuts they consume or not, so tons of meat might end up wasted or rotting away if you are not crafty enough to use it for things like meat stock, pet food or even gelatin production. It can also be generational.  The thing that will always annoy me about meat production is the fact that tons of the meat might get wasted if you are not careful, and that just sits so wrong with me.  An animal grew, was slaughtered and butchered for humans to consume it...and sometimes we might eat SOME of that animal, the rest of it might go to absolute waste. It just so wasteful and somehow cruel; if you are going to kill a cow, eat the whole damn cow. We use the bones, the hair, the leather. Intestines are the only thing we don't eat and we used them for tennis strings for years. Horns were used for buttons, and in Argentina we still use horns and hooves for some Mate bowls.  Wasteful consumption (or lack thereof) of meat is also a huge problem that the meat industry has, aside from the use of lands, and the awful conditions we have to grow the animals in order to get more meat (that will actually go to waste anyway!).

This is misinformation. The largest amount of CO2eq emissions for beef IS NOT methane from cow farts, it's from having to transport kgs over kgs of feed towards the cows. That is why grassfed is so much better than factory farmed trash. And the impact of methane on human-made global warming is about 3%, not 25%. Also it's not just 13% grass-fed beef worldwide but rather 35%. Maybe not exactly grass-fed but in the efficient category of a very prominent WHO study where for example plant waste products are upcycled into meat. Chicken don't exclusively eat feed crops. They are specialist carnivores, they thrive on bugs, slugs and worms etc.

I am really dissapointed in this video. Dont get me wrong , i love Kurzgesagt and i have probably been subscribed for 4 - 5 years.  But the fact that they overlooked probably one most important factors of this debate and posted the video without proper research and context behind the numbers makes me kinda mad.  When you farm wheat (used for making flour and bread) as an example, only a very small percentage of the plant is edible to humans.    We pick out the small wheat kernels and then we throw away more than 80% (by weight)of the plant - because we just cant eat it! Thats where cows come in. Those 80% of the plant - that we would usually throw away,burn or maybe use for some other industry - can be eaten by cows.  This means that you have to take this in to consideration when you state that   "49% of soy production goes to cows while only 48% go to humans" (paraphrasing).  What if those 49% which are given to cows are not even edible by humans in the first place!  Also the enviromental implications of being able to grow a crop that feeds humans AND feeds cows are huge. The potential to setup super effective farms that can use the bi-product from one food industry to sustain another is literally the kind of technology that can save our world.  The fact that this is not talked about in the video and that the numbers are not clarified is terrible.  What does those percentages mean? Weight, Volume , Calories?  Hopefully this comment gets some traction and Kurzgesagt gets a chance to clarify all of this...

The biggest problem with this video is that it's a single variable analysis of a massively complex issue. It doesn't address the fact that farm land requires a large land area which leads to deforestation and importing water. All this to say that the sheer fact that life exists produces greenhouse gases so the solution is carbon capture and reducing greenhouse gases already in the atmosphere not reducing emissions because emissions will never be zero. Taking things to the extreme, if your goal is reducing emissions entirely then that leads to mass murder and genocide because that's a real argument that has been made by real people past and present.

I feel like this is missing the point.  Types of emissions matter.  Where the carbon originates from matters.  The carbon emitted from fossil fuels is carbon that was locked away for millions of years.  The carbon that cows emit was locked away for only a few years if not months in the grass and food they ate.  It was already on the surface of the earth in plants.  Plants that would  decay its carbon *mostly* back into the atmosphere anyway.  So saying that the transportation doesn't contribute much is really really problematic.  We NEED to keep fossil fuel and coal IN THE GROUND.

Hey Kurzgesagt! I know that human going vegan/vegetarian will help the world pollution, but I'd like to know how real the ""free up land" and "CO2 removed" claim is. Let's say if I go vegan today, I stop eating any kind of meat, but I doubt the local market in this little village will reduce their chicken meat just because one person (me) in this 1000 population go vegan. And let's say if there are 10 of us in this village go vegan, enough to make the meat seller reduce their stock, but the local factory farm that produce meat for 2 millions people on this island (including our village) surely won't change how many chicken, cow, etc they breed per month/year. In this case, 10 of us didn't make any real change to this world, I know we will be healthier but the claim of "reducing X amount of pollution per year" seems disputable. I really love meat, chicken specifically. I don't think I will ever go vegetarian, I don't think the whole world will ever go vegetarian, but if there's a large production of substitutes for real meat, I guess it will help this world a lot.

You might want to consider the cost to people's health/healthcare systems when eliminating meat for a high carb, plant based diet. People were all but physically beaten into believing they should avoid meat and eat more grains/sugar to improve their health around the 1960s+... what followed was the greatest increase in metabolic diseases, obesity, and heart disease ever seen in history. The combo of chemical plant crafted high omega-6 polyunsaturated vegetable/seed oils with the switch to a diet heavy in grains, corn, soy, potato, etc. was a 1-2 knockout punch to people's overall health. Now we know that animal products and monounsaturated and saturated fat are actually protective against these issues, and a high carbohydrate diet is the leading cause of most modern disease and healthcare cost.

Oof! Well, I as an individual have a bit of a problem. I'm allergic to tomatoes. Yeah, it's the vast majority. In fact, my options for vegan food are so limited by my allergy, that I'd most likely literally die of malnutrition if I went vegan. So unfortunately, I don't really have a choice. I do appreciate the dairy free milk alternatives, though. My mother is lactose intolerant, so on her birthday, I made a chocolate pudding cake with almond-coconut milk instead of cow's milk and it tasted much better than the cow's milk variant! I do what I can and I appreciate what's available, but I do have my limits that are beyond my control.

Glad you mentioned the bit about factory farms, even if it's unfortunate. That's sort of a general trend, things people want to do to "get back to nature" (growing your own food, moving out into the countryside, etc) are often actually the worst things for the climate. Manhattan has some of the lowest emissions per capita of any part of the US, while rural Vermont has some of the highest. The best thing for the climate would be if we all lived in giant skyscrapers, never traveled, and got all of our food from factory farms.   That's a tricky thing about environmentalism in general, often a fix for one problem actually makes another problem worse (like organic food has far more carbon emissions per calorie).
Buy locally to support your local farmers and your local communityтАЩs economy. DonтАЩt sell out local farmers for international TOFU. Illinois stands with Wisconsin and Illinois pig and cow farmers

We really need a video about Xenobots
For all those asking why they didn't cover artificially produced meat - it's because it doesn't exist on a commercial scale yet. Nobody has managed to scale artificial meat production (as opposed to meat substitutes) to a scale where it's capable of being part of the solution. If it turns out to be possible to produce artificial meat cheaply en-masse then that would be great, but you can't rely on a technology that nobody has yet proved works (and is economically viable) on a large scale, and nobody is capable of predicting whether technology that doesn't currently exist might exist in the future. It's the same reason why nobody is going to suggest humanity will depend on nuclear fusion in a video on future energy - it'd be great if it became feasible, but nobody knows whether it ever will.
The more I learn about this topic the more I feel like moderation is going to be the big answer here. Portion sizes have GOT to play a part in all this. It has to be possible, to eat enough to fuel our bodies - and still FEEL like we've eaten enough. Speaking as a person who very much enjoys animal based proteins - not having ANY meat in my diet is depressing. Possible? Healthy? Yeah. But DEPRESSING. Why the hell should I want to live longer and healthier if I'm going to be miserable? "You'll live seven years longer if you give up bacon" - yeah no.  So then, finding ways to rethink what we "expect" to get on our plates makes the most sense. Of course meat demand is high - marketing has made it so, and that was on purpose. But what if we look at the dinners of the past? No, I don't mean the Middle Ages necessarily - but taking a good look at pre-Industrial age ways of eating might help inform us as to changes we can make NOW. We could learn a lot about what nutrition looked like back then - and adjust as needed to match our current understanding - a task that might be much EASIER today, since we do have a global economy and can transport foods from all over, or grow things in places they didn't originate from (with caution, of course). Too, we can alter our thinking from "a working man needs a lot of calories!" For SOME jobs that's still true, but the greater majority of folks have sedentary jobs or at the least, they aren't weeding fields and herding critters and other forms of back-breaking labor.  But the marketing schemes still want to portray "ideal dinner" as being the sort of thing that feeds a half dozen adult males who do hard labor all day long.  That's just not reality anymore, and the food industry doesn't want us to know that! SO figuring out how to change that, might be the most effective thing to do.

9:21 - Wait, the comparison here seems a bit skewed.  The land would save 800 bil. tons of CO2 *over 100 years,* and we emit 50 bil. tons *per year.*  So wouldn't that mean we'd emit 5 trillion tons of CO2 over the same period of 100 years (50 bil. x 100 = 5,000 bil or 5 tril.)?  If so, then all this land is only sequestering... 16% of our total emissions over the same period of time?  It's a significant amount, for sure, but the graphic makes it look more like this one major change would fix the problem by itself.  All of ^this being said, I'm not saying this is a bad idea, by any stretch.  I recognize that tackling the climate crisis means have to implement a wide array of changes/fixes, and there isn't going to be one single thing that magically solves all our problems.  Incremental steps like a 1/6th reduction in emissions are still really good!  My comment here is more strictly about the implication made by the one graphic, rather than aiming to be a takedown of the entire video.

1:35 even if we deminish all other sources our carbon budget would be used up by 2100. Yeah that way we are doomed no matter what .... because it is calculated by ignoring all other factors.  That carbon in these emissions comes from the CO2 in the atmosphere. It is a cycle that goes through all lifeforms fueled by the Sun and photosynthesis. So no, as soon all other means (mainly transport and heating) come from renewable energy then these 26% are far less of a problem than this video makes it out to be. (If any) 4:40 Also, the comparison between the Avocado shiped between SA & EU and the local beef ... seriously ignoring the fact that the 1kg Avocados ALSO have to be shipped from the port to the store?! 4:50 is still a correct point but notbecause of this really bad shipping comparison, but because of your next point, that meat needs a lot of plants to grow at the rate we consume it at the moment. But in the end it comes down to the fact that NATURE has a cycle in place that makes carbon go thourgh all carbon-based life forms fueled by the sun with photosynthesis. The issue interfering with that cycle is carbon-fossil-fuel that was in the earth for millenia and is now burned in an exceeding rate. What I'm curious about is why us humans aren't starting to move our agriculture into space.  After all, it's a win-win for the planet: More food can be produced up in space-based capsules than down here on Earth (and we can even use Luna, Mars, or Venus if a food requires gravity to properly grow, such as animal products), and it frees up land for other uses, such as energy production and carbon recapture.

I'm disappointed that the comparison is made to the  altruistic utopia where that land is converted directly into counter carbon fields. In reality what is always missing from the calculation is that the land is profitable in the current model and needs to do so in any future model. Its just as likely that that plant covered animal feed land would become houses, commercial property, or even factories. None of which would offset or dramatically produce a different result and potentially end in worse. Focus should be on how to drive the value of the land to producing clean air in addition to a different and marketable source of food. Then the shift to more rare and more expensive meat can be a reality. If it isn't market driven and that includes demand, it simply isn't likely to happen.

Lies in this video: 1. Grazing cows allow soil to sequester more carbon, to the point of being carbon neutral (How do you think millions of bison roamed many years ago and there was no problem then) 2. 13% of cows are pastured - false, 100% of cows spend 3/4 of their lives on pasture, then are fed 90% human-inedible grains in the last 1/4 3. The idea that humans could avoid eating meat. There are over 15 nutrients only found in meat that we cannot live without (you can manage for a few years, though) 4. Methane being a cow issue. There are many bigger sources of methane like swamps and natural gas. Cows are part of a natural cycle of producing and capturing carbon, oil is not    What I've Learned has a much better researched video on this with an actual climate expert.

When you say that cows are eating crops, I think it is more complicated. We grow crops mainly for humans, but since we only eat a part of the cereal, we give the left overs to cows. For exemple, soy is made of 20% of fat: fat is the part that us, humans, turn into oil to eat it. Then there is 80% of the soy that we don't know what to do with, and we feed it to cows so everyone is winning in the deal, farmers who grow crops and farmers who have cows.

there are some other aspects that you might not have covered. I know me personally, since I started eating exclusively meat, I have been eating less. a meal a day if that pretty much. I also have been losing weight, and thus been walking more to different places instead of driving. and in general lost weight is always better for the health care system, so less resources are spent on that. not sure how these other indirect Co2 contributor's are effected but I am sure it amounts to something at least.  regardless I am going to continue to eat meat, I just feel so much better on it, it is really a night and day difference. occasionally I will have some veggies as a snack, but my main thing is staying away from grains and that sort of stuff.  In regards to climate change and Co2 levels, you guys should do a video on historical Co2 levels and its correlation to planet wide greening, and temperature for as far back as we have data for. I think when you look at the bigger picture, Co2 might not be as sinister as you might have thought ;) I am far more concerned about plastic, garbage, and chemicals in the ocean and what not, stuff like that, then I am with Co2 levels. At the end of the day Co2 is just an atom of carbon, a building block of life, it is literally plant food floating in the air, and two oxygen atoms. I am no ecologist or anything, but it would seem like we are just distributing plant food throughout the planet. and historically when there is high Co2, the planet gets a greening effect, cause we are feeding all the plants and what not. that greening effect then cools the planet once it gets to a certain level, as those plants are absorbing and using sunlight instead of the ground or bodies of water absorbing it an wasting it as heat. I realise this is counter intuitive to what we are always told, but in my opinion this is the only thing that explains these correlations in the past, because we certainly where not around producing Co2 at the time. I know polar bears have survived 4 or 5 warming periods due to warming cycles caused by higher Co2, and those cycles where all harsher and happened faster then the one we are experiencing now, and they made it though just fine, I think we will as well.

Ok, but why no one is talking about movements like Permaculture? It is the methdology of turning food production into fully functional ecosystems that each year make the soil better not worse. The whole premise of the movement is to be carbon negative and prevent desertification of land (unlike today's agriculture). Animals are essential part of every healthy ecosystem and they can be carbon negative when part of whole ecosystem (acutally the ecosystem needs them to function). Spoiler alert: it still means less meat and more expensive meat than today :)

You are showing the amount of co2 removed over 100 years from the point where 3 billion hectares has already been restored to wild grasslands and forests. Starting from that point, it would take 100 years to amount to 800 bil tonnes of co2 removed. Then you put another line under this, showing co2 created PER YEAR of humans, which is 50 bil tonnes. But the comparison isn't a good one since the upper line talks per 100 year and the lower per year. And you never really clarify this IMO. Maybe I'm too picky, but it almost looks intentional since you bothered to write "PER YEAR" on the lower graph, but not "PER 100 years" in the upper. Buy local do matter, but not because of the carbon footprint of the transport chain. It matters because it creates market incentives for the existence of small familiar producers and only small producers are capable of producing without using too many fertilizers or herbicides. A big farm works more like a company with some employees and needs to profit, so it is a good trade to have fewer employees and use more fertilizers and herbicides. A small familiar farm is not like a company, it has a fixed labor force and they want to cut off expenses in fertilizers and herbicides. So, it is more likely for a small farm to use organic fertilizers and herbicides (like manure or cover crops) because those things are labor-expensive, but require almost nothing else than labor. Therefore, small familiar properties are capable of addressing the enormous carbon footprint of fertilizers and herbicides.  But the existence of such properties is not a given because of inequality. Take the case of Brazil, my country. Unlike the USA, where the Homestead Act made the property of land easy to have, here the land has been concentrated since colonial times. Even so, most of the good food produced here to feed our people is produced in small properties, while huge properties focus mainly on soy and cattle for exportation (Brazil is the biggest exporter of beef and soy in the world).  As always, it is impossible to address climate change without addressing social inequality.

I understand that this video is directed at people living in large urban areas, but we can't forsake nor condemn those who don't simply because of OUR unsustainable lifestyles, when most of the colonized world had figured out sustainable lifestyles long ago, before colonizers came along.

It used to be the case that when humans faced problems they thought about solutions to overcome them.  Nowadays there's never a complete solution, it's always "don't do this don't do that".  All of these issues already have solutions but our politicians need them to push authoritarian agendas. The solution is: reforestation of non-arable land. Reducing land usage through underground production via hydroponics and stuff, part of the production happening in the place of consumption. Nuclear energy and/or renewables. Genetically engineered livestock, or just grown/farmed meat, not raised/killed meat. And, most importantly, free markets, because markets regulate the resource allowance of most people in a reasonable way which means that if our profuctio  capacity doesn't keep up the habits will change voluntarily due to price fluctuation and meat will be consumed less.
So basically the source of everything is our human and animal population is way too high. We canтАЩt afford to cut all animal products due to not having nearly enough productivity with other food resources, and the carbon emissions will still greatly increase with the gain of vegetation due to demand. WhatтАЩs contradicting is the fact we can let all the animals continue to live outright because they will also play a big part in emissions.

I have to say, this is probably the worst Kurzgesagt video they've ever done. There is so much blatant misinformation here it is astounding. "We won't dive too deep..." Yes, please do dive deep! Set the record straight.   For example: Avocado's still have to travel from the port, through perhaps X amount of countries or states before it ends up in a supermarket. Where are the calculations of C02 produced for that? They just compare ships and trucks, show a ship travelling half the globe with a truck travelling 2 blocks. Kurzgesagt's intention is pretty clear here. They picked a message and worked they're way back to find arguments supporting it.   Grazing ruminants on land that used to be rainforest, yes that's obviously terrible. So do a video on that. Don't say "meat is bad because it kills jungles!". This is just lazy. They tried to set the record straight by adding in that some land can't be used for growing crops. But glossing over it and giving buts. This is a much more nuanced tale. Some land can't be used for different kinds of crops because the land is so poor, or the weather is not optimal for anything other than feed crops. There is so much more information to give to show a complete picture that people can use to gain a better understanding of the topic. But no: meat bad, look this. This is just lazy.  Let's talk about the fact that ruminants graze on feed that is grown naturally. The feed (be it grass or corn or whatever) is actually carbon neutral. It takes carbon and methane from the water and air, stores it, the cow eats it, burps and poops most of it out and thereby releases it. Net zero effect. What about the fact that there have been ruminants in the millions for millenia on the north american continent that have lived perfectly fine and have not destroyed the planet just by eating?  This video is entirely skewed and just lazy.   I recommend watching the video on meat by the yt channel What I've Learned.

Why only account for carbon dioxide emitted by livestock when we don't account for what was sucked in by plants to make this emission possible in the first place. It's like having only likes counter without dislikes counter, totally unrepresentative.  Carbon is not created from nothing inside a cow. A cow gets it from plants. And plants suck this carbon from atmosphere via photosynthesis. Boom! No extra carbon is pumped into atmosphere except for the one which was there already. That's why planting more trees doesn't really solve the problem. The tree sucks carbon from the atmosphere and uses it to build its own flesh. What's happening next when the tree dies? It decomposes, and all the carbon captured is emitted back. That's why oceanic microorganisms are so important: when they die, they fall to the bottom and captured carbon in their bodies stays there forever.  These 40% of crops that we feed animals with - the thing is these crops are not human-edible anyway! For example stems of the corn. You cannot just stop feed animals with them and start to feed humans for this reason. It's embarassing you didn't check for this fact.  About fact that my local products transportation is more expensive per weight unit than overseas transportation: dude I don't buy my groceries in the sea ports, okay? They still need to be transported to the local shops, as the locally produced meat does, so these expences cancel out and we still have overseas products being heavier than local (not dramatically though)

0:07 what about getting your d... yeah food is alright
woah, that's a little underhanded at 9:23 - "Remove 800 million tons over 100 years, humans generate 50 million tons per year." So for the loss of space, it would take out 8 million tons per year from what humans generate. I'm not saying that it's bad, but the way you have it presented makes it sound like a far bigger impact (as in overwhelmingly larger than what humans produce) than what it actually is.
This entire video is skewed by methane emission "equivalents", which are a fundamentally broken measure that overestimates the amount of GHG emissions that beef produces.  When CO2 is emitted from fossil fuels, it will stick around practically indefinitely, making it a long term problem.  Methane emissions on the other hand only stick around for 12 years, before it is broken down into CO2 in the atmosphere by chemical reactions. But that CO2 originally came from the atmosphere! (it was absorbed by grass from the air). This is simply part of the ongoing atmospheric carbon cycle that has a short term effect on warming. Moreover, if the amount of methane being released by a herd of cows now is the same as that being released 12 years ago, then the net effect is ZERO over time (it is being broken down in the atmosphere at the same rate as emission). It's a bit like if we asked people to pay a carbon tax on the CO2 that they exhale every time they breathe out; that CO2 came from the atmosphere originally, and shouldn't be taxed. Yet we ask farmers to pay a carbon tax on methane emissions? Do they get that money back 12 years later?
The fact that he said "well, its complicated" instead of "short answer, you'd die" means that its possible

The issue I have is that half the so called meat emissions come from the change of land usage. So as long as global meat consumption just remains at it's current level, the emissions in the data have effectively already been made. The other half is methane, which degrades down to something like 1/16th of it's greenhouse gas potential after about 12 years. So again, this is a largely temporary effect and, assuming meat production remains as it is, is only maintaining greenhouse gas levels rather than adding to them. Therefore as the video points out, stopping eating meat won't so much reduce your greenhouse gas emissions as enable the banking of pre-existing emissions. Ultimately if you go by the stats in the video, if everyone went vegan immediately then we would only bank something like 16 years worth of emissions and this would take 100 years to achieve. So my point is that while it is very much beneficial to cut down on meat, it is hugely more beneficial to focus our efforts on fossil fuels.

My mother used to tell me that back when she was young meat wasn't something that was eaten everyday, and when it was people made sure to not waste anything because it was supposed to be good stuff. Over time with economic growth meat became a readily available good that could be consumed every day at every occasion.  My take is that there's probably nothing wrong with meat, aside from improving the production aspects to decrease emissions and improve the conditions of the animals, but there is probably something unsustainable in the modern demand for meat, and meat should return to be a rarer good to be consumed less often compared to pastas, vegetables and fruits.  It's not a vegans VS carnivores argument, eat whatever you want, but keeping up an industry that must sustain industrial quantities of meat and cow herds for billions of people daily may be too much going forward. It's still going to be something very hard to sell to people, but I think a reduction in production, that keeps meat available but as a semi-luxury food, could be a good way forward.

You messed up the numbers with shipping food vs buying locally. You excluded how the food arrived at the origin port, where it goes from the destination port (typically a warehouse or distribution center) and then how it gets to a market. You also have to look at seasonal crops and how they are distributed. This is why it is hard to compare and quantify the impact food (the general) production and distribution has on the environment.

You also seemed to forget that we feed a lot of non-edible things to cows. We don't necessarily eat 100% of the wheat we harvest. We just eat the seeds, which leaves a whole lot of plant material we don't eat.   Furthermore you also need to account for the distribution of cows and their uses. For example India has millions of cows they only use for dairy due to religious beliefs. Thus they're vastly more inefficient than American dairy which slaughters unused cows for meat.  Plus then you have to account for water usage, as well as decay potential for plants. Rice relies on vast irrigation and plant decay for example. Tree related plants also either relay on flooding or in the best cases drip lines. But regardless of that the trees still drop their leaves which decay on their own.   Furthermore you also need to account for how trees aren't even the most efficient co2 converters, algae are.

some flaws in this video:  1. yes, the destruction of forests does release CO2, but so does tilling of cropland which also leads to runoff in waterways. 2. All human-edible plants have waste ie. corn and soy husks which are used to feed animals, because it would be a waste to feed human edible food to animals. 3. Protein synthesis from meat and vegetables are not the same, as the body can more efficiently absorb the nutrients from meat. 4. Additionally, meat from beef has a lot more micronutrients necessary for life compared to any vegetable and isn't comparable based on calorie and protein intake alone. 5. The comment about methane being the largest emission and most powerful despite not providing any evidence that cattle provide a influential amount is kinda biassed.

The problem is, as always, the prisoner dilemma. Even if I turned vegan tomorrow, will everyone else? Or a majority? Or even a significant portion of the population? Probably not. And my own individual impact is minimal, so me doing it alone will affect nothing but my own dissatisfaction. So if doing it alone will affect nothing, and few enough people will do it to create an impact, why should I do it? This is why collective action is necessary for any kind of meaningful change. Talking about the data isn't enough.

Nitrous oxide is 300 times as potent a greenhouse gas over carbon dioxide. Nitrous oxide comes from plant agriculture. So less emissions, but stronger emissions are coming from plant agriculture. It comes from synthetic fertilizer. Synthetic fertilizer is partly responsible for desertification. Grazing farm animals can reverse desertification by spreading their droppings, returning nutrients to the earth, and don't emit nitrous oxide. It's not so simple.

ThereтАЩs over 70 billion farm animals to feed 7 billion people. ItтАЩs obvious that you have to grow more food to feed the animals to feed humans and that is very inefficient way to feed a global population. Is it absolutely necessary to have nutrition filtered through an animal. Feed crops produced in North America are enough 5o feed the starving populations of the world 2.5 times over according to the industries own data. Time to change protein is not an issue thereтАЩs no protein deficiency wards at your local hospital. It ainтАЩt a problem.
Comparing locally produced beef with fruit that is shipped across the ocean is incomplete since also the transoceanic food needs to be transported to your local grocery store. So you have the environmental impact of local shipping plus the transoceanic shipping.
Certainly there's a significant economic and cultural argument in favour of beef production in some parts of the world, northern Britain and Ireland being a good example.   Here there's huge amounts of otherwise unproductive grassland, and the agricultural economy is almost exclusively livestock, cattle in the valleys and sheep on the hills. Abandoning that land would be very costly, you'd either have the government buy all the land at market price at a cost of at least 80-100 billion pounds and be saddled with millions of hectares of money draining grassland, or they can permanently subsidise farmers to basically do nothing with their land, which would be even more expensive in the long run and even more unpopular. Telling the farmers to lump it isn't politically viable, they're a very vociferous minority with the power to cause a lot of disruption.  It would also have an enormous cultural impact. Some villages and small settlements owe their entire existence to livestock farming, without it there would be little reason for anyone to live there, other than perhaps a few retirees and hotel owners. They're often a long way away from towns, so have already experienced a population drain as agriculture has become less labour intensive. This would probably be enough to be a final nail in the coffin for some of the most isolated places.  I don't have a good answer to this really, in an ideal world we could just leave the land to nature and every government would have enough income to sustain over a fifth of their land being a money sink. But farmers need to be placated and a historical agricultural culture needs to be preserved, or at least able to adapt without losing its essence.

Some really beautiful scenes in there! <3 As an addition to the amazing facts in this video, I would like to add that we need either cattle or wild grazing animals in order to keep a high state of biodiversity! And I would personally prefer if we didn't hunt the wild grazers and help them manage the grasslands instead, like they did for many moons before the human explosion.
CO2 and methane emitted by animals come from crops and crops get the carbon from the atmosphere, itтАЩs a cycle. The focus needs to be in stopping emissions coming from fossil fuels, CO2 trapped for millennia, that is now being released.
Did you Ignore the carbon cycle or ruminants and did not discuss the possible usage of ruminants to discard what remains from crops? Ruminants do not add carbon to the atmosphere if you actually look at them. They use carbon from the plants, release it to the atmosphere, then the methane breaks now and is absorbed by the plants as CO2 and water. this is not excusive to the ruminants as any and all crops will release methane once they start to decompose, so if we get rid of cows we will have huge decomposition landfills in order to create plant based fertiliser, which will just release constant methane and be a definate explosion hazard as current landfills are (there have been cases of former landfills which were converted into something exploding). Cows allow for us to do this exact same thing but more safely, we do use manure as a major fertiliser afterall. Why is no one asking where the Carbon comes from?

7:20 could that title be any longer
The thing with talking in generalities about "beef" and "pork" and "chicken" is that it assumes that all breeds offer the same returns and the same inputs.  This is incorrect.  Over the decades a single breed has come to dominate production in each of the big three. This is due to breed associations lobbying and marketing as well as industry pushing for, size, shape, weight etc metrics.  Take beef, the most prominent breed might just be the worst one to be producing when it comes to inputs and CO2 costs. where they can  get 50-60% cut-ability rates, while other breeds can get 70%+ while requiring the same or less inputs.  Agriculture has a huge role to play, and once of the first things that can and should be done is looking at the breeds that are being produced and changing to more efficient breeds.  Couple that change with feed input changes, and reductions in CO2 grow while also increasing quality (this is just another way of saying, stop feeding animals corn). I am glad thee video, even lightly touched on this subject, since it never gets any attention.
The thing is that it doesn't matter. Hear me out, the carbon from beef comes from the carbon in the plants which comes from the air. That's the carbon cycle. The only reason the CO2 is climbing is by the introduction of new carbon to the cycle (through fossil fuels). If we stopped all fossil fuels now, the carbon cycle would stay in place exactly how it is now (minus some little variations over time of course). So let's just stop it, bury the excess carbon and fuel ourselves with wood.

What's the carbon foot print of Printed meat?
Meat isn't the problem, its what we feed our animals that is. Everyone needs gigantic cuts of the finest steaks and pork and it involves shoveling massive amount of cultivated foods, the largest user of fresh water, into them and having them be insanely large. Ruminants like cows, chickens, goats and (noninvasive) pigs are literally nutrition up cycling machines, they eat the grass, tubers, and seedlings that have no nutritional value to humans and turn it into many pounds of nutrient dense meat. They do this quite well on land that cannot otherwise be cultivated due to poor ground conditions such as rocks and a lack of vital minerals.   2/3 of the livable land on earth is like this btw, yet we find it necessary to dump insane amounts of resources into making land  farmable with a majority of what's farmed not even being used for human or animal feed and is sent straight to a factory to use even more resources to be further processed into some kind of oil or sugar that is killing us.   The most devious thing about all of this is that they've somehow managed to convince people meat is the problem when its just a symptom of the real problem which is our food system. People claim good science because they quote 10 year old articles from the WHO which have been debunked and the researchers have even admitted to omitting or out right misconstruing the information presented. Methane only lasts much longer in the atmosphere because most CO2 is quickly absorbed into the ocean, which acidifies it and makes it much harder for the algae that convert it into O2 to thrive and keep it in balance. Much like CO2 and water methane has a cycle of it's own which does not keep in the atmosphere for long and for all intents and purposes (unlike just about every other natural system on earth) has gone mostly unmolested by human activity. The amount of methane producing livestock and the methane they produce has flat lined and hasn't risen or fallen dramatically in the past 200 years, and yet suddenly now it's causing global warming. It's disingenuous at best and overtly malicious at worst to continue to point to methane as any sort of factor when it comes to global warming and the use of resources such as fresh water at large when researchers and climatologists have had the emissions of CO2 into the earth's atmosphere pinpointed as the number 1 cause of climate change for YEARS.   Just remember, history repeats itself, if you see companies like Beyond meat and the like claiming they are sustainable and forward thinking and "not your grandma's typical corporate conglomerate" you should be cautious. Companies have overthrown governments to make an extra few cents on bananas, millions of dollars were "charitably donated" to the  american heart association in it's infancy by vegetable oil companies when they dominated the cooking fat market and convinced america it was the healthier option despite the rise in heart disease and metabolic issues that rose sharply and lock step with the rise in the use of said synthetic cooking fats, and just a few years later the AHA comes out with their first health bulletin for the american people and suddenly animal fats which humans have consumed in excess for thousands of years are the cause of heart disease and that everyone should switch to vegetable oil. Point being the game of making money has not changed, and a majority of science is funded by companies, the fad today is sustainable and healthy, if a company can't pay for research that solidly concludes that their product is that, then they can definitely pay for some research that says the alternative is worse, has happened, and will continue to happen.   Note: i have nothing personally against beyond i just used them as a well known example, if you want meat made from plants then that's your decision and i support it, a big part of living in the free world is having the options and the freedom to choose what you consume and for what reasons, even if it kills you (sugar)

Thanks for posting again!
"The more animals suffer, the better they are for climate change." This is patently false. The reason they give is that they're spending less energy and the  food comes right to them, thus less gasses. This, to me, reads like a high school physics question: "Ignoring the energy used by the technology transporting the food, how much energy is saved..."  The quote source is also unsatisfactory. It is legitimately as if a high school student skimmed as many essays as they could on the topic to get a good quote and slapped in the first one they found. The source says, to summarize, that grain fed animals emit less in total green house gasses because they reach weight faster, and spending less energy grazing. This ignores several critical aspects of green house gas emission. First of all, I've already addressed how that grain is transported to the cows and how that would not be any more efficient greenhouse-wise than the cows finding it themselves.   Second, cows that graze are generally in grasslands. Grasslands are awesome for carbon capture. Grasslands need grazers to survive. Thus, cows grazing in grasslands means better carbon capture in that grassland. As for the methane and co2 emissions of cattle, most of it comes from their dung. That dung happens to be the best fertilizer you've ever seen, especially for grasslands. So cows not only do the necessary grazing to maintain the health of that grassland, but it also fertilizes it, speeding up the whole process.  This has been studied extensively, and is generally common knowledge to those who are actually involved in cattle farming (not factory farming). I can source it too, look up University of Alberta "Grazing livestock could reduce greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, study shows".   That's not the only source, it's actually hard to find anything claiming that factory farms are worse for emissions than grassland. In my mind, factory farms are the enemy, both in their treatment of animals and the affects they create on the environment. I don't know what their reason for it is, but to explicitly claim that the humane alternative is actually worse for the environment when that's not only false, but actually very hard to argue it's in any way true. I'm having a hard time imagining any intent here other than nefarious, unless they really did get that lazy in their research which might even be worse.  Making this claim discourages people from seeking or fighting for a more humane alternative. If they assume this to be true, then they're effectively forced to make a moral choice between factory farms or no meat at all. Why would you fight for more humane meat when it's worse for the environment, and why would you let meat be a thing if there's no humane way to do it? I seriously can't tell if this video is propaganda for meat factories or the anti-meat population, it honestly kind of serves as both.  Long story short, you're wrong, and the in which you're wrong actively discourages every productive course of action that could be taken in the meat production conversation. I normally like these videos but shitty misinformation and half truths like this are exactly the reason no progress has been made in getting rid of factory farms.

Nice Video!
What a very one sided video
Not all crops grown for animal consumption could be used for human consumption. Here in Canada, animal feed is often made from screenings or heated/otherwise contaminated feed that is not safe for human consumption. Erogot for example, humans can only safely consume wheat that is 0.04% ergot. Animals such as cows can handle a fair bit more than that. You have to be careful not to use too much ergot in either case because a high enough dose can induce abortions in livestock.
My main thing about vegan diets is the fact that you have to supplement A LOT of vitamins and essential amino acids and nutrients. That consuming meat, especially red meat, covers in spades and is the reason why we as humans are omnivorous. I feel that just cutting meat cold turkey isn't the entire solution here, sure environmentally speaking it would aid a lot. Yet practically speaking I'm not sure it would be the entire picture, given you would would have to look into other resources in order to make up for the missing nutrients. As a society I am unsure if we are entirely there to transition to a full vegan diet, along with some may not be able to even partake in a vegan diet in concern with allergies and the such.   I know a lot of vegan like to peddle that its a natural diet, or is healthier, but the truth of the matter is that vegan diets are not natural, nor are the necessarily healthier. Go ahead and burn me at the stake for saying this if you wish, but in truth a lot of vegans can be in poorer health than people that are omnivorous in their dietary intakes. Given vegans tend to be insufficient in important nutrients, like vitamin B12 for instance, given plant based foods. Do not contain an adequate amount, and means that you have to supplement your daily intake in through pills and the such. Along with vegan diets sometimes can be less healthy if you consume a lot of processed foods, which tend to contain a lot of sugars in them. Which is counter intuitive to a "natural" diet, with the latter being means your not exactly eating the healthiest diet.  The other thing I feel that wasn't covered well was that even if we remove a lot of these meat farms, some of it would still be taken up by new farms. That would grow plant based crops given the surge in demand and need for plant based foods. That would to me mean that all of the land being given back would have to be taken up again,  in order to ensure enough food is grown. With famine and crop diseases being another consideration that wasn't covered. As another issue with plant based crops is companies tend to grow clones of a single crop type, which as seen currently with bananas. Doesn't end well as if any singular disease were to crop up, entire crops would be annihilated before new ones could be grown to replace them. In which we would need crop diversity to avoid and compensate for all of this. Which in turn would cause a need for more farm land to ensure that crops are grown separately to avoid cross breeding given how our society works when it comes to crops.  Meat helps to bridge this gap by proving an alternative source, which sadly to me makes it a bit necessary to perpetuate currently, until new solutions are found.   While I do agree that we need to do something about our carbon impact, and I tend to agree with most of your videos, this one I take a little issue with. I feel that there are other solutions to the beef issue that aren't being considered, like lab grown meats. That would cutout the animal entirely and seriously reduce the amount of carbon emissions, and give back land that is currently being used in meat production. Achieving the lessened carbon foot print, while also maintaining the supply of meat, with the only solution I could possibly see for a practical global vegan diet. As suggested, would be highly processed foods fortified with nutrients that are missing from a vegan diet. To ensure that dietary needs are met, which is again is counter intuitive, but the only practical way to pull this off.

Why no one ever talk about the fact that methane emitted from animals is part of a cycle and as it goes into the atmosphere, it also come back? The carbon you are emitting while eating meat has been taken from the atmosphere by the grass the cow has eaten, not from the underground. This is different if u drive a car, because the emission you are doing is NOT part of a cycle. You are taking Carbon from underground and pump it into the atmosphere. I say this is game changing and NOBODY talks about it! Emitting greenhouse gasses from eating meat is substantially different from emitting greenhouse gasses that take the carbon from underground.

You didn't hit on the nutrition difference in practice. Beef and meat is way more nutrient dense than plant based. So how much more would we have to farm and eat to get the same amount? Once you multiply that into the mix, the difference is so little that it's virtually pointless. The larger problem is the population growth for humans on top of that. Even if we get rid of cows and their emotions, the human growth would just replace the cows. Besides, without the cows, there wouldn't be any fertilizer for the crops for humans. So we are in a symbiotic relationship with our farm animals. They can't live without us taking care of them, and without the shit they produce, we can grow food to eat. So we can't even go completely vegetarian because the crops won't grow.    I get the idea that food production overall is high emissions, but food should be lower on the totem pole of problems when we need to be switching to long term nuclear and geothermal energy and leave solar and wind behind as the failures they are. On top of that, we need to switch back to steam power and using clean burning fuels like natural gas and biofuels for engines. A stems engine turning a generator to power electric motors would be more environmentally friendly than electric cars that require coal burning plants to recharge. Not getting a real difference accept you can't go more than a few hundred miles. A steam engine/electric would work like a normal engine with no dangerous emissions and could replace everything.   Lots to discuss, and need to figure out how to proceed. But in all honesty, we outgrown our planet. We need to either down size or colonize the moon and Mars, possibly Europa and the asteroid belt.

Human life > Any animals life
So lets see here. 1 Cow gives us rounded up 200kg of beef (199.518kg). 1 kg of Beef gives 260g of Protein. Which is enough to feed a Family of 5 with a average weight of 52kg per person. So a single cow in this case, produce enough food to give 1000 people with the average weight of 52kg food for a day. This is if we go by that each person need 0.8-1g of protein per kg of weight.  So how much potatoes do we need to do the same? Well 12kg of Potatoes is equal to 1kg of Beef. That means we need 2400kg of potatoes to feed the same amount of people for a day (Rounded up from 11.818181818181818181818182 per kg of potatoes to 1kg of beef in protein value).  Now anyone who can figure out why eating 12kg of potatoes is pretty much impossible gets a +1 to their intelligence stat. But eating 1kg of beef is way easier. But we can't sustain ourselves on Just beef or Just potatoes either. We are Omnivores, we eat *everything* because we need *everything*.  As an example with Iron. The average man age 18-50 need roughly 8.7mg of Iron per day. 1kg of Beef (Depending on the cut) gives 3.6g of Iron. Meanwhile Potatoes are difficult with Iron. A single 295g of Unpeeled, Boiled and added Salt Baked Potato, gives 3.2mg of Iron. Where roughly 50% of that comes from the Salt, and 50% from the Skin. And it also depends a lot on the type of potato and where it has been grown.  So it is very complicated, and there is no real answer. Also people take up how much water cows drink. Forgetting that most of that water comes from rain, rivers and lakes. Where over 70% of our drinking water goes to plantations. And the worst offender of drinking up water supplies are Almond Trees, but no one bats an eye about that, since they want their Almond Milk, which takes even more water to produce. So again, there is no good answer. And we can't just cut out food from our diet, since everything has something other things does not. And we need a lot of different things.

I like that Kurzgesagt stuck to the environmental issues but didn't completely ignore the ethical issues. Ultimately, the vast majority of meat consumption is voluntary rather than necessary, so an animal is being raised and then killed on purpose when it didn't need to be. Some people don't care about that, because they don't care about animals (or selectively care about convenient animals like pets), but that is a whole lot of voluntary killing. Then there is the suffering of the animals before they are killed, which as Kurzgesagt pointed out is directly related to the efficiency and environmental impact of meat production; less suffering is a result of production methods that also have a greater environmental footprint.  So, yeah, as much as meat is an important part of our culture, it is still voluntary and could be voluntarily given up. Doing so would be the ethical choice.

Love your videos as always, but why is it that you guys never talk about the advancements being made into lab grown meat? Particularly by harvard students?  It's a nigh ultimate answer to all of the concerns with meat production. It comes with absolutely no suffering to the animal (one need only an initial harvested sample of muscle tissue about the size of a rice grain to begin the culturing process), it entirely free of risk of contamination or disease that factory farming brings about, is real beef unlike the impossible burger, is the single most resource efficient way to develop and harvest meat because you are -only- growing the muscle tissue, not the whole rest of the animal along with it, and even addresses local transportation emissions because lab grown can be produced in urban facilities that are much closer to market as opposed to out in rural areas. And certainly doesn't require any deforestation to make room for it or for its food.  If the world invested into switching over from animal harvesting to complete independent muscle tissue culturing, all forms of meat would suddenly become morally vegan, and ecologically very similar to plant agriculture.

Buying local produce may not have an overall large impact on the environment, but does is at least have an effect on the local economy? One of the arguments I've heard for trying to buy locally produced products (food, items, etc) is that it increases the demand for work locally, which can help keep job opportunities within your community, and often with smaller local businesses, instead of large mega-corporations that will farm out labour (pun not intended) to foreign countries, where the pay is much lower and working conditions are not as good. From a moral and/or economic standpoint, is there still a benefit to buying locally, even if the environmental impact is tiny?

In one breath you guys discount the carbon sink that is cattle pasture (grass) and then say if the cows werenтАЩt there we could have natural grasslands (grass). ItтАЩs literally the same thing, we just control which animals get fed by the grass.  Also, you may want to consider how grass and rumenants (animals which eat grass) evolved. Codependently. Get rid of the rumenants, the grass begins to die, bare patches are formed, the soil dries out, the soil microbes die, MASSIVE carbon is released and the land dies, turning into desert. Removal of roaming rumenant herds kills grassland.  The American Midwest was once a sea of grass with an average soil depth of ten feet as measured by the USGS. Nowadays the soil is only 1-2 feet. So where did all that soil/carbon go? And did slaughtering tens of millions of Bison perhaps contribute to the slow death of the prairie?

Okay, that's disingenuous of you.  Humans don't grow crops just to feed herd of cows or sheep or pigs. We grow crops for us humans. The parts of the plants we grow but can't eat is processed into animal feed. 48% of any cereal crops is used feed humans but, the remaining 52% of the very same crop is used to feed animals. So is you have 100 acers of wheat 42% of the wheat crop can feed humans because that all we can digest of the plant. The other 52% of the plant is used to feed animals because they can digest it.  Same for soy and any other crop that we humans grow. We don't grow crops just to feed animal. We feed animals the parts of the plants we grow but can't eat. While I agree on the emission amounts, presenting it this incredibly vague and inaccurate way in regards to how crops are actually used by humans to feed ourselves and the animals we eat is just propaganda in my opinion.

I respect Kurzgesagt a lot. I even bought their new book! But this is by far their most biased video. Meat definitely has a not insignificant effect on the environment, don't get me wrong. However, comparing it's effect to only two separate plant items on the chart and not all vegetables is definitely going to make meat look bad. They have even said in their own videos that methane is barely a factor in global warming compared to carbon dioxide. They mention how nutrient dense meat is compared to other foods. People don't realize how many chronic and acute health problems one can avoided by not being nutrient deficient. Meat is a very convenient and easily accessible way to get the nutrients you need. Especially compared to this hyper processed "wonder" meat. You'd be dead in a month eating only beyond burger. They show how much better pasture raise meat is in this video, yet still demonize it by only mentioning transportation emissions and comparing it (again) to individual plant products instead of vegetables and fruits as a whole. Renewables in general have a massive impact on the environment. Huge amounts of land is consumed for wind farms and no one talks about the hundreds of thousands of birds (endangered included) that are killed by them. How about the massive toxic waste that is produced by solar panels that still have a short life span and can't be recycled? Or that 90 percent of what you put in the recycle bin doesn't get recycled? Properly implemented renewables are probably the long term solution, but right now, none of them come without major environmental consessions. Nothing humans do is without consequence and it is irresponsible to live life acting like it is even possible. Educate yourself so you can take care of your own health and that of your family in the best way you can. If that means eating vegetables do it. If it means eating meat, do it. Don't try to virtue signal. You'll just come off as uninformed and morally lazy.

I think another point people don't make that often is what will happen to the livestock if demand for meat falls to really low levels? Farmers won't keep cows around if their value is less than the cost of maintaining them so lots of domesticated farm animals will either be culled, not allowed to breed or potentially set free into the wild - something they have not been bred to cope with. These animals are so differentiated from their original ancestors that they only really live to serve humans and if they can't do that then I can see a large number of species becoming functionally extinct  Edit: I didn't say demand was going to fall in a day. Over a long period of time this will happen. Livestock will become less and less valuable to keep.

I was positively surprised by this video, a lot of people act as if factory farming isnt the most efficient method of killing animals for food and end up saying that everything would be fine if the cows where grass-fed/free-range.
I have a question:  Facts from sources:  Tempcontrolled transport:   - sea 0,02 kg CO2 per tonne-km -rail 0,06 kg CO2 per tonne-km -road 0,2 to 0,66 per tonne-km  from sources in description:   тАУ For example, shipping one kilogram of avocado from South America to Europe generates about 0.3 kilograms of CO2 equivalents in transport emissions and around 2.5 kilograms overall тАУ while one kilogram of beef from your local butcher will come in at 18 kg in CO2 equivalents at least. So even when shipped at great distances, emissions from almost all plant-based foods cause lower emissions than locally produced animal products.   Most of the avocados coming to Europe are from Central and South America. The biggest exporters are Mexico, Peru, Dominican Republic and Colombia. We based the calculation here on a freight route from Peru to Belgium  which is around 12000km, and generates about 0.3kg CO2eq.  12000km * 0.023kg per tonne-kilometer / 1000 ~ 0.3 kg CO2eq per kg   I would agree with this if all stores and warehouses would be situated around ports but from experience I know this is not the case so we have to accept the fact that these products still require road or atleast rail transport on top of it. (Which is an increase of x10 to x33 and x3 respectively for every extra kilometer to the stores/warehouses/markets inbetween.) Where locally produced meat only has the higher emissionsrate for a shorter distance without the sea transport on top.   My point being: the argument that there is low emissions on transport of these goods doesn't really hold up.

I think no matter what, there is no reasonable way for human civilization to be carbon neutral or negative without having dedicated technologies running to counter our actions. Even if we become as clean and efficient as possible, if we want to have a good standard of living, there will be emissions. However, not only can nature handle some extra carbon, but if we had dedicated carbon capture tech running off of clean power, then we could all "have our steak and eat it too" with out having to worry about every single kilo of emissions.

definitely not state sponsored malnutrition like in cuba where cows are PROPERTY of the state.
I mean, food is PART of the system. Carbon-emissions and FOSSIL-carbon-emissions are very different things, with very different consequences. One is adding more carbon into the system and driving climate-change, the other is releasing the carbon already inside of the system and driving climate-change.  It might seem like a "semantics" kind of thing. But the difference is basically that "cutting down a forest" (whilst problematic for a variety of different reasons), doesn't actually really cause any more carbon-emissions than simply allowing the forest to rot away on its own (it'll just be a more "rapid impact", which is admittedly not great in the middle of a crisis). So unless you're planning to BURY that forest several kilometers underground in order to properly remove the carbon from the system, simply having "more forest" isn't going to do anything more than temporarily delay those carbon-emissions from being released once again.  It's a bit like saying that "cows fart methane" without acknowledging that the food that the cows eat would produce that methane ANYWAY, even without the cow to facilitate things.  There's definitely an argument for changing how we farm various things. Mono-cultures are for example notoriously bad for wildlife, and fertilizer can easily contaminate water-supplies. But this idea that some foods will inherently produce the kind of carbon-emissions that would drive climate-change forward (rather than the methods of "harvesting/transporting" those foods being the actual villain) sounds very disingenuous.
This video has a pretty misleading title. You don't make any references to climate in it. With the way the title is phrased, I expected an equal amount of video time to be dedicated to ethics of factory farming, and nutritional hazards/benefits of eating meat. The perspective in this video was much more narrow.
