I feel like using a life cycle analysis for animal products raises some weirdly existential issues, particularly if you're talking about the cost of raising an animal to maturity for food. By that logic, a genocide of cows would be one of the best things for the environment. And a genocide of humans even more so. Is that something you're ethically ok with? Because the cow doesn't cease to exist just because you've stopped eating it. And it will still try to live, consume and have offspring unless it dies. Then the counter argument becomes, if animals co-exist with humans anyway, why not make them part of our food systems. Like I said, LCAs have a nasty habit of simplifying some extremely complex issues particularly when they have to deal with living things.

Very misleading information at times honestly.   For example, when saying that 48% of our crops go directly to humans as food, and 41% to animals, you completely ignore the fact that a massive part of our crops cant even be digested by humans.  Usually we eat a very small part of the crops we grow, the seeds or the fruit of it. The husks or stems from the crops are inedible to us, but NOT to farm animals.   Not giving that part of our crops to animals would mean throwing it away currently. But this is completely overlooked here, framing it as if we give loads of "human food" to cattle.

with every food chain layer, energy output decreases by around a factor of 10. So 1000J of animal feed is needed to produce 100J of beef. There is no valid argument for sustainable meat because it would always be more efficient to give the energy the livestock is consuming straight to humans.

I think you missed one of the most obvious arguments against meat, and that is the one with ecological pyramids. LetтАЩs say you grow 10 kg of crops, you can either feed that to an animal and get 1 kg of meat or you can eat the 10 kg of crops yourself. From an energy efficiency perspective eating the crops is a whole lot better. If youтАЩre wondering why you only get 1 kg of meat even though you gave the animal 10 kg of food? It is that way because when the animal is alive it releases heat (energy), so when your animal has eaten all of the food and grown into something you can eat, it has released 90% of the energy you gave it тАФ> 1 kg of meat.

Very incomplete picture painted here.  Among the omitted points are:  1: It's takes an average of 660 gallons of water to produce 1 beefburger patty, with all the attendant energy use to process that water for consumption. 2: Animal (not just cow) waste is often dumped or leeches into the sea and rivers, destroying ecosystems, especially microbiological, i.e. coral reefs. 3: Much of this arable 'non-viable" land could be used to grow hemp or other hardy, multiuse crops, which grow under very harsh conditions, and require little cultivation. 4: Most of the world's grains are actually grown in order to feed livestock animals. Meaning that much of the carbon footprint caused by crops is actually caused by livestock rearing.  These are to name a few off the top of my head - there are more omittances. Don't believe me, check these facts yourself. If you want a compelling watch, check out a documentary film called Cowspiracy. It's not the most up-to-date report, but it highlights many effects on the environment, which are left out here, to further your inquiry.  Main thing to take away: meat production is very bad for the planet. A move towards more ecological farming encourages and incentivises animal cruelty. If you think it's bad based on this video alone, it's much worse than you think.

My big question with it all is really: How much of the emissions contribute permanently to global warming, and how much of it is reversed with the next set of feed crops grown? Sure, we can make a one-time investment in forest lands but unless we sequester that carbon back, we're just delaying by ~15 years. Which is in itself commendable, but that's if *everyone* goes vegan. Meanwhile, if we transition to no-fossil-fuel meat production, then every bit of emissions from the animals could only come from one source: That which is absorbed by the plants they eat. Methane breaks down to CO2 and water, CO2 is used up by the plants that feed the animals - it's a closed cycle. So my question ends up being whether this would be a solution to the problem, or if not, why not?   Not that I'm arguing that that's realistically feasible now, necessarily, but it makes me curious.

How about carbon cycles. Every plant a animal eats is buitlt up from the carbon it gets out of the air. So unlike oil which comes from the ground and gets carbon from millions year old fossils and doesn't grow back fast. Atoms cant be destroyed. If a carbon atom goes from plant to cow to human to CO2 or from cow to methane to CO2. The plants that started the cycle should consume the same CO2 or at least a large part of it. I see the earth built up out of 3 carbon batteries. Fossil reserves, surface carbon(trees plants materials) and the atmosphere. Surface and atmosphere can exchange pretty quickly using combustion and photosynthesis. While fossil can only take from surface at a very slow rate. Right now we are taking all the fossil carbon and turning it into atmospheric carbon faster than it can grow back. The whole food chain is surface. So apart from burning large amounts of forest and using the surface for usage with less capacity it should balance itself out right? I dont know if im thinking way to simplistic but it seems logical this way and i never hear anybody else about it.

One important thing omitted in the video: Animals don't get fed the part of wheat and cereals humans usually eat. They can use the stalk and leaves and everything we can't use out of them. So simply going by produced raw weight of material and comparing which goes to human and which goes to animals is not really an accurate way of seeing how much we "waste" on animals.

One factor I've never seen addressed in the meat vs. plant impact on global CO2 emissions: In the US, a lot of beef is raised on land that used to be roamed by bison. Not arguing that two wrongs make a right, but we killed off most of the bison and so the methane they used to emit is gone, replaced to some degree or another by beef cattle. I realize, that doesn't impact all of the carbon associated with the meat biz, and I'm certainly open to arguments that it's an insignificant factor, but I would at least like to see it addressed once.

...
The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) is the United Nations body for assessing the science related to climate change.  They found that under the most extreme scenario, where no animal products are consumed at all, adequate food production in 2050 could be achieved on less land than is currently used, allowing considerable forest regeneration, and reducing land-based greenhouse gas emissions to one third of the reference тАЬbusiness-as-usualтАЭ case for 2050.   Even if you want to deny the evidence, this can be proven with simple math and logic:  In which scenario will we need more land, water, food, and overall resources? 1)	Feeding, housing, and watering 70 billion animals and 8 billion people. 2)	Feeding, housing, and watering 8 billion people.  And donтАЩt forget, all those animals create A LOT of urine and feces. And they make a lot more of it than us. It all has to go somewhere and multi-billion dollar companies may or may not be too picky about where it goes. All that urine and feces also creates a lot of gas.

Meat is actually a major cause for there being so much hunger in the world. 80 percent of all agricultural land is devoted to growing feed for farm animals. Most of those calories are lost when they are transferred into meat, eggs and dairy. Thus, if the world's population ate half as much meat as we do now, we would in an instant be able to feed the 800 million people who go to bed hungry every night.
to be safe, let's be flexible on the types of food we enjoy eating. Considering how nice it must be to be eco friendly, I would *try* eating less beef
Let's postulate this.   Plants, especially crops, need fertile soil. (Otherwise they don't grow, obviously.)  Now a lot of fertiliser is made from animal bones, blood & manure. The nutrients from these then go back in the soil, making it fertile.   If (hypothetically) everyone stopped eating meat, and farm animals were no longer a thing, how long before the fields used to grow food crops become totally devoid of fertility? Considering that EVERY person on the planet now eats a 100% plant-based diet. Would that then result in deforestation simply to have access to fertile soil?   Would that deforestation then lead to less carbon absorption, and leaving areas unsuitable for farming for years?   So the question is, would ending meat consumption eventually lead us to the exact same situation?   Something to think about.
I've been waiting for so long.... it was worth the wait
In terms of beef's impact, I have two words for you: cultured meat. The tech is still growing, but if we keep developing it further, we could potentially grow meat at a lower cost than farm-grown, causing it to become cheaper than traditional meat. Hell, we've already seen it applied to Waygu beef and foie gras, and those lab-grown versions are apparently just as good as their traditionally-made equivalents, so it's not like cultured meat is a non-factor to be glossed over.  What's more, with the flexibility and compactness of growing meat in a lab, a smaller start-up could potentially price their varied products lower than farm-grown and still make a profit, meaning that traditional suppliers would potentially lose business unless traditional meat was subsidized enough for it to compete with cheaper lab-grown stuff.

"Pasture land alone can't support the ruminants living on it." This is patently untrue. Pastures can support a LOT of animals, it's just that leaving a lot of malnourished animals on an overgrazed, fenced in pasture and finishing them with corn in a feed lot produces far cheaper beef than herding those same animals over pastures using a rotating grazing system. Needing people to constantly look after and tend to the animals is far more expensive than just putting them on a small fenced in lot and basically forgetting about them until they are grown up.
There are two points I feel should be included: the role of bovine and other ruminating animals in the process of regenerative agriculture, and diet supplements to reduce emissions(seaweed in particular).
Yes we should use less animals products, but it's not realistic to go 100% vegan.

itтАЩs also really bad for the animals youтАЩre consuming, unnecessary cruelty
I do think there's some misleading things in this video. One of them is how the numbers about soy are reported. It starts off by having 2 sets of numbers. The one that is spoken tells about 19% soy being used by humans and 77% by animals (the rest is industry but this part isn't spoken). However at the same time you have the bird's speech bubble telling that the majority of beans is crushed into soy cake for animals and soy oil for processed food and biofuel. And the sneaky thing here is that the numbers here are percentages *by weight*. What this means is that even if you stopped using the soy cake part for animals, you would still need the same amount of actual soy plants to keep the same amount of soy oil required for food and fuel (and probably more for food since you need to replace meat). All you'd have changed is that we now have a bunch of soy cake that we need to find another purpose for.  The same thing goes for other types of feed, though this is highly dependant on the country. A lot of plants come with extra materials that we humans can't eat (or sometimes just won't eat just because it's deformed, humans are picky like that). One way to dispose of this is to feed them to animals. If we don't, they would just rot away and also emit a lot of methane and CO2.  Another thing that bothers me about the conversation of food and CO2 is that nobody ever seems to mention the circle of life. Plants grow from CO2 in the air. Animals eat plants and other animals. And when animals breathe or die, they release that CO2 back into the world (Over simplification). This means that within this circle, it's impossible to introduce carbon that wasn't already there to begin with. Which means that in order to increase the CO2 in the air, you have to introduce an outside source of carbon. Hello fossil fuels. But for some reason people are more interested in how much cows eat and burp than the fossil fuels required for beef and the alternatives.  Lastly, according to Wren (the CO2 calculation website) changing my mainly carnivorous diet (showing my bias here) to a completely vegan diet, would save about 5% on my total CO2 footprint (which already was about 30% lower than my country's average). So it doesn't really seem like meat has that much of an impact compared to the rest of our lives.
I don't understand why everyone is so concerned with decreasing our carbon footprint like literally just let everything happen that's a problem for future generations to solve

You're making a category error at 8:30 in, Cows are not necessarily eating the same parts of the plant(or even the same plants). For example humans eat just the kernals of a corn plant but cows can eat the whole stalk, leaves and cob, the same with cotton plants (which we don't eat) and wheat and oats etc. So it's not an apples to apples comparison.

So you omitted a point: altering cattle feed and even gut bacteria of cattle to produce less methane.  I recall a study where mixing seaweed with cattle feed suppressed the emissions of CO2 significantly.  If our current cattle are methane factories, putting a price tag on methane production would both encourage less beef being eaten, but also encourage beef producers to alter and breed low methane cows.  Also, a point you omitted is that methane that enters the atmosphere decays into CO2, so a methane emission is just a deferred, more potent CO2 emission.

Fun fact that is often missed out in videos like this is that livestock dont just randomly create greenhouse gases naturally inside of them like some sort of industrial factory, they get it from the plants thy eat which in turn get it from the atmosphere so it is carbon neutral and not like fossil fuels that we dig up and release into the atmosphere.  Also, another fun fact, we all cant go vegan as our bodies are all different and so while some can go vegan with no issues, others will have severe health issues which is why nutritionists nowadays dont advise a single diet for all of humanity but suggest to try different diets out to see what works best for you.

The methane released by cows is acually in a closed loope system, they consume grass, transformed it into methane, than then transform into CO2 into the atmosphere and get absorbed by grass to be eaten again. So in the long term, there is 0 net emissions.  One other aspect not talked about here is waste. A third of all food produced ends up in the trash, if we were less wasteful, food production wouldn't be suche a problem, whatever the diet.

Way to miss a massive detail y'all. I'm sorry but I'm fed up with the lie that cattle cannot be grass-fed. Beef production could be shifted 100% to grass-fed (with GAINS in efficiency) if we simply converted the fields currently growing crops to feed to cows into pasture. The math has been done, any field can produce the same amount of calories in grass as in corn and soy. As well grass does not suffer from major disease or pests, does not require fertilizer, acsesses deep nutrients, prevents runoff, and stores rain water more efficiently. Simple math will also tell you that this method would also take less transportation. Cows gain 1 pound for about every 5 they eat, thus if you are transporting the cows from the food instead of the food to the cows, you are likely to require significantly less transportation. Not even including the reduced need for pharmaceuticals since the cattle would be spread over a much greater area (and actually exposed to sunshine) compared to a CAFO. Please look past the lies you have been told and think critically about the problem. Cows are adapted to eat grass, they were never meant to eat corn.

Some things to think about with this;  1. A huge majority of the 'human food' we do end up sending to feedlots are actually the inedible parts (oat hulls, soy hulls, wheat stems and leaves, spent beer grains, etc) of plants and so you could argue we are simply using our resources more efficiently than letting it rot in landfills (which is a massive source of emissions btw)  2. The argument that the non-arable land used for grazing animals (grasslands, mountains, etc) could be used for ecological restoration instead is misguided for a few reasons. One is that you are ignoring just how much of a carbon-sink these grasslands are. if they are properly managed and grazed, they are an important tool in restoring the climate. Grasslands absorb carbon and sequester it by building soil (which forests are surprisingly bad at). This cannot be done without grazing animals (or people having to manually mow grass or have controlled fires) because grasslands will actually die if there arent animals. Look into some of the Siberian and African restoration projects involving grasslands to understand this a bit better. They key is proper management, however.   3. The transport emissions issue comes down to a flaw in the scientific method. Many of the early studies (mostly done by IPCC) that measured emissions from vehicles ONLY measured tailpipe emissions. Even the authors of some of these reports admitted this later. They did not measure the emissions cycle of the transport method in the same way that they measured the whole life cycle of cattle. This means the numbers are very misleading and I fully believe transportation (and buying locally) actually plays a massive role in this debate and is being underplayed in this video.  4. Countries like the United States are astronomically better at land management and farming practices than third-world countries. If you look at the agricultural emissions of the united states, its comparatively very low despise the massive cattle herds. Using a 'global average' is misleading. We need to spread better farming practices globally.   Overall I liked the video, but I think there were some important things missing and one has to be careful about the data sources as they are largely based on flawed and/or politically driven studies. Some degree of common sense, deductive reasoning and logic needs to play a part in this as well.

"Because of this feed demand, less than half of crops are used directly as food." -> Incorrect. Farmers are not stupid. For example, before a farm harvests wheat, the quality of the crop will be assessed, the crop sorted, and animals get fed the portion that does not make the cut for human consumption. You get 2-3 times less money for your wheat if you sell it / use it as animal feed as you would if it can be sold for flour, so why would you? Plant production exists in parallel with meat production and not to supply it. You get all sorts of social problems, beside the environmental ones where that's not true.

This is a bit misleading: I know they said that beef is an outlier, and they mentioned that several points are controversial, but then they continue to roll with only one animal and one side of each controversy. The short term climate effect from beef is large due to methane, but the effect in 100 years is negligible.  They say that even the best beef is worse than the worst plants. This is not true. Most vegetables are worse, only grains, beans and roots are better. If you remove the methane contribution (because it is short term), then even mediocre beef is better than broccoli. Furthermore, beef is by far the worst "offender". Chicken have a calorie conversion ratio of 1.7. They are fed with animal feed. This animal feed is grown much more efficiently than comparable food for humans. This leads to Chicken being better for the environment than all fruit and leafy vegetables. Also some roots are worse. Only grains and starchy roots are better. You can not make a meal based on grains and starchy roots that is comparable in quality to a mixed meal. If you substitute the meat portion of a mixed diet, then it would be fairer to compare with fruits and vegetables, and not with grains and potatos.

"chicken and pigs, which exclusively use feed crops..." Um... in most of Southeast Asia, chickens are basically allowed to roam free and eat whatever they can catch. You just catch them when you need them for dinner, and/or make nest baskets for laying eggs. Pigs are mostly fed with leftovers + wild-harvested plants like wild sugarcane or water spinach which grow abundantly on land unsuitable for agriculture without need for cultivation. But then again, these are basically backyard "farms", which don't exist anymore in most of the western world.   The problem with these calculations is that they assume agriculture is industrial by default.

What a great video. Here's another point in favour of plant alternatives: Most corpse meat we eat bears absolutely no aesthetic resemblance to any part of an animal carcass (think burgers, sausages, and nuggets for example). This is by design. People are kind of grossed out by the idea of eating corpses, so companies do their best to hide the familiar anatomical shapes that might put people off. This is an own-goal for the corpse meat industry, because plant matter is a universally better building material than corpses. So any shape you can make out of blended up corpse meat, you can make it easier and better out of blended up plant meat. And there's never accidentally a beak in your nuggets.

One thing that is mostly ignored in these debates is the price of the product: Look, the best thing for the climate would be to consume nothing. Dumping your monthly check onto a bank account doesn't hurt the climate, buying things will. The more you can buy from your paycheck, the more the climate will suffer. Thus, the best thing would be to make products more expensive. People will be able to consume less and this will benefit the climate. Saying that mass-produced meat is better for the climate is technically true, but not if you account for the low prices. In the end, it comes down to this logic: People won't buy a specific amount of things every month, they will rather just spend a specific amount of money. Making things more expensive will directly benefit the climate.

"Beef has a high nutrient density lets see how it compares" -> Only compares protein (which itself is made up of 20 key amino-acids) not any of the 40 odd micronutrients....  You can't look at 1 variable out of 60 and expect a useful outcome now can you. And that is before looking at bioavailibility, and nutrient form (K1/2, DHA/LA, iron/heme)  Considering how important the argument is, I don't see why people only look at protein and calories. They are important but beefs big selling point is how rich in things like iron/zinc, B12, etc. it is, yet they are not calculated in...

in the first half I was thinking the video is only looking at CO┬▓ emissions, which would've been far from the complete picture. habitat destruction & segmentation, deforestation, desertification & ocean dead-zones are all greatly driven by animal agriculture and major factors in environmental destruction. animal agriculture does not just emit green-house gases, but also destroys the planets carbon sinks. and here, pastures are often even bigger culprits than factory farming.  it's also nice to see that they debunk the idea that "we couldn't use that land for something else anyways". while some pasture land may not be suitable for fields that grow human-edible foods directly, there's of course plenty of other environmentally important uses for it, such as actually leaving it as natural habitats for bio-diversity.  I don't agree that it is complicated at all. you simply have to look at the input and output of animal agriculture to see the obvious issue and understand that it is inherently unsustainable. it is extremely inefficient to channel our resources through the bodies of animals - generally large mammals - over a period of several years. the output is puny. as long as we have this inefficient middle-man for converting calories, there's very little room for optimization (and any optimization comes of course at the cost of even more horrendous conditions for the animals), while on the other hand, there's still massive room for optimization in animal-free agriculture.  without a doubt, animal agriculture at scale has no future if we are to achieve sustainability.

IтАЩm wondering how marginal human related emissions are to pre-industrial natural emissions though. Simply measuring the emissions per cow does not take into account how (in North America at least) 2/3 of methane emissions are inherent to the naturally occurring ruminant herds native to the continent. Speaking on a geographical time scale, wouldnтАЩt simply eliminating cattle eventually have diminishing returns as animals, like bison and elk, repopulate to their pre-industrial numbers? Certainly a reduction in beef consumption is necessary, but if the goal is emission reduction, would this mean beef isnтАЩt as bad as the current measurements would suggest?

The Amazon uses most of the oxygen it produces, making it useless outside of тАЬCO2 storageтАЭ. 2. 1st world countries can actually care about the environment. One of the many reasons Brazil remains a poor country is due to the Forrest they canтАЩt cut down. If they were allowed to remove most of it they could actually pull themselves out of poverty. And letтАЩs also not forget the fact that тАЬclimate changeтАЭ itself is an intensely vague science. Originally it was global warming (it still is really) but it was changed because it was proven in scientific communities that the earth is not always warmer. Also anyone actually studying all aspects of climate change know that the margin of тАЬchangeтАЭ is so low we can only barely say тАЬthe earth is getting hotterтАЭ. In the last 5 years the earths average temperature (a ridiculously difficult concept to calculate in and of itself) has risen like a degree or a few. Extend that number out to 50 to 60 years and the margin is not even 1 degree. That implies (using simple logic) that the earths temperature balances itself. Trees store CO2. Trees grow faster and larger in warmer climates. The earth gets warmer when CO2 is released. This implies that cutting down trees and increasing CO2 levels actually increases tree growth, ultimately reducing CO2 levels. The entire world works this way. It recycles material in order to make new material. The death scare of climate change is nothing more than a political talking point to allow the rich and powerful to scare you into letting them take control, to stop having kids, to keep 3rd world countries in poverty and not be contenders for the worlds wealth, and even to keep the wealthy countries in greater poverty (you see this in the United States gas and transportation crisis right now) Pretending that these are actual crisis issues is just feeding the elite the power to control the way we think and it prevents us from holding them accountable to their bad actions. The intense influx of lumber from the Amazon would also increase supply of lumber worldwide, reduce price of construction material, and even reduce the price of housing worldwide as it would be cheaper to produce. All around and in every direction the тАЬclimate changeтАЭ argument does nothing but give more power and money to the elite, keeps the poor poorer, reduces current quality of life and lifestyle, polarizes people, and even convinces some that worldwide human population needs to be reduced. (Essentially calling for genocide with a few extra steps) That is what they want, and we all need to stop playing this silly game.

My contribution to the problem of the difficulty of changing our habits regarding food comes from the experience of losing the sense of taste as a symptom of covid. We should not separate pleasure from moral obligation (or practical urgency) on these issues, because in fact, pleasure, taste for food, and appetite (among many other emotional and other factors) are closely related. The fact of not feeling the taste of anything drastically lowers your appetite and even saddens you (imagine eating a cake and it feels like eating a sponge). Many people say that the worst thing about having covid is the loss of taste. How does this translate into action? Diversifying taste and making taste, social and emotional connections with other types of food, including the acts of cooking, sharing what is cooked, enjoying experimentation, giving our palate time to find new tastes. Etc. Unfortunately not everyone can change their habit so easily. In those cases, it must be done in a positive way for all aspects, and that it is not just a solitary task or a form of punishment. Thank you for reading.  Mi aporte a el problema de la dificultad de cambiar nuestros h├бbitos respecto a la comida, viene de la experiencia de perder el sentido del gusto como s├нntoma del covid. No deber├нamos separar el placer de la obligaci├│n moral (o urgencia pr├бctica) en estos temas, porque de hecho, el placer, el gusto por una comida y el apetito (entre muchos otros factores emocionales y otros m├бs) est├бn intimamente relacionados. El hecho de no sentir el gusto de nada te baja dr├бsticamente el apetito y entristece incluso (imagin├б comer una torta y que se sienta como comer una esponja). Muchas personas dicen que lo peor de tener covid radica en la perdida del gusto. ┬┐C├│mo se traduce esto en una acci├│n? Diversificando el gusto y haciendo conexiones gustativas, sociales y emocionales con otros tipos de comida, lo que incluyen los actos de cocinar, compartir lo cocinado, disfrutar la experimentaci├│n, dar tiempo a nuestro paladar a encontrar nuevos gustos. Etc. Por desgracia no todo el mundo puede cambiar de h├бbito tan facilmente. En esos caso hay que hacerlo de forma positiva para todos los aspectos, y que no sea solo una una tarea solitaria o una forma de castigo. Gracias por leer.

I greatly appreciate the tact used in this video to approach a delicate subject, but for the sake of furthering an important conversation I'd like to point out a few things that I feel are, respectfully, misrepresented in this video.    Firstly, I was very glad to see that pointed out just how powerful carbon sequestration can be. You mention the value of "restoring wild grasslands'', so I'd ask for anybody viewing to consider exactly how wild grasslands came to be in the first place. The North American Continent, for example, was not long ago a vibrant grassland ecosystem precisely because of the 50 million-plus buffalo that foraged here. Large grazing ruminants like cows don't WASTE more land (as stated at the end of the video), they RESTORE more land. This is the entire thrust behind the regenerative agriculture movement. Large herds of cows and other ruminants have already been used to restore millions of hectares of (non-arable), thanks to methods that mimic the natural grazing patterns of wild animals. When raised properly, large grazing animals aren't a drain on grasslands, they're an essential component of them. If you take issue with this claim, then you're left to defend the notion that ecosystems like those of the North American Continent around 11700 were so abundant IN SPITE of the ruminants that lived there, as opposed to because of them.   Second, with regard to methane emissions. If cows are such a large contributor to this issue, I'd like to ask: for how long has this been a problem? Cows and other methane-emitting animals have existed for millions of years, of course. So haven't they been putting methane into the atmosphere this whole time? Well, you say it yourself in the video: methane only stays in the atmosphere for about a decade. That means that the methane emitted from today's ruminants is effectively only replacing methane that was emitted from cows 10 years ago. Methane isn't simply deposited in the atmosphere, It's a cycle. And while it's true that atmospheric methane concentrations have increased, the number of grazing ruminants has decreased over the last several centuries. So why point the finger at cows when it's the other methane producing sources that have grown?   Thanks for the video, and I hope you don't mind my contribution to the (hopefully polite) conversation.

This still seems like an incredibly imbalanced coverage of the production of meat and its implications for net carbon emissions.  You sure are keen on emphasizing that plants can absorb carbon (9:35 graph), but completely ignore the fact that plant feed too absorbs carbon to facilitate the feeding of cattle etc. in the first place, you completely avoid making any complete life cycle/net carbon emission assessment of what it takes to produce x amount of meat (which is much much lower than the total carbon emissions giving people the wrong idea).  You do correctly state that transport accounts for very little of the total carbon emissions (which is the the only actual net contribution to the carbon contents in the atmosphere, as it relies on releasing long inert carbon into the atmosphere, unlike the carbon neutral cycle that is plants to animals repeat.)   There is still an increase to the steady state equilibrium resting average global temperate, for a giving amount of meat production, as it "upcycles" some carbon to methane (which is a stronger greenhouse gas, which is eventually broken down with a half life in the atmosphere of ~9.1 years), but this still deferrers importantly from the combustion of fossil fuels for power, as a static amount of fossil fuel based power will keep increasing the total carbon in the atmosphere, whereas a static amount/size of a cattle herd has a constant (not increasing) contribution.

I feel like this ignores a crucial point. The problem isn't just greenhouse gas emissions. It's extra greenhouse gas emissions. Animals producing methane and CO2 is normal and they've been doing that for over half a billion years. Raising animals for meat doesn't actually create more animals or more greenhouse gas emissions, because we prevent other animals from using that land. Killing off a bunch of other animals.  Which isn't to say that's any better. It's definitely also destructive to the environment. But it is destructive in a different way. We're not creating more animals, just changing the composition of the planet's animal population to be more "useful" to us. And thus, we're not increasing greenhouse gases by raising animals. If not for cows, other animals would be burping and farting instead. So, it's really just the transportation, processing, and storage that is a concern as far as I can see, and that can all be taken care of by switching to green electric energy sources.  Then, there's also the option of lab grown meat which hopefully isn't too far off.

Free idea for an episode. The summer of 1816, otherwise known as 'The Year Without a Summer'' when a supervolcano in Indonesia erupted and sent the northern hemisphere into a volcanic winter. North America, Europe and much of Asia reported snowfall in July. Crops were ruined and widespread famin caused panic leading many to believe the world was ending. Although the worst of it occured during 1816 the effects didn't really fully go away for over 50 years. It's a forgotten event that is both historically and scientifically interesting

This video is misleading on many levels. Let's see why (wall of text alert)  1- we need food to live so we could be the problem, not the food. But erase ourselves is not a solution, it's just nihilistic thinking. 2- changing to veggies is a false solution. You don't just stop meat and eat another thing because the nutrition is different. Meat is what made human brain superior. When agriculture became a good food source, humans still risked themselves to find meat because the benefits are worth the risk. Also, the land and the problems meat causes have a huge economic impact. If it exists an equivalent nutritious substitute with less real estate use and money spending, we've had already found it. 3- if "elites' profit" is an argument, it's "the elites" that are trying to stop us from eating it. Anyway, only poor people would stop consuming meat even if it becomes law. Do you really think that the very rich will stop it? They don't even follow mask mandates around themselves.  5- insects are not a solution. If they were, asian countries like China would stop consuming meat looking for the economic challenges. They eat bugs for centuries. 6- the video itself pointed out that transportation and oil emissions are not a problem on the food chain, which will guide us to the elephant in the room: climate change is caused by the energy industry, which uses mostly oil, gas, coal and others. So: 7- Even if we reduce meat consumption by 90%, the environmental impact would be less than 20% overall. That means we could make the entire world change its diet forever, climate change will still be a huge problem. That means meat is not really the problem here. 8-  (see 2) if meat is really so important to our diets to the point that we became smart (like, not animals) because of it, removing it will not only NOT solve the problem at all, we could still become less intelligent, therefore less capable to make the world better because we're risking to lose brain power. And if you assume (3) has a chance to be true, then don't be s1up1d.  We don't have a meat problem.

I have a few questions:  1. If we cut the meat production by 100%, does that free up 100% of the land currently being used by meat production? As stated in the beginning of the video, meat is one of the most nutrient dense foods. If we want to replace that source of nutrients with plant based alternatives, we need to increase the production of plant based alternatives by A LOT, right? What kind of resources will that require?  2. Animals eat a lot of food that humans can't consume for nutrients, right? I.e left-overs from what humans produced but weren't able to consume for themselves. Is there something else we can use that food for? Or will it just go to waste?  3. There is a statement here that we have significantly more methane in the atmosphere now than we did a century ago (or some time period back). At what rate has the population of cows grown over the past few decades?  4. In a previous video by Kurzgesagt, "Can YOU Fix The Climate?", Kurzgesagt stated "The concept of your personal carbon footprint was popularized by the oil producer BP in a 2005 ad campaign. Argubly one of the most effective and sinister pieces of propaganda that still seriously distracts all of us from the reality of the situation".   In that same video stating, in the context of making a change for the climate, "Even the most motivated person can't even make a tiny dent [by changing their lifestyle]". Then in this video stating "You can decide for youself what you want to do with this information", implying that you should change your lifestyle? Is it strange to judge those two statements, or ideas, to be inconsistent? I do not disagree with what is said in this video.  I'm uncomfortable with what was left unsaid.  There are factors that need to be addressed if we stop farming meat and only focus on plants.  - Modern agriculture uses pesticides that are bad for the land, wildlife and you.  Organic methods cannot produce enough food to feed billions of people. - Fertilizer has to come from somewhere.  If you eliminate the population of farm animals that will increase strip mining. - What is going to happen to the species that humans domesticated?  They cannot live in the wild.  Extinction is normally thought of as a bad thing.
Has Kurzgesagt not heard of regenerative farming and capturing carbon in soils through practices like intensive rotational grazing of livestock. We can literally offset the methane by capturing more carbon with the use of livestock like cattle. We can turn the sad mostly under-productive pastureland we have into much healthier more productive and ecologically functional land this way plus capture a greater amount of carbon than is emitted from the meat production.

Maybe its time for another gutten tag
Theres a bunch of issues that I have with this argument.  Number one, the emissions by livestock like farting and burping are not used fairly. No one ever mentions that the methane released by the animals is taken from their feed in the form of carbon dioxide, which is then turned into methane and released. This is very important, because the methane turns back into CO2 in the air, and is absorbed by the plants again. Its actually carbon neutral, much like biofuels. A massive chunk of meats emissions can be taken out of the equation right away, but this is never mentioned.  Number two, the feed. Many people like to point out that most meat livestock aren't fed on grass (for cows specifically) but crops. That's true, however it's never mentioned that about 96% of the crop feed that these animal's are given is left over byproducts that aren't even for human consumption (think stems and leaves of corn for example). Livestock is a very important part of removing waste from crop farming in an economically sustainable way, getting a second use out of crops is very good. Yes, 41% of cereal crops are used to feed animals, but most of that cant be eaten by people anyway. Its lies by omission.  Number three, water consumption. Not mentioned in this video, but still important. People always go on and on about how much water meat production wastes. Not true, it wastes slightly more than agriculture. Most of the water that's always used in these equations saying "ohhh livestock waste so much water" is green water. Green water is literally just rainwater that's been sucked up by grass and crop feed that gets pissed straight back out into the water cycle. 90%+ of the water consumption in the meat industry is green water. Almonds from California takes more water waste to produce than meat does.  It's so annoying when these things are never mentioned so I thought I would say them. Big fan of kurzgesagt but I dont agree with them this time and this is why.
Ok I agree with the points in the video but at 9:33 when they compare the 800 billion tons of CO2/100 years to the 50 billions produced/1 year, isn't it a bit dishonest ? Because if I'm not wrong ( I may be ), that means the quantity produced in 100 years would be 5 000 billions. Or did "50 billions tons ├йquivalent per year" mean they already counted it as being a 100 years ?

No.  It isn't.  If anything it is better for the climate.  Regenerative agriculture can actually sequester CO2 in the ground. Those studies saying otherwise are absolutely lying due to political bias.  The train is because they don't take into account the fact that it is a CYCLE.  Any CO2 or methane a cow releases has to come from the plant foods they eat, and those plants have to first absorb that CO2 from the atmosphere.   And again, with regenerative agriculture, you can actually absorb more CO2 and methane than is released.

Unfortunately there is very little I can do individually, as these phenomena are influenced mainly by politics, which is currently mostly giving incentive to these practices with the argument of economic growth. Truly heartbreaking ЁЯШФ.

what the fuck is a kilogram
Eating meat does not add new Carbon to the Carbon cycle, which means that in the long run it doesn't make climate change worse unless we increase production (more methane and deforestation). Keeping production of meat at the same level will won't have as much of an impact on the environment as there is from fossil fuels.   Decreasing meat consumption in the long term will lower methane levels helping us lower our CO2 equivalent emissions, increasing it will create more methane and deforestation and increase CO2 equivalent emissions.   Lowering fossil fuel consumption will be the most important part of solving Climate Change, meat is mostly a distraction form it.

Don't worry, in the future: we'll all decide that meat is WRONG.
Key points seem to be:  * Food production creates 26% (a bigger percentage than it sounds like) of all man-made greenhouse emissions.  * Meat creates WAY more emissions than plant-based foods - even if we look at it as emissions per calorie as opposed to emissions per kg of food. * Beef is the worst meat for emissions, standing way out above all other meats.  * Bigger issue - cow FARMING requires destruction of land (incl burning forests) which makes the emission footprint way, WAY worse, releasing sequestered carbon in trees and soil. * Cows - (meat in general, but cows FAR more so) - requires a HUGE amount of agricultural resources (grass-fed is something of a marketing ploy, still requiring quite a lot of feed). 41% of the wordтАЩs cereals are used for animal feed, e.g. 77% of soy production is used for animal feed (and the rest doesnтАЩt even account for tofu and soy milk). * Ethical issue - тАШcruelerтАЩ meat = less emissions.   * Going beef free ALONE would free up 2 billion hectares of land (and fully vegan, 3 billion).  * If said land was used to grow forests, restore grasslands - anything that could suck out emissions from the air. This could remove 800 billion tonnes of carbon emissions over about a century (though for context - we produce about 50 billion per year atm. The above scenario would reduce that number by 8 billion tonnes.).  Key takeaway: PURELY in terms of emissions (and ignoring ALL other nutritional/cultural/accessibility/potential cascade/ethical factors), it seems that reducing meat production = better for the environment.   Key action (implied) for those of us that eat meat: less/no beef would be a good first step for everyone, since that causes such outsize damage in terms of methane, which is an especially damaging greenhouse gas. For those who want to go further, choosing less/no lamb, and then less/no pork would also help reduce emissions, if we can turn that into reduced overall demand.
10:08 First step is to choose pork or chicken burgers instead.

"Food is arguably the best thing about being alive. No other bodily pleasure is enjoyed multiple times every day and never gets old"  Gotta disagree with you there fam.
I think the problem also has to do with this idea that it's the responsibility of the individual to fight climate change, not the collective. When you tell people "you have to stop eating meat to fight climate change", it makes people dismiss you because the idea they themselves can do anything really to impact climate change is a silly notion. We will never get to a point where enough people stop eating meat that it has a noticeable impact on climate change. Instead we must use a top-down approach: Ban factory farms, strictly regulate all meat production, ensure they are producing as little emissions as possible. This will in turn raise the price of meat, which will decrease both supply and demand.

Isn't the goal of ending climate change to restore the carbon cycle's balance? Because I remember learning that the carbon cycle was necessary for life on Earth to exist, but we're producing more carbon than it can handle at the moment. So the solutions should look less like "we need to stop all carbon emissions on Earth, regardless of what they are" and more like "we need to stop unnecessary and excessive emissions and facilitate the carbon cycle's continuance so we don't wreck life on Earth". I don't pretend to be any kind of expert, but I'd imagine that animals and plants producing carbon-- as carbon-based life forms-- would be part of the natural cycle and therefore ok?  I just think it would be more logical and efficient to focus on things like carbon free energy and on projects that clean up the messes we've made, rather than targeting things like food and livestock, which are largely necessary AND scarce in certain places. Food itself is just not negotiable and should be factored out of this argument. Processing would be the only thing we could target in that particular industry, and regular people can't do anything about how their food is processed. Regardless of how little meat we eat, it's still being produced.

Lotta bias against meat and vegan propaganda here - Best beef emits 9 KG CO2  per 100g protein  vs 4.5 KG CO2 per 100g protein against worst plant rich in protein. DISLIKE BUTTON
I think the question here isn't about whether our decision will change the world for the better, but whether our decision will make the companies in charge of those production change for the better. With this in mind, the question suddenly seems far more complicated.   And I do hear you already, 'production increase and decrease according to thr demand for it', which stands true for most cases, but take a moment to consider that while production will almost certainly increase if the demand does, as no one minds having a bit more profit, it may not be entirely true vice versa. Think about this, if you started to lose profit on something that normally sells well, your first reaction wouldn't to immediately stop stocking up on that item, but instead try to figure out why, and if you can make people start to buy it again, with the 'stop' button saved as a last resort for when you give up. It's not as straightforward as 'demand go up, production go up, demand go down, production go down'.   So then what next? Wait it out? Until the companies in charge of meat production goes out of business? I think it's pretty clear that neither will the government force that to happen, nor will those companies just stand and watch as their brand burns down like a rainforest.   To be honest? I have no idea what to do either. I'm certainly not against the idea of a vegetarian lifestyle, but the question remains whether that'll actually reduce or stop meat production remains.
I'm interested to see if "What I've learned" will make a reaction to this, this video felt like a response to his videos.

There is a video on YT that I watched about a guy that was heavily invested in saving the world by changing his habits and spending less. It was eye opening when he realized that everything he achieved i changing his lifestyle is being annihilated by a single steak in his fridge. He was living as all humans should live - caring for the environment that ultimately keeps us alive, but his feeding habits were throwing all that in the garbage. He set off on discovering why meat was so bad for the environment and he got shocked when NOBODY from both sides - environmental protection agencies and cattle raising business wanted to have anything to do with him. He got a wake up call. His own "buddies" that he supported for years didn't want to stand with him on this one because "meat supporters" had a big say in both places. So it the industry could pollute with NO RESTRICTIONS WHATSOEVER, as long as it delivered cheap meat in the stores. Meanwhile you can still get your green environmentalists money to fight climate change by any other means, as long as you don't touch the subject of changing the meat industry. One like here equals one dislike in the video
Your argument against eating locally grown is kinda flawed I think. Yeah, shipping might be very efficient vs source to store, but you left out the fact that all of that product still has to be transported to and from the ships. There are all kinds of vehicles involved with loading and unloading those vessels as well. So locally only (on a very basic level) has 2 vehicle trips involved (to and from the stores), whereas shipping involves 4 trips, to and from the source, and then to and from the store, with the addition of the shipping itself and all of the vehicles involved with that. *Eventually* all of those vehicles will ideally be electric or hydrogen powered, but that'll still lead to situations where one end of the supply chain is using clean energy, because they can afford it, and the other is still using fossil fuels.
@8:06 Because of the low crude protein(N) in foliage, ruminants take longer to achieve their useful weight thus, grass-fed cattle sheep & goats are actually WORSE for the environment!

Does this analysis take into account the possibility of expanding Regenerative Agriculture, such as the methods used by Joel Salatin on Polyface farm? There is something fundamentally different about his approach to farming than other methods that allows for higher production with lower land use, whilst building soil to lock carbon away.  We would definitely have to eat less meat, but arguably this is the only way we should be raising animals for meat.

Bruh. THEN why do we live?
A pasture allows a multitude of plants, including flowers bees need, to grow.  It also provides habitat for small animals.  Then you have how 1 pound of beef contains far more calories and nutrients than say 1 pound of spinach or soybeans.  On top of this, if you replace pastures with crops, you've destroyed acres of habitats, and need dedicated machinery and chemicals to keep the plants well fed and free from pests.  As well as draining the water table far faster than if the fields were used for cattle; the aquifers in America's breadbasket are being drained faster than they can be replenished due to over farming, and we are en route to a new dustbowl epidemic.  This whole meat vs vegetable argument completely falls apart depending on how you look at it and how biased you are.

As much as I liked your video about "Can YOU Fix Climate Change?". Then this one feels to me very biased. I agree with statements about meat production is taking a lot of land, the statement about livestock contributing to climate change by producing methane feels invalid. Since methane breaks in atmosphere afaik around 12 years, then we can claim, that if we would have constant number of animals, then amount of methane also should stay constant. It's not cumulating same way co2 does. And all that co2 is plant based, not from fossil fuels, so it's closed cycle. I agree, that reducing meat consumption we could reduce hunger worldwide. But I strongly believe, that animal based methane doesn't contribute to the climate changes, at least not as much as stated in this video. However, all I can hope is you to change my mind in future, or your own, depending on the facts. Cheers!

.
There are many flaws in your arguments, and also in your data. Of course 50% of our agricultural plants are fed to ruminants, because 50% of the plant is cellulose, stocks, leaves, etc. Only a tiny fraction of the the grain plant is the actual grain we eat. The rest is a waste product that cows can eat. Ruminants are efficient in converting cellulose garbage AND grass (not human usable garbage) into consumable food. Non-ruminants are by far the biggest problem. Chicken, Pork, etc is a higher problem because they eat exactly what we eat.  The carbon of deforestation is a problem yes, especially if its burned. But this is bio-active carbon, that has been in the cycle for a while now. This carbon, while its a problem, is nothing compared to the insane amounts of un-systematic-carbon we pump out of the ground. That carbon hasn't been in the system for 300! million years. Our carbon cycle is not in equilibrium with these carbon sources. There is no balance, that takes million of years (Spoiler: Which we don't have).  So your are making a false assumption on the 2 biggest issues against meat. While the meat industry has many issues (inhumane animal practices, antibiotics resistance, bad working conditions), the climate is not the issue. And while we are talking about the meat industry, we are turning a blind eye on the one source that is killing our habitat: FOSSIL FUELS. Arguably 99% of climate change is created by that. By focusing on other issues except fossil fuel, we give the fossil fuel industry exactly what they need - time to make the most profit available before the market runs dry.  So please do some more research on these. Meat is not the problem. Fossil fuels are.
Such a terrible video. Who did you get your info from? Klaus Schwab and his agenda buddies? So much omitted information and just taking the official narrative as gospel. When if you look deeper it's a load of nonsense.  Failed to mention actual nutrition and needed nutritional value in food products, skewed information regarding animals roaming naturally on land and eating grass, failed to mention the sheer huge amount of unnatural types of fruit and vegetables needed to live on an actual vegan diet (not local and shipped from all over the world, where they too have destroyed the natural land to grow them all), failed to mention the laboratory-made "vitamins & minerals" needed to be on a vegan diet (and even then they aren't absorbed properly as they aren't in their natural form for human consumption). Your gut bacteria gets destroyed, meaning your immune system, just look up gut and immune problems in ex-vegans etc.  So regardless of the official narrative, even if true, you still can't be vegan as it's unhealthy and unnatural. The China study and blue zone societies that were studied were again skewed and information as omitted.  Oh and this is coming from somebody who was a vegan for 7 years. It makes the vast majority unwell eventually and the funny thing is all vegans can parrot off is "B B B but you didn't do it right!". Sacrificing one's own liberty should never be a choice when pursuing climate changing. Always think "Win-Win" in terms of climate pursuit: when we want to make meat more eco friendly or 'ethical', it often results in a superior product, thus a Win-Win. When we say "Stop eating meat" to someone who eats meat, we are telling them to compromise to something that, frankly, won't make as large of a difference compared to changing your Retirement Fund, search browser or other products you use. I'm a meat eater, but I also switched my super, use biodegradable products and limit my plastic: its a Win-Win for me to do so because I get to enjoy my lifestyle, as well as reach greater health in myself, as many 'cheaper,' less eco-friendly options, are also less healthier for myself. You can be self-centred and still care about the planet.

1. Unavoidable emissions from agriculture. Cut forests, NOx from fertilisers, manures. Food= 26% emissions. Real driver of climate change.  2. Life Cycle Assessments- full life- tells us that- beef emissions largest. Lamb also high. Then pork , then poultry. Least are crops.  3. Nutrient density, if taken, animal protein is still costly.  4. Worst beef comes from certain practices. But best beef is worse than worse plants 5. Local food? Will it make difference? Transportation and packaging doesn't much. Only 11% emissions. Last few supplies make most pollution. Shipping in contrast is very efficient. In markets themselves, the emissions are higher. Transport doesn't play a big role. 6. Methane highest from direct farms. Then CO2. Powerful methane, though short life. 7.  Diary methods, geography, etc. Destruction of forests for farm lands is the worst. Much emissions. Farms burning down rainforest damages.  8. More animals suffer, more emission efficient. e.g. animals not allowed to pasture, less destruction of lands of vegetations. But on other side, unused resources can be used in pastures. So pasturing can be efficient as food can't be grown there. But there are other factors, just grass feeding won't suffice. High demand of meat is met by crops grown specially for them. 41% of cereals for animals. Similar for soy which destroy rainforests. 9. Food is a huge driver of emissions. Buying locally doesnt solve. Pastures alone doesn't feed animals.
